"We have seen increased crossings and smuggling since word of staffing cuts began circulating," Moran said. "The illegals have even told us that is why they tried crossing. The border is safer but by no means secure."

Despite these concerns, the push for immigration reform continues, with the AFL-CIO reaching a deal with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on a guest worker program last Friday. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said the Gang of Eight has reached a deal on immigration reform on CNN's State of the Union over the weekend, but Republican Senator Marco Rubio has said reports of a deal are premature.

The debate over immigration reform and border security is ongoing, with both sides claiming that the other must come first. However, as the situation on the ground continues to deteriorate, it is clear that a comprehensive approach is needed to address the complex issues surrounding illegal immigration.

Title: Cohen's Lawyers to Stop Representing Him in Criminal Investigation, Search for New Representation

Article:

Attorneys for Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's longtime personal lawyer, are expected to stop representing him in the criminal investigation into his business dealings, according to a person familiar with the matter. The review of over 3.7 million documents seized in an April raid of Cohen's home, office, and hotel room is nearing completion, and his lawyers are designating which communications they believe are protected by attorney-client privilege.

The review is expected to be completed by a Friday deadline set by Judge Kimba Wood of the Southern District of New York. After that, Cohen's lawyers, Stephen Ryan, Todd Harrison, and others at the firm McDermott, Will & Emery LLP, will cease representing him. The firm has been representing Cohen since June 2017.

Cohen is currently searching for a new federal criminal lawyer in New York, with a preference for someone with close ties to the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office. It is unclear whether Cohen will cooperate with prosecutors in the case, as he has not yet made a decision. He has not been charged with any crime.

The investigation is focused on whether Cohen committed bank fraud, campaign-finance violations, and other possible crimes. The Manhattan U.S. attorney's office is leading the investigation, and a spokeswoman declined to comment. Cohen has denied any wrongdoing.

A special master has been appointed by Judge Wood to oversee the document review and decide whether communications designated as privileged by Cohen, Trump, or the Trump Organization can be seen by government investigators. The law firm's expected withdrawal was first reported by ABC News.

Title: FBI Agent Peter Strzok Testifies Before Congress, Defending His Actions Amidst Controversy

Article:

FBI agent Peter Strzok testified before the House Judiciary and Oversight Committees on Capitol Hill for over 10 hours, facing intense questioning about his role in the investigations into Hillary Clinton's private email server and potential coordination between Russia and the Trump campaign. Strzok's testimony was marked by controversy, with Republicans expressing outrage and Democrats defending him.

Strzok, who was involved in both investigations, faced scrutiny over a series of text messages he exchanged with his lover, former FBI attorney Lisa Page. The messages, which included a reference to Trump supporters smelling like "Trump support," sparked concerns about his political bias. Strzok denied having bias and claimed that his personal opinions did not influence his work.

However, his testimony was met with skepticism from Republicans, who accused him of having an "unprecedented level of animus" and questioned his integrity. House Oversight Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy pressed Strzok on why he was removed from the Russia investigation, with Strzok citing a directive from FBI attorneys. Gowdy threatened Strzok with contempt of Congress and potential criminal liability.

Democrats, on the other hand, defended Strzok, with Rep. Steve Cohen (D-TN) saying he would give Strzok a Purple Heart if he could. The hearing was marked by heated exchanges, with some Democrats yelling "outrageous" and "you need your medication" in response to Rep. Louie Gohmert's (R-TX) questioning.

Lisa Page, Strzok's lover and former FBI attorney, will be questioned by members of Congress in a closed-door session, having watched Strzok's testimony. The controversy surrounding Strzok's actions and motivations is likely to continue, with both sides of the political aisle having strong opinions on the matter.

Title: Kerry Urges UN to Take Action on Syria's Chemical Weapons

Article:

In a strongly worded statement, Secretary of State John Kerry has dismissed claims by Syrian President Bashar Assad and the Russian government that the opposition was behind the alleged chemical attack in August. Kerry made the remarks during a surprise appearance at the daily State Department briefing on Thursday, ahead of the upcoming UN meeting in New York.

Kerry's comments come after Assad denied any involvement in the attack, claiming that the opposition was responsible. However, Kerry was quick to dismiss these claims, stating that "sarin was used, sarin killed" and that the world can decide whether the regime or the opposition was responsible.

The Secretary of State emphasized that the UN report on the attack, which concluded that there is conclusive evidence of a chemical attack, is clear and unequivocal. He urged the UN to take action and hold those responsible accountable, stating that "this fight about Syria's chemical weapons is not a game."

Kerry's comments are a clear rebuke to the Syrian and Russian governments' claims that the opposition was behind the attack. The US and its allies have long maintained that the Syrian government was responsible for the attack, and Kerry's statement reinforces this position.

The UN meeting next week will be a crucial moment for the international community to take a stand on the issue of Syria's chemical weapons. Kerry's comments highlight the urgency of the situation and the need for the UN to take decisive action to hold those responsible accountable.

Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Offers Unlikely Praise for Trump on Several Issues

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisanship, former President Jimmy Carter, a self-proclaimed liberal Democrat, expressed support for President Trump on several issues in an interview with The New York Times. Carter, who has been a vocal critic of Trump's policies in the past, surprised many by praising the president's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East and his willingness to engage with Saudi Arabia.

Carter, who has been known for his diplomatic prowess, particularly in his efforts to broker a peace deal between Israel and Egypt, commended Trump's attempts to negotiate a resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. He also expressed admiration for Trump's outreach to Saudi Arabia, noting that the Arab world places great value on family ties.

The 39th president also showed a willingness to work with Trump on a diplomatic resolution to the conflict with North Korea, an issue that has been a major point of contention between the two leaders. Carter, who brokered a deal with North Korea in 1994, said he would be willing to help Trump negotiate a deal with the country, despite their differences.

On the issue of Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election, Carter was skeptical, stating that there is no evidence to suggest that Russian actions changed any votes. He also weighed in on the NFL controversy surrounding players kneeling during the national anthem, expressing a preference for players to stand during the anthem, but acknowledging that they have the right to protest.

While Carter's comments may come as a surprise to some, they highlight the importance of finding common ground and working together to address the complex issues facing the country. As a former president and Nobel Peace Prize winner, Carter's opinions carry significant weight, and his willingness to engage with Trump on these issues is a testament to the power of diplomacy and cooperation.

Title: Obama Administration Delays Employer Mandate, Adding to Uncertainty Around Health Law

Article:

The Obama administration's decision to delay the employer mandate to provide health insurance is the latest in a series of changes to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The move, announced this week, pushes back the deadline for businesses with 50 or more employees to offer insurance to their full-time workers from January 1, 2014, to January 1, 2015.

The delay is the latest in a series of tweaks to the law, which has undergone significant changes since its passage in 2010. The courts have rewritten the Medicaid expansion, while Congress has repealed a long-term care program and eliminated reporting requirements for businesses.

The delay has left many wondering what other changes may be on the horizon. Timothy Jost, a professor at the Washington and Lee University School of Law, notes that the law is still evolving and that "there will be certainly opportunities here for further confusing people."

The employer mandate, which requires businesses to offer insurance to their full-time employees or face a fine of $2,000 per worker, has been a point of contention among opponents of the law. Senator Jerry Moran, a Kansas Republican, argued that the delay "exposes the fundamental flaws" of the law, which he claims has not lowered costs or increased access to healthcare as promised.

Democrats, on the other hand, argue that the delay is a necessary step to ensure the law is implemented correctly. Jim Manley, a Democratic strategist and former spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, noted that the law's impact will not be fully felt until 2014, making it difficult to sell to the American people.

The complexity of the law has been a major factor in its implementation. Congress did not adopt a single-payer system, instead giving states the option to set up their own health insurance marketplaces or allow the federal government to do so. This has resulted in a patchwork of state-run and federally facilitated marketplaces.

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the law's core provisions while allowing states to opt out of the Medicaid expansion has also added to the complexity. Some statehouses are still grappling with whether to accept the opt-out.

The delay of the employer mandate is the latest in a series of changes to the law, which has seen lawmakers go back and recapture some of the money the law would have overpaid as tax credits for those using subsidies to buy insurance on the exchanges. The repeal of a business expense reporting requirement has also been a recent development.

As the law continues to evolve, it remains to be seen what other changes will be made. One thing is certain, however: the Affordable Care Act is a complex and ever-changing piece of legislation that will continue to be a topic of debate and discussion in the coming years.

**House to Vote on $60 Billion Sandy Aid Package by January 15**

The House of Representatives is expected to vote on a massive aid package for Superstorm Sandy victims by January 15, following a meeting between Speaker John Boehner and lawmakers from New York and New Jersey. The decision comes after a bipartisan outcry over the initial decision to postpone the vote until the next session.

According to Representative Peter King, R-N.Y., the House will vote on a $9 billion flood insurance measure on Friday, followed by a vote on a $51 billion aid bill on January 15. The meeting between Boehner and lawmakers from the affected states was described as "positive" and "extremely productive."

While the decision still pushes the vote to the next session, it appears to have calmed tensions within the party. King, who had earlier criticized the decision to postpone the vote, expressed optimism about the new plan. "As far as I'm concerned, I think I can speak for all of the members of the New York and New Jersey delegations, it was an extremely positive meeting," he said.

The aid package, which has been passed by the Senate, aims to provide relief to those affected by the devastating storm, which caused widespread damage and loss of life in the Northeast. The package includes $60 billion in aid, with $27 billion allocated for flood insurance and $33 billion for other relief efforts.

Lawmakers from both sides of the aisle have urged action on the bill, with House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer decrying the decision to postpone the vote. "We can not and we should not wait," he said. "We must not walk away. I urge the speaker of this House to reconsider and act immediately. Now is the time to act."

The storm, which hit the Northeast in October, caused significant damage and loss of life, with at least 120 deaths reported. The hardest-hit states were New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut, with thousands of homes and businesses damaged or destroyed.

**Title:** US Vice President Warns North Korea Against Provoking Military Action

**Article:**

In a stern warning, US Vice President Mike Pence cautioned North Korea against testing the resolve of the US military, promising an "overwhelming and effective" response to any use of conventional or nuclear weapons. Pence made the statement while aboard the USS Ronald Reagan, a US naval vessel, during a visit to the US Yokosuka naval base in Tokyo Bay.

Pence emphasized the importance of readiness, stating, "The United States of America will always seek peace, but under President Trump, the shield stands guard and the sword stands ready." He also reiterated the US commitment to working with allies like Japan, China, and other global powers to apply economic and diplomatic pressure on North Korea.

The warning comes as the US and North Korea engage in a heated standoff over the latter's recent missile launches. The US has condemned the launches as a reckless act of provocation, while North Korea has described them as a necessary response to the US and South Korea's military exercises.

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis also weighed in, calling the latest missile launch a "reckless" act and assuring allies in Asia that the US is ready to work towards a peaceful denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. Mattis did not specify the type of missile launched, but an official said it was a Scud variant, known as the KN-17.

The US has been working closely with its allies in the region, including Japan and South Korea, to address the North Korean threat. Pence emphasized the importance of maintaining a strong alliance with Pacific Rim nations and protecting freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, where China has been staking claims to disputed territory.

Meanwhile, China has called for a return to negotiations and expressed concerns over the escalating tensions on the Korean Peninsula. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov also urged caution, hoping that the US will not take unilateral action like it did in Syria.

The situation remains uncertain, with the US and North Korea engaged in a game of cat and mouse. While Pence's warning is a clear indication of the US's resolve, it remains to be seen what actions will be taken next.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Weigh In on Tech Industry Dominance

Article:

In a recent interview with ABC's Jonathan Karl, Senator Cory Booker expressed his disagreement with fellow Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren's proposal to break up some of the country's most powerful technology companies, including Amazon, Facebook, and Google. Booker argued that such a move would not be fitting for a president and sounded more like a Donald Trump-style approach.

Booker emphasized the importance of addressing corporate consolidation in America, stating that it has "really ill effects" on the economy. He pledged to call for Justice Department investigations and antitrust laws to rein in monopolies if elected to the White House. However, he disagreed with Warren's plan to create a "level playing field" by breaking up giant tech firms.

"I don't think that a president should be running around pointing at companies and saying 'breaking them up without any kind of process here,'" Booker said. "It's not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks. That sounds more like a Donald Trump thing to say, 'I'm going to break up you guys.'"

Booker clarified that he was not comparing Warren to Trump, calling her "my friend." However, he emphasized that a president should not use their personal beliefs to dictate which companies to break up.

Another Democratic presidential candidate, Senator Kamala Harris, also weighed in on the dominance of Silicon Valley's major tech titans. She stated that Facebook "has prioritized its growth over the best interests of its consumers, especially on the issue of privacy." When asked if the social networking company should be broken up, Harris replied, "I think we have to seriously take a look at that."

The debate highlights the ongoing discussion among Democratic presidential candidates about the role of technology companies in the economy and society. While some candidates, like Warren, advocate for breaking up tech giants to promote competition and innovation, others, like Booker, emphasize the need for a more nuanced approach that balances the benefits and drawbacks of corporate consolidation.

**Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh Faces Intense Scrutiny in Senate Confirmation Hearing**

The Senate Judiciary Committee held a contentious confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh on Tuesday, with Democrats expressing frustration over the withholding of documents related to his past White House service and protesters being arrested in droves.

The hearing, which lasted over seven hours, saw Democratic senators repeatedly interrupting the committee's Republican chairman, Chuck Grassley, and demanding that the proceedings be adjourned. The session quickly became chaotic, with 61 protesters being removed from the room and nine more outside the hearing.

Kavanaugh, nominated by President Donald Trump, told senators that a judge must be independent and not swayed by public pressure. He emphasized the importance of the Supreme Court as the "last line of defense for the separation of powers and the rights and liberties guaranteed by the Constitution."

Democrats, however, expressed concerns about Kavanaugh's potential impact on abortion rights, healthcare access, and gun control. They demanded more documents related to his time as staff secretary to former President George W. Bush and his two years as a lawyer in the White House Counsel's Office.

The hearing also saw tense moments, with protesters shouting slogans and Democratic senators accusing Republicans of obstruction. Republican Senator John Cornyn characterized the proceedings as "mob rule," while Democratic Senator Dick Durbin countered that what they were hearing was "the noise of democracy."

The confirmation process is expected to continue through Friday, with the Senate likely to vote on Kavanaugh's nomination by the end of September. The court's next term begins in October.

Kavanaugh's nomination has sparked intense debate, with liberals concerned about his potential impact on the landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling legalizing abortion nationwide. The hearing gave Democrats a platform to make their case against Kavanaugh ahead of November's congressional elections, in which they are seeking to seize control of Congress from Republicans.

**Title:** Tensions Escalate Between US and Iran as Leaders Trade Barbs

**Article:**

The United States and Iran have engaged in a war of words, with both sides trading hostile warnings and accusations. The tensions between the two nations have been building for months, fueled by disagreements over Iran's nuclear program and its activities in the Middle East.

US President Donald Trump tweeted that Iran would "suffer consequences the likes of which few throughout history have ever suffered before" if it threatened the US. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani responded by saying that war with the US would be "the mother of all wars." The comments have sparked concerns about the potential for a military conflict between the two nations.

The tensions are rooted in the US decision to withdraw from the 2015 nuclear deal, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), and reimpose sanctions on Iran. The deal, which was signed by the US, UK, France, China, Russia, and Germany, aimed to curb Iran's nuclear activities in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions. However, the US has long been critical of the deal, arguing that it did not restrict Iran's "destabilizing activities" in the region enough.

Iran has denied any wrongdoing and has accused the US of trying to undermine its economy. The country is already feeling economic pressures, with large-scale protests over rising prices and a decline in the value of its currency, the rial. The US has imposed sanctions on Iran, which have had a significant impact on its economy.

The US has also accused Iran of supporting militant groups in the region, including the Houthi rebels in Yemen. Iran has denied these allegations, and the US has provided military support to its allies in the region, including Saudi Arabia, which is a major adversary of Iran.

The situation is complex and multifaceted, with both sides having valid concerns and grievances. The US is concerned about Iran's nuclear program and its activities in the region, while Iran is concerned about the impact of US sanctions on its economy and its sovereignty.

As the situation continues to unfold, it is essential to remain vigilant and work towards a peaceful resolution. The world is watching closely, and any escalation could have far-reaching consequences.

Title: The Affordable Care Act's Future: A Delicate Balance

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has faced a tumultuous rollout, with many criticizing its implementation. Despite this, the idea of repeal is not imminent, as it would require a significant number of Democrats to vote with Republicans to override a presidential veto. Currently, only 39 House Democrats and a handful of Senate Democrats have supported a bill to allow insurance carriers to restore canceled policies and sell them to newcomers outside of the Obamacare exchanges.

Representative Steve Cohen, D-Tenn., believes that there is no veto-proof number of Democrats willing to support repeal. He notes that the Affordable Care Act is a Democratic Party creation and that Democrats will be vulnerable to Republican attacks regardless. While some Democrats may be shaken by the rollout's difficulties, they cannot unbrand themselves from the law.

The Affordable Care Act's future is uncertain, with two possible scenarios emerging. One possibility is that it will limp ahead, with the other being a swift reversal of fortune. If the website issues persist and enrollments do not spike, the law may face significant challenges. A net reduction in individual market coverage could lead to political, moral, and substantive concerns.

On the other hand, if the website issues are resolved and enrollments increase, the law may experience a "nowhere to go but up" scenario. In this case, the media's focus on anecdotal evidence and hardship would shift to raw numbers, and the law's success would be difficult to ignore. If total enrollments approach the 16 million projected by the Congressional Budget Office, the tale of the ACA's success would be impossible to ignore.

In this scenario, opponents of the law would struggle to find fault with its progress, and Democrats could even repurpose the Upton bill to put Republicans on record against stripping new beneficiaries of their health plans. This could effectively stop the repeal campaign in its tracks. Ultimately, the Affordable Care Act's future is uncertain, but its success or failure will have significant implications for the country's healthcare system.

Title: Impeachment Efforts Against President Obama Unlikely, Despite Republican Rhetoric

Article:

The idea of impeaching President Barack Obama has been a long-standing dream for some in the tea party movement, but it's unlikely to become a reality, even if Republicans win big in the November elections. According to a CNN/ORC International poll, nearly two-thirds of respondents oppose impeaching the President, making it a difficult task for Republicans to muster the necessary votes.

House Speaker John Boehner and other GOP leaders have been trying to tamp down expectations among their conservative base, stating that there are no plans to impeach the President. House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan also dismissed the possibility, saying it doesn't rise to the level of "high crimes and misdemeanors."

Meanwhile, President Obama and Democrats are using the threat of impeachment to raise money and rally their supporters. The President has accused Republicans of being "mad because I'm doing my job" and urged them to "stop just hatin' all the time."

The issue has become a major point of contention in the lead-up to the elections, with Democrats linking the Republican-led lawsuit against the President to possible impeachment. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has raised $7.6 million online since the lawsuit was announced, according to Rep. Steve Israel.

While some Republicans, like Rep. Tom Cole, believe that Congress has the right to hold the President accountable through lawsuits and other means, others, like Brown University political scientist Wendy Schiller, see impeachment as a "far-fetched" maneuver that could alienate independent voters.

The debate highlights the deep divisions within the Republican Party, with some members of the tea party movement pushing for impeachment and others, like Speaker Boehner, trying to steer the party away from this divisive issue. The outcome of the elections will likely determine whether the impeachment debate continues to dominate Washington in the final two years of Obama's presidency.

Title: Snowden's Asylum Request Remains in Limbo as He Remains at Moscow Airport

Article:

Edward Snowden, the former NSA contractor who leaked classified information about government surveillance programs, remains stuck at Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport, awaiting a decision on his asylum request. The 30-year-old whistleblower had applied for temporary asylum in Russia last week, but it appears that even with new legal papers, he still must wait for Russian authorities to consider his application.

Snowden's situation has sparked a flurry of speculation, with some reports suggesting he would be able to exit the airport and enter Russia with the help of a Russian lawyer. However, a spokeswoman for the Federal Migration Service has denied having any information about the status of Snowden's application.

Snowden has been staying at the airport's transit zone since June 23, when he arrived on a flight from Hong Kong. He is wanted by the United States, where he faces charges of espionage and theft of government property. The U.S. Ambassador in Moscow has demanded that Russia turn him over to face the charges, stating that "Mr. Snowden ought to be returned to the United States to face the felony charges against him."

Meanwhile, Russian President Vladimir Putin has said that Snowden can be granted asylum in Russia only if he stops leaking secrets. Granting Snowden asylum would add new tensions to U.S.-Russian relations, which are already strained by criticism of Russia's pressure on opposition groups, Moscow's suspicion of U.S. missile-defense plans, and Russia's resistance to sanctions against the regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad.

The situation remains unclear, with Snowden still stuck at the airport and awaiting a decision on his asylum request.

**Title:** "Promoting Religious Freedom: A Key to Global Stability and Security"

**Article:**

The Middle East and North Africa are facing a crisis of unprecedented proportions, as Christian communities are being targeted and persecuted by terrorist organizations like ISIS. The destruction of sacred Christian communities and relics, as well as the displacement of Christians from their homelands, has created a refugee crisis with far-reaching implications for regional stability and security.

While the international community has rightly condemned the violence perpetrated by ISIS, the United States and its allies have yet to take decisive action to address the root causes of this crisis. The Obama Administration has failed to prioritize religious freedom in its response to growing terrorist threats and development efforts worldwide.

As a nation founded on the principles of religious freedom, the United States has a unique responsibility to promote and protect this fundamental human right. Integrating religious freedom into its overall response to global threats would help eliminate the underlying causes of violent extremism, promote international economic stability, and foster greater respect for human rights.

Promoting religious freedom would also undermine the efforts of terrorist organizations like ISIS to capitalize on simmering religious intolerance and recruit supporters from disaffected populations. By building alliances with local and regional leaders who champion pluralism and tolerance, the Obama Administration can expose the moral bankruptcy of radical ideologies and empower minorities to advocate for their rights and interests.

A U.S. foreign policy committed to religious freedom can advance national security interests, stabilize and consolidate democracy, promote economic growth, and prevent religiously-motivated terrorism. It can also support governance structures necessary for economic and political security in developing nations, where higher levels of religious freedom are associated with higher levels of economic productivity and growth.

Finally, promoting religious freedom sends a powerful message to threatened communities around the world: America is a friend to those who value religious liberty. This support builds enduring goodwill towards the United States and reminds all observers that the U.S. remains committed to a world where justice and human dignity are central to legitimate governance.

**Harris Ends Presidential Bid, Citing Lack of Financial Resources**

California Senator Kamala Harris announced on Tuesday that she is ending her bid for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, citing the lack of financial resources to continue her campaign. Harris, who was once considered a front-runner in the crowded Democratic field, struggled to gain traction and secure the necessary funding to compete with her opponents.

Harris's campaign raised $12 million in the first three months, but was unable to attract the same level of support as other candidates, such as Pete Buttigieg and Elizabeth Warren. Despite her impressive fundraising haul, Harris's campaign was hampered by flat fundraising and a lack of attention from traditional donors.

In a statement, Harris acknowledged the role of money in politics and took a subtle jab at billionaires Tom Steyer and Michael Bloomberg, who are funding their own presidential bids. "I'm not a billionaire, I can't fund my own campaign," she said.

Harris's campaign faced several challenges, including an inconsistent pitch to voters and confusing policy positions. She struggled to capitalize on her strengths, including her experience as a prosecutor and her call for economic and social justice.

Harris's departure from the race erodes the diversity of the Democratic field, which is now dominated by a top tier of white and mostly male candidates. Her exit leaves 15 Democrats still vying for the nomination.

Several of her opponents praised Harris's campaign, with former Vice President Joe Biden calling her a "solid person, loaded with talent." Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders commended her for "running a spirited and issue-oriented campaign." New Jersey Senator Cory Booker called her a "trailblazer."

Harris's campaign was marked by several stumbles, including confusing policy positions and a lack of consistency. Her campaign also faced criticism from some of her own aides, who shared grievances with the news media and eventually left the campaign.

Despite her departure from the race, Harris's legacy as a trailblazer for women and minorities remains intact. Her campaign was marked by a focus on her experience as a prosecutor and her call for economic and social justice.

Title: Healthcare.gov's Progress Report: A Mixed Bag of Progress and Challenges

The Obama administration's efforts to fix Healthcare.gov have been met with a mix of progress and challenges. In a recent interview with NBC's Chuck Todd, President Obama acknowledged that the website has been dysfunctional and promised that it will be working for the vast majority of users by the end of the month. However, insurance industry officials and Republicans in Congress remain skeptical about the administration's claims.

The administration has made some progress in fixing the website, including the creation of a new account creation process and the ability to apply for insurance through phone and in-person assistance. However, the process is still plagued by technical issues and glitches, with many users still experiencing difficulties in accessing the website.

The administration's official line is that Healthcare.gov will be working for the vast majority of users by the end of the month, but its detailed assessments make it harder to believe. Insurance industry officials and Republicans in Congress are not convinced, and the political fallout is already being felt.

The administration is facing a difficult political landscape, with Republicans in Congress pushing for legislation that would allow insurance companies to keep offering plans that were canceled due to the Affordable Care Act. The bill, known as the Keep Your Health Plan Act, has little policy merit but is popular with the public and is intended to fracture the pro-Obamacare coalition.

The administration is also facing pressure to extend the open enrollment period and provide hardship exemptions from the penalty to people in states without functioning marketplaces. However, this would require congressional action, which is unlikely given the political divide.

The administration's options are limited, and the political fallout is already being felt. The absence of a plan B would create a vacuum for congressional saboteurs, and Democrats would likely get sucked into it. Opposing all proposed solutions won't be sustainable, and at that point, Obama would have to entertain the prospect of allowing Republicans to inflict lasting damage upon his signature achievement.

In conclusion, the progress report on Healthcare.gov is a mixed bag of progress and challenges. While the administration has made some progress in fixing the website, the technical issues and glitches remain, and the political fallout is already being felt. The administration's options are limited, and the political landscape is difficult, but it is crucial that the administration finds a way to make the website functional and ensure that the Affordable Care Act is implemented successfully.

Title: Trump Writes Letter to Pelosi, Criticizing Impeachment Process as "Illegal, Partisan Attempted Coup"

Article:

In a six-page letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, President Donald Trump expressed his strong opposition to the impeachment process, calling it an "illegal, partisan attempted coup." The letter, released on the eve of a historic vote in the House of Representatives, is a compilation of the president's grievances with the process and Pelosi's conduct.

Trump writes that he wants his thoughts to be preserved for the historical record, stating that he does not expect the letter to change the outcome of the vote. He accuses Pelosi of being inauthentic and of turning a "policy disagreement" into an impeachable offense. The president also takes issue with Pelosi's demeanor throughout the process, saying that "no intelligent person believes what you are saying."

The letter is filled with personal attacks on Pelosi, with Trump accusing her of trying to undo the results of the 2016 election and suffering from "Trump derangement syndrome." He also claims that Pelosi is interfering in America's elections and subverting democracy.

In a separate statement, Trump told reporters that he takes "zero" responsibility for the looming impeachment, saying that the perfect phone call he had with the President of Ukraine was the reason for the impeachment proceedings. The president's comments were a departure from the tone of his letter, which was laced with anger and personal attacks.

The letter is a remarkable compilation of the president's grievances with the impeachment process and Pelosi's conduct. While it is unlikely to change the outcome of the vote, it provides insight into the president's views on the matter.

Title: Trump Threatens to Cut Off Federal Funds for California Wildfires, Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a recent tweet, President Donald Trump threatened to cut off federal funds for California wildfires, stating that the money is being wasted and that the state's forest management practices are to blame. Trump claimed that "billions of dollars are sent to the State of California for Forest fires that, with proper Forest Management, would never happen."

However, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a California representative, responded by saying that Trump's threat "insults the memory of scores of Americans who perished in wildfires last year and thousands more who lost their homes." She also called on House Republican leader Kevin McCarthy, another Californian, to join her in condemning Trump's decision and reassuring millions of Californians that the government will be there for them in their time of need.

Critics have questioned whether Trump has the legal authority to withhold FEMA funds, which have been appropriated by Congress. State officials have also accused Trump of playing politics with the California wildfires and said he does not understand the issues involved in fighting fires. Brian Rice, president of the California Professional Firefighters, stated that Trump is wrong to blame the fires on state forest management, citing the damage in and around Paradise, California, and saying that the people there "have only begun to be able to rebuild their lives."

Rice also noted that more than 60% of California's forests are controlled by the federal government, not the state. California Governor Gavin Newsom, who has criticized Trump over firefighting policy, tweeted that Trump's approach is "governing by fear and division." Newsom also proposed $105 million in new spending to prevent, fight, and escape wildfires in the wake of one of the state's worst fire seasons.

It is worth noting that Trump has previously threatened to cut off federal funds for California wildfires, but the administration has not published an order. The controversy surrounding Trump's threat highlights the ongoing debate over forest management and firefighting policies in California.

Title: Preparing for a Smooth Grocery Shopping Experience Amidst the Pandemic

Article:

As the world continues to navigate the challenges posed by the coronavirus, grocery shopping has become a daunting task for many. With the need to maintain social distancing and avoid crowded areas, it's essential to prepare for a smooth and stress-free experience. Here are some tips to help you navigate the grocery store safely and efficiently.

Firstly, take a few extra moments to organize your shopping list by department or aisle. This will help you stay focused and avoid wandering around the store, which can lead to unnecessary interactions with others. Additionally, consider shopping alone to minimize the number of people in the store at one time.

If you're shopping for multiple households, consider combining your lists to reduce the number of trips you need to make. This can also help you avoid having to make multiple trips to the store, which can be a significant time-saver.

Before you head to the store, be prepared for potential wait times and plan accordingly. Some stores may have limited capacity, so it's essential to be patient and flexible. If you're not comfortable waiting in line, consider shopping at a different time or using curbside pickup services.

When you're in the store, be mindful of social distancing guidelines and avoid close contact with others. If you're unsure about the store's policies, ask an employee for guidance. Some stores may have specific rules or procedures in place to minimize the risk of transmission.

It's also essential to be prepared for the possibility that some items may be out of stock. Many stores are experiencing supply chain disruptions, so it's a good idea to have a backup plan in place. Consider asking your partner or family members if they have any preferences or alternatives if their favorite items are unavailable.

Finally, be patient and understanding with fellow shoppers. Everyone is doing their best to navigate these challenging times, and a little kindness and empathy can go a long way.

By following these tips, you can help ensure a smooth and stress-free grocery shopping experience. Remember to prioritize your safety and the safety of others, and don't hesitate to ask for help if you need it.

**Title:** Migrant Child's Death Highlights Challenges Faced by Families Seeking Asylum in the US

**Article:**

The tragic death of an 8-year-old migrant boy, Felipe Alonzo-Gomez, while in the custody of US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has sparked concerns about the treatment of children and families seeking asylum in the United States. The incident comes just weeks after the death of a 7-year-old Guatemalan girl while being held by CBP.

According to a timeline released by CBP, Felipe was apprehended with his father at a location near the Paso Del Norte port of entry in El Paso, Texas, for illegal entry. He was then transferred to the Paso Del Norte processing center, where he was provided with food, snacks, and water, and agents logged six welfare checks.

Over the next two days, Felipe and his father were transferred to the El Paso Border Patrol Station, where they were provided with showers, food, and water, and agents logged 17 welfare checks. They were then transferred to the Alamogordo Border Patrol Station in New Mexico to finalize processing.

On the day of his death, Felipe was taken to the hospital after a processing agent noticed he was coughing and had glossy eyes. He was diagnosed with a common cold and given medication. However, he was held for continued observation due to a 103-degree fever.

Felipe was eventually released from the hospital with a prescription for Ibuprofen and amoxicillin, a commonly prescribed antibiotic. He and his father were transported to a temporary holding facility, where Felipe was given a dose of the prescribed medication and agents conducted several welfare checks.

Tragically, Felipe began to feel nauseous and vomited, and agents helped clean up the vomit. His father declined further medical assistance, saying the child had been feeling better. However, during transportation back to the hospital, Felipe lost consciousness and was pronounced dead.

The Guatemalan Consulate was notified of the child's death, and his father is currently detained at the Alamogordo Station pending transfer to ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations. The Guatemalan Foreign Ministry has issued a statement expressing condolences and offering assistance to the boy's father and assuming responsibility for the repatriation of the boy's remains.

The incident has sparked concerns about the treatment of children and families seeking asylum in the US, and CBP has announced several policy changes around its care of children under 10 years old. The incident serves as a stark reminder of the life-and-death challenges faced by migrants as they attempt to come to the US.

Title: FBI Agent Peter Strzok Testifies on Hillary Clinton's Emails, Clarifies Controversial Texts

Article:

FBI Agent Peter Strzok, who was involved in the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server, testified before the House Judiciary Committee last year, providing insight into the investigation and clarifying some of the most controversial texts he exchanged with his mistress, Lisa Page.

According to the transcripts released Thursday, Strzok stated that Hillary Clinton was not a target, witness, or suspect during the investigation, and that she was considered a "critical player" but not the only person of interest. Strzok's testimony contradicts some of the claims made by Republicans, who have accused the FBI of bias in its handling of the investigation.

Strzok's testimony also shed light on his personal life, including his affair with Lisa Page, an FBI lawyer. He admitted to having the affair, despite knowing that it made him vulnerable to blackmail by foreign enemies. Strzok also discussed his time working on the investigation into President Trump, and his involvement in the special counsel's investigation led by Robert Mueller.

The transcripts also revealed some surprising discrepancies between Strzok and Page's accounts of their text messages. Strzok disputed Page's claim that she believed Trump was the "menace" she referred to in one text, saying he thought she meant Russia. Strzok also clarified the meaning of another infamous text exchange, in which Page expressed concern that Trump would become president and Strzok replied "No. No he won't. We'll stop it." Strzok said he didn't mean that he would take action to prevent Trump from becoming president, but rather that he didn't think the American people would elect him.

Strzok also defended his texts from March 2016, in which he said Hillary Clinton would win the White House "100 million to zero." He stated that his confidence in her did not influence his investigative efforts.

The release of Strzok's transcripts is the latest development in the ongoing debate over the FBI's handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's emails. While some Republicans have accused the FBI of bias and political motivations, Strzok's testimony suggests that the investigation was conducted fairly and without political influence.

Title: The Dark Side of the Death Penalty: A Judge's Dilemma

Article:

The debate surrounding the death penalty has long been a contentious issue, with proponents and opponents presenting their arguments. However, a recent case has shed light on the darker side of this controversial topic. The case involves two brothers, Henry Lee McCollum and Leon Brown, who were wrongly convicted of murder and spent 30 years on death row. Their story is a stark reminder of the potential harm caused by false and coerced confessions, and the power of DNA tests to exonerate the innocent.

The case is a stark reminder of the flaws in the justice system, where innocent lives can be lost due to corruption and indifference. The brothers' conviction was based solely on their coerced confessions, which were later found to be false. The case highlights the importance of DNA evidence and the need for a thorough investigation into the circumstances surrounding a crime.

The case has sparked a renewed debate about the morality of the death penalty. Justice Antonin Scalia, a strong supporter of the death penalty, has been criticized for his stance. In a 1994 decision, he disagreed with Justice Harry Blackmun's decision to disavow his support for capital punishment, citing the brutal nature of some crimes. However, his comments have been widely criticized as insensitive and lacking in compassion.

The case of the two brothers is a stark reminder that the death penalty is not always just or fair. The brothers' 30-year ordeal is a testament to the flaws in the justice system and the need for reform. It is a stark reminder that the death penalty is not always a guarantee of justice, and that innocent lives can be lost due to corruption and indifference.

In conclusion, the case of the two brothers is a stark reminder of the darker side of the death penalty. It highlights the importance of DNA evidence and the need for a thorough investigation into the circumstances surrounding a crime. It also raises questions about the morality of the death penalty and the need for reform.

Title: Younger Generations' Growing Affinity for Socialism: A Complex Picture

Article:

A recent survey by YouGov and the Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation has shed light on the growing trend among younger generations to embrace socialism. The poll found that 70% of Millennials and 64% of Gen Z respondents are somewhat or extremely likely to vote for a socialist candidate. This shift towards socialism coincides with a decline in support for capitalism, with 50% of Millennials and 51% of Gen Z having an unfavorable view of capitalism.

However, the survey also revealed a concerning lack of understanding about socialism and its historical implications. According to the Concise Encyclopedia of Economics, socialism is a centrally planned economy where the government controls all means of production. Despite this, many young people may not fully comprehend the concept, with 20% of Millennials believing the Communist Manifesto guarantees freedom and equality for all, compared to just 2% of Baby Boomers and 5% of Gen X.

The trend towards socialism is not necessarily a rejection of capitalism, as many young people still value entrepreneurship and small business, hallmarks of capitalism. However, they do not connect these activities with capitalism and a free market. This lack of understanding is concerning, as it may lead to a misunderstanding of the consequences of socialist policies.

The survey also highlighted a broader lack of knowledge about American history, with almost 20% of Millennials flunking a five-question test of basic knowledge about American history, and only 35% of high school students correctly identifying the individuals on Mount Rushmore. This lack of historical context may contribute to the growing appeal of socialism, as young people may not fully understand the consequences of socialist policies.

The article also quotes Matt Kibbe, a libertarian economist, who attributes the appeal of socialism to young people's focus on values and personal experience rather than empirical facts. According to Kibbe, socialism is often seen as a belief in community, dignity, and bottom-up problem-solving, rather than a historical reality.

The survey's findings raise important questions about the future of American politics and the economy. While it is essential to understand the concerns and values of younger generations, it is equally crucial to ensure that they have a solid understanding of economic philosophies and historical context.

Title: Experts Warn of Ongoing Threat from Islamic State as July 4 Weekend Warning Sparks Concern

Article:

The recent warning issued by the FBI, Homeland Security, and National Counterterrorism Center about a potential terrorist threat over the July 4 weekend has sparked concerns about the ongoing threat posed by the Islamic State (ISIS). Former Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge and former CIA Deputy Director Mike Morell have both emphasized the gravity of the situation, warning that the threat is real and will continue to be a permanent fixture unless action is taken.

Ridge, speaking on Fox News Channel's "Your World with Neil Cavuto," stated that the White House's dismissal of the warning as "standard operating procedure" was inaccurate. He emphasized that the threat is real and will continue to be a concern for the foreseeable future. "It's a scourge with which we're going to have to deal with... for the foreseeable future," Ridge said.

Morell also sounded the alarm, stating that he would not be surprised if an attack occurred in the United States within the next week. "That's how serious this is," he said.

The warning comes amid a "confluence of events," according to House Homeland Security Chairman Mike McCaul. The holiday honoring America's founding, combined with ISIS's one-year anniversary of major territorial gains and the current holy month of Ramadan, creates a concerning environment.

ISIS has claimed credit for three terror attacks on Friday across three continents, which Ridge believes were likely coordinated. "This is a global scourge, and, frankly, until the White House, until this president, western allies, and countries in that region, with the exception of Iran, get serious about destroying ISIL, we're going to be living with this threat on a fairly regular basis," Ridge said.

The warning highlights the need for a more aggressive stance against ISIS, which has been expanding its reach beyond Syria and Iraq. Unless action is taken, the threat may become a standard warning, with the United States at risk of being targeted at any time.

Title: Federal Workers and Contractors Struggle as Shutdown Drags On

As the partial government shutdown enters its fourth week, thousands of federal workers and contractors are facing a new reality: unemployment. The shutdown, which began on December 22, has left many without paychecks, forcing some to seek unemployment benefits for the first time.

John Woodson, a long-time federal contractor, was among those who visited an unemployment office in Washington, D.C. to file a claim. "We should still be at work right now," he said. "Politicians should handle this – don't put this on the citizens. You're hurting us. You're hurting our families."

Woodson, like many others, is struggling to make ends meet. He is worried about how he will provide for his family, and is considering taking on extra work to make ends meet. "I might have to wash some cars, go back detailing or wash some windows – whatever it takes to put some food on the table," he said.

Federal workers and contractors are not alone in their struggles. According to officials in D.C. and Maryland, at least 7,000 unemployment claims have been filed since the shutdown began. The number is expected to rise sharply if the shutdown continues.

The shutdown has affected an estimated 800,000 employees, with 420,000 working without pay and 380,000 on furlough. The financial strain is taking a toll on many, with some federal workers and contractors feeling embarrassed and ashamed to ask for help.

Michelle, a long-time federal employee, said she never expected to be in this position. "I show up to work, I do a good job, I'm doing everything a responsible adult is supposed to do," she said. "All of a sudden, it's all blown up and I don't know what else to do."

The shutdown is not only affecting federal workers and contractors but also the economy. According to the federal government, the shutdown will cost at least $50 million a day in lost wages and productivity. There are also hidden costs, such as the impact on the mental health and well-being of those affected.

Randy Erwin, president of the National Federation of Federal Employees, said the shutdown is having a devastating impact on federal workers. "Who in the world is going to want to work for the federal government when workers are disrespected... when people are not able to fill prescriptions, bouncing checks [and] ruining their credit?" he said.

The details surrounding who is eligible for unemployment benefits can be complicated. Federal employees who have been furloughed can apply for benefits, while those deemed "essential" and working without pay are not eligible. Those who do receive benefits will have to reimburse the government if Congress votes to give employees backpay, which typically happens when the government re-opens.

The U.S. Office of Personnel Management has issued guidance for furloughed workers on what to do during a shutdown, including how to write to creditors and mortgage companies.

On Friday, President Trump said he would sign a bill passed by both the House and the Senate to give back pay to federal workers affected by the shutdown. However, the shutdown continues to drag on, leaving many federal workers and contractors struggling to make ends meet.

**Title:** US and Cuba Take Historic Steps Towards Normalization of Relations

**Article:**

In a significant breakthrough, the United States and Cuba have announced a prisoner exchange, marking a major step towards normalizing relations between the two nations. American contractor Alan Gross, who had been held in a Cuban prison for five years, has been released and returned to the US.

The agreement, announced by President Obama at the White House, was the result of over a year of secret negotiations between the two governments. As part of the deal, the US has agreed to release three Cuban agents convicted of espionage in a controversial trial.

Gross, 65, was arrested in 2009 and sentenced to 15 years in prison for bringing telecommunications equipment into Cuba while working as a subcontractor for the US Agency for International Development. The Cuban government accused him of being part of a US-led plot to overthrow the government.

The release of Gross is seen as a significant step towards normalizing relations between the two countries. The US and Cuba have agreed to begin talks on restoring diplomatic relations, including the re-establishment of an embassy in Havana. The US has also announced plans to ease travel restrictions and potentially lift the Cuban embargo, which has been in place since the 1960s.

The release of Gross comes after a year of secret talks between the two governments, with President Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro speaking by phone earlier this week to discuss the progress made. The two leaders discussed issues of importance in the hemisphere, while acknowledging that they will have differences to come.

Gross's release has been met with relief and joy from his family and supporters, who had been advocating for his release for years. His wife, Judy, had said in a statement earlier this month that "enough is enough" and that her husband had paid a terrible price for serving his country and community.

The humanitarian release of Gross is seen as a significant step towards normalizing relations between the two countries, which have been at odds for decades. The US and Cuba have been engaged in a complex dance of diplomacy and politics, with both sides seeking to improve relations while also addressing their differences.

The release of Gross and the beginning of talks on restoring diplomatic relations mark a significant turning point in the history of US-Cuba relations. As President Obama said in a statement, "Today, the United States is taking historic steps to chart a new course in our relations with Cuba and to further engage and empower the Cuban people."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee to Vote on Brett Kavanaugh's Nomination Amidst Controversy

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote on Brett Kavanaugh's nomination to the Supreme Court, despite ongoing controversy surrounding allegations of sexual misconduct. The committee's Republican prosecutor, Rachel Mitchell, has advised senators that the case would not hold up in a courtroom, according to sources.

Mitchell's guidance could sway fence-sitting senators ahead of the vote, which is scheduled for Friday afternoon. While it is not necessary for Kavanaugh to secure a majority approval from the committee to advance to the full Senate, a favorable recommendation could bode well for his nomination.

So far, 48 Republican senators have pledged to vote in favor of Kavanaugh, with three remaining undecided: Senators Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski, and Mike Enzi. Enzi is expected to vote in support of Kavanaugh, but has not publicly announced his position.

Collins and Murkowski, along with Democratic Senator Joe Manchin, met with each other on the sidelines Thursday evening to discuss the nomination. Manchin, a moderate Democrat from West Virginia, is seen as a possible "yes" vote for Kavanaugh.

Other Republican senators, including Jeff Flake, have announced their support for Kavanaugh. Flake, who sits on the Judiciary Committee, expressed doubt about the allegations against Kavanaugh, saying that if someone makes an allegation, they want there to be some corroboration.

The controversy surrounding Kavanaugh's nomination has sparked a heated debate, with some arguing that the allegations against him are serious and deserving of further investigation, while others believe that the lack of corroboration and the passage of time make it unlikely that he committed the alleged acts.

The full Senate is expected to vote on Kavanaugh's nomination on Tuesday, with Republicans holding a narrow majority. While some Democrats have announced their opposition to the nomination, others remain undecided. The outcome of the vote is far from certain, and the controversy surrounding Kavanaugh's nomination is likely to continue to be a major topic of discussion in the coming days.

Title: Facebook's Early Data Sharing Experiments Led to Regulatory Agreement

Article:

Facebook's early experiments with data sharing, which began in late 2009, led to a significant change in the way the company handled user information. At the time, Facebook changed the privacy settings of its 400 million users, making some of their information accessible to the entire internet. The company shared this information, including users' locations and political and religious leanings, with Microsoft and other partners, which it called "instant personalization." The feature aimed to create a better internet where companies could customize what users saw on websites like Bing.

However, the move drew criticism from privacy advocates and many Facebook users who felt that the company had shared their information without permission. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) investigated and in 2011 cited the privacy changes as a deceptive practice. Facebook officials stopped promoting the feature and entered into a consent agreement.

As part of the agreement, Facebook introduced a comprehensive privacy program, which was initially overseen by two chief privacy officers. The company also hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to assess its privacy practices every two years. However, the program faced internal resistance from the start, with some engineers and executives viewing the reviews as an impediment to innovation and growth.

Moreover, many of Facebook's special sharing partnerships were not subject to extensive privacy program reviews, according to two former employees. Executives believed that these partnerships were governed by business contracts that required them to follow Facebook's data policies, so they didn't require the same level of scrutiny. The privacy team had limited ability to review or suggest changes to these agreements, which had been negotiated by more senior officials at the company.

Facebook officials stated that members of the privacy team were consulted on the sharing agreements, but the level of review depended on the specific partnership and the time it was created. The company's early experiments with data sharing led to a regulatory agreement, which aimed to ensure that Facebook handled user information responsibly.

Title: US Senate Confirms First Female CIA Director Amid Controversy Over Torture Techniques

Article:

The US Senate has confirmed Gina Haspel as the CIA's first female director, despite her involvement in the agency's post-9/11 interrogation program, which included the use of controversial techniques such as waterboarding. The 54-45 vote followed a contentious debate among senators about the CIA's use of enhanced interrogation methods during the Bush administration.

Haspel, a 33-year veteran of the CIA, oversaw a "black site" in Thailand after the 9/11 attacks, where harsh interrogation techniques were used on suspects, including sleep deprivation, nudity, and extreme temperatures. The techniques were deemed to be torture by a Senate report.

Six Democrats crossed party lines to vote in favor of Haspel's confirmation, with Senator Mark Warner stating that she had pledged to never use such methods again, even if the president demanded it. Warner emphasized that Haspel had told him the agency should never have resorted to such techniques and would not use them if ordered to do so.

Two Republicans, Jeff Flake and Rand Paul, voted against Haspel's confirmation, citing concerns over her involvement in the CIA's use of enhanced interrogation techniques. The confirmation would not have been possible without the support of Democrats.

The confirmation of Haspel as CIA director has sparked controversy, with human rights groups criticizing her role in the CIA's use of torture. The agency's use of enhanced interrogation techniques was banned by President Barack Obama in 2009.

Haspel's confirmation comes as President Donald Trump has previously called for the US to resume waterboarding terrorism suspects. The CIA has refused to release Haspel's exact record, citing national security concerns.

The confirmation of Haspel as CIA director sends a message about the agency's commitment to diversity and inclusion, with Senator Richard Burr stating that it will send a signal to the current workforce and the workforce of the future that a lifetime of commitment to the agency can and will be rewarded.

**Title:** Balancing Accountability and Regional Security in the Yemen Conflict

**Article:**

The ongoing humanitarian crisis in Yemen has sparked a renewed focus on the role of Saudi Arabia and Iran in the conflict. While the United States is rightly holding Saudi Arabia accountable for the brutal murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, it is essential to acknowledge Iran's direct responsibility for the suffering and tragedy in Yemen.

The humanitarian crisis in Yemen is staggering, with over 57,000 lives lost, half of the population on the brink of famine, and 2.3 million displaced. The conflict between the Saudi-supported government and the Iran-backed Houthi rebels has created a complex web of alliances and rivalries, with both sides committing human rights abuses and perpetuating violence.

Iran's involvement in the conflict is multifaceted, with the country providing arms, training, and terrorist proxies to the Houthi rebels. The Houthi rebels have used Iranian-supplied advanced arms to launch ballistic missiles against Saudi cities, unleash explosive drones against civilian targets, and deploy anti-ship missiles against commercial vessels in the Arabian Gulf. Moreover, Iran-backed Houthi rebels have detained thousands of Yemenis and subjected many to extreme torture.

The United States has a significant stake in ending the Yemen conflict, not only to address the humanitarian crisis but also to stop Iran and its Shi'a terrorist proxies from establishing a foothold in the region. The U.S. must also consider the long-term implications of a potential political settlement that would formalize an Iranian-Yemeni security relationship, potentially harming U.S. national security interests.

While the Saudi government must answer for Khashoggi's murder, congressional efforts to limit or end U.S. cooperation with the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen risks emboldening Iran and increasing the suffering of the Yemeni people. The U.S. must balance its concerns about Saudi Arabia's actions with the need to address Iran's direct responsibility for the conflict.

Ultimately, resolving the Yemen conflict requires not only ending Iranian and Saudi complicity but also removing Iran's foothold in Yemen and its ability to destabilize the Arabian Peninsula. The U.S. must engage with its partners, including Saudi Arabia, to promote a political solution and ensure that any ceasefire or political settlement does not legitimize Iran's involvement in the region.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address Focuses on Economic Fairness and Middle-Class Economics

Article:

In his State of the Union address, President Obama delivered a message that was both timely and relevant, highlighting the growing economic divide in the United States. With only two years left in his presidency, Obama chose to focus on the need for economic fairness, emphasizing the importance of raising wages and creating jobs for the middle and working classes.

The President's proposal, dubbed "middle-class economics," aims to address the issue of economic inequality by redistributing wealth from the top earners to those below. He proposed increasing the capital gains tax to 28%, imposing ordinary income tax rates on dividends, and ending a tax code provision that shields inherited wealth. These changes would finance a set of tax breaks for middle-income families, including credits for two-earner couples, increased child care and college tuition credits, and other programs.

While some may view Obama's proposal as radical, it is actually a moderate approach to addressing economic inequality. The plan is designed to be revenue-neutral, with the tax increases paying for the new programs to avoid the endless wrangling over deficits that have exhausted both political parties and the American public.

Obama's speech was not just a call to action for his remaining time in office but a message for the future, with implications for the 2016 presidential elections and beyond. By raising the plight of the middle class and the issue of economic inequality, Obama has inserted these issues into the political debate, making it difficult for future presidential candidates to ignore.

The proposal may also appeal to Republicans, who may find attractive the idea of doing something for those in the middle class, even if it means raising taxes on top-tier earners. The President's speech was not just a call to action for his remaining time in office but a message for the future, with implications for the 2016 presidential elections and beyond.

**New Article:**

**Emails Reveal Early Description of Benghazi Attack**

The United States Department of State has released email alerts sent during the September 11 attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, providing the earliest known description of the events that unfolded that night. The emails, obtained by [News Agency], detail the response of government agencies and intelligence agencies as the attack progressed.

The first alert, sent at 4:05 p.m. Eastern time, reported "US Diplomatic Mission in Benghazi Under Attack" and described "approximately 20 armed people fired shots; explosions have been heard as well." The alert also mentioned that Ambassador Christopher Stevens and four embassy personnel were in the compound's safe haven.

Subsequent emails, sent at 4:54 p.m. and 6:07 p.m., provided updates on the situation, including the fact that the firing had stopped and a response team was on site attempting to locate embassy personnel. The third email also reported that the Islamic military group Ansar al-Sharia claimed responsibility for the attack on Facebook and Twitter and called for an attack on the Embassy in Tripoli.

The emails are likely to become part of the ongoing political debate over whether the administration attempted to mislead the public about the nature of the attack, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans, including Ambassador Stevens. President Obama told CBS News in a previously scheduled interview 14 hours after the attack that he did not believe the assault was simply a result of mob violence, but rather that "there are folks involved in this who were looking to target Americans from the start."

The House Oversight Committee has confirmed that the information in the emails will be part of their ongoing investigation into the Benghazi attack. The White House and State Department declined to comment on the email alerts.

Title: Obama Urges Bipartisan Cooperation to Fix Washington's Broken Politics

Article:

In a recent fundraiser for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, President Barack Obama emphasized the need for bipartisan cooperation to fix the broken politics in Washington. While acknowledging the challenges facing the country, Obama expressed optimism that the current political system can be improved.

"We've got everything we need to succeed, but the one thing that's still missing is a politics that matches up with the decency and hard work and determination and creativity of the American people," Obama said. He urged politicians to work together to create a government that benefits the next generation of Americans.

The president highlighted several key issues, including gun control, education, U.S. infrastructure, and climate change. He emphasized the importance of addressing climate change, stating that it will have a significant impact on the future of the country. "We will over the next couple of decades have the capacity to be energy independent for the first time - incredible change," Obama said. "It will change geopolitics for generations to come and it frees ourselves from dependence not only on foreign oil generally, but from some of the most volatile parts of the world."

The fundraiser, held at the Chicago Hilton, attracted around 150 people who paid between $1,000 and $5,000 to hear the president speak. The event was the first of two fundraisers Obama is headlining for the DCCC during his one-night visit to his hometown. The president also met with donors and Democratic power players, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, DCCC Chairman Rep. Steve Israel, and Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

In a separate event, Obama visited the home of longtime supporters Paul and Bettylu Saltzman, who he credited with helping him get elected. The dinner event, which cost $10,000 per person or $32,400 per couple, attracted around 70 people.

This is not Obama's first time headlining fundraisers for the DCCC, with three more scheduled for the year. The president's efforts aim to support the Democratic Party's efforts to regain control of Congress and promote a more cooperative political environment.

Title: Democrats Prepare to Unveil Ambitious Government Expansion Proposals in the New Year

Article:

As the new year approaches, Democrats are gearing up to introduce a slew of big-government bills that could potentially see a floor vote in the House of Representatives. These proposals, which include "Medicare for all" and other generous-but-costly welfare programs, have been languishing in the minority for years and could finally get a chance to pass under Democratic leadership.

The Democratic Party's "A Better Deal" campaign platform outlines a range of proposals, including rolling back the Trump tax cuts to pay for nearly every item on the list. The most liberal bills have emerged from the Congressional Progressive Caucus, which has gained significant momentum in the wake of the midterm elections.

Some of the key proposals include "Medicare for all," which could cost nearly $33 trillion over 10 years, as well as a "Green New Deal" platform pushed by progressives like Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. This plan calls for a tuition-free and federally funded education system, guaranteed jobs with an emphasis on "green" jobs, and more.

While it's unclear whether these proposals will become laws, Democratic lawmakers are optimistic about the prospects of passing some of these measures. Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman, D-N.J., told Fox News that she expects to see many of these measures come to the floor under Democratic leadership.

The consideration of these measures could also embolden Republicans working to recover from their midterm losses. House GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy has warned that Democrats are moving "toward clear socialism" and suggested Republicans need to make the case for "unleashing the great powers of liberty and freedom."

Some of the Democratic Party's agenda items include:

* "Medicare for all," which could cost nearly $33 trillion over 10 years
* A "Green New Deal" platform, which includes a tuition-free and federally funded education system, guaranteed jobs with an emphasis on "green" jobs, and more
* "College for all," which would eliminate tuition and fees at public colleges and universities for families earning up to $125,000
* "Debt-free college," which would provide more federal funding to states to alleviate student loan debt
* "Child care for all," which would ensure that no family under 150 percent of a state's median income pays more than 7 percent of their income for child care
* A "jobs guarantee" program, which would provide federal funding to put people to work immediately in both the public and private sector

While some of these proposals may face opposition from Republicans, others may find bipartisan support. For example, a $1 trillion infrastructure package is an area where Democrats and Republicans may be able to find common ground.

As the new year approaches, it remains to be seen which of these proposals will become laws and which will remain on the backburner. One thing is certain, however: the Democratic Party is gearing up to make its mark on the legislative agenda in the coming year.

Title: White House Faces Challenges as Obamacare Website Issues Erode Democratic Unity

Article:

The White House is facing a new challenge as the problems with the Affordable Care Act (ACA) website continue to plague the administration. The issues have eroded the unity among Democrats, which had been a key factor in the party's success in the past. The website's botched rollout has transformed President Barack Obama from a leader who seemed to have gained political momentum to one who is now struggling to regain ground.

The shutdown, which lasted for 16 days, had brought Democrats together, with every member of the House and Senate standing behind the president. However, the problems with the website have caused divisions to resurface. Some Democrats, like Senator Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), are questioning the administration's ability to fix the issues and are pushing for changes to the deadlines and time frame.

The White House is confident that the public is past looking at Obamacare as a political issue and wants to see it preserved, if repaired. However, the Democratic trouble they've faced so far stems from the same urgent concerns they have to see the website improved. The administration is working to overhaul the site, but the process is taking longer than expected.

Meanwhile, some Republicans are expressing concern that the focus on the website's issues is diverting attention from other problematic aspects of the law. Polls show that support for Republicans remains low, while support for Obamacare is still increasing.

The situation has led to a growing number of people on the Hill pushing the White House to change its current position on fixing the website without changing the deadlines or time frame. Senator Manchin, who has always been suspicious of the individual mandate, has announced a plan to delay the penalty for a year, but has yet to receive a response from the White House.

The White House is trying to address the political fallout as they work to improve the website. However, the challenges ahead are significant, and it remains to be seen whether the administration can recover from the setbacks and maintain the unity among Democrats.
