In the end, the controversy surrounding Cuomo's statement serves as a reminder of the ongoing political divide in the United States, with both sides dug in and unwilling to budge.

Title: Grassroots Effort Seeks to Convince Elizabeth Warren to Run for President

Article:

A small office park in Des Moines, Iowa, is the hub of a grassroots campaign to persuade Senator Elizabeth Warren to run for the Democratic presidential nomination. The effort, funded by MoveOn.org and Democracy for America, has gained momentum, with volunteers and staff working tirelessly to convince the Massachusetts senator that she has the support and momentum to win.

The campaign's focus is on the middle class, with supporters emphasizing that Warren understands and represents their struggles. Volunteers are using grassroots political techniques, setting up phone banks, and attending small Democratic meetings across the state to spread the word about Warren's potential candidacy.

Despite Warren's repeated denials of a presidential run, the campaign remains optimistic, with volunteers believing that she can still be convinced to join the race. The campaign's regional field director, Blair Lawton, said that the goal is to show Warren that she has support across the state and a path to victory.

The campaign has also been attending small Democratic meetings, such as one in Tipton, where representatives from Run Warren Run explained why they believe Warren is the best candidate for the nomination. While some attendees were politely received, others were more skeptical, with some expressing support for other candidates, such as Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton.

The campaign has eight staff members in Iowa, who travel the state promoting Warren's candidacy, and also has staffers in New Hampshire. Despite the long odds, volunteers remain committed to their cause, believing that Warren's message of income inequality and regulating Wall Street resonates with voters.

While some may view the campaign as an anti-Clinton effort, supporters insist that it is a pro-Warren movement, focused on the senator's policies and ideals. Even if Warren decides not to run, the campaign believes that the effort will still have long-term benefits, including building the progressive community in Iowa.

The campaign's regional field director, Blair Lawton, said that the goal is to show Warren that she has support across the state and a path to victory. Volunteers are confident that they can get her to enter the race, but even if she doesn't, they believe that the campaign will still have a positive impact on the progressive movement in Iowa.

Title: US-Iran Nuclear Talks: What's the Real Deal?

Article:

The ongoing negotiations between the United States and Iran over the latter's nuclear program have been shrouded in mystery, with many questions surrounding the nature of the agreement that is expected to be reached by the end of March. While the Obama administration has been touting the importance of a "framework" agreement, some experts are warning that the deal may not be as concrete as initially thought.

According to Western diplomats involved in the talks, Iran has been resisting the idea of a formal, written agreement at this stage, instead opting for a more general statement of "understanding" followed by a final accord in June. This has led some to question the true nature of the agreement and whether it will be a binding document or simply a political statement.

The White House has downplayed the supposed March deadline, with Press Secretary Josh Earnest stating that the administration is seeking a "political agreement" that includes specific commitments from Iran on its nuclear program and facilities, as well as intrusive inspections. However, experts point out that this agreement will not be a binding document, but rather a "technical" agreement that will require further negotiations to implement.

The lack of a written agreement has raised concerns among some lawmakers and experts, who worry that the deal may not be as comprehensive as initially thought. The Iranian government has not acknowledged the March deadline, and some have questioned the true nature of the agreement.

The negotiations have been ongoing for months, with the US and its allies seeking to limit Iran's nuclear capabilities. The deal is seen as a key part of President Obama's legacy, and some have speculated that the administration is seeking to declare victory on "ending" Iran's nuclear program before any actual deal is made. The liberal media has been quick to praise the deal, with some critics warning that the agreement may not be as concrete as initially thought.

As the deadline approaches, it remains to be seen what the true nature of the agreement will be and whether it will be a binding document or simply a political statement.

Title: Congressional Gridlock: A Tale of Two Agendas

Article:

The current state of affairs in Congress has led to a stark contrast between the Democratic and Republican parties' approaches to legislation. While Democrats are actively working on a range of bills, Republicans seem to have put their focus solely on opposing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and have suspended their own agenda.

According to conservative reporters, comprehensive immigration reform, tax reform, and tweaks to the federal health-care law are likely dead in the water for the rest of this Congress. This assessment is supported by Rep. Devin Nunes, an ally of House Speaker John Boehner, who stated that the GOP lacks the necessary votes to pass significant legislation.

The Senate, on the other hand, has already passed a comprehensive immigration reform bill and the Employment Non-Discrimination Act. If the House fails to produce similar legislation, it may appear as though they are not contributing to the legislative process. Additionally, the House Majority Leader Eric Cantor has committed to passing an ACA alternative this year, but this intention may fizzle, leaving Republicans with a political loser as their official health care reform platform going into the midterms.

The electoral map is also playing a significant role in the GOP's strategy. Senate Democrats are defending seats won in 2008, when Barack Obama won the presidency in a landslide, and the House in a midterm three years after they gerrymandered themselves a durable majority. Under these circumstances, even a bad GOP strategy may yield significant gains in the Senate and retention of the House.

However, it is unusual for a party to put all their chips in one basket so early in the cycle. The 2006 midterms saw Congressional Democrats outline a broad and thorough agenda and vow to advance them through the House within the first 100 working hours of their majority. In contrast, this year's Republicans are not capable of producing similar legislation.

Winning in 2014 may not require Republicans to be proactive, but it may also leave them without much to tell the public if it watches Democrats actually doing things and begins to wonder what the GOP has to offer other than a single-minded hatred of Obamacare.

Title: Supreme Court Weighs In on Contraceptive Coverage: A Delicate Balance Between Religious Liberty and Governmental Interests

Article:

The Supreme Court is currently deliberating on two cases that challenge the Trump administration's accommodation on contraceptive coverage, which allows employers with religious or moral objections to opt out of providing birth control coverage to their employees. The Obama administration's original accommodation, on the other hand, required objecting organizations to notify the federal government, which would then work with the objectors' health insurers to offer costless contraception directly to their employees.

The debate centers around whether the contraceptive mandate and the Obama administration's workaround impose a substantial burden on the religious beliefs of employers. Critics argue that the mere act of giving notice would be intolerable and that only a full exemption will do. However, the Obama administration's compromise struck a balance between religious liberty and governmental interests, requiring objecting organizations to notify the government and allowing employees to still access contraception coverage.

The Supreme Court's conservative majority has expressed sympathy for religious objectors seeking exemptions from generally applicable laws. However, some justices have also expressed concerns about the Trump administration's broad exemption, which may not be required by law. In a 2019 opinion, Justice Neil Gorsuch proposed revising the nondelegation doctrine, a constitutional doctrine used in the 1930s to restrict Congress's power to delegate authority to the executive branch. This suggests the possibility of a cross-partisan coalition to strike down the broad exemption.

The outcome of this case will depend on the court's interpretation of the delicate balance between religious liberty and governmental interests. The Obama administration's accommodation aimed to strike a balance between these competing interests, requiring objecting organizations to notify the government and allowing employees to still access contraception coverage. The court's decision will ultimately determine whether the Trump administration's accommodation is a step too far in accommodating religious objections, or if it is a necessary compromise to protect the religious beliefs of employers.

Title: NATO Allies' Defense Spending: Separating Fact from Fiction

Article:

In a recent speech in Brussels, President Trump reiterated his claims about NATO allies not pulling their weight in defense spending. However, a closer examination of the facts reveals that the situation is more complex than Trump's statements suggest.

Firstly, NATO is not a club with annual membership fees, as former Obama administration National Security Council official Aaron O'Connell explained. There is no ledger or account of what countries owe or pay. Instead, NATO members made a commitment in 2014 to spend at least 2% of their GDP on defense by 2024. Currently, only nine of the 29 member countries are expected to meet this target this year.

Germany, the largest economy in NATO after the US, is one of the countries that does not plan to reach the 2% mark. Trump singled out Germany, stating that it pays only 1.25% of its GDP on defense, while the US pays 4.2%. However, the Pentagon puts the US defense spending at 3.3%, and American University's Garret Martin notes that the US has global military commitments that far surpass those of its European allies.

Trump also claimed that the US pays 70-90% of the cost of protecting Europe, but former NSC staffer O'Connell disputes this, stating that the US pays 22% of the common NATO budget, not 90%. NATO reported that European members have increased their spending by $35 billion, a trend that began in 2014, predating Trump's presidency.

NATO General Secretary Jens Stoltenberg pointed out that despite Trump's criticism of the US spending too much, the US has actually increased its funding for military presence in Europe by 40% since Trump became president. The Senate and House have also overwhelmingly approved resolutions backing NATO.

In conclusion, while Trump's claims about NATO allies' defense spending may have been exaggerated, the reality is that NATO members are working together to increase their defense spending and meet their commitments. The US has its own unique global military commitments and responsibilities, and its defense spending is not solely focused on Europe.

Title: Trump's Carrier Deal: A Test of His Business-Friendly Approach

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence are set to take a victory lap in Indianapolis on Thursday to tout their role in convincing Carrier to keep nearly 1,000 U.S. jobs from moving to Mexico. The deal, which was announced on Wednesday, is being hailed as a success by Trump's transition team, who claim it demonstrates the president-elect's commitment to protecting American jobs and workers.

According to Kellyanne Conway, Trump's former campaign manager and top adviser, the deal shows that the USA is "open for business" and that Trump's business-friendly approach can be replicated once he takes office. Few details were revealed about what was offered to Carrier, which is owned by United Technologies, a much larger company based in Connecticut with contracts with the U.S. government.

Media reports suggest that Carrier, which produces furnaces in Indianapolis, will keep about 850 jobs in the state and was given tax incentives by Indiana's government to stay. The White House downplayed the news, saying President Obama's policies had created more than 800,000 manufacturing jobs. Trump's team, however, argued that the Carrier deal shows that Trump can build a positive climate for business, behind an overhaul of the tax code and reduction of regulations, that will grow the economy at a faster pace than what has been seen during the Obama years.

Fiscally conservative groups are staying quiet about the deal for the time being, but if it turns out that Trump and Pence offered any special concessions to Carrier, they are likely to cry foul. Brent Gardner, chief government affairs officer at Americans for Prosperity, said that the particulars of the agreement have not been released, but the group's position on corporate welfare has not changed.

Chart Westcott, a Texas-based investor who belongs to the Koch donor network, said that he would have no trouble if Trump used his leverage to keep American jobs from being shipped overseas. However, he noted that if Trump cut a deal with Carrier in which American taxpayer dollars were spent, it would be a huge moral hazard and not necessarily a good thing for the U.S. taxpayer.

The deal has also raised concerns about Trump's willingness to negotiate one-on-one with companies, which could lead to CEOs threatening to leave the country in exchange for a sweeter deal. However, House Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said he had no issues with Trump personally getting involved to prevent the outsourcing of jobs.

Overall, the Carrier deal is a test of Trump's business-friendly approach and his ability to deliver on his campaign promises. While some have praised the deal as a success, others are waiting to see the details of the agreement before passing judgment.

Title: Rubio's Road to the White House: A Horse Race to Watch

Article:

As the Iowa caucuses approach, Marco Rubio is gaining momentum in the Republican presidential race. Dubbed "Republican Obama" by Ted Cruz, Rubio is a young, eloquent senator with a compelling personal story and a strong chance of becoming the next President of the United States. Like Barack Obama eight years ago, Rubio is a first-term senator with a charismatic presence and a compelling narrative.

Rubio's campaign is built on his personal story, which resonates with many Americans. As the son of Cuban immigrants, he understands the struggles of the American Dream and the importance of hard work and perseverance. His rags-to-riches story is an inspiration to many, and his commitment to faith and family values is commendable.

However, Rubio's campaign faces stiff competition from Cruz and Trump, who are both well-funded and well-organized. Rubio needs to focus on building his data-crunching capabilities and investing in infrastructure to stay competitive. He also needs to address the equality of all ethnic groups and religions in the country, a message that resonates with many Americans.

Rubio's strengths lie in his ability to communicate complex issues clearly and provide detailed solutions. He has been articulate in laying out his plans for immigration, healthcare, and national security, and his website provides more substantive details than his opponents. Rubio's involvement with the "Gang of Eight" may be a liability for some, but it shows his willingness to work across the aisle to find solutions.

As the race heats up, Rubio needs to pace himself and stay focused. He has the potential to win the nomination and become the next President of the United States. With his charisma, leadership skills, and commitment to the American Dream, Rubio is a strong contender in this horse race.

**Extension of Nuclear Talks with Iran: A New Deadline Set**

The United States and its allies have agreed to extend the deadline for a nuclear deal with Iran by seven months, giving negotiators more time to hammer out the details. The new deadline is set for March 1, with a final agreement expected to be reached by July 1.

The extension comes after a week of intense diplomatic efforts by US Secretary of State John Kerry and other Western foreign ministers, who met in Vienna to push for a breakthrough. While some progress was made, significant differences remain on key issues, including the number and type of centrifuges Iran can have, as well as the duration of constraints on its nuclear program.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani expressed optimism about the progress made, saying that "many gaps have been eliminated" and that the sides are "still some distance" from a deal. However, critics in the US Congress are skeptical, with some Republicans warning that Iran is simply buying time to continue its nuclear program.

The extension has also raised concerns about the potential for additional sanctions, with some lawmakers threatening to impose new measures if progress is not made. The US administration, however, is urging patience, saying that giving talks an extra few months will allow for a more comprehensive agreement.

The negotiations have been ongoing for over a decade, with the US and its allies seeking to limit Iran's ability to develop a nuclear weapon. While some progress has been made, significant differences remain, and the extension is seen as a necessary step to give negotiators more time to work out the details.

The stakes are high, with the US, Iran, and other world powers seeking to avoid a nuclear arms race in the region. The extension is seen as a crucial step towards achieving this goal, and negotiators will continue to work towards a comprehensive agreement.

Title: Israeli Politics in Flux: Gantz and Lieberman Form Alliance to Challenge Netanyahu

Article:

In the aftermath of last week's national elections, Israeli politics are in a state of flux. Benny Gantz, leader of the Blue and White Party, has announced an alliance with Avigdor Lieberman, leader of the Yisrael Beiteinu party, to form a new government. This development has dealt a significant blow to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's chances of retaining power.

Gantz and Lieberman met on Monday to discuss their shared goals and objectives, with Gantz stating that they will work together to "pull Israel out of the political deadlock and avert a fourth round of elections." The two leaders have been working to unify the anti-Netanyahu forces, which include Lieberman's secular, ultra-nationalist party and the Arab-led Joint List.

However, the road to forming a government remains uncertain. Netanyahu's Likud party emerged as the largest party in the election, but he fell short of the required 61-seat majority needed to form a new government. His opponents, led by Gantz, control a majority of seats, but deep divisions exist between the parties involved.

Netanyahu is facing a significant challenge as he prepares to go on trial on March 17, charged with fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes. His lawyers have requested a delay in the start of the trial, citing the need for more time to review evidence, but prosecutors have opposed any delays.

Israel's president, Reuven Rivlin, must decide by next week who to choose as the prime minister-designate. Typically, the president chooses the candidate he believes has the best chance of forming a governing coalition. Netanyahu has defiantly insisted he won the election and accused his opponents of trying to "steal the elections" by aligning with Arab-led parties he claims are hostile to the state.

The situation remains fluid, with many questions still unanswered. Will Gantz and Lieberman be able to overcome their differences and form a stable government? Will Netanyahu be able to hold on to power despite the challenges he faces? Only time will tell as Israeli politics continue to unfold.

Title: US Military Conducts Airstrike Against Senior Terrorist Leader in Somalia, President Obama Defends Drone Strikes

Article:

The US military has conducted an airstrike against a senior terrorist leader in Somalia, targeting Hassan Ali Dhoore, an operational commander of the al-Qaeda-linked terror group al-Shabab. The strike was aimed at Dhoore, who was involved in planning a number of attacks, including some that resulted in the deaths of three Americans.

According to the Pentagon, Dhoore was a member of al-Shabab's Amniyat wing and was heavily involved in high-profile attack planning in Mogadishu. He was responsible for the December 2014 attack on Mogadishu International Airport that killed several African Union personnel and a US citizen, as well as the March 2015 attack on the Maka al-Mukarram Hotel in Mogadishu that killed 15 people. The Pentagon stated that Dhoore was planning to attack US citizens in Mogadishu.

In a press conference, President Obama acknowledged that in the past, the US military's use of drones and airstrikes had sometimes inadvertently killed civilians, but emphasized that procedures for approving such strikes have improved. "There has been legitimate criticism that the architecture around the use of drone strikes or other kinetic strikes wasn't as precise as it should have been, and there's no doubt that civilians were killed that shouldn't have been," Obama said. "What I can say with great confidence is that our operating procedures are as rigorous as they have ever been and that there is a constant evaluation of precisely what we do."

The airstrike was conducted on Thursday, and officials are still assessing the results to determine if Dhoore was killed. The Pentagon stated that killing him would be a "significant blow" to the terror group's operations and ability to conduct attacks.

**The Fabrication Frenzy: Why Journalists Need to Set a Higher Standard**

The recent scandal surrounding NBC News anchor Brian Williams' fabricated war story has sparked a heated debate about the importance of truth in journalism. Williams' admission that he "mistook" his helicopter ride during the 2003 invasion of Iraq has led to widespread criticism and a re-examination of the blurred lines between fact and fiction in reporting.

While Williams is not the only notable figure to embellish their military service, his actions are particularly egregious given his position as a trusted news anchor. The public expects journalists to adhere to a higher standard of truth-telling, especially when sharing personal stories.

The phenomenon of journalists embellishing their own stories is not unique to Williams. Politicians, including President Ronald Reagan and Senator Joe Biden, have also been caught fabricating their military experiences. However, the stakes are higher for journalists, who are paid to be more vigilant about the stories they tell.

The human tendency to embellish personal stories is universal, and journalists are no exception. When sharing their own stories, people tend to add dramatic pauses, exaggerate reactions, and make up details to engage their audience. However, journalists are expected to resist this temptation and stick to the facts.

Williams' story is a prime example of how journalists can get caught up in the "juice" model, adding details to make their stories more exciting. His early tellings of his helicopter ride were accurate but dull, but over time, he began to conform to the "juice" model, adding details about the "dangers" he faced.

The consequences of Williams' actions are severe, and his reputation has taken a significant hit. However, this incident serves as a reminder that journalists must hold themselves to a higher standard of truth-telling. As W. Joseph Campbell, a scholar on media myths, notes, "The allure of a hero's status can be irresistible. It's a warping, cinematic effect."

In conclusion, the Brian Williams scandal highlights the importance of journalists setting a higher standard for themselves and their reporting. While it is natural for people to embellish their stories, journalists must resist this temptation and prioritize accuracy and truth.

Title: Indiana Governor Mike Pence Endorses Ted Cruz, Praises Donald Trump

Article:

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has announced his support for Senator Ted Cruz in the upcoming Republican primary, citing Cruz's "principled conservatism" and commitment to limited government. However, Pence also took the opportunity to praise fellow Republican candidate Donald Trump, stating that he "likes and respects" all three candidates.

In a radio interview with WIBC in Indianapolis, Pence emphasized that his endorsement was not intended to sway the votes of Indiana Republicans, saying, "I encourage everyone to make up their own mind." He also stressed that he will work hard for whoever wins the Republican nomination in the fall.

Pence's endorsement of Cruz is significant, as it comes ahead of the Indiana primary on Tuesday and could give Cruz a boost in the Hoosier State, where he is currently trailing Trump in recent surveys. Cruz has received endorsements from other prominent Republicans, including Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who gave him a crucial win in the Wisconsin primary.

While Pence's endorsement of Cruz was notable, it was not as forceful as some might have expected. However, Pence's praise for Trump was notable, as he commended the billionaire businessman for giving voice to people's frustrations and taking a stand for Hoosier jobs. Trump, who is currently leading the Republican pack, needs 42 percent of the remaining delegates to win the nomination, and a sweep of Indiana's 57 delegates could put him within striking distance of the nomination.

Regardless of the outcome, Pence's endorsement serves as a reminder that the Republican primary is still very much up for grabs, with several key states yet to vote.

**Title:** Republican Candidates Engage in Substantive Policy Discussion at Kemp Forum

**Article:**

In a rare departure from the usual campaign trail rhetoric, a group of Republican presidential candidates gathered at the Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity to discuss policy proposals and ideas. The event, moderated by Speaker Paul Ryan and Senator Tim Scott, provided a platform for the candidates to engage in a substantive conversation about issues such as the earned income tax credit, charter-school education, and poverty alleviation.

The forum, which lasted over five hours, was a welcome change from the usual campaign trail antics, with no mention of divisive topics like banning Muslims or arming elementary schools. The candidates, including Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, Ben Carson, John Kasich, and Marco Rubio, spent the session in a collegial back-and-forth discussion of policy proposals.

The event was a stark contrast to the heated rhetoric employed by poll leaders Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, who did not attend the forum. Trump's rallies have been marked by boisterous crowds and inflammatory rhetoric, while Cruz has been known for his controversial statements and personal attacks.

The candidates who participated in the forum praised the event, with John Kasich calling it a "breath of fresh air" and Lindsey Graham joking that it was a welcome break from the "primary chatter." Marco Rubio and John Kasich's afternoon session was briefly interrupted by young immigration protesters, but the candidates remained calm and professional, with Rubio responding to the protesters with a promise to enforce the country's immigration laws.

The event highlighted the candidates' policy positions, with Jeb Bush discussing his background in policy-making and Chris Christie explaining the details of the earned income tax credit. The forum provided a platform for the candidates to showcase their ideas and engage in a substantive conversation about the issues, a departure from the usual campaign trail rhetoric.

Title: What Happens to Your Campaign Contributions When a Presidential Candidate Drops Out?

Article:

When a presidential candidate drops out of the race, it's natural to wonder what happens to the campaign contributions they've received. With millions of dollars at stake, it's essential to understand the rules and regulations surrounding campaign finance. The Federal Election Committee (FEC) sets the guidelines, but the world of campaign finance can be complex and open to interpretation.

When a candidate drops out, their campaign is not required to return donations, but they do have options for using excess funds. According to FEC rules, excess funds can be used to cover expenses or spent on other candidates. This means that if you donated to a candidate who dropped out, your money might be used to pay off outstanding debts or expenses, such as salaries for campaign staff or moving expenses.

If the campaign has no outstanding debt, the excess funds can be allocated towards the candidate's future campaigns. For example, John Hickenlooper, who dropped out of the presidential race and announced his Senate bid, is likely to allocate his excess funds towards his Senate campaign.

However, there is a gray area when it comes to using campaign funds. Candidates can use donations to purchase "gifts," as long as they are not given to the candidate's family. What constitutes a "gift" is open to interpretation, leaving room for discretion.

Candidates can also use excess funds to support political action committees or other candidates in a race. Alternatively, they can donate the funds to charities at their discretion.

While the FEC's rules are in place, it's difficult to ensure that your donation is used exactly as intended. However, you can research a campaign's spending throughout and after a presidential bid is over. The FEC requires campaigns to file reports until the committee is terminated, allowing you to track how the campaigns spend any residual funds they maintain.

To view these reports, visit the FEC database and search for the candidate's campaign name. You can also search for any former presidential candidate's campaign from any other election.

While there are limitations to these filings, it's essential to stay informed and hold candidates accountable for their campaign finance practices. By doing so, you can make informed decisions about your donations and support candidates who promote campaign finance reform.

**Romney's Campaign Faces Growing Frustration Among Republicans**

As the presidential election approaches, Republican candidate Mitt Romney's campaign is facing growing frustration among party members and strategists. Despite being locked in a tight race with President Barack Obama, Romney's campaign has yet to gain a commanding lead in any of the major battleground states.

In Florida, Ohio, and Colorado, Republicans are expressing concerns that Romney is not campaigning enough in their states and that resources are not trickling into vital counties. In Ohio, some Republicans have expressed concern that Romney is not spending more money and appearing more frequently in rural counties where he needs a strong turnout to win the state.

However, Romney's campaign officials say they are making strategic decisions and are planning to increase their get-out-the-vote operations. They believe some of the concern in the toss-up states is being created by hyped news media reporting on Romney's latest missteps.

Romney has been focusing on Iowa as one of his more promising states, but a recent poll showed Obama with an 8-point advantage there. Romney's wife, Ann, has urged Republicans to stop second-guessing her husband and get behind his campaign.

Despite the challenges, Romney still has an opportunity to win over voters who are ready to reject Obama. Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine believes Romney can still win Ohio and the race, saying it's a "very doable thing."

The president and his aides are aware that everything can change in an instant, particularly with three presidential debates looming. Obama's job approval rating has reached 50 percent in recent polls, and he has taken the edge away from Romney on questions of who voters believe will be a better steward of the economy.

The article provides a balanced view of the situation, highlighting both the challenges and opportunities facing Romney's campaign. It also provides quotes from various stakeholders, including Republicans and Romney campaign officials, to provide a well-rounded perspective.

**Tensions Escalate as North Korea Fires Missile Over Japan, US and Allies Respond**

In a move that has raised concerns about the escalating tensions on the Korean Peninsula, North Korea launched a mid-range ballistic missile designed to carry a nuclear payload over Japan and into the northern Pacific Ocean on Tuesday. The test, which was condemned by the international community, has sparked a renewed sense of urgency among world leaders to address the growing threat posed by the reclusive state.

The missile, which flew over the Japanese island of Hokkaido, was seen as a provocative act by the international community, with the United States, Japan, and South Korea all expressing concern about the implications of the test. The White House released a statement from President Trump, saying that "all options are on the table" in response to the North Korean regime's actions.

The test has also sparked a response from South Korea, which conducted a live-fire drill involving powerful bombs in response to the missile launch. The drill, which involved four F-15 fighter jets dropping eight MK-84 bombs, was seen as a demonstration of the country's military capabilities and its commitment to defending itself against the North Korean threat.

The latest missile test comes just days after North Korea launched what was assessed as three short-range ballistic missiles into the sea, and a month after its second test of an intercontinental ballistic missile, which analysts say could reach deep into the US mainland when perfected.

The international community has been working to address the growing threat posed by North Korea's nuclear program, with the United Nations imposing sanctions and the US and its allies conducting military exercises in response to the regime's provocations. The latest missile test has only added to the sense of urgency, with world leaders calling for a united response to the growing threat.

In a statement, the White House said that President Trump spoke with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe about the "grave" North Korean threat, and that the two leaders committed to increasing pressure on North Korea and convincing the international community to do the same. The Pentagon also released a statement, saying that the missile launch did not pose a threat to North America, but that the US military is investigating the incident.

The latest developments have sparked concerns about the potential for further escalation on the Korean Peninsula, and the need for a united response from the international community to address the growing threat posed by North Korea's nuclear program.

Title: White House Refuses to Confirm or Deny President's Involvement in National Security Leaks Investigation

Article:

The White House has refused to confirm or deny whether President Obama will cooperate with the Justice Department's investigation into recent high-level national security leaks. The investigation, led by two career attorneys, is looking into the disclosure of highly classified information, including details about a top-secret "kill list" and a US cyberattack on Iranian infrastructure.

White House Senior Adviser David Plouffe said during an appearance on "Fox News Sunday" that the administration will cooperate with the investigation, but refused to comment on the president's involvement. "An investigation has been announced. Let's let that proceed," Plouffe said.

The leaks, which were published in The New York Times, have sparked concerns about the potential damage to national security. Some congressional Republicans and political pundits have speculated that the White House authorized the leaks to aid the president's re-election effort, while others believe it was an unauthorized disclosure.

Senator Joe Lieberman, an independent from Connecticut, expressed concerns about the potential consequences of the leaks, particularly the disclosure of cyberwarfare against Iran. "There's a danger that it may legitimize an Iranian or terrorist counter cyberattack on us because we did it," he said.

Many on Capitol Hill, including Lieberman, have called for the appointment of independent prosecutors to investigate the matter, rather than relying on investigators who report directly to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. The White House has rejected these calls, instead appointing two US attorneys to lead the investigation.

Despite being pressed on the question, Plouffe refused to say whether the president would agree to one-on-one interviews with the investigators. The White House has also refused to comment on whether the president's staff will cooperate fully with the investigation.

The controversy has sparked comparisons to the Valerie Plame scandal, in which former President George W. Bush instructed his entire staff to come forward with any information they had about the source of the leak. The investigation ultimately revealed that State Department official Richard Armitage was the source of the leak.

Senator Lieberman urged the administration to follow the Bush administration's playbook and cooperate fully with the investigation. "I think the administration ought to do everything it can to eliminate any appearance that people in the administration leaked this highly classified information for political or other personal purposes," he said. "If I were advising the president, I'd say he should sit down and talk to the investigators."

Title: The Growing Divide: Understanding Political Polarization in the United States

Article:

The recent email from a friend, Joe, sparked a thought-provoking conversation about the growing political polarization in the United States. As a Democrat, Joe and I may find ourselves on opposite sides of the political spectrum, but our friendship is built on shared values and a willingness to engage in respectful dialogue. However, the numbers suggest that our political differences are not just a coincidence. In fact, research from the Pew Research Center and other reputable organizations reveals a stark reality: political polarization is on the rise.

The Pew Research Center's 2014 study, based on interviews with 10,000 adults, paints a vivid picture of the current state of American politics. The study found that the overall share of Americans who express consistently conservative or liberal opinions has doubled over the past two decades, with 92% of Republicans to the right of the median Democrat and 94% of Democrats to the left of the median Republican. This ideological divide has led to a situation where many individuals are surrounded by like-minded individuals, making it difficult to engage in meaningful dialogue with those who hold opposing views.

The study also highlights the importance of social networks in shaping our political beliefs. Two-thirds of consistent conservatives and half of liberals say most of their close friends share their political views, suggesting that social reinforcement plays a significant role in shaping our political identities. Furthermore, the study found that highly negative views of the opposition party have doubled since 1994, with 43% of Republicans and 38% of Democrats holding unfavorable opinions of the opposing party.

The reasons behind this growing polarization are complex and multifaceted. Some suggest that partisan news media and the internet have contributed to the problem, while others argue that it is a natural response to the increasing complexity of modern society. Regardless of the cause, the consequences are clear: political polarization is a significant obstacle to effective governance and civic engagement.

As individuals, we can take steps to bridge the divide by engaging in respectful conversations with those who hold opposing views. We can also support organizations and initiatives that promote civic engagement and political discourse. Ultimately, it is up to each of us to recognize the importance of political polarization and take action to address it.

**Global Trade Tensions Escalate as US and China Announce Tariffs**

The trade war between the world's two largest economies, the United States and China, has intensified, sending shockwaves through global markets. The US and China have announced new tariffs on each other's goods, with the US planning to impose duties of up to 25% on $300 billion worth of Chinese imports, while China has announced tariffs ranging from 5% to 25% on $60 billion worth of US products.

The US Trade Representative's office has announced a public hearing next month to consider imposing duties on an additional $300 billion worth of Chinese goods, including cellphones and laptops, but excluding pharmaceuticals. The move is seen as a response to China's decision to impose higher tariffs on a range of US goods, including frozen vegetables and liquefied natural gas.

The trade tensions have sent global markets into a tailspin, with a gauge of global stocks shedding 1.9% on Monday, its biggest one-day drop in over five months. China's yuan currency fell to its lowest level since December, and oil futures slumped.

US President Donald Trump has said he will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping at a G20 summit in late June, and expressed optimism that the meeting could lead to a fruitful outcome. However, the Chinese government has emphasized that the talks are not a "one-way street" and must be conducted on the basis of equality.

The trade war has had a significant impact on US farmers, with soybean sales to China plummeting and US soybean futures hitting their lowest level in a decade. The US government has announced plans to provide around $15 billion to help farmers whose products may be targeted by the tariffs.

The trade tensions have also led to concerns about the potential impact on the global economy, with economists warning that the tariffs could lead to higher prices for consumers and reduced economic growth. The US Chamber of Commerce has warned that the tariffs could cost American businesses and households around $3 billion annually.

In a statement, the US Trade Representative's office said that the tariffs are intended to address China's "unfair trade practices" and "forced technology transfers." China has responded by saying that the tariffs are a response to US "unilateralism and protectionism" and that it hopes the US will "get back to the right track" of bilateral trade and economic consultations.

The trade war has been ongoing for over a year, with the US and China imposing tariffs on each other's goods in a tit-for-tat escalation. The US has imposed tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, while China has imposed tariffs on $50 billion worth of US products. The trade tensions have also led to concerns about the potential impact on global supply chains and the overall economy.

Title: Senator Doug Jones to Vote to Convict President Trump on Both Impeachment Articles

Article:

Senator Doug Jones (D-Ala.), considered one of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats facing re-election in November, announced on Wednesday that he will vote to convict President Trump on both articles of impeachment. Jones's decision comes hours before the Senate is set to vote on the two House-passed articles, which accuse Trump of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

In a statement, Jones said he had spent many sleepless nights reviewing the evidence and weighing the legal precedents before making his decision. He acknowledged that the second article, which deals with alleged obstruction of Congress, gave him "even more pause" and that he "struggled to understand" the House's strategy. However, after careful consideration, Jones concluded that Trump's actions demonstrate a "deliberate and unconstitutional" obstruction of Congress.

On the first article, abuse of power, Jones expressed deep concern over Trump's actions, stating that the President's personal interests took precedence over national interests and threatened the security of the United States, its allies in Europe, and Ukraine. He emphasized that Trump's actions were more than just inappropriate, but an abuse of power.

Jones's announcement comes as a surprise to some, as he had previously expressed uncertainty about his vote and had hinted at the possibility of splitting his votes. However, his decision to vote to convict on both articles underscores the gravity of the situation and the importance of upholding the Constitution.

The Senate's vote on the two articles of impeachment is expected to be a historic moment in American politics, with the outcome having significant implications for the country's political landscape.

**Title:** Fact-Checking the Claim: "No Oversight, No IGs, No Accountability" in Coronavirus Relief Effort

**Article:**

The recent virtual rally by presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden claimed that President Trump's administration is implementing the coronavirus relief effort with "no oversight, no IGs, no accountability." However, a closer examination of the CARES Act reveals that several oversight mechanisms were established to ensure transparency and accountability in the distribution of economic relief funds.

The Pandemic Response Accountability Committee, established by Section 15010 of the CARES Act, is responsible for auditing the economic relief funds to prevent waste and abuse and ensure efficient distribution. The committee's membership includes inspectors general from various departments, including Defense, Education, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Justice, Labor, and Treasury, as well as the Small Business Administration and Tax Administration.

The CARES Act also established the Congressional Oversight Commission, tasked with overseeing the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve's lending practices to create transparency about how the money is being used and determine the economic impact of the loans. The commission is made up of five members, with each chamber's leaders appointing one member, and is required to submit reports to Congress every 30 days until its termination on September 20, 2025.

Despite President Trump's criticism of the inspectors general on the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee and his choice for a special inspector general, it is inaccurate to claim that there is "no oversight, no IGs, no accountability" in the coronavirus economic relief effort. The CARES Act established multiple oversight mechanisms to ensure transparency and accountability, and the special inspector general for pandemic recovery, once confirmed, will be responsible for conducting audits and investigations of the making, purchase, management, and sale of loans and investments made by the Treasury Department.

In conclusion, while there may be disagreements over the scope and implementation of the oversight mechanisms, it is essential to acknowledge the existence and purpose of these measures to ensure accountability and transparency in the coronavirus economic relief effort.

**White House Rejects Bipartisan Immigration Deal, Calls it a "Non-Starter"**

A bipartisan group of lawmakers, led by Senators John McCain and Chris Coons, is set to introduce a new immigration bill in the Senate, which would grant eventual citizenship to young undocumented immigrants who came to the US as children. The bill, which has 54 co-sponsors, does not address all of President Trump's stated immigration priorities, including ending family-based immigration categories and the diversity visa program.

The bill would, however, increase resources for the immigration courts, where cases can take years to finish, and would not immediately authorize the $30 billion requested by Trump to build the border wall. Instead, it would greenlight a study of border security needs.

The White House has dismissed the bill as a "non-starter," with a spokesperson calling it "a lot of effort to write up a bill worse than the Graham-Durbin immigration bill, but somehow this one is worse." Trump tweeted about the latest immigration efforts, stating that any deal on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program that does not include "STRONG border security and the desperately needed WALL is a total waste of time."

Senator Coons defended the bill, calling it a "strong starting place" and a "fresh start" if other talks about immigration do not result in a compromise. He emphasized that the bill addresses the status of the Dreamers and border security, and that the worst thing would be failing to act or only doing a one-year stopgap.

The bill has received support from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and moderate Republicans, but the President has not embraced the proposal, largely due to what it leaves out. The Senate is expected to turn to a floor debate on immigration soon, and Senator Coons has been part of a group of bipartisan lawmakers meeting to find a compromise that could pass with more than the 60 votes needed to advance legislation.

**Election Forecast: A Close and Uncertain Race**

As the 2016 presidential election approaches, the outcome remains uncertain, with both Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump vying for the White House. According to a recent forecast, Clinton holds a slight edge, but Trump is closing the gap.

**The Electoral College Landscape**

The Electoral College system is a crucial factor in the election, with each state's electoral votes playing a significant role in determining the winner. The forecast shows Clinton leading in key states such as New York, California, and Illinois, while Trump is strong in states like Texas, Florida, and Ohio.

**Tipping Points and Voter Power Index**

Two measures help capture the importance of each state in determining the outcome: "Tipping-point chance" and "Voter power index." Florida, Pennsylvania, and Michigan are considered crucial states, with a high tipping-point chance, while New Mexico, Nevada, and Colorado are also significant due to their voter power index.

**Popular Vote and Electoral Vote**

The forecast also projects the popular vote and electoral vote outcomes. While Clinton leads in the popular vote, Trump is closing the gap. The Electoral College outcome is more uncertain, with a 1.0% chance of an Electoral College deadlock and a 0.5% chance of a recount.

**Crazy and Not-So-Crazy Scenarios**

The forecast also explores various election outcomes, including an Electoral College deadlock, a recount, and a popular vote victory for either candidate. The chances of these outcomes are as follows:

* Electoral College deadlock: 1.0%
* Recount at least one decisive state within 0.5 ppt: 8.3%
* Clinton wins popular vote: 81.4%
* Trump wins popular vote: 18.6%
* Clinton wins popular vote but loses Electoral College: 10.5%
* Trump wins popular vote but loses Electoral College: 0.5%
* Johnson wins at least one electoral vote: 0.3%
* McMullin wins at least one electoral vote: 0.3%
* Clinton majority wins at least 50% of the vote: 28.7%
* Trump majority wins at least 50% of the vote: 2.3%
* Clinton landslide double-digit popular vote margin: 6.1%
* Trump landslide double-digit popular vote margin: 0.3%
* Map exactly the same as in 2012: 0.2%
* Clinton wins at least one state Mitt Romney won in 2012: 71.6%
* Trump wins at least one state President Obama won in 2012: 85.0%

As the election approaches, the outcome remains uncertain, with both candidates vying for the White House. The forecast will continue to update as new data becomes available, providing a clearer picture of the election outcome.

**Supreme Court to Hear Landmark Cases on Same-Sex Marriage**

The United States Supreme Court has agreed to review two landmark cases related to same-sex marriage, sparking a new wave of debate and excitement among advocates on both sides of the issue. The court's decision to take up the cases, Windsor v. United States and Hollingsworth v. Perry, has sent shockwaves through the legal community and beyond.

The cases involve the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Proposition 8, a California voter-passed measure that banned same-sex marriage in the state. The Supreme Court's review of these cases marks a significant milestone in the ongoing legal battle over same-sex marriage.

Gay rights activists are cautiously optimistic that the court's review will ultimately lead to a victory for same-sex couples. "This is it – the Supreme Court marriage moment that the ACLU has been working towards for years," said James Esseks, litigation director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender & AIDS Project. "These cases are poised not just to take down DOMA and Prop 8, but to be the next building blocks for LGBT equality more broadly."

On the other hand, traditional-values groups are heartened that the marriage issue will finally be heard, noting that gay marriages are still not recognized in more than 80 percent of the states. "Taking the case sends a strong signal that the justices are concerned with the rogue rulings that have come out of San Francisco, at both the trial court and appellate levels," said John Eastman, chairman of the National Organization for Marriage, which opposes gay marriage. "Had the Supreme Court agreed with the rulings, it could have simply declined to accept the cases and let the decisions stand."

The Supreme Court's review of these cases is expected to be a closely watched and highly anticipated event, with oral arguments likely to take place in late winter or early spring and decisions issued by summer. The court's decision will have significant implications for same-sex couples across the country, who are eager to have their relationships recognized and protected by the law.

In the meantime, same-sex couples in Washington state are celebrating the recent legalization of gay marriage, with hundreds of couples tying the knot on Sunday. "We're totally thrilled," said Keith Bacon, who took vows with Corianton Hale, his partner of six years. "We had looked at this as maybe a day we would sign a piece of paper and seal the deal, and instead we're having this huge party being thrown in our honor. It's just mind-blowing."

The legal battle over same-sex marriage is far from over, but the Supreme Court's decision to review these landmark cases marks a significant step forward for advocates on both sides of the issue.

Title: Republican Governors Shift Focus from Tax Cuts to Spending Priorities

Article:

In a departure from the traditional Republican playbook, several Republican governors are rethinking their approach to taxation and spending. Gone are the days of sweeping tax cuts and promises of economic booms, replaced by a more measured approach that prioritizes spending on key areas such as education, healthcare, and infrastructure.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who gained national attention for his anti-union stance, is now playing down suggestions of deep income tax cuts, instead focusing on addressing the state's $2.2 billion budget gap. Ohio Governor John Kasich, also rumored to have presidential ambitions, is proposing to raise taxes on energy drilling companies to fund an income tax cut, despite opposition from a Tea Party faction in the General Assembly.

Michigan Governor Rick Snyder, who has faced criticism from conservative circles for his support of financial aid for Detroit, is proposing higher gasoline taxes to improve roads, an idea unpopular among some on the right. The shift in priorities is partly due to the cautionary example of Kansas, where Governor Sam Brownback's large business and income tax cuts led to a significant budget shortfall and nearly cost him re-election.

In Florida, newly sworn-in Governor Rick Scott has laid out an agenda that prioritizes spending billions more on schools, the environment, and transportation, a departure from his first term's $3.3 billion in education cuts. Arizona Governor Doug Ducey, who promised not to raise taxes in his inauguration speech, omitted mention of his campaign pledges to cut income taxes each year, a move that surprised few given the state's growing budget shortfall.

Several Republican governors, including Tennessee's Bill Haslam and those in Wyoming and North Carolina, have announced their support for Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act, citing the fiscal benefits of accepting federal aid. The shift in priorities reflects a growing recognition that tax cuts alone are not enough to drive economic growth and that a more balanced approach is needed to address the state's pressing issues.

Title: Hillary Clinton Reiterates Her Stance on Private Email Server Investigation

Article:

In a recent interview on NBC's Meet the Press, Hillary Clinton reiterated her stance on the ongoing investigation surrounding her use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State. When asked if she had been contacted by the FBI, Clinton replied, "No, no, they haven't." However, she emphasized that she is willing to cooperate with the investigation and has already made her emails publicly available.

Clinton acknowledged that using a private email server while in office was a "mistake," but maintained that she had every reason to believe her emails were being stored on a government server. She emphasized that she has taken steps to rectify the situation and is confident that the investigation will conclude without any wrongdoing on her part.

Clinton also addressed the ongoing debate with her Democratic rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, stating that she is "confident" they will debate before the New York primary on April 19, but would not commit to a specific date. Sanders has been pushing for a debate, citing the importance of giving voters a chance to compare the two candidates' positions.

Clinton expressed confidence that she will carry the Empire State, while Sanders believes he has a chance to win New York, his home state. The two candidates have been engaged in a heated primary battle, with Clinton holding a significant lead in the delegate count.

The investigation into Clinton's email practices has been ongoing since last year, with the FBI looking into whether she mishandled classified information. Clinton has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and has made her emails publicly available, while Sanders has criticized her for not doing enough to address the issue.

Title: Police Use of Force Against Man in Public Space Raises Questions

Article:

A recent cellphone video has surfaced, capturing a disturbing incident of police misconduct in downtown St. Paul, Minnesota. The video shows a 28-year-old man, Christopher Lollie, sitting in a public area, waiting to pick up his children from New Horizon Academy. The encounter began when a female officer approached Lollie and asked him to identify himself, claiming he was refusing to leave the area.

Lollie explained to the officer that he had been sitting for 10 minutes and didn't see any reason to leave. The officer persisted, and a second officer arrived, attempting to touch Lollie. The situation escalated, with Lollie becoming increasingly upset and refusing to comply with the officers' demands. The video shows the officers eventually cuffing Lollie and using a taser on him.

According to the police report, the officers were called to the First National Bank Building on a report of an uncooperative male refusing to leave. The female officer's identity has not been released. Lollie's children were not present at the time of the incident, but their classmates and teacher witnessed the event. The teacher provided a witness statement, stating that Lollie was calm and cooperative, and the officers' actions were unjustified.

The charges against Lollie were eventually dropped on July 31, reportedly due to the teacher's statement and footage from the building's security cameras. Lollie chose not to post the video until the charges were dropped, citing the emotional toll the experience had taken on him. He expressed frustration that, despite being a law-abiding citizen, he still faced this kind of treatment.

The incident raises questions about the use of force by law enforcement and the treatment of individuals, particularly those from marginalized communities. The St. Paul Police Department has not commented on the incident, but it serves as a reminder of the importance of transparency and accountability in law enforcement.

Title: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver Addresses Controversy Over Houston Rockets GM's Hong Kong Tweet

Article:

NBA Commissioner Adam Silver spoke at a news conference in Tokyo on Tuesday, addressing the controversy surrounding Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey's tweet in support of anti-government protesters in Hong Kong. The tweet, which was later deleted, sparked backlash from Chinese officials and fans, leading to the cancellation of two NBA preseason games in China.

Silver emphasized that the league is not apologizing for Morey's tweet, citing the importance of freedom of expression. However, he acknowledged that the tweet had caused upset among Chinese officials and fans, and expressed regret that it had caused disruption and disharmony.

The NBA Commissioner also stated that the league is not apologizing for the consequences of Morey's tweet, including the cancellation of the games in China. He noted that the league has a long-standing relationship with China and understands the importance of maintaining good relations with the country.

Silver also expressed hope that the situation can be resolved and that the NBA can continue to have a positive impact on the lives of fans in China. He emphasized that the league's values of freedom of expression and human rights are important, and that the NBA will continue to stand by them.

The controversy has sparked a wider debate about the role of sports and politics, with some calling for the NBA to take a stronger stance on human rights issues. The NBA has faced criticism in the past for its handling of similar controversies, including its response to the 2019 Hong Kong protests.

In conclusion, the NBA Commissioner's comments highlight the complex and sensitive nature of the situation, as the league navigates the delicate balance between its values and its business interests.

Title: Controversy Surrounds Obamacare Architect Jonathan Gruber's Comments on Voter Stupidity

Article:

Jonathan Gruber, a prominent economist and architect of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), has been at the center of a controversy after tapes surfaced of him making derogatory comments about voters. In the recordings, Gruber is heard saying that voters needed to be "bamboozled" and that the healthcare law's passage was dependent on the "stupidity of the American voter."

The comments, made in 2010, have sparked outrage among some lawmakers and healthcare advocates, who are now questioning Gruber's role in the ACA's defense. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who had previously cited Gruber's work in a 2009 "myth-buster" document, distanced herself from him, saying she didn't know who he was and that his comments were a year old and had been recanted.

Gruber's comments were made during a discussion about the healthcare law's individual mandate, which was upheld by the Supreme Court in 2012. In the recordings, he said that the law was written in a "tortured" way to ensure that the Congressional Budget Office didn't score the individual mandate as a tax, and that the lack of transparency was a "huge political advantage."

While Gruber has since apologized for his comments, some lawmakers are calling for him to be removed from the healthcare law's defense strategy. House Speaker John A. Boehner, a Republican, said that American voters are "anything but stupid" and oppose the healthcare overhaul for valid reasons.

The controversy has also raised questions about Gruber's role in the Obama administration's legal strategy. In legal briefs submitted to a federal court in Virginia, Obama administration attorneys cited Gruber's work in a case defending their ability to pay subsidies to enrollees regardless of whether they are part of state-run or federally run health care exchanges.

However, Gruber's comments about subsidies have been used by opponents of the healthcare law to bolster their arguments. In a case before the D.C. Circuit, the administration tried to downplay Gruber's comments, saying that "post-enactment statements by a non-legislator are entitled to no weight." However, Gruber's comments have been used by opponents of the healthcare law to argue that the administration's claims about subsidies are misleading.

The controversy has also raised questions about Gruber's financial ties to the healthcare law. He has made hundreds of thousands of dollars off Obamacare, serving as a consultant to the Department of Health and Human Services and to states that used health care grant money to pay him for his services.

While some have called for Gruber to be removed from the healthcare law's defense strategy, others have defended him, saying that his comments were taken out of context and that he has since apologized for his remarks.

Title: Analysis of Trump's Proposed Rule to Revive Short-Term, Limited-Duration Insurance

The Trump administration's proposed rule to revive short-term, limited-duration (STLD) insurance has sparked controversy, with some arguing it will undermine the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and others seeing it as a way to provide affordable health insurance options. A recent study by the Urban Institute provides new insights into the potential impact of this proposal.

The study estimates that the rule would increase the number of Americans with health insurance by 1.7 million, while reducing costs to taxpayers. The report also highlights that 4.2 million people would enroll in STLD plans, with premiums significantly lower than those available on the exchanges. In contrast, 7.4 million people on the exchanges would see no change in premiums, and 4.5 million would see a slight increase.

The study's findings suggest that the benefits of the proposal far outweigh the costs. While some may argue that the availability of affordable plans outside the ACA's risk pool could deprive the exchanges of essential revenues, the report shows that this is not the case. In fact, the study estimates that the number of people on unsubsidized ACA-compliant plans would fall by 1.5 million, while the number on subsidized plans would fall by 600,000.

The Urban Institute's study also examines the net fiscal impact of STLD deregulation. While some may worry that the government will lose revenue as low-risk individuals disenroll from subsidized plans, the report finds that the number of people on unsubsidized plans would actually increase, offsetting the losses. As a result, the reform would slightly reduce federal spending on health care for the nonelderly by $686 million, or 0.2 percent.

Overall, the study's findings suggest that the deregulation of STLD plans would reduce the cost of health insurance, cover more people, and slightly reduce the burden on taxpayers. While some may still have concerns about the impact on the ACA, the data suggests that this proposal would provide a valuable alternative for those seeking affordable health insurance options.

**US to Allow Lawsuits Against Foreign Companies Using Confiscated Cuban Properties**

The Trump administration has announced a major policy shift, allowing lawsuits in US courts against foreign companies that use properties confiscated by the Cuban government since Fidel Castro's revolution in 1959. This decision is expected to expose US, European, and Canadian companies to legal action and deal a blow to Cuba's efforts to attract more foreign investment.

The move is part of the administration's efforts to punish Cuba over its support for Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, whom the US considers a "dictator." The decision is also seen as a response to the Cuban government's refusal to abandon Maduro and its refusal to hold free and fair elections.

The US National Security Adviser, John Bolton, will explain the decision in a speech in Miami on Wednesday, along with new sanctions on Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua, which the administration has branded a "troika of tyranny."

The decision is expected to have significant implications for foreign companies operating in Cuba, including Canadian mining firm Sherritt International Corp and Spanish hotel chain Melia Hotels International SA. The US companies that have forged business deals in Cuba since the easing of restrictions under former President Barack Obama may also be affected.

The European Union has warned that it may challenge the US decision at the World Trade Organization, citing concerns that it could lead to a cycle of counterclaims in European courts. The Cuban government has also condemned the decision, calling it "illegitimate, unenforceable, and without legal effect."

The US official dismissed the EU's warning, saying that the decision would only cause a "bump" in the business world but send a message of US resolve against Havana. The decision is expected to be met with resistance from the international community, including Canada and the European Union.

The move is seen as a major shift in US policy towards Cuba, which has been a Cold War foe for decades. The US has maintained an economic embargo on the island since 1960, and the new decision is seen as a way to increase pressure on the Cuban government to change its stance on Venezuela.

**Budget Deal Sparks Debate Among Lawmakers and Interest Groups**

A bipartisan budget agreement negotiated between House Republicans and Senate Democrats has sparked intense debate among lawmakers and interest groups, with some hailing it as a step towards fiscal responsibility and others criticizing it as a missed opportunity to address long-term spending issues.

The deal, brokered by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan and Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray, aims to reduce the deficit by $23 billion over the next decade. While it includes some sweeteners for defense contractors and oil drillers, it also increases fees on air travelers and requires higher pension contributions from recently hired federal employees.

Conservative groups, such as the Club for Growth and Heritage Action, have been vocal in their opposition to the deal, citing concerns that it does not do enough to restrain entitlement programs and does not address the long-term costs of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.

"This deal is a betrayal of the American people," said Rep. Jim Jordan, Ohio Republican. "We sacrificed our biggest point of leverage, the sequester, in the rush to get a short-term deal that does not address the long-term costs of these programs."

On the other hand, some liberal lawmakers have expressed concerns that the deal does not go far enough in addressing the needs of federal workers and the long-term unemployed. "This deal balances the budget on the backs of federal workers and does not address the needs of the 1.3 million Americans who are set to lose their unemployment benefits," said Rep. Chris Van Hollen, Maryland Democrat.

The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the bulk of the plan's deficit reduction will come in the final three years of the deal, while the new spending will occur over the next two years. The Treasury Department has reported that the government ran a $135.2 billion budget deficit through the first two months of the year, a significant improvement from the $226.8 billion deficit at the same time last year.

The deal has also drawn criticism from industries and interest groups that will be affected by the increased fees and pension contributions. Airlines for America, a trade group representing U.S. airlines, has expressed disappointment that fees on air travel were increased, citing concerns that it will impact demand, jobs, and the economy.

The National Treasury Employees Union has also launched a pre-emptive strike against the proposal, saying that federal employees have suffered enough under pay freezes and furloughs. "We continue to believe that there should be zero cuts to federal pay and benefits in this deal and that federal employees are being asked to contribute a disproportionate share toward deficit reduction," the group said.

The deal is expected to be voted on in the House as early as Thursday, with House Speaker John A. Boehner confident that he has the votes to pass the bill. However, several Republican senators, including Rand Paul and Tom Coburn, have already come out against the deal, and many other Republican senators are expected to oppose the accord.

**New Jersey Bombing Suspect Captured After Dramatic Gun Battle with Police**

A 28-year-old Afghan immigrant, Ahmad Khan Rahami, was captured on Monday after a brief but intense gun battle with police in Linden, New Jersey. The suspect was identified as the primary person of interest in a series of bombings that occurred over the weekend in New York and New Jersey.

Rahami was found sleeping in the doorway of a bar in Linden, and when police approached him, he pulled out a gun and shot an officer, identified as Angel Padilla, in the abdomen. The officer was wearing a bulletproof vest and was expected to recover. A second officer, Investigator Pete Hammer, suffered a graze wound to the head.

Rahami was shot in the leg and eventually brought down and captured alive. He was taken to University Hospital in Newark for treatment and was later charged with five counts of attempted murder of a police officer. He was being held on $5.2 million bail and remained at the hospital.

The investigation into the bombings, which injured 29 people in New York's Chelsea neighborhood and caused no injuries in New Jersey, is ongoing. Authorities found Rahami's fingerprint on an unexploded bomb discovered on West 27th Street, and officials are still searching for two individuals who removed the bomb from a duffle bag after it was allegedly placed on the street.

The FBI launched a raid on Rahami's apartment in Elizabeth, New Jersey, on Monday morning, and officials said they found no evidence of any foreign training or involvement. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said authorities are not currently searching for any other suspects, and the FBI's assistant director in New York, William Sweeney Jr., stated that there is no indication of a cell in the area.

The investigation is ongoing, and federal charges are expected to be filed in the coming days.

Title: Sanders Criticizes Bloomberg's Wealth, Refuses to Commit to Accepting Campaign Donations

Article:

During a CNN town hall on Tuesday night, Senator Bernie Sanders criticized billionaire Michael Bloomberg's wealth, saying it was "offensive" and that he didn't think it was right for someone with such vast resources to buy the presidency. However, Sanders refused to commit to accepting campaign donations from Bloomberg or any other billionaires if he were to win the Democratic nomination.

Sanders' comments came after two recent polls showed Bloomberg as his closest competitor in the race. When asked if he saw Bloomberg as the biggest threat to his nomination, Sanders said, "I think it's a bit obscene that we have somebody who chose not to contest in Iowa, in Nevada, in South Carolina, in New Hampshire, where all of the candidates – we did town meetings, we were talking to thousands and thousands of people, working hard – he said, 'I don't have to do that. I'm worth $60 billion. I have more wealth than the bottom 125 million Americans. I'll buy the presidency.' That offends me very much."

When asked if he would accept help from billionaires like Bloomberg if nominated, Sanders dodged the question three times, saying he was proud of the grassroots movement his campaign had built and that he didn't have a super PAC. He emphasized that his campaign had received more contributions from individual Americans than any other candidate in history, with an average contribution of $18.50.

Sanders also reiterated his commitment to supporting the Democratic nominee, regardless of who it is, and said he would not accept donations from super PACs. However, he refused to commit to accepting donations from Bloomberg or other billionaires, saying he would support the Democratic nominee if he were to win the nomination.

The exchange highlights the ongoing debate within the Democratic Party about the role of big money in politics and the best way to take on President Donald Trump in the general election.

Title: House Republicans Unveil Plan to Wean Country Off Obamacare Subsidies Amid Supreme Court Ruling

Article:

House Republicans have outlined a plan to phase out Obamacare subsidies, anticipating a Supreme Court ruling this month that could significantly impact the Affordable Care Act. The proposal, described as a "work in progress," would continue to provide full subsidies to all beneficiaries, regardless of their location, but would allow states to opt out of the program and receive block grants to help their residents obtain insurance. The block grants and subsidies would expire in 2017, requiring the next president and Congress to replace the law entirely.

The plan, which has not been finalized, would repeal the Affordable Care Act's insurance mandates on individuals and employers, a move that is likely to spark controversy among Obamacare supporters. The proposal would use a budget process known as "reconciliation" to pass the plan, which could be vetoed by President Obama.

Some lawmakers are hesitant to approve Obamacare subsidies for the rest of 2015 and 2016, fearing it sends the wrong message to voters after the GOP has spent years trying to repeal the entire law. Others believe that Congress should let states opt out of Obamacare if the subsidies go away or extend temporary aid outside of the health law's framework.

The Supreme Court is expected to rule on a part of the law that says subsidies can be paid to residents in states that established their own exchanges. The administration argues that this was intended to cover everyone, while opponents say it was meant to exclude the 34 states that refused to set up exchanges and instead rely on the federal HealthCare.gov program. More than 6 million Americans stand to lose subsidies if the court rules against the administration.

While some Republicans are supportive of the plan, others are still working through the details. "We don't know what the Supreme Court is going to do, but we want to be ready," said Sen. John Cornyn, Texas Republican. The Senate is expected to discuss its own plans in the coming days.

The proposal is a response to the Supreme Court's consideration of a lawsuit, known as King v.
