While men in full-time work still earn more than women, the data conceals a widening gap between the family patterns of the college-educated top one-third and those of the non-college-educated bottom two-thirds. The latter group is experiencing a breakdown in family life, with marriage rates declining and family instability increasing.

The debate over same-sex marriage may be settled, but the crisis of the American family is far from resolved. The question is not whether same-sex marriage is allowed, but how to ensure that the next generation of American children enjoys a more equal chance and wider opportunities from a more universal commitment to marriage. It is a challenge that requires a nuanced understanding of the complex factors driving the decline of marriage and a commitment to finding solutions that benefit all families, regardless of sexual orientation.

Title: Romney's Vice Presidential Search: A Mystery Wrapped in Secrecy

Article:

Mitt Romney's search for a running mate has been shrouded in secrecy, with the Republican presidential candidate refusing to reveal any details about his top contenders. However, his wife, Ann Romney, has dropped a tantalizing hint that a woman might be in the running. "We've been looking at that, and I love that option as well," she told CBS News in an interview.

The Romney campaign has been tight-lipped about the search, with Mitt Romney declining to comment on the status of the process. "That's something I'm keeping close with my team," he said. The search is expected to be a crucial decision, as the chosen running mate could help sway undecided voters and energize the Republican base.

Speculation has been rife about the potential candidates, with several high-profile Republicans mentioned as possible contenders. These include Ohio Sen. Rob Portman, former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty, Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal. However, Ann Romney's comment has added a new dimension to the speculation, with some wondering if a woman might be the ultimate choice.

Ann Romney outlined her criteria for the ideal running mate, stating that the person should be "someone that obviously can do the job but will be able to carry through with some of the other responsibilities." She emphasized the importance of the running mate being someone who will have Mitt Romney's back and who he will enjoy being around. "Competent, capable, and willing to serve this country," she said.

The Romney campaign's decision-making process is expected to be influenced by the experience of the 2008 election, when Sen. John McCain chose Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin as his running mate. While Palin's selection was seen as a bold move, it ultimately proved to be a liability for the McCain campaign. This time around, Mitt Romney has said that preparedness to be president is his top requirement for a running mate.

The Romneys' joint interview with CBS was a rare moment of transparency for the couple, who spent the week relaxing with their family at their lakeside estate in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire. The break from the campaign trail allowed Mitt Romney to recharge and reassess his strategy, with his wife by his side. The couple's sons, including eldest son Tagg, have also been involved in the campaign and running-mate search.

As the search continues, speculation will undoubtedly continue to swirl around the potential candidates. One thing is certain, however: the choice of running mate will be a crucial decision that could make or break Mitt Romney's chances of winning the presidency.

Title: Understanding the Rise of Mass Incarceration in the United States: A Guide to the Key Factors

Article:

The United States has seen a significant increase in its prison population over the past 40 years, with the number of incarcerated individuals growing from around 300,000 in 1970 to over 2.2 million today. But what drove this surge in incarceration? A 2014 National Research Council report shed light on the two main reasons behind this trend: prosecution has become more efficient, and prison sentences have lengthened.

The report debunked two common misconceptions about the rise of incarceration. Firstly, it found that crime rates have not significantly contributed to the increase in incarceration. Crime rates have fluctuated over the past 40 years, and there is no clear correlation between crime rates and incarceration rates.

Secondly, the report concluded that better policing did not lead to more criminals getting arrested. The arrest-to-crime ratio, which measures the proportion of crimes that police are able to find and arrest suspects for, remained relatively flat since 1980. This suggests that policing effectiveness has not improved significantly over the past three decades.

So, what did contribute to the rise of mass incarceration? The report found that prosecution has become more efficient, with more people who get arrested ending up in prison. This is partly due to the fact that more crimes now require a prison sentence, and partly because most people who get convicted of crimes plead guilty in exchange for a shorter prison sentence, making it easier for prosecutors to move cases through the courts.

The report also highlighted the role of harsh sentencing policies in the 1980s and 1990s, which led to longer prison sentences. Mandatory minimum sentences, including "three-strikes" laws and "truth-in-sentencing" laws, forced people convicted of certain crimes to serve longer periods of time. These policies have contributed significantly to the growth of the prison population.

The report's findings suggest that sentencing reform policies, which some state governments and lawmakers have been pursuing, are a crucial step towards reducing mass incarceration. By addressing the root causes of the problem, policymakers can work towards creating a more just and effective criminal justice system.

**Title:** Politicians Distance Themselves from Controversial Comments on Race and Slavery

**Article:**

A recent controversy surrounding Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy's comments on race and slavery has sparked a heated debate about the intersection of politics and racial sensitivity. Bundy's remarks, in which he questioned whether African Americans were better off under slavery or as recipients of government subsidies, have been widely condemned as offensive and racist.

The comments, made during an interview with The New York Times, have drawn criticism from politicians and experts alike. Senator Rand Paul, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, called Bundy's remarks "offensive" and "wrong on race." Senator Dean Heller of Nevada and the Republican National Committee also distanced themselves from Bundy's comments, labeling them "appalling and racist."

Experts on race and politics say Bundy's comments reflect a larger cultural phenomenon, in which some individuals and groups are resistant to changing demographics and the growing diversity of the United States. "We are looking at some of the 'last white men standing,'" said Mark Anthony Neal, an African-American studies professor at Duke University. "His comments represent that, and people rally around him because of this idea that white men are under siege."

The comments also echo those of other public figures, such as rocker Ted Nugent, who called President Barack Obama a "subhuman mongrel," and "Duck Dynasty" star Phil Robertson, who shared fond memories of working alongside African Americans in Louisiana cotton fields. These comments, while not representative of the views of the majority, reflect a fringe element within American society that is resistant to change and diversity.

Politicians who have previously embraced these individuals as cause célèbres are now facing an awkward situation. Texas Attorney General Greg Abbott, a potential gubernatorial candidate, took heat for Nugent's appearance at a campaign event, while Senator Ted Cruz and Governor Rick Perry distanced themselves from Nugent's remarks. Conservative radio host Sean Hannity expressed concern that Democrats will use Bundy's comments to paint the entire right wing as racist.

The controversy highlights the importance of politicians being mindful of their words and actions, particularly when it comes to issues of race and social justice. As the demographics of the United States continue to shift, politicians must be prepared to address the concerns and perspectives of a growing minority population.

Title: White House Exerts Executive Privilege Over 'Fast and Furious' Documents, Tensions Escalate

The ongoing controversy surrounding the "Fast and Furious" operation has reached a boiling point, with the White House exerting executive privilege over documents subpoenaed by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. This move has sparked a heated debate between the Obama administration and the committee's Republican majority, with the committee expected to vote on whether to hold Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress.

The controversy began after the December 2010 death of a U.S. Border Patrol agent, whose death was linked to the botched gun-trafficking operation. The operation, which was launched in 2009, aimed to track the flow of guns from the U.S. to Mexico, but it was shut down in 2011 after it became clear that the operation had failed to prevent the sale of thousands of weapons to Mexican drug cartels.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has been investigating the operation since 2011, with Attorney General Holder appearing before the panel in June to answer questions about the operation. However, the committee has accused the Obama administration of not fully cooperating with their investigation, and has subpoenaed documents related to the operation.

The White House's decision to exert executive privilege over the documents has been met with criticism from Republicans, who argue that it is an attempt to stonewall the investigation. "This is an untimely assertion by the Justice Department," said Committee Chairman Darrell Issa. "We did not set out to hold Holder in contempt, but rather to get the information the committee needs to complete its work."

Democrats, on the other hand, have defended the administration's decision, arguing that the documents are protected by executive privilege and that the committee's investigation is politically motivated. "The administration has more than fully cooperated with the committee's investigation," said a committee aide.

The committee is expected to vote on whether to hold Holder in contempt of Congress, which would be a rare and serious step. If the committee votes to hold Holder in contempt, the matter would then go to the full House, where it would require a majority vote to pass. However, past examples suggest that the matter may not get that far, as the Justice Department has historically been reluctant to take the matter to court.

The controversy has sparked a heated debate about the balance between executive privilege and congressional oversight, with both sides accusing the other of overstepping their authority. The outcome of the vote is uncertain, but one thing is clear: the "Fast and Furious" controversy is far from over.

**Montana's Special Election: Gianforte Wins, But Questions Linger**

In a closely watched special election, Republican Greg Gianforte emerged victorious in Montana's at-large congressional district, defeating Democrat Rob Quist. The election was marked by controversy, however, after Gianforte allegedly body-slammed a reporter from The Guardian newspaper, leading to a criminal charge of misdemeanor assault.

Gianforte won the election with 50.3% of the vote, compared to Quist's 43.9%. Libertarian Mark Wicks received 5.8% of the vote. The Associated Press called the race for Gianforte more than 2.5 hours after polls closed.

Gianforte apologized to the reporter, Ben Jacobs, saying it was a mistake and that he took an action he cannot take back. "That is not the person that I am and it is not the way that I will lead in this state," he said.

The outcome of the election means Republicans will maintain their majority in the House of Representatives, with a 239-193 advantage.

The election was seen as a test of the political landscape, with Democrats hoping to capitalize on anti-Trump sentiment and score an electoral victory. However, Republicans were able to hold onto the seat, despite Gianforte's controversial behavior.

The incident with the reporter has sparked questions about whether Gianforte's behavior is acceptable and whether he should be allowed to join the GOP conference. House Speaker Paul Ryan said Gianforte should apologize to Jacobs, but ultimately, the decision lies with Montana voters.

The election was also marked by a large number of absentee ballots, with over 200,000 cast before the election. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee released a television ad highlighting the incident with the reporter, but it was not enough to sway voters.

The outcome of the election is a blow to Democrats, who had hoped to capitalize on anti-Trump sentiment and score an electoral victory. However, Republicans were able to hold onto the seat, despite Gianforte's controversial behavior.

Title: The Importance of Discussing Politics at the Thanksgiving Table

Article:

As the holiday season approaches, many of us are reminded to avoid discussing politics at the dinner table. However, this year, it's more crucial than ever to engage in open and honest conversations about the issues that affect our families and communities. The media often warns us against bringing up politics at the table, but what's the harm in sharing our thoughts and opinions with our loved ones?

For many families, Thanksgiving is a time to reflect on the values that have brought them together for generations. It's an opportunity to share stories, traditions, and experiences that have shaped our lives. As a conservative, I believe it's essential to use this holiday to connect with our progressive relatives and friends, and to share our perspectives on the issues that matter most.

In today's polarized society, it's easy to get caught up in echo chambers and avoid discussing politics altogether. But by doing so, we're missing out on the chance to understand each other's viewpoints and work towards common goals. As a conservative, I've had the privilege of living in a liberal city, where I've seen firsthand the impact of progressive ideology on our community. I've also seen the importance of having open and respectful conversations about our differences.

So, what can you do to make the most of your Thanksgiving conversation? Start by sharing your personal story and experiences. Explain why you live where you live, and how your family has benefited from your decisions. Share your values and beliefs, and be open to hearing others' perspectives. Don't be afraid to discuss the issues that matter most to you, such as religion, education, and law enforcement.

Remember, the goal is not to convince others of your point of view, but to understand theirs. By doing so, we can build bridges and foster a more empathetic and compassionate society. So, this Thanksgiving, take the opportunity to engage in meaningful conversations and build connections with your loved ones. Who knows, you might just find that you have more in common than you think.

Title: Trump's Presidency Brings New Era of Storylines and Challenges for Newsrooms

Article:

The outcome of the presidential election has sent shockwaves through the media industry, leaving newsrooms scrambling to adapt to the new reality. As Donald Trump prepares to take office, journalists are eager to dive into the complexities of his presidency and the implications it will have on the country.

The unexpected turn of events has brought a mix of excitement and uncertainty to newsrooms. "This changes everything," said Phil Griffin, president of MSNBC. "We left the studio at 4 a.m., and we knew there was a whole other world of storylines and changes that are going to happen."

Major TV news operations were bracing for a ratings letdown as the election wound down, but Trump's victory has brought a new wave of storylines and challenges. CNN had its highest online traffic ever on Election Day, and the election was a significant revenue driver for its parent company, Time Warner. However, the company was warning as early as summer that its ratings would drop next year.

The first 100 days of any presidency are always exciting, particularly when a new party takes over in Washington, D.C. The transition, with politicians jockeying for key Cabinet positions, is a horse race of its own kind. But Trump, the inexperienced politician suddenly leading the federal government, adds multiple and substantive layers to the story.

Gauging Trump's comfort level with the press is already underway, and it's been as challenging as pinning down his stance on issues. Reporters who have known him for years speak of his accessibility and willingness to banter, yet he's also sought political advantage in bashing the mainstream media. "Let's see how much access he grants," said Chris Ariens, editor of TVNewser. "He's not the candidate anymore. He's not going to be calling into Fox and Friends."

One of the first major interviews Trump granted after the election was to 60 Minutes, which will air Sunday. Jeff Fager, executive producer of 60 Minutes, said the show had planned on pursuing an interview with the president-elect regardless of the election outcome, but because so much of Trump's governing philosophy and policy specifics are unknown, it heightens the urgency.

"It's not about good TV. It's about how we can help people better understand," Fager said. "There's a lot to talk about. Hopefully, we'll get some details."

In an interview clip released early by CBS, Trump said he's willing to retain some key provisions of the Affordable Care Act, including prohibiting insurers from denying coverage to patients with pre-existing conditions.

There has already been plenty of hand-wringing in American newsrooms about the failure to properly assess the impact of Trump's voters and the issues that drove them so eagerly to the voting booths. Coverage planning for Trump's presidency must entail deep-diving into these issues to hold him accountable for some of his outlandish proposals.

Beyond issues, scrutinizing Trump's governing styles and tendencies – not as a career politician, but honed on the fly based on his experience as a real estate developer and TV personality – will also be a rich source of stories. "He's a businessman who's a negotiator," Fager said. "There's a lot of stories that could be generated in (covering) someone who's got a totally different perspective on how to get things done."

While no news executives may admit it publicly, the possibility of Trump's gaffes and unfiltered diatribes, frequently evident during his campaign, remains an intriguing variable, said Mark Feldstein, a broadcast journalism professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, and a former journalist at NBC. "Media critics are always attacking TV for ideological bias," he said. "But the real bias is toward conflict, controversy, and excitement because that's what increases revenue. Whether you love or hate him, he is going to bring controversy."

**Trump's Shift on Immigration and Inner Cities: A Closer Look**

In a recent move to court non-white voters, Republican nominee Donald Trump has softened his stance on immigration and made a pitch to African American and Latino communities. The real estate mogul and reality TV star has been criticized for his hardline stance on immigration, which has been difficult to pin down. However, his latest statements suggest a more nuanced approach.

During a town hall meeting with Fox News anchor Sean Hannity, Trump said that immigrants who are not in the US legally will "pay back taxes" and "work with them." This is a departure from his previous stance, which included a "deportation force" to remove the estimated 11 million undocumented migrants living in the US.

Trump's shift comes as he tries to win over Hispanic and African American voters, who have been skeptical of his campaign. A recent Quinnipiac University poll showed Hillary Clinton leading Trump by 62 points among likely non-white voters.

In a speech in Akron, Ohio, Trump highlighted the struggles faced by African Americans and Hispanics, saying that they have been failed by their politicians and are suffering from poverty, rejection, and poor education. He asked, "What do you have to lose?" However, his statement has been criticized for painting a broad-brush portrait of American cities and using language that is offensive to the very voters he is trying to reach.

Trump also claimed that crime is at "levels that nobody's seen," citing inner cities as an example. However, crime statistics show a steady decline since 1991, with some demographics still experiencing high rates of criminal activity. A recent analysis by the Associated Press found "few if any" black executives in Trump's organization, despite his claims of employing many African Americans.

In another statement, Trump claimed that 58% of young black men and women are unemployed, citing Bureau of Labor Statistics data from 2015. However, the BLS puts the unemployment rate among 16- to 19-year-old black Americans at 25.7%, adjusted seasonally. The campaign's economic adviser, David Malpass, explained that the 58% figure was based on BLS data from 2015 and included labor force participants and those outside the labor force, such as students and retirees.

Economists have criticized the campaign's calculation, saying it is statistically misleading to include segments of the population that are actively not seeking employment.

Title: Biden's Presidential Bid: A Test of Unity and Electability

Article:

Joe Biden is set to officially announce his third presidential bid, with many considering him the front-runner or co-front-runner alongside Bernie Sanders. He has led in 36 of the 37 polls included in RealClearPolitics' compilation of 2020 Democratic-nomination-contest surveys, and leads in all publicly available polls of Iowa and even Kamala Harris' California. However, the big question haunting his candidacy is whether he has lost the ability to unite his party across ideological and demographic lines.

Biden's reputation for insensitivity has been reinforced by allegations of inappropriate behavior toward women, giving doubts about his candidacy a more urgent currency. While his standing in horse-race polls has remained steady during the winter and spring of activist/media discontent, his approval rating among Democrats is still high, with 75% of Morning Consult's tracking poll respondents approving of him. He is also the top second-choice candidate among those whose favorite is Kamala Harris, Beto O'Rourke, or Bernie Sanders.

However, it's unclear if this will last, particularly if and when his rivals start throwing punches at him. Some critics argue that Biden's past record, including his association with less defensible political and policy trends, will undermine his ability to unite the party. Others believe that his efforts to distinguish himself from more progressive candidates could fall flat, or that he may fall between stools by trying to accommodate himself to a more self-consciously progressive electorate.

Biden's standing as a unity candidate could also be undermined by his own efforts if he finds it necessary to distinguish himself from more progressive candidates as representing a moderate tradition. Some have suggested that he may run a campaign that feels like an apology tour, talking endlessly about how much he has learned and grown since his past mistakes. This could be a recipe for disaster, as Ross Douthat notes, "a kind of Biden campaign would probably lose...as badly as Jeb Bush did."

On the other hand, Biden's electability could be his greatest asset. He is doing better than any other Democrat when matched against the incumbent, and his ability to appeal to white working-class swing voters in the Rust Belt states could be a key factor in the general election. If Trump's strength holds, Biden's electability could be a major advantage, covering up many of his perceived sins.

Ultimately, Biden's presidential bid will be a test of his ability to balance his past record with his vision for the future, and to appeal to a broad range of voters. While it's still early days, his campaign will be closely watched to see if he can overcome his challenges and emerge as a strong contender for the Democratic nomination.

**New Article:**

**Diplomat's Testimony Raises Questions About Allegations Against Biden**

A recent closed-door testimony from Kurt Volker, a senior diplomat and former special envoy to Ukraine, has sparked new questions about the allegations against former Vice President Joe Biden. Volker's testimony, released by the House Intelligence Committee, contradicts claims made by President Donald Trump and his allies that Biden pressured Ukraine's government to investigate his son, Hunter Biden, in exchange for political favors.

According to Volker, Biden's actions were motivated by a desire to root out corruption in Ukraine, not to benefit his son. Volker testified that Biden's push to fire Ukraine's prosecutor general, Viktor Shokin, was widely supported by the international community, including the European Union, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom.

Volker's account also undercuts the notion that Hunter Biden was hired by Burisma, a Ukrainian gas company, to curry favor with the Obama administration. Volker testified that it was "quite possible" that Burisma executives believed they were buying influence through Hunter Biden, but Volker did not believe that Biden would take any improper action on his son's behalf.

The testimony has raised questions about the motivations of Yuriy Lutsenko, Ukraine's former prosecutor general, who made explosive allegations against Biden in March. Volker testified that Lutsenko's allegations were self-serving and motivated by a desire to save his own job.

The controversy surrounding Biden's actions in Ukraine has been a central focus of the House impeachment inquiry, with Trump and his allies claiming that Biden pressured Ukraine to investigate his son in exchange for political favors. However, Volker's testimony suggests that the allegations against Biden are unfounded and motivated by political agendas.

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen how the testimony will impact the impeachment inquiry.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Releases Impeachment Report, Republicans Push Back

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee has released a 658-page report detailing the impeachment case against President Trump, outlining two articles of impeachment: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The report claims that President Trump has placed his personal and political interests above national security, free and fair elections, and the system of checks and balances. The committee argues that Trump's actions warrant impeachment and removal from office.

The report also notes that while there is no need for a crime to be proven for impeachment, Trump's actions encompassed other offenses, both constitutional and criminal in character. The committee believes that Trump's abuse of power included both the constitutional offense of bribery and multiple federal crimes, and that he has betrayed the national interest and the people of the nation.

However, Republicans have pushed back against the report, calling the Democrats' actions "unprecedented, unjustifiable, and will only dilute the significance of the dire recourse that is impeachment." Ranking Member Doug Collins (R-GA) blasted the Democrats for deciding to "pursue impeachment first and build a case second" based on hearsay and assumptions. The minority also argued that not one of the criminal accusations leveled at the president over the past year has found a place in the articles.

The full House is expected to vote on the articles of impeachment this week.

**Teenager Found Safe After 88-Day Ordeal, Suspect Arrested**

A 13-year-old Wisconsin girl, Jayme Closs, has been found safe and sound after being missing for 88 days. The teenager was discovered on Thursday, fleeing on foot from a remote house, and was taken into police custody after a woman who was walking her dog stopped to call authorities. Jayme was reunited with her family on Friday after speaking with investigators.

The suspect, 21-year-old Jake Thomas Patterson, was arrested and charged with kidnapping and murder. Authorities believe Patterson planned his actions and took steps to avoid detection, but Jayme's determination to survive ultimately led to her escape.

Patterson was found down the road from the house where Jayme was being held, and was arrested based on a description of his vehicle provided by the teenager. Investigators are still trying to determine what Jayme experienced during her captivity and why Patterson seemed determined to abduct her.

The Barron County Sheriff, Chris Fitzgerald, expressed relief and gratitude for Jayme's safe return, saying, "The will of a kid to survive – it's unthinkable." Fitzgerald also noted that there was no indication of a prior relationship between Patterson and the Closs family, nor any social media contact between the two.

The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are still trying to piece together the events surrounding Jayme's disappearance and captivity. The local district attorney's office plans to issue a criminal complaint next week.

Title: US Withdraws from Global Arms Treaty, Citing Sovereignty Concerns

Article:

The United States has officially withdrawn from the Arms Trade Treaty, a global agreement aimed at regulating the international sale of conventional weapons. The decision was announced by President Trump, who cited concerns over American sovereignty and the potential for the treaty to impinge on the rights of American gun owners.

The Arms Trade Treaty was approved by the United Nations General Assembly in 2013 and signed by President Obama, but it has never been ratified by the US Congress. The treaty has been ratified by 101 countries, including the member states of the European Union, but China and Russia are not parties to it.

Some critics of the treaty argue that it could lead to stricter gun regulations in the US, while others see it as a way to ensure that other countries follow the same standards as the US in regulating arms exports. Thomas Countryman, a former assistant secretary of state who was the lead US negotiator for the treaty, said that the treaty has no impact on Second Amendment rights and was designed to ensure that the US maintains its leadership in arms exports.

Rachel Stohl, managing director of the conventional defense program at the Stimson Center, a Washington think tank, expressed concerns that the decision to withdraw from the treaty will undermine international peace and security, increase irresponsible and illegal sales of conventional weapons, and harm the American economy.

Ted Bromund, a senior research fellow in Anglo-American relations at the Heritage Foundation's Margaret Thatcher Center for Freedom, praised the president's decision, citing low levels of compliance with the treaty and saying that nations are free to impose their own legal controls on arms exports.

The decision to withdraw from the treaty has been met with criticism from some lawmakers, including House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel, who called it a "politically-motivated appeasement of the National Rifle Association."

Title: Senator Tim Scott Receives Death Threats and Racial Slurs, but Mainstream Media Ignores the Story

Article:

Senator Tim Scott, the only black Republican in the Senate, has been receiving death threats and racial slurs on his office voicemail, according to a recent report by The New York Times. The senator shared two audio recordings with the publication, which contained profanity and racist slurs, including one caller who threatened to "put him in his crosshairs."

Despite this disturbing news, the liberal broadcast networks ABC, CBS, and NBC failed to report on the story, instead choosing to focus on promoting John Bolton's anti-Trump book and decrying President Trump's rallies. The networks also ignored House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's incendiary comments about the Republican Party being "trying to get away with murder" in reference to the death of George Floyd.

The New York Times article highlighted Senator Scott's concerns about the media's portrayal of his police reform legislation, stating that he believes the media is characterizing him as being on the "wrong side" of the issue. The article also noted that the senator shared two audio recordings with the publication, which included a caller who threatened to "take his one-way ticket straight to hell."

In a separate incident, CBS Evening News failed to cover Speaker Pelosi's comments about the Republican Party, despite having a reporter, Steve Futterman, conduct an interview with her. Futterman did not fact-check Pelosi's statement, which was widely criticized as false and divisive.

The lack of coverage of Senator Scott's story and Speaker Pelosi's comments raises questions about the media's priorities and their commitment to reporting on important issues. As the country continues to grapple with issues of racial tension and police reform, it is crucial that the media provides accurate and balanced coverage of these topics.

Title: Bridging the Divide: A Personal Journey of Understanding Across Party Lines

Article:

As a real estate broker and Albanian-born US citizen, I, Rremida Shkoza, have always been passionate about the importance of understanding and empathy in our society. Recently, I participated in a unique opportunity to engage in a bipartisan forum, known as a Living Room Conversation, focused on the topic of immigration. The experience was a transformative one, as I discovered that even those with differing political views can find common ground and shared values.

The conversation was facilitated by Tracy Hollister, who invited me to join a group of three Democrats and three Republicans, including Sue Googe, a Republican who had immigrated from China. I was initially hesitant, given my personal experience as a refugee who had risked her life to escape communist Albania and find freedom in the United States. However, I was determined to approach the conversation with an open mind.

As we shared our personal stories and experiences with immigration, I was surprised to find that my Republican counterparts, Julia Song and Mario Benavente, were not only understanding but also empathetic towards the struggles of migrants and refugees. Julia, a Brazilian immigrant herself, emphasized the importance of not losing sight of the humans at the heart of the debate, while Mario, the son of immigrants, shared his own experience witnessing the struggles of tired and hungry migrants arriving in North Carolina.

Through our conversation, we discovered that we all shared a common goal: to find a way to balance our values of freedom and democracy with the need to help others. We acknowledged that our country is far from perfect, with issues like racism, xenophobia, and homelessness still prevalent. However, we also recognized that we can work together to address these challenges and create a more just and compassionate society.

The experience was a powerful reminder that even in the face of disagreement, we can find common ground and build bridges across party lines. It's not about agreeing on every issue, but about understanding and respecting each other's perspectives. As Americans, we want to continue to be a beacon for democratic values, but we must also acknowledge our own flaws and work towards creating a more perfect union.

In the end, I left the conversation feeling hopeful and inspired, knowing that even in the midst of division, we can find common ground and work towards a brighter future.

Title: Federal Law Enforcement's Use of Unmarked Vehicles Raises Concerns in Portland

Article:

In recent weeks, federal law enforcement officers have been using unmarked vehicles to patrol the streets of Portland, Oregon, detaining individuals without explanation or justification. The tactic has raised concerns among protesters and observers alike, who claim that the officers are targeting individuals based on their appearance or political beliefs.

According to reports, the officers, who are part of the U.S. Marshals Special Operations Group and Customs and Border Protection's BORTAC, have been driving around downtown Portland in unmarked vehicles, detaining individuals without explanation or justification. The tactic has been used to detain at least 13 people, with some being charged with crimes related to the protests.

The use of unmarked vehicles and the lack of transparency have raised concerns about the legitimacy of the detentions. Many have compared the tactic to those used by authoritarian regimes, where individuals are detained and disappeared without explanation.

The protests in Portland have been ongoing for over six weeks, with demonstrators calling for an end to systemic racism and police brutality. The federal government has sent in law enforcement officers to protect federal property, but critics argue that the officers are overstepping their authority and targeting innocent individuals.

The situation has sparked concerns about the erosion of civil liberties and the potential for abuse of power. Many have called for greater transparency and accountability from the law enforcement agencies involved.

In a statement, Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf said that the department will not "abdicate its solemn duty to protect federal facilities and those within them." However, critics argue that the use of unmarked vehicles and the lack of transparency are a clear violation of due process and the rule of law.

The situation in Portland highlights the importance of transparency and accountability in law enforcement. It is crucial that law enforcement agencies prioritize the safety and well-being of all individuals, regardless of their political beliefs or affiliations.

Title: Romney Clarifies Stance on Health Care Mandate, Calls it a Tax

Article:

In a recent interview with CBS News, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, clarified his stance on the individual mandate in President Obama's health care law, stating that it is indeed a tax. This statement comes just days after his campaign said the mandate should be considered a penalty, not a tax.

Romney's comments were made during an interview with Jan Crawford, where he acknowledged the Supreme Court's ruling that the mandate is a tax. "While I agreed with the dissent, that's taken over by the fact that the majority of the court said it's a tax, and therefore it is a tax," he said.

Romney's campaign had previously taken a different stance on the issue, with spokesman Eric Fehrnstrom stating that the mandate should be seen as a penalty, not a tax. However, Romney's latest comments align with the views of many leading Republicans in Congress, who have been quick to label the mandate as a new tax.

The issue of how to characterize the mandate is a sensitive one for the Romney campaign, given his previous support for universal health care in Massachusetts. While Romney has pledged to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, he had previously avoided calling the mandate a tax, possibly due to his Massachusetts plan's similar mandate.

Romney made his comments while vacationing in New Hampshire, where he is currently campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination. The debate over the individual mandate is likely to continue as the election season heats up, with both sides presenting their arguments on the issue.

Title: Political Unforced Errors: A Game of Power and Polarization

Article:

In the game of politics, unforced errors can be just as costly as they are in sports. When politicians make mistakes, the consequences can be far-reaching and damaging. Recently, both sides of the political spectrum have committed unforced errors, showcasing the lack of strategy and thinking that can come with the pursuit of power.

Hillary Clinton's decision to use a private email server while serving as Secretary of State has raised eyebrows. While it may have been seen as a way to maintain control over her communications, it has also raised questions about transparency and accountability. Clinton's defenders argue that it was a necessary measure to protect her privacy and security, but critics see it as a lack of trust in the official government email system.

Meanwhile, the Republican-led Senate's open letter to the Iranian leadership has been widely criticized as an attempt to undermine the nuclear deal between the U.S. and Iran. The letter, signed by 47 senators, was seen as a partisan stunt that undermined the authority of the President and the State Department. While senators have the constitutional power to approve treaties, this letter was seen as a misuse of that power and a display of arrogance.

These unforced errors are not new to politics. Politicians often make mistakes that can have far-reaching consequences. However, in this age of political polarization, these errors can be particularly damaging. The lack of trust and cooperation between parties can lead to a breakdown in governance and a failure to address the country's pressing issues.

In the end, these unforced errors are a reminder that politics is a game of power and strategy. While politicians may make mistakes, it is up to the public to hold them accountable and demand better.

Title: DOJ Establishes Task Force to Combat Violent Anti-Government Extremism

Article:

The Department of Justice (DOJ) has launched a new task force aimed at combating violent anti-government extremism, according to a memo issued by Attorney General William Barr on June 26. The initiative aims to investigate and prosecute violent acts, prevent extremist violence before it happens, and ultimately eliminate it as a threat to public safety and the rule of law.

The task force will provide training and resources to local law enforcement agencies to help them identify and apprehend perpetrators of violence. It will also work closely with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to gather information about violent anti-government extremist individuals, networks, and movements, and share that information with federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies.

In his memo, Barr noted that some extremist groups have targeted police officers and government officials, destroyed public and private property, and threatened innocent bystanders. He emphasized that these groups seek to deny constitutional rights to others and resort to illegal methods.

The announcement comes amid ongoing protests and demonstrations across the country, sparked by the death of George Floyd, who died in police custody on May 25. While most protests have been peaceful, some have turned violent, with reports of looting, arson, and property damage.

The task force will focus on identifying and prosecuting individuals who engage in violent acts, as well as preventing extremist violence before it happens. Barr emphasized that the initiative is not aimed at suppressing peaceful protests or restricting constitutional rights, but rather at addressing the violent actions of a small minority.

The announcement was made on the same day that President Donald Trump signed an executive order protecting American monuments, memorials, and statues from destruction. The order aims to combat recent criminal violence and impose long prison sentences for those who engage in such acts.

The DOJ's new task force is part of a broader effort to address the growing threat of violent extremism and maintain public safety.

Title: Rick Perry Suspends Presidential Campaign, Ending Bid for GOP Nomination

Article:

Former Texas Governor Rick Perry announced on Friday that he is suspending his campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, citing his inability to gain traction in a crowded and experienced field. Perry, who served 14 years as governor of Texas, had struggled to raise money and gain momentum throughout his campaign.

In a speech to the Eagle Forum in St. Louis, Perry acknowledged that his political future had become clear to him, stating, "That is why today I am suspending my campaign for the presidency of the United States. We have a tremendous field of candidates - probably the greatest group of men and women. I step aside knowing our party is in good hands, as long as we listen to the grassroots, listen to that cause of conservatism. If we do that, then our party will be in good hands."

Perry's decision comes less than a week before he was set to join the rest of the field for the second debate of the primary season. This marks the second time Perry has suspended his presidential campaign, after his 2012 bid was considered one of the biggest campaign failures in modern political history.

Despite his efforts to learn from his mistakes and improve his fundraising abilities, Perry never found a niche in the crowded field of candidates. Last week, reports emerged that he had stopped paying staffers, and some of his team had defected to other campaigns.

Michael Dennehy, a Perry supporter and strategist in New Hampshire, expressed disappointment but acknowledged the decision, stating, "I fully support his decision. Campaigns are unpredictable, but it is a shame that a man with the most successful executive experience and the one who can best relate to middle-class America will not be on the ballot as we choose the Republican nominee."

Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union, noted that Perry struggled to rebound after being relegated to the second tier in the first presidential debate and would likely face similar challenges in the second debate. "I knew that his demotion in Cleveland was punishing for him," Schlapp said. "It was really a body blow. He put a good face on it because he has class, but that was brutal for him."

Perry's departure leaves just four candidates in the second-tier debate: Former Sen. Rick Santorum, former New York Gov. George Pataki, Sen. Lindsey Graham, and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal. The main stage remains occupied by 11 candidates, including businessman Donald Trump, retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina, and several governors and senators.

In his prepared remarks, Perry expressed gratitude for his supporters and his family, stating, "As I approach the next chapter in life, I do so with the love of my life by my side, Anita Perry. We have our house in the country, we have two beautiful children and two adorable grandchildren, four dogs, and the best sunset from our front porch that you could ever imagine."

Title: Trump's Pro-Israel Advisors Defend Stephen Bannon Against Anti-Semitic Accusations

Article:

The appointment of Stephen Bannon as chief strategist to the incoming Trump administration has sparked controversy, with some accusing him of being an anti-Semite and Israel-hater. However, several prominent pro-Israel figures have come to his defense, citing his record of supporting Israel and fighting against anti-Semitism.

The Zionist Organization of America (ZOA) has released a statement defending Bannon and his media company, Breitbart News, against accusations of anti-Semitism. ZOA President Morton Klein stated that Bannon is "an American patriot who defends Israel and has deep empathy for the Jewish people."

Klein also pointed out that Breitbart News has a track record of fighting against anti-Semitism and promoting pro-Israel views. The article highlights several examples of Breitbart's pro-Israel reporting, including its coverage of the Palestinian Authority's defamatory claims against Israel and its reporting on the rise of anti-Semitic incidents on US college campuses.

Other pro-Israel figures, such as Newt Gingrich, Rudy Giuliani, Mike Pence, Mike Huckabee, Sheldon Adelson, and Orthodox Jews Jared Kushner, David Friedman, and Jason Greenblatt, have also come to Bannon's defense. Ivanka Trump, the president-elect's daughter, has also been mentioned as someone who would not allow an anti-Semite to work with her father.

The article also questions why the Anti-Defamation League (ADL) and other critics of Bannon did not raise similar concerns about Hillary Clinton's advisors, who included some individuals with a history of anti-Israel views. The article notes that George Soros, a major donor to Hillary Clinton, has been a vocal critic of Israel.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced view of the controversy surrounding Stephen Bannon's appointment, highlighting the complexity of the issue and the need for a balanced approach to understanding the complex relationships between politics, religion, and identity.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Directs Prosecutors to Pursue Most Serious Charges, Reversing Obama-Era Policies

Article:

In a significant shift in criminal justice policy, Attorney General Jeff Sessions has directed federal prosecutors to pursue the most serious charges possible against the vast majority of suspects, a move that is likely to send more people to prison for longer terms. This decision marks a reversal of Obama-era policies aimed at easing overcrowding in federal prisons and rethinking how drug criminals are prosecuted and sentenced.

The new policy, outlined in a memo sent to US attorneys and made public on Friday, instructs prosecutors to "charge and pursue the most serious, readily provable offense," which is more likely to trigger mandatory minimum sentences. These rules limit a judge's discretion and are typically dictated by the quantity of drugs involved in a crime.

While the memo acknowledges that there may be cases where "good judgment" warrants a prosecutor to deviate from this rule, any exceptions will require approval from top supervisors and must be documented, allowing the Justice Department to track the handling of such cases by its 94 US attorney's offices.

The directive rescinds guidance from Sessions' Democratic predecessor, Eric Holder, who told prosecutors they could, in some cases, leave drug quantities out of charging documents to avoid triggering long sentences. Holder's 2013 initiative, known as Smart on Crime, aimed to encourage shorter sentences for nonviolent drug offenders and preserve Justice Department resources for more serious and violent criminals.

The Obama administration's policy shift coincided with changes to the US Sentencing Commission that made tens of thousands of federal drug prisoners eligible for early release, and an Obama administration clemency initiative that freed convicts deemed deserving of a second chance. As a result, the federal prison population declined from nearly 220,000 in 2013 to just under 190,000 today, with nearly half of those inmates incarcerated for drug crimes.

Advocates for the previous policy argue that the change will revive the worst aspects of the drug war and fill prisons back up, while critics say it will subject more lower-level offenders to unfairly harsh mandatory minimum sentences. The move is likely to be met with controversy and debate in the coming weeks and months.

**NSA Headquarters Confrontation: Details Emerge on Incident**

A dramatic incident unfolded at the National Security Agency (NSA) headquarters in Ft. Meade, Maryland, on Monday morning, with a vehicle attempting to ram the security gates and prompting a confrontation with security forces. The incident resulted in shots being fired, with at least one uniformed guard injured and taken to an ambulance.

According to eyewitness accounts and reports from various news outlets, the vehicle, which was stolen from a hotel, collided with a police car and another vehicle at the security gates. Debris was scattered across the intersection, and a white cloth covered something beside the black vehicle.

The NSA police force responded to the incident, with local agencies providing support. The FBI has taken over the investigation from the NSA's security force, with no links to organized terrorism established.

Two people were injured during the incident, with one fatality reported. The gender of the individuals involved is disputed, with some reports suggesting two men were in the vehicle, while others claim two women were involved. Authorities found cocaine and a weapon in the car.

The incident is not the first recent report of trouble at the NSA headquarters. Earlier this month, the FBI arrested a man for firing shots at the building as part of a shooting spree that lasted several weeks.

The investigation is ongoing, with the FBI working to determine the motives behind the attempted ramming and the identities of the individuals involved.

**US Photojournalist Luke Somers Killed in Yemen During Failed Rescue Attempt**

A US photojournalist, Luke Somers, was killed during a failed rescue attempt in Yemen, confirmed Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Saturday. Somers had been held by al-Qaeda militants since his abduction in Yemen's capital of Sanaa in September 2013.

Hagel described Somers' death as "murder at the hands of terrorists" and stated that there were compelling reasons to believe his life was in imminent danger. The US and Yemeni special forces conducted a rescue operation, but it was unsuccessful.

During the operation, US commandos dropped in by helicopter and killed all the al-Qaeda-linked terrorists. No US forces were wounded, according to a senior Defense Department official. The operation was authorized by President Obama due to information that Somers' life was in immediate danger, including a video released by his captors announcing his impending execution.

A second hostage, South African Pierre Korkie, a teacher abducted in Yemen in May 2013 with his wife, was also killed during the failed raid. Korkie's wife, Yolande, had previously been released by al-Qaeda militants.

Those who knew Somers remembered him as a curious and adventurous person who was drawn to new experiences. "He really wanted to understand the world," said Shawn Gillen, an English professor and chairman of Beloit College's journalism program.

The US officials believe the militants shot the two men during a firefight, and that both were alive when American forces pulled them from a building on the group's compound and got them aboard aircraft, where medical teams operated on them during a short flight to the USS Makin Island, a Navy ship in the region.

The psychological and emotional devastation to Yolande and her family will be compounded by the knowledge that Pierre was to be released by al-Qaeda, according to Gift of Givers, the aid group that negotiated his wife's freedom.

The incident highlights the risks and challenges faced by journalists and aid workers operating in conflict zones.

**Tragedy Strikes Mormon Community in Northern Mexico: Nine Killed in Apparent Drug Cartel Attack**

A devastating attack on a Mormon community in northern Mexico has left nine people dead, including three women and six children. The incident occurred on Monday in the border state of Sonora, an area known for its high levels of organized crime activity.

According to reports, the victims were members of a farming community of dual U.S.-Mexican citizens who had settled in the area nearly a century ago to practice polygamy. The community had been established after a dispute with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints over the practice.

The attack is believed to have occurred when the victims' vehicle stopped due to a flat tire, and assailants opened fire, killing the driver and four children, including 6-month-old twins. The attackers then set the vehicle on fire. Two other cars were attacked nearby, resulting in the deaths of two women and two children.

A member of the family described the scene as chaotic, with a child being gunned down while running away. At least eight survivors, including as many as seven children, are believed to have escaped, with some suffering serious injuries. A 9-month-old was shot in the chest, and a 4-year-old was shot in the back. One 13-year-old reportedly walked 14 miles to the family's home to get help after hiding his wounded siblings in the brush.

The incident has sparked outrage and condolences from around the world, including from U.S. President Donald Trump, who offered his support to the Mexican government in its efforts to combat organized crime. "If Mexico needs or requests help in cleaning out these monsters, the United States stands ready, willing & able to get involved and do the job quickly and effectively," Trump tweeted.

The attack highlights the ongoing challenges faced by the Mexican government in combating organized crime and drug cartels, which have been a major concern for the country for years. The incident serves as a stark reminder of the risks and dangers faced by those living in the region.

Title: Billy Graham's Legacy Lives On: A Life of Evangelism and Devotion

Article:

Billy Graham, the renowned evangelist, has left an indelible mark on the world, spreading the gospel of Christ to millions through his tireless efforts and unwavering dedication. His passing has sent shockwaves of grief and gratitude across the globe, as people from all walks of life pay tribute to his remarkable life and legacy.

Graham's remarkable journey began with his altar call at a crusade in Baton Rouge in 1970, where he inspired countless individuals to find their faith. His eloquence and sincerity earned him the respect and admiration of people from all backgrounds, including Protestants, Catholics, Muslims, and Jews. His crusades, which drew millions of attendees, were a testament to his ability to connect with people from all walks of life.

Graham's impact extended far beyond his crusades, as he used every available medium to spread his message. He was a pioneer in using television and radio to reach a wider audience, making him one of the most prominent religious figures of the 20th century. His influence was not limited to his own generation, as he inspired a new generation of evangelists and pastors.

Those who had the privilege of attending his final public events shared their personal experiences, highlighting his unwavering commitment to his faith. Craig Allen, who attended his last major sermon in Baltimore in 2006, recalled Graham's perseverance despite his declining health, saying, "He was going to give it his all, no matter how he felt." Michael Freeland, who attended a crusade in New Orleans in 2006, remembered Graham's frailty but his passion and energy when he preached, saying, "That was the Holy Spirit. That was him doing something he was passionate about."

Maggie Rousseau, who drove 14 hours from Savannah, Georgia, to see Graham for the first time in New York City in 2005, said, "There was just something about him. I don't know what it was, but you believed him." Her husband, Bill, added, "He spoke, and you listened."

While some may argue that Graham's impact has diminished over time, his legacy continues to inspire and motivate new generations. As Robert, a Boston University religion professor, noted, "He lived a good life, and he can say, as Paul did in his letter to Timothy, 'I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.' For him, death is not the end."

In conclusion, Billy Graham's life and legacy serve as a testament to the power of faith, perseverance, and devotion. His tireless efforts to spread the gospel of Christ have left an indelible mark on the world, and his influence will continue to inspire and motivate generations to come.

Title: The Pandemic's Double-edged Sword: Balancing Lives and Livelihoods

Article:

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought the world to a standstill, claiming over 75,000 lives in the United States and over 270,000 globally. The economic toll has been severe, with the Congressional Budget Office predicting a decline in the US Gross Domestic Product and millions of jobs lost. The choice seems stark: continue strict social distancing measures to minimize the spread of the virus and save lives, or reopen the economy and risk a second wave of infections.

President Trump has emphasized the need to reopen the country, acknowledging that some people will be affected. However, experts argue that the point of social distancing was to "flatten the curve" and slow the spread of the virus, allowing governments to take public health measures to keep people safe. Unfortunately, this approach has not been taken, and the lockdown has not been lifted.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has posed a poignant question: "How much is a human life worth?" He emphasizes that the cost of a human life is priceless, and that sacrifices must be made for the common good. The federal government has largely abandoned its own standards for lifting shelter-in-place orders, and 31 states have decided to reopen, despite concerns from experts that this will lead to an increase in cases.

The impact on the economy is uncertain, and it's unclear what people will contribute to the economy even if states end official restrictions. With incomplete and sometimes contradictory information about the virus and its effects, it's difficult to predict what the future holds.

The question remains: how much is a human life worth? As a society, we have historically been willing to incur costs to save lives and improve public welfare. However, there are limits to this tradeoff. Few people suggest deactivating the country's financial engines to fight opioid addiction deaths or flu or heart disease or traffic accidents. Why do it for this one very bad respiratory virus?

The decision to reopen the economy or continue social distancing measures is a difficult one, and the answer is not clear-cut. As the pandemic continues to unfold, it's essential to weigh the costs and benefits of each approach and consider the long-term consequences of our choices.

Title: Trump Weighs In on Immigration Policy, Suggests Softening Stance

Article:

In a recent town hall with Sean Hannity, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump reiterated his stance on illegal immigration, stating that there will be "no amnesty" for those who have entered the country illegally. However, he also expressed a willingness to work with these individuals, suggesting a possible softening of his previous stance.

Trump's comments come as he prepares to unveil his new immigration policy next week in Phoenix, Arizona. During the town hall, he emphasized the need to prioritize deporting "bad" immigrants, while also acknowledging the difficulty of deporting those who have lived in the country for decades and have established families.

"I've had very strong people come up to me, really great people, and they've said, 'Mr. Trump, I love you, but to take a person who's been here for 15 or 20 years and throw them and their family out, it's so tough, Mr. Trump,'" Trump said.

Trump also took aim at sanctuary cities, which he believes are "protecting criminals" and making it difficult for police to do their jobs. "We've got to get rid of the sanctuary cities, we're protecting these people. We're protecting criminals," he said.

While Trump's comments may suggest a more nuanced approach to immigration, it remains to be seen how his new policy will address the complex issue. His speech in Phoenix is expected to provide more insight into his plans, which could potentially include a compromise on deportation and a more targeted approach to addressing illegal immigration.

**Pennsylvania and Beyond: Primary Elections Set to Shape Congressional Landscape**

Tuesday's primary elections in Pennsylvania and other key states will determine the fate of congressional seats and governorships, with several notable contests on the horizon. In Pennsylvania, voters will decide the Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate, while Idaho will choose its Republican gubernatorial candidate. Nebraska and Oregon will also hold primaries, with the latter featuring a crowded field of 10 Republicans vying for the governorship.

In Pennsylvania, the primary will settle the chaotic congressional landscape, with 84 candidates running in 18 House districts following a court-ordered redistricting. The state's Republican-dominated House delegation is up for grabs, with five GOP members not seeking re-election or retiring. The 7th District, which Hillary Clinton won in 2016, has six Democratic candidates vying for the nomination. The 5th District, where Rep. Patrick Meehan resigned amid allegations of sexual harassment, has 10 Democratic candidates.

In the Republican Senate primary, Rep. Lou Barletta is heavily favored to become the party's challenger against Democratic Sen. Bob Casey, who is seeking a third term. Barletta has the backing of President Donald Trump, who recorded a phone call urging GOP voters to support him "fully, strongly, and proudly."

In Nebraska, the Democratic primary in the 2nd Congressional District features a moderate former Rep. Brad Ashford fighting for his old seat and Kara Eastman, a children's nonprofit administrator, running to his left. Ashford, a former Republican, served one term in Congress before losing to Republican Don Bacon in 2016. Eastman is campaigning on devoutly Democratic themes such as single-payer healthcare, gun control, and reducing climate change.

In Idaho, the Republican primary for governor features Lt. Gov. Brad Little, who has the endorsement of outgoing Gov. C.L. "Butch" Otter, and Tommy Ahlquist, an emergency room doctor turned developer. The state is heavily Republican, making the primary a crucial step in determining the general election outcome.

Oregon's Republican primary for governor has 10 candidates vying for the nomination, with businessman Sam Carpenter, state Rep. Knute Buehler, and retired Navy pilot Greg Wooldridge emerging as leaders in fundraising and GOP straw polls. However, Democratic Gov. Kate Brown remains the favorite to win in November, having won a special election in 2016 and becoming governor in 2015 following the resignation of Gov. John Kitzhaber amid an ethics scandal.

These primary elections will shape the political landscape in key states, with implications for the November elections and the balance of power in Congress.

Title: August Jobs Report: US Employers Add 130,000 Jobs, Missing Expectations Amid Global Uncertainty

The US labor market added 130,000 jobs in August, falling short of Wall Street's expectations of 158,000 new jobs. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.7%, near a 50-year low, while the labor force participation rate remained unchanged at 63.2%. Average hourly earnings rose 3.2% over the past year to $28.11, slightly higher than projections.

The jobs report comes amid concerns about the slowing global economy and the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China. The industries most affected by the trade war, such as manufacturing and retail, reported losses. However, other sectors like healthcare and finance showed notable gains, with 24,000 and 15,000 new jobs added, respectively.

The Federal Reserve is likely to take note of the jobs report as it considers interest rate decisions. The report may give the Fed justification to lower short-term interest rates by a modest 25 basis points when policymakers meet in mid-September.

The jobs report also highlights the ongoing debate about the state of the US economy. Some experts believe that the current economic expansion, which has reached a record length, may be slowing down and could be followed by a recession within two years. Others argue that the US consumer is resilient and will continue to drive the economy forward.

In a statement, Tony Bedikian, managing director at Citizens Bank, noted that the on-again, off-again US-China trade talks are providing more theater than substance, and that the US consumer is tuning them out and keeping spending. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is set to discuss the economic outlook in a speech later this week in Zurich.

Overall, the August jobs report provides a mixed picture of the US labor market, with some sectors showing growth and others struggling. As the economy continues to navigate the challenges of global uncertainty and trade tensions, the jobs report will be closely watched for signs of a slowdown or a continued expansion.

**California Issues Stay-at-Home Order to Combat Growing Coronavirus Epidemic**

California Governor Gavin Newsom has issued a stay-at-home order for the state's 40 million residents, effective immediately, in an effort to combat the growing novel coronavirus epidemic. The directive, which is the widest-ranging of any state so far, requires people to remain in their homes except for essential travel.

The order, announced late Thursday, follows similar restrictions issued earlier this week for the San Francisco Bay Area. Governor Newsom emphasized that the directive is necessary to protect the state's residents, saying, "We're confident that the people of the state of California will abide by it, will do the right thing."

The order includes exemptions for essential travel, such as trips to grocery stores, gas stations, farmers markets, food banks, convenience stores, takeout and delivery restaurants, banks, and laundromats. Critical infrastructure, including food and agriculture, healthcare, transportation, energy, and financial services, are also exempt.

California is one of the hardest-hit states, with over 1,000 confirmed cases of the virus and 19 deaths. The state's official projection estimates that up to 56% of residents could become infected, which would equate to over 22 million people. However, Governor Newsom emphasized that the stay-at-home order aims to make those numbers "moot."

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that the total number of cases in the U.S. has surpassed 10,000, although officials believe the actual number of infections is likely higher due to a lack of test kits. Globally, the number of reported cases has reached nearly 250,000, with over 10,000 deaths.

The stay-at-home order is a significant step in California's efforts to combat the spread of the virus, and it remains to be seen how effective it will be in reducing the number of cases and preventing further spread.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Complex Legacy on National Security

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder's tenure has been marked by a mix of successes and controversies in the fight against terrorism. Holder, who announced his resignation last week, took office in 2009 with a promise to distance the Justice Department from the harsh interrogation techniques used during the Bush administration. However, his efforts to prosecute the mastermind of the 9/11 attacks and other alleged co-conspirators in a New York courtroom were met with political opposition and public safety concerns, ultimately leading to the Obama administration's decision to abandon the plan.

Despite this setback, Holder's Justice Department has won numerous convictions in terrorism cases, including the prosecution of plots to explode a bomb in Times Square and on a Detroit-bound airliner. However, his legacy on national security has been marked by criticism from both sides of the political spectrum.

Some have praised Holder's efforts to bring suspected terrorists to trial in civilian courts, citing the successful prosecution of Osama bin Laden's son-in-law as an example. Others have criticized his decision to authorize targeted drone strikes against Americans abroad and his defense of the government's bulk collection of millions of Americans' telephone records.

Holder's successor will face many of the same policy questions, including how to close the Guantanamo Bay detention facility and what to do with the remaining detainees. The new attorney general will also have to navigate the complex issues surrounding the prosecution of suspected terrorists and the balance between national security and civil liberties.

In conclusion, Eric Holder's legacy on national security is complex and multifaceted, marked by both successes and controversies. While some have praised his efforts to bring suspected terrorists to trial, others have criticized his decisions on drone strikes and surveillance. Ultimately, the public's perspective on Holder's record may be different from his own, as many of the details of his decisions remain classified.

**Title:** US Deports Iraqi Christians Amidst Ongoing Concerns Over Safety and Persecution

**Article:**

The Trump administration has been deporting hundreds of Iraqi Christians, citing concerns over their safety and potential persecution in their homeland. However, experts and human rights advocates have raised questions about the accuracy of these claims, highlighting the complexities of the situation in Iraq.

According to a senior Trump appointee at the US Agency for International Development (USAID), militias aligned with Iran have been terrorizing and extorting Christian families in northern Iraq, with only 1-2% of Christians returning to the region due to persecution. This assessment was submitted to a government commission and has been used in court proceedings to support deportation efforts.

On the other hand, a Middle East expert, Michael Rubin, has argued that Iraq is a more stable country with an increasingly professional government, and that Iraqi Christians are "largely immune" from political violence. Rubin's declaration was submitted to courts as part of the deportation process.

The assessments by Rubin and other experts have significant consequences, as the administration has sought to deport hundreds of Iraqis, many of whom are Christians, who immigrated to the US years ago. To stay in the US, many of the Iraqis have to prove that if they are deported, they are most likely to be tortured by, or with the tacit permission of, the Iraqi government.

While the Iraqi government has defeated the Islamic State and won back control of its territory, religious and ethnic minorities have little faith that the government can protect them against active, semi-official armed groups. Experts warn that Iraq is in a situation of "terminal collapse," with the continued presence of extremists and an unreliable central government.

Lawyers for the deportees have also filed declarations from human rights experts arguing that the deportees would be at risk of detention and abuse. The Trump administration has highlighted the dangers faced by Christians to support its decision to allocate hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid for them and other religious minorities in Iraq and Syria.

The cause is especially popular with Trump's conservative Christian base, which he is seeking to solidify ahead of the 2020 presidential election. Vice President Mike Pence has made this issue a priority, with his aides pressuring USAID to direct more funds to religious minorities in Iraq, including Christians.

The complexities of the situation in Iraq highlight the need for a nuanced understanding of the issues involved. While some experts argue that Iraq is a more stable country, others warn of ongoing persecution and violence against religious and ethnic minorities. As the US continues to deport Iraqi Christians, it is essential to consider the competing perspectives and ensure that any decisions are based on accurate information and a commitment to protecting human rights.

Title: Virginia Election Results Show Anti-Immigrant Strategy Backfires, Voters Reject Bigotry

Article:

The recent election in Virginia has sent a clear message: anti-immigrant rhetoric is a losing strategy. Despite predictions that Ed Gillespie's anti-immigrant ads would pay off, the results showed that voters from all racial and ethnic backgrounds rejected his divisive approach.

According to a pre-election survey by Latino Decisions, Latino voters were less enthusiastic about Gillespie after seeing his MS-13 ads, with a 45-point margin against him. But it wasn't just Latino voters who turned away from Gillespie. Whites, African-Americans, and Asian-Americans also rejected his anti-immigrant stance by significant margins.

Data analysis revealed that exposure to Gillespie's MS-13 ads actually drove white college-educated voters away from the Republican candidate. In fact, voters who were aware of the ads were more likely to vote for Gillespie's Democratic opponent. This trend was not limited to the governor's race; the Gillespie campaign had coattail effects, but of the wrong kind. Across all racial groups, those who were aware of Gillespie's anti-immigrant ads were more likely to vote for Democratic candidates in the Virginia House of Delegates.

The results suggest that Democrats have a winning strategy by positioning themselves as the party that stands against hatred and bigotry and in favor of inclusiveness and opportunity. This approach not only resonates with Latino, African-American, and Asian-American voters but also wins over enough white voters who oppose immigrant bashing.

The implications are significant, particularly for the 2018 midterm elections. Voters of color and white college-educated voters, often referred to as the Democratic base, will decide crucial House and Senate races. The results in Virginia show that anti-immigrant rhetoric is a losing strategy, and Democrats have an opportunity to capitalize on this trend. By speaking out strongly against bigotry, Democrats can win over voters and secure victories in the 2018 elections and beyond.

Title: Trump Calls for "Red Wave" to Pass Immigration Bill, Accuses Democrats of Obstruction

Article:

President Donald Trump took to Twitter on Friday to express his frustration with the lack of progress on an immigration bill in Congress, calling for a "red wave" to pass the legislation. Trump accused Democrats of "doing nothing but obstructing" and urged Republicans to wait until after the midterm elections to tackle the issue.

The president's tweet came after House Republicans abruptly pulled a major immigration bill from consideration on Thursday, pushing a vote into next week. The bill, which was seen as a compromise between moderate and conservative factions, would have provided a pathway to citizenship for 1.8 million young illegal immigrants, as well as funding for a border wall.

However, the bill faced opposition from some Republicans who felt it did not go far enough in addressing their concerns about border security and chain migration. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., called the bill a "non-starter" and said it was not a compromise with Democrats.

Trump's comments on Twitter were met with criticism from Democrats, who accused him of playing politics and refusing to work with them to find a solution to the decades-old problem. "It takes two to tango," Trump said, extending an invitation to Democrats to come to the White House to discuss immigration. However, he also had scathing words for what he called the "extremist, open border" lawmakers.
