The president's tweets also touched on the recent controversy surrounding the administration's "zero tolerance" policy, which has led to the separation of children from their parents at the border. Trump signed an executive order on Wednesday ending the practice, but Democrats have pushed for ending what they described as "indefinite detention" of families at the border.

The debate over immigration reform is likely to continue in the coming weeks, with both sides dug in and refusing to budge.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's Comments on Palestinian Statehood: A Misunderstood Reality

Article:

In recent days, the Western media has been abuzz with a false story claiming that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has ruled out the possibility of a Palestinian state. The report, published by Ha'aretz, a left-wing Israeli newspaper, stated that Netanyahu had said he would not endorse a Palestinian state under any circumstances. However, a closer examination of the actual comments made by Netanyahu reveals a more nuanced and context-dependent stance.

The interview in question took place with the conservative Israeli publication NRG, in which Netanyahu was asked about his previous support for a Palestinian state, expressed in a 2009 speech at Bar Ilan University. Netanyahu clarified that his comments were not a rejection of the idea of a Palestinian state, but rather a warning about the potential consequences of creating such a state in the current political climate.

According to Netanyahu, building a Palestinian state today would create a "free space" for radical Islam to attack Israel. He emphasized that this reality has been created in recent years and that anyone ignoring it is "burying their head in the sand." Netanyahu also noted that the left-wing government would likely join international efforts to divide Jerusalem and return to the 1967 borders.

In other words, Netanyahu did not dismiss the possibility of a Palestinian state, but rather highlighted the risks and challenges associated with creating such a state in the current political environment. This nuanced stance was lost in translation, as the media quickly picked up on the sensational headline and ran with it.

It is worth noting that Netanyahu's policy aligns with that of the late Israeli Prime Minister Yitzchak Rabin, who in 1995 stated that a permanent solution would involve a Palestinian entity "less than a state" and emphasized the importance of a united Jerusalem under Israeli sovereignty.

In conclusion, the media's misinterpretation of Netanyahu's comments has led to a misunderstanding of his stance on Palestinian statehood. A closer examination of the actual comments reveals a more complex and context-dependent view, highlighting the challenges and risks associated with creating a Palestinian state in the current political climate.

Title: Cruz and Trump Engage in Heated Exchange Over Abortion Ad

Article:

In a heated exchange, Senator Ted Cruz and businessman Donald Trump are locked in a bitter feud over an ad running in South Carolina that questions Trump's record on abortion. The ad, which features footage of Trump in a 1999 interview saying he is "very pro-choice," has sparked a strong reaction from Trump, who has threatened to sue Cruz over the ad.

Cruz, however, is standing firm, vowing to run the ad "more frequently" and accusing Trump of being "frivolous" in his threats. "You have been threatening frivolous lawsuits for your entire adult life," Cruz said at a press conference in South Carolina. "Even in the annals of frivolous lawsuits, this takes the cake."

The ad in question is part of a larger debate over Trump's stance on abortion, with Cruz's campaign arguing that voters have a right to know the truth about Trump's views on the issue. Trump, on the other hand, has denied being "pro-choice" and has called Cruz a liar.

The feud has escalated since Trump sent a cease-and-desist letter to Cruz's campaign, demanding that the ad be taken down. Cruz has refused, and the two have traded barbs in the media. Trump has called Cruz a liar, while Cruz has ridiculed Trump's lawsuit threats.

The ad is just the latest development in a contentious primary season, with Cruz and Trump vying for the Republican nomination. The two have also clashed over issues such as immigration and foreign policy, and their feud has only intensified in recent days.

In a statement, Trump's campaign said the ad was "replete with outright lies, false, defamatory and destructive statements" and that Cruz could be held liable for damages if it's not taken down. Cruz's campaign, on the other hand, called the threats "laughable" and said that voters have a right to know the truth about Trump's views on abortion.

The feud has also spilled over into other areas, with Cruz denying allegations of dirty tricks from his campaign and calling on anyone with evidence to come forward. Rubio, another Republican candidate, has also been involved in the controversy, accusing Cruz's team of being behind a fake Facebook page that wrongly claimed he had switched his endorsement from Cruz to another candidate.

As the primary season continues, the feud between Cruz and Trump is likely to remain a major storyline, with both candidates vying for the support of Republican voters.

Title: New Allegations Emerge About Trump's Involvement in Cohen's False Testimony

Article:

New reports have surfaced suggesting that President Trump directed his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, to lie about the Trump Tower project in Moscow. According to BuzzFeed, Cohen pleaded guilty in November to lying about the deal in testimony and a two-page statement to the Senate and House intelligence committees. Special counsel Robert Mueller noted that Cohen's false claim that the project ended in January 2016 was an attempt to "minimize links between the Moscow Project and Individual 1" - widely understood to be Trump - "in hopes of limiting the ongoing Russia investigations."

The allegations have sparked a heated debate among lawmakers, with some calling for an immediate congressional investigation into the matter. Representative David Cicilline (D-RI) and Representative Ted Lieu (D-CA) have concluded that the report proves Trump is guilty of obstruction of justice, with Cicilline stating that "if the President directed Cohen to lie to Congress, that is obstruction of justice. Period. Full stop."

While the report has yet to be confirmed or corroborated, one of the authors of the BuzzFeed report, Anthony Cormier, stood by his reporting on CNN, calling it "100 percent" true. The report has also sparked calls for further investigation, with Cicilline stating that the House Judiciary Committee should start holding hearings to establish a record of whether Trump committed high crimes.

However, when asked by CNN's John Berman if he has evidence to prove Trump told Cohen to lie, Cicilline admitted that he has not seen the evidence referenced in the article. Despite this, Cicilline emphasized the importance of investigating the matter further, stating that "we have to wait for the reports to be confirmed before we can call on that... You have one opportunity to move forward on something so serious."

The allegations have significant implications for Trump's presidency, with some calling it the "most serious threat" to his presidency. The controversy has sparked a heated debate among lawmakers and the public, with many calling for further investigation and accountability.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Stresses Need for Compromise on Debt Ceiling and Government Funding

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner reiterated on Sunday that the Republican-led House will not agree to raise the nation's debt ceiling without conditions to rein in deficit spending. In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Boehner emphasized that the government shutdown, now in its sixth day, is a result of the need for a comprehensive solution to address the country's fiscal issues.

Boehner stressed that the Republican Party will not support a "clean" debt ceiling increase, which would not include any conditions to address the underlying problems. He believes that raising the debt limit without addressing the nation's fiscal issues is unacceptable.

The House Speaker also reiterated that Republicans will not back down on their demand for changes to President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, known as Obamacare, as a condition for passing a bill to reopen the government. The Democratic-led Senate has rejected this demand, and Obama has stated that it is the responsibility of Congress to raise the debt limit by the October 17 deadline.

Boehner acknowledged that there are not enough votes in the House to pass a "clean" continuing resolution on the budget to reopen the government. He also dismissed the idea of a group of 195 House Democrats and 21 Republicans who have expressed support for a six-week "clean CR" without defunding Obamacare, stating that there is no one in the "back room" willing to compromise.

The House Speaker emphasized the need for a conversation between the two parties to address the nation's fiscal issues, stating that President Obama knows his phone number and can call him anytime. However, he also acknowledged that his party has tried to pass several bills that would fund parts of the government while talks continue, but these efforts have been rejected by Democrats.

Overall, Boehner's comments highlight the ongoing impasse between the two parties over the government shutdown and the debt ceiling, and the need for a comprehensive solution to address the nation's fiscal issues.

Title: US Air Campaign Against Islamic State Faces Criticism for Limited Impact

Article:

The US-led air campaign against the Islamic State (IS) and the Khorasan Group has faced criticism for its limited effectiveness, with some experts questioning the strategy and tactics employed. The latest example of this criticism came in the form of a recent airstrike in Syria, which destroyed the Islamic State's rooftop communications array but left the building intact.

The limited impact of the airstrikes is further compounded by the Iraqi security forces' mixed results in combat and their inability to reverse most gains made by the Islamic State. Additionally, Iraqi troops lack the key skill of finding and designating ground targets for US warplanes, making the American air campaign more difficult.

Retired CIA operative Bart Bechtel expressed frustration with the limited scope of the airstrikes, saying, "I was mad as hell when I saw the hit on a supposed ISIL building. The right question is: Why not the whole building?" He believes the strikes are designed to show the American public that President Obama is taking action against the Islamic State, rather than actually targeting the terrorist group.

A retired Air Force general who has remained in touch with the jet fighter community also criticized the air war, saying it is too narrow and lacks sufficient planes, heavy ordnance, and sorties. The general suggested that the US should use more powerful weapons, such as 2,000-pound bombs, to target the Islamic State's command centers.

The Pentagon has defended the air campaign, citing the destruction of the Islamic State's communications array as a significant blow to the group. However, critics argue that the strikes are not enough to degrade the Islamic State's capabilities and that more aggressive action is needed.

The air war has also been criticized for its lack of boots on the ground, with some experts arguing that the absence of US combat troops makes it difficult to effectively target the Islamic State's command centers and leadership. The Iraqi army has shown itself unable or unwilling to stand up to the Islamic State, and the country's special operations forces lack the necessary equipment and experience to spot targets for US warplanes.

The Pentagon has acknowledged that the air campaign could go on for years, and some experts believe that a more intensive and sustained effort is needed to defeat the Islamic State. Until then, the air campaign will continue to face criticism for its limited impact and lack of progress against the terrorist group.

Title: Trump Considers Restricting Domestic Flights to Combat Coronavirus Spread

Article:

In an effort to curb the spread of the coronavirus, President Donald Trump has announced that his administration is considering restricting domestic flights in the United States. This move comes as some governors have already taken action to limit travel within their states. For instance, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has ordered anyone flying to Florida from New York, New Jersey, or Connecticut to self-isolate for 14 days, while Alaska and Hawaii have implemented similar measures.

Trump emphasized that while restricting flights could help slow the spread of the virus, he is aware of the potential hardship it would impose on the airline industry. "Once you do that, you are clamping down on an industry that is desperately needed," he said during his daily briefing on the crisis.

However, airlines, industry officials, and health experts argue that flights are an essential service, providing transportation for people and cargo, and should continue during the crisis. The federal government has underscored this position by including a provision in the $2 trillion coronavirus aid package that requires airlines to maintain a minimum level of service through at least September.

Despite the concerns, Trump has not ruled out the possibility of restricting flights entirely. "We are going to be – hopefully before we close things – we're going to start to open things," he said on Fox & Friends. "Airports, when you close them and reopen them, it's a tremendous deal. It's a tremendous deal. In addition, you need them for emergencies, you have emergency flights."

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) would be responsible for implementing any restrictions or shutdowns, but has declined to comment on rumors. Airlines have already reduced their flight schedules in response to plummeting passenger demand, and Trump has imposed travel restrictions on foreign nationals from China and most of Europe, as well as non-essential travel from Mexico and Canada.

While some states have taken action to limit travel, Trump believes a national stay-at-home order is not necessary, citing the Midwest and Alaska as examples where the virus has not been as prevalent. "You have to give a little bit of flexibility," he said.

Title: Healthcare.gov Website Concerns: High Insurance Plan Prices and Limited Choices Ahead

The Obama administration is bracing for another wave of criticism as the healthcare.gov website is expected to face scrutiny over high insurance plan prices and limited choices. According to internal War Room notes obtained by CNN, project managers are concerned that once individuals begin selecting plans on the improved website, media attention will focus on their choices and, in some cases, there may be fewer options than desired to promote consumer choice and an ideal shopping experience.

The notes also highlighted the issue of relatively high-cost plans, which may be a concern for those seeking affordable healthcare options. This comes as a Manhattan Institute analysis revealed that Obamacare will increase underlying premiums by 41% on average in most states. Prior to the law's online healthcare markets launching on October 1, the administration estimated nearly 500,000 people would enroll in subsidized private insurance within the first month.

However, the website's technical issues have hindered enrollment, with at least 3.5 million Americans receiving cancellation notices from their private carriers due to coverage not meeting the standards set by the Affordable Care Act. The exact number is unclear, as data from half the states is still unavailable. The administration has refused to release official Obamacare insurance plan enrollment numbers until mid-November, when a crash effort of computer fixes may be showing results.

Despite the challenges, Americans remain divided over the new healthcare law, with negative views outweighing positives. However, they also lean against repealing it. As the website continues to face scrutiny, the administration will need to address concerns over high insurance plan prices and limited choices to ensure a smoother enrollment process and a more positive public perception.

Title: Campaign Finance Update: Romney's Fundraising Surge and Obama's Concerns

Article:

The Supreme Court's recent ruling on the Obama administration's tax policy has led to a significant influx of funds for Mitt Romney's presidential campaign. According to reports, the Romney team has taken in $4.2 million in the past 24 hours, a significant boost to their fundraising efforts.

In response to the ruling, Romney has stated that he would repeal the entire bill on his first day in office if elected president. This move has sparked concerns among some critics who argue that it would disproportionately benefit the wealthy and large corporations.

Meanwhile, President Obama has expressed concerns about the impact of the ruling on his re-election campaign. In an email, he acknowledged that he will likely be outspent in the election, citing the significant fundraising advantage enjoyed by the Romney campaign. Obama noted that while he is not just talking about super PACs and anonymous outside groups, but also the Romney campaign itself, which has raised more than three-quarters of its money from individuals giving $1,000 or more.

The President emphasized that while it is possible to be outspent and still win an election, it is much more challenging to overcome a 10-to-1 fundraising disadvantage. He urged his supporters to donate $3 or more to help bridge the gap and ensure a competitive election.

The Obama campaign has reported that over 2.2 million Americans have already contributed to their cause, and the deadline to donate is approaching. As a token of appreciation, donors who contribute $3 or more will be entered into a drawing to attend one of the last grassroots dinners of the campaign, featuring Michelle and the President.

In contrast, Romney's campaign has not publicly disclosed the details of their fundraising efforts, sparking concerns about the influence of big donors on the election. The Obama campaign has highlighted the importance of grassroots support, emphasizing that their fundraising efforts are driven by small donations from everyday Americans.

As the election approaches, both campaigns will continue to focus on fundraising efforts to stay competitive. The outcome of the election will depend on a variety of factors, including the candidates' policies, debate performances, and grassroots support.

Title: Obama's Farewell Address: A Call to Action for Civic Engagement and Unity

Article:

Former President Barack Obama delivered a farewell address to the nation on Tuesday night, wrapping up his eight-year tenure in the Oval Office. In his speech, Obama reflected on his original quest for the presidency, touted his record, and laid down a charge to the nation: to stay at it.

Obama's call for continued action may be of most consequence, as he warned that inequality, racial divisions, and the decline of fact-based consensus pose a threat to democracy. He urged Americans to accept the responsibility of citizenship and to take action to address these issues.

The former president also touched on his post-presidency plans, which include doubling down on his commitment to Organizing for America, a group that sprang from his presidential campaigns. He also plans to work on redistricting with former Attorney General Eric Holder, who chairs the National Democratic Redistricting Committee.

Obama's speech was notable for its broad, nonpartisan tone, as he called for national unity and civic engagement. He encouraged Americans to get involved in the political process, whether by running for office or volunteering for a cause they care about.

The former president also hinted at his plans to stay involved in politics, albeit in a more behind-the-scenes capacity. He will be based in Washington for the next two and a half years, while his younger daughter finishes high school, making him the first president since Woodrow Wilson to remain in the capital after leaving office.

Obama's speech was met with cheers and applause from the crowd of 18,000 in his adopted hometown of Chicago. His call to action and commitment to civic engagement are likely to resonate with many Americans, as the country grapples with the challenges of the Trump presidency and the need for greater unity and cooperation.

In his farewell address, Obama reminded Americans that the future is theirs to shape and that they have the power to create positive change. He encouraged them to take action, to get involved, and to stay engaged in the hard work of forming a more perfect union.

Title: The Economy's Mixed Performance: A Complex Picture

Article:

The US economy's recent growth, at 4.6% in the second quarter, has sparked debate about President Obama's role in the recovery. However, a closer examination of the data reveals a more nuanced picture. While the economy has shown some growth, it has also experienced periods of slow growth and even decline. This mixed performance has led to a lack of clear association between the president and the economy.

One quarter does not make a summer, and the economy's growth rate has been inconsistent throughout President Obama's tenure. In fact, only one other quarter during his presidency has matched the 4.6% growth rate. The economy's worst quarter, with a growth rate of -2.1%, was in 2014, which was the worst performance since 2009.

The economy's growth rate has been below 2% in 10 of the 22 quarters during President Obama's presidency. The average annual GDP growth rate for his five-year term was slightly above 2.1%, and if 2009's negative 2.8% growth rate is included, the average falls to below 1.2%. This is lower than the average annual growth rate of 2.5% during the 1980s and 1990s.

The unemployment rate has also been a concern, with a high average annual rate of 6.9% during President Obama's first five years in office. This is higher than the average annual rate of 5.5% during the 1990s and 2000s. The unemployment rate has only recently fallen below 6% for the first time since President Obama took office.

The economy has received significant assistance from the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and fiscal policy, with the federal debt held by the public more than doubling from 2008 to 2013. However, this has not translated into strong economic growth.

President Obama's association with the economy's performance is also influenced by politics. The president is often seen as responsible for the economy's performance, and the public tends to associate him with the economy's slow growth. Additionally, Americans are accustomed to excellence in the economy and are disappointed by the lack of strong growth.

In conclusion, the economy's performance during President Obama's tenure has been mixed, with periods of growth and decline. While the president has received some credit for the economy's growth, he has also faced criticism for the slow growth and high unemployment rates. The economy's performance is complex and influenced by various factors, including monetary and fiscal policy, and the public's expectations of excellence.

Title: Obama's Second Term Challenges: A Test of Leadership and Legacy

Article:

President Barack Obama's second term has been marked by setbacks and challenges, with the latest being the failure to pass key legislation and the ongoing controversy surrounding the government's handling of the economy. Despite these hurdles, Obama's advisors and supporters remain optimistic about his ability to navigate the complexities of his second term and leave a lasting legacy.

Second terms have historically been a challenging time for presidents, with many facing significant obstacles and setbacks. Ronald Reagan's Iran-Contra affair and Bill Clinton's impeachment are notable examples. Even George W. Bush's efforts to revamp Social Security and address the Iraq War were met with resistance and ultimately failed to gain traction.

However, some presidents have managed to make significant breakthroughs in their second term. Reagan signed a nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union, Clinton balanced the budget, and Bush's troop surge in Iraq helped turn the tide of the war.

For Obama, the recent drop in the projected deficit announced by the Congressional Budget Office serves as a reminder that his second term is not without its accomplishments. Despite the setbacks, Obama's advisors believe that he has the ability to focus on the bigger picture and maintain his equanimity.

"Being in office for nearly four and a half years gives the president some perspective – it helps separate the signal from the noise," said Dan Pfeiffer, a White House senior adviser. "When you have dealt with real-life and-death problems, the political ones seem much smaller and affect you less."

While Obama's second term has been marked by challenges, his supporters believe that he has the ability to navigate the complexities of his second term and leave a lasting legacy. Only time will tell if he will be able to overcome the obstacles and achieve his goals.

Title: Holder's Response to Fast and Furious Investigation Raises Questions and Concerns

Article:

The controversy surrounding the botched anti-gunrunning operation Fast and Furious has led to a heated debate between the Obama administration and congressional Republicans. The operation, which aimed to track illicit guns to bigger traffickers, has been criticized for allowing many of the guns to "walk" into Mexico, with some later found at the crime scene where Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry was killed in 2010.

The Terry family, who have been vocal about their concerns, believe that Attorney General Eric Holder and other Justice Department officials are "hiding something" in their response to the operation. In an interview with Fox News, Kent and Josephine Terry expressed frustration that the Obama administration may be preventing them from getting the full story about their son's death.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee voted along party lines to recommend holding Holder in contempt of Congress for not handing over a trove of documents related to Fast and Furious. The full House would still need to approve the resolution for it to take effect. President Obama has asserted executive privilege in keeping many of the documents out of public view.

Holder has testified that he only learned about Fast and Furious after Terry's death and condemned the tactics. However, GOP lawmakers have suggested that top officials at the Justice Department knew more about the operation than they have said. The Terry family has expressed disappointment with the Obama administration's latest actions, stating that the refusal to disclose documents and President Obama's assertion of executive privilege "serves to compound this tragedy" and "denies the Terry family and the American people the truth."

The controversy has raised questions about the power of the presidency and the limits of executive privilege. The immediate question is whether the documents contained information so damaging that the president was willing to risk the bad PR by moving to lock them down. Republicans have questioned whether Obama's assertion was legitimate and have suggested that the White House had tipped its hand by asserting privilege over the documents.

The Department of Justice has defended its response, with Holder saying that Issa, the committee chairman, rejected what he thought was "an extraordinary offer." The developments come as Holder tried to negotiate a way to avert the contempt proceedings, with Issa indicating a willingness to postpone the vote after Holder indicated a willingness to make compromises and supply some documents in response to House Republicans' subpoena.

The controversy surrounding Fast and Furious has sparked a heated debate about the role of the Justice Department and the Obama administration in the operation. While the Terry family and congressional Republicans are seeking answers, the controversy has also raised questions about the limits of executive privilege and the power of the presidency.

Title: White House Proposes 5% Across-the-Board Cut in Domestic Spending in 2020 Budget

The White House has unveiled its proposed 2020 budget, which includes a 5% across-the-board reduction in domestic spending. According to Larry Kudlow, a White House economic adviser, the move is aimed at addressing the growing budget deficit, which is expected to hit $897 billion.

Kudlow emphasized that the budget will contain a proposed 5% reduction in domestic spending, which will affect various programs favored by lawmakers in both parties. However, the proposal will not touch retirement programs such as Medicare and Social Security.

The budget will also maintain the 3% tax cuts implemented in 2018, which Kudlow believes will continue to drive economic growth. The proposal will not address the main factors behind the growing deficits, including the 2017 tax cut and increasing spending for the Pentagon and domestic agencies.

The budget will also allocate additional funds for the construction of the president's border wall, with a request for at least $8.6 billion in new funding and $5 billion for the Department of Homeland Security. The proposal will also include $3.6 billion in military construction funds.

Kudlow emphasized that the budget will prioritize border security, citing the crisis of economics, crime, and drugs along the US-Mexico border. The proposal is expected to face opposition from lawmakers, who have previously rejected similar spending cuts.

The proposed budget is part of the ongoing debate over the country's fiscal policy, with some arguing that the growing deficit is a major concern and others believing that economic growth will eventually offset the costs. The debate is likely to continue as lawmakers wrestle over the budget and its implications for the country's economic future.

Title: Senator Lindsey Graham Weighs in on Trump's Upcoming Meeting with Putin and Supreme Court Nominees

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina, recently shared his thoughts on President Trump's upcoming meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin and the Supreme Court nominees. In an exclusive interview with Fox News, Graham emphasized the importance of holding Putin accountable for Russian meddling in the 2016 US election.

"I think President Trump should directly take on Putin and challenge him on his denial of Russian interference in our election," Graham said. "Don't let him deny the obvious. They're still trying to disrupt the 2018 election cycle." Graham also expressed concerns about Turkey's growing influence in the region, calling it "an ally adrift."

On the topic of North Korea, Graham attributed the country's criticism of US rhetoric as "gangster-like" to Chinese involvement. "I see China's hands all over this," he said. "We're in a fight with China... If I were President Trump, I would not let China use North Korea to back me off of the trade dispute."

Regarding the Supreme Court nominees, Graham praised the four candidates reportedly being considered by Trump, calling them "winners." He particularly highlighted Thomas Hardiman, a Third Circuit Court of Appeals judge, as a strong contender. "If you're a conservative Republican, the four people named – particularly Thomas Hardiman – are all winners, and all Republicans should embrace these picks," he said.

However, Graham also criticized the increasing partisanship in the Senate, stating that even George Washington would struggle to secure Democratic votes for a conservative nominee. "I've never seen it this dysfunctional," he said. "There's nobody that President Trump could nominate from a conservative bent that will get many Democratic votes."

The nomination process has become increasingly contentious, with some analysts urging Trump to try to defuse the tension. Fox News political analyst Juan Williams noted that the perception of the court is at stake, and the potential for a conservative justice could lead to a "rubber stamp for a conservative social agenda."

Title: Colorado Lawmakers Consider Allowing Voters to Revise Presidential Ballots After Candidates Drop Out

Article:

In the midst of Colorado's first presidential primary in 20 years, some voters who have already submitted their ballots with votes for candidates who have since dropped out are facing a dilemma. While elections officials have encouraged voters to turn in their Super Tuesday mail ballots early, this means that some voters have selected candidates who are no longer in the race. Colorado Secretary of State Jena Griswold has clarified that voters who have already marked their ballots but have not yet returned them can still obtain new ballots or cross out their previous selection and choose a new candidate.

However, some lawmakers are now discussing the possibility of allowing voters to revise their ballots in future presidential primaries. House Majority Leader Alec Garnett believes that voters should have the opportunity to change their votes even if their candidate drops out, and is advocating for a statutory change to make this possible. "Every voter should have the opportunity, even if their vote was cast for the election, and their candidate dropped out, to go in to the county clerk and have the opportunity to pull a provisional ballot and vote for who remains in the race," Garnett said.

Garnett notes that this issue may not have been fully considered during the legislative process, but believes it's something that should be discussed with lawmakers on both sides of the aisle. Senate Majority Leader Steve Fenberg also acknowledges that this is an issue that lawmakers can tackle in future elections, although he is unsure what the exact solution should be. "It could be logistically difficult, but I think it's worth looking into," Fenberg said.

The issue is particularly relevant in Colorado, which is one of only four states that holds all-mail ballot elections statewide. The problem is exacerbated by the fact that the primary election for presidential candidates is how the state parties select delegates, and some candidates who dropped out, such as Pete Buttigieg, could still receive delegates because they had a significant amount of support. While voters who have already submitted their ballots cannot change their votes this year, lawmakers are considering ways to make this possible in future elections.

Title: Former Trump Lawyer Admits to Hiring Firm to Influence Polls, Owes Thousands in Unpaid Bills

Article:

A bombshell revelation has emerged about Michael Cohen, the former personal lawyer and fixer of President Donald Trump. According to a report by the Wall Street Journal, Cohen hired an IT firm, RedFinch Solutions LLC, to influence polls and rankings in Trump's favor before his presidential campaign. The report also claims that Cohen failed to pay most of the money he owed to the firm.

Cohen took to Twitter to confirm the allegations, stating that he acted at the direction of and for the sole benefit of Trump. He also expressed regret for his "blind loyalty" to the president. The tweet sparked a flurry of reactions, with many calling for accountability and transparency.

The report highlights a series of events that took place in 2014 and 2015, when Cohen allegedly asked John Gauger, the owner of RedFinch Solutions, to manipulate the results of a CNBC poll and a Drudge Report ranking. Gauger told the Wall Street Journal that he was unsuccessful in getting Trump into the top 100 in the CNBC poll, but managed to get him ranked fifth in the Drudge Report ranking.

Gauger also revealed that he performed other services for Cohen, unrelated to the president, and received payment for some of them. One such project was the creation of the Twitter account "@WomenForCohen", which still exists today. The account's bio describes Cohen as "strong, pit bull, sex symbol, no nonsense, business-oriented, and ready to make a difference!"

In 2017, Cohen requested a $50,000 reimbursement for "tech services" from the Trump Tower Organization, according to federal prosecutors. However, it is unclear whether this reimbursement was related to the poll-rigging efforts.

Cohen was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to campaign finance violations, bank fraud, and lying to Congress. None of the charges are connected to his dealings with RedFinch.

The Trump Organization declined to comment on the matter, but Rudolph Giuliani, one of Trump's lawyers, called Cohen a "thief". "If one thing has been established, it's that Michael Cohen is completely untrustworthy," Giuliani said.

The revelation raises questions about the extent of Cohen's involvement in Trump's campaign and the potential impact on the election. As the investigation continues, it remains to be seen what other secrets will be uncovered.

**House Democrats Weigh Options for Impeachment Proceedings Amid Senate Uncertainty**

In the aftermath of the House of Representatives voting to impe the President, Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her colleagues are considering their next steps, including the possibility of delaying the transmission of the articles of impeachment to the Senate. This move has sparked debate among legal scholars and lawmakers alike, with some arguing that it could be a strategic move to ensure a fair trial.

According to sources, Pelosi has been approached by Democratic colleagues who are concerned about the Senate's handling of the trial. They point to an op-ed by constitutional lawyer Laurence Tribe, who argues that the Senate's current approach would not render a meaningful verdict. Tribe's proposal suggests delaying the transmission of the articles until the Senate agrees to run a fairer process.

Pelosi's remarks on the matter were cryptic, leaving many wondering what her next move will be. When asked if the articles would be transmitted to the Senate, she responded, "You're asking me, 'So are we all going to go out and play in the snow?' That has not been part of our conversations."

House leaders, including Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler and Financial Services Chairwoman Maxine Waters, emphasized that the focus should be on the president's impeachment, rather than the Senate's handling of the trial. However, some Democrats are concerned that the Senate's lack of interest in serving as an impartial overseer of the trial could undermine the entire process.

One option being considered is delaying the transmission of the articles until the Senate agrees to run a fairer process. This could give the House more time to build its case and potentially uncover new evidence and witness testimony. Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) has approached every member of House leadership about the idea and received responses ranging from interest to outright support.

While Pelosi has not made a final decision, she has indicated that she is considering the option. Her decision will likely be influenced by discussions with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer. The House will continue to deliberate and consider its options, with the ultimate goal of ensuring a fair and transparent impeachment process.

Title: Healthcare Reform in New Hampshire: A Test of Public Opinion

Aritcle:

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has become a contentious issue in the upcoming midterm elections in the United States. In New Hampshire, a closely divided state between Democrats and Republicans, the law is being tested as a potential liability or asset for Democratic candidates. The law, aimed at expanding health insurance coverage to millions of Americans, has faced criticism from Republicans and skepticism from some voters.

Three races in New Hampshire illustrate the challenge for Democrats, who are trying to overcome voter skepticism about the 2010 healthcare reform law. Senators Jeanne Shaheen, Kay Hagan, and Mary Landrieu, all Democrats, have been targeted by conservative groups, such as Americans for Prosperity, in their campaigns.

Despite the challenges, Shaheen and Representative Carol Shea-Porter, a fellow Democrat, are among the earliest advocates of the healthcare law. Shaheen believes that as Americans get to know Obamacare, they are embracing it, citing a "lot of misinformation" about the law. She notes that the reality is that it's beginning to work for people.

However, 51% of New Hampshire adults oppose Obamacare, while 37% support it, according to a University of New Hampshire Survey Center poll. Sixty-one percent of voters believe medical costs will increase under the act. Andrew Smith, director of the center, notes that the perception is that the law will hurt families and increase costs, making it a significant challenge for Democrats.

Skeptics like Derek Gagnon, a 33-year-old auto mechanic, are concerned about the individual mandate, which requires almost all legal U.S. residents to buy health insurance or pay a fine. Gagnon has no health insurance and says he won't sign up for the private insurance offered through the government-run website, HealthCare.gov.

On the other hand, some people like Patrice Glynn, a 54-year-old New Hampshire resident, are already convinced of the benefits of Obamacare. Glynn, a diabetic, lived without health insurance for nine months before signing up on HealthCare.gov and is now convinced that the law is working.

Dean Spiliotes, a New Hampshire political analyst, notes that Shaheen still has political capital in the state and doubts that the healthcare issue alone can defeat her. He believes that if Obamacare rises to the level of taking out Shaheen, there is something larger going on.

In conclusion, the Affordable Care Act remains a contentious issue in the upcoming midterm elections, with both sides presenting their arguments. While some voters are skeptical of the law, others are already convinced of its benefits. The outcome of the elections will depend on how effectively Democrats can communicate the benefits of the law and address the concerns of skeptical voters.

Title: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman Steps Down Amidst Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has resigned from his position, effective Tuesday, following allegations of sexual misconduct and abuse by four women. The allegations, published in The New Yorker, include claims of physical and emotional abuse, with one accuser describing being choked and called a "brown slave" by Schneiderman.

Schneiderman, a prominent figure in the #MeToo movement and a vocal critic of President Trump, had been hailed as a champion of women's rights and a defender of the #Resistance. However, the allegations against him have sparked widespread condemnation from both sides of the political aisle.

The New Yorker article reported that the women came forward after the resignation of White House aide Rob Porter, who was accused of abusing his ex-wives. The women's accounts of Schneiderman's behavior, which included physical and emotional abuse, have been corroborated by multiple sources.

Schneiderman has denied the allegations, stating that he has engaged in consensual role-playing and sexual activity, but has not assaulted anyone. However, his resignation has been met with widespread criticism, with many calling for him to step down.

The controversy has also drawn attention from the Trump administration, with Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway tweeting "Gotcha" in response to Schneiderman's resignation. Trump Jr. also weighed in, tweeting "Hey Eric, it's not 'role-playing' if only one of you is in on it."

The allegations against Schneiderman have sparked a broader conversation about the importance of accountability and the need for leaders to hold themselves to a higher standard. While Schneiderman's resignation is a significant blow to the #MeToo movement, it also serves as a reminder that no one is above the law and that those in positions of power must be held accountable for their actions.

Title: Obamacare's Fixes May Do More Harm Than Good

Article:

The ongoing efforts to fix the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) have led to a plethora of ideas and proposals, but many experts warn that these fixes could ultimately do more harm than good. The latest development is President Obama's executive order, which allows insurers to continue offering canceled plans to customers who want to keep them. However, this move has been met with skepticism, as it may attract healthier individuals to remain outside the Obamacare pool, potentially destabilizing the system.

According to an Associated Press survey, at least 4.2 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their insurers, with many of these individuals being healthier than those who will be attracted to Obamacare. This could lead to higher premiums and potentially an unsustainable insurance system. Cori Uccello, senior health fellow at the American Academy of Actuaries, notes that allowing healthier individuals to remain outside the pool could lead to higher costs and an insurance system that cannot support itself.

Insurers are hesitant to reverse course and implement the change, citing state laws that prohibit "substandard" plans. California and New York are among the states that have enacted such laws. A reversal could add to the confusion and lack of confidence already surrounding Obamacare, which could have debilitating consequences.

Larry Kocot, a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution, notes that the rollout of Obamacare has surpassed the glitches experienced during the rollout of Medicare Part D. "It's very, very hard to address confusion," he says.

Despite the potential downsides, the political pressure to fix Obamacare is intense. The blowback from those unhappy with the cancellations has reached a "Category 5 political hurricane," as Rep. Greg Walden (R-Oregon) put it. Real people are facing higher premiums and deductibles, and they are telling their members of Congress about it. Obama's approval rating has sunk to 39 percent, and his executive order has been met with skepticism from many Democrats.

The politics of Obamacare have become so damaging to Democratic lawmakers that nearly 40 House Democrats peeled from their caucus to support a bill backed by Rep. Fred Upton (R-Michigan). Most Democrats do not like this bill, and Obama has promised to veto it, as it would allow new customers to sign on to canceled plans, potentially worsening the outlook for Obamacare's sustainability.

Instead, Democrats such as Sen. Mary Landrieu of Louisiana are working on their own legislation. The outcome of these efforts is uncertain, but the rollout of Obamacare is producing problems beyond a broken website. Fixing them is like pulling on a loose thread – give it a tug, and things start to unravel.

**Google Search Results Show Bias Toward Left-Leaning News Outlets, Study Finds**

A recent report by media technology group AllSides has shed light on the political leanings of Google News and search engine results. The study analyzed the online news aggregator's homepage and search engine results over a two-week period, revealing a strong preference for media outlets with a left-leaning perspective.

According to the report, the overall bias of Google News was found to be 65% toward the left, 20% toward the center, and 16% to the right. The study also found that left-leaning news was often one of the top two results displayed, while news from the center of the political spectrum was less visible.

The report also analyzed the prominence of news sources in search results, finding that left-leaning news outlets dominated the top results. In fact, the study found that 91% of the time, left-leaning news won out over right-leaning news when the two perspectives competed. When the competition was between left-leaning and center-leaning news, the left-leaning news still held a strong advantage, winning 80% of the time.

The report stopped short of accusing Google of intentionally rigging its results, instead attributing the bias to the natural and unintended consequences of its algorithms and the fact that most news outlets and journalists lean left.

Google itself has denied any allegations of political bias, stating that its goal is to provide the most relevant answers to users' queries and that it does not bias its results toward any political ideology.

The findings of this study have sparked debate among users and politicians alike, with some calling for greater transparency and accountability in online search results. As the digital landscape continues to evolve, it is essential to ensure that online platforms provide a fair and balanced representation of news and information.

Title: Indonesia Takes Step Towards Ending Child Marriage, But More Needs to be Done

Article:

Indonesia has made a significant step towards ending child marriage by raising the minimum age of marriage for girls from 16 to 19. This decision was prompted by the country's Constitutional Court ruling that it was discriminatory to have a lower minimum age of marriage for girls than for boys. While this is a positive development, Indonesia is not the worst offender when it comes to child marriage. According to UNICEF, 14% of Indonesian women marry before they reach 18 years old, compared to 59% in Bangladesh and 76% in Niger.

Child marriage is a complex issue, often linked to rigid gender norms, conflict, and poverty. Education is a key factor, with girls without schooling three times more likely to be married by 18 than those with secondary education. However, in many cultures, education for girls comes second to marriage and its associated duties.

Cutting a childhood short can have significant consequences. Girls who marry young are at increased risk of sexual violence, poorer health, and higher school drop-out rates. They are also less likely to participate in the labor force, which has significant economic costs. A study found that child marriage cost Indonesia's economy 1.7% of GDP in 2014. The welfare benefit of ending the practice worldwide is estimated to be worth around $22 billion.

Indonesia's new policy is a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done to tackle the social and economic forces that drive child marriage. Ensuring that girls complete their 12 years of compulsory schooling and reducing unintended pregnancies by improving access to contraception and sexual-health education would be a start. Giving girls more control over their bodies would allow them to exercise more sway over their future, including who they marry.

Title: Federal Authorities Prepare to Protect National Monuments Amid Ongoing Protests

Article:

The Trump administration has instructed U.S. marshals to be prepared to guard national monuments across the country, following President Donald Trump's vow to crack down on those destroying federal property during ongoing protests. The move is part of a "major effort" to bolster security around national monuments, with marshals expected to begin their work before the end of the week.

According to an email from Marshals Service Assistant Director Andrew C. Smith, the agency has been asked to provide federal law enforcement support to protect national monuments nationwide. The email, marked as an "Attorney General Assignment," suggests it came from Attorney General William P. Barr.

The decision comes after weeks of statues being toppled nationwide, with initial targets being Confederate monuments, but more recent destruction of tributes to the founding fathers and abolitionists. President Trump has warned that those found damaging federal property will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law, with penalties ranging from 10 years in prison to life.

The president has also authorized the Federal Government to arrest anyone who vandalizes or destroys federal property, including monuments, statues, or other such property in the U.S. The action is effective immediately, but may also be used retroactively for destruction or vandalism already caused.

In a tweet, President Trump addressed the issue, stating that it is "very sad to see states allowing roving gangs of wise guys, anarchists & looters, many of them having no idea what they are doing, indiscriminately ripping down our statues and monuments to the past." He emphasized the importance of understanding and remembering history, even in difficult times, and learning from it.

Unarmed National Guard troops will also be sent to monuments around Washington, D.C. to assist the U.S. Park Police in protecting the monuments in the nation's capital. The move aims to ensure the preservation of national monuments and the protection of federal property.

Title: NSA's XKeyscore Program: A Vast Database of Foreign Communications

The National Security Agency (NSA) has a program called XKeyscore, which provides access to a staggering amount of internet data. The program collects and stores a vast amount of information, with some sites receiving over 20 terabytes of data per day. However, due to the sheer volume of data, the NSA has implemented a multi-tiered system to store "interesting" content in other databases, such as Pinwale, which can store material for up to five years.

XKeyscore appears to be exclusively focused on foreign signals intelligence, including phone conversations, emails, and chat communications. Analysts can use the program to monitor Facebook chats and private messages, as well as search for internet browsing activities using various information, including search terms and websites visited.

The program also allows analysts to learn the IP addresses of every person who visits a specified website. However, it is unclear whether this includes U.S. persons or only foreign nationals. Under U.S. law, the NSA is required to obtain an individualized FISA warrant only if the target of their surveillance is a U.S. person, but XKeyscore provides the technological capability to target even U.S. persons for extensive electronic surveillance without a warrant, as long as some identifying information is known to the analyst.

The NSA documents claim that by 2008, 300 terrorists had been captured using intelligence from XKeyscore. While the FISA Amendments Act of 2008 requires an individualized warrant for the targeting of U.S. persons, NSA analysts are permitted to intercept the communications of such individuals without a warrant if they are in contact with one of the NSA's foreign targets.

Greenwald suggests that this validates Snowden's statement that he had the authority to wiretap anyone, from a U.S. citizen to the President, if he had a personal email. However, it is unclear whether XKeyscore provides real-time surveillance capabilities or gives anyone the authority to wiretap a U.S. citizen. Rather, it appears to be a database search tool that provides access to tremendous volumes of foreign communications, which can then be searched by NSA analysts.

There are known "compliance problems" with the NSA's surveillance programs, as communications by U.S. persons can end up in the database if the other end of the conversation is overseas. The NSA's minimization procedures are supposed to prevent such "inadvertent" targeting of U.S. persons, but there are exceptions to this rule.

**House Republicans Struggle to Reach Agreement on Healthcare Bill**

The Republican-led effort to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is facing significant challenges, with several Republicans announcing their opposition to the current bill. The White House and congressional Republicans are struggling to gather enough votes to pass the bill, with at least 21 Republicans opposed and 17 lawmakers still undecided.

The bill's fate is uncertain, with no vote scheduled and no clear indication of when one might take place. Vice President Mike Pence is set to meet with Senate Republicans and lawmakers on Capitol Hill to lobby for support.

President Donald Trump has expressed optimism about the bill's chances, stating that it will guarantee coverage for Americans with pre-existing conditions. However, the bill's language on pre-existing conditions has been a point of contention, with some Republicans expressing concerns that it may not provide adequate protections.

The bill's passage is crucial for the Republican Party, which can only afford to lose 22 votes assuming all Republicans are present and no Democrats cross over. The party is under pressure to deliver on its promise to repeal and replace the ACA, which has been a key campaign promise for years.

Despite the challenges, some Republicans remain hopeful that the bill can still pass. "I hope we keep going," said Rep. Brett Guthrie, a Republican who serves on the House's Energy and Commerce Committee. "I don't think we can stop."

The bill's fate will likely be decided in the coming days, as lawmakers continue to negotiate and try to find common ground.

Title: Oklahoma High School Students Protest Alleged Bullying and Lack of Action After Rapes

Article:

Hundreds of students from Norman High School in Oklahoma walked out of their school on Monday to protest the alleged bullying and lack of action taken by school administrators after three female students reported being raped by the same person. The students, who were joined by parents and community members, held signs and chanted slogans such as "No justice, no class" and "No more bullying."

The protest was sparked by allegations that the school failed to take adequate action after the students reported the rapes and bullying. The three teens and their families claim that school administrators did not respond promptly or effectively to their reports, and that the bullying continued despite their efforts to report it.

The students' story gained widespread attention after a detailed account was published on Jezebel, a popular online news site. The Norman Police Department has launched an investigation, but no arrests or charges have been made, and no further details have been released.

In a statement, Norman Public Schools Superintendent Joe Siano encouraged parents to talk to their children about alternatives to the walkout, such as wearing stickers and ribbons provided by the school. The school is also expanding a task force to study the implementation of a targeted, research-based sexual assault curriculum for students.

The three teens who were allegedly raped told Jezebel that they stopped attending classes and left school voluntarily after the bullying became unbearable. Friends of the teens started a Facebook page, YES ALL Daughters, to show support for them. The page drew nearly 10,000 likes in just two weeks, and the teens organized the protest with the help of their mothers and relatives.

The protest was peaceful, with organizers posting a list of "Protest Do's and Don'ts" on the Facebook page, including instructions to be peaceful, law-abiding citizens who do not disturb local businesses and to not respond to negativity. The Daily Oklahoman reported that hundreds of students attended the protest, while organizers estimated that around 1,500 students participated.

The students who organized the protest said they wanted to show solidarity with all victims of bullying and harassment, and to demonstrate that they will not tolerate such behavior. The protest was a powerful display of student activism and a call to action for school administrators to take bullying and sexual assault seriously.

Title: Ryan's Speech: A Mixed Bag of Economic Analysis and Debt Focus

Article:

Paul Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, delivered a speech at the Republican National Convention in Tampa that received a standing ovation from the audience. While he effectively criticized the Obama administration's economic policies, his own economic growth solutions were unclear and muddled. Ryan's speech focused heavily on debt and deficits, which may not resonate with Americans who are struggling to find employment.

Ryan's speech was strongest when he analyzed the Obama administration's economic policies, which he described as "Obamanomics." He effectively highlighted the flaws in the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, and defended the Republican Party against Democratic attacks on Medicare reform. However, his economic growth solutions were unclear and did not provide a clear vision for the country's economic future.

Ryan's failure to mention Mitt Romney's proposed tax cuts, including a 20% across-the-board reduction in marginal tax rates and a 25% corporate tax rate reduction, was surprising. These policies have been touted as key to promoting economic growth, and their omission left many wondering what the Romney-Ryan ticket's economic plan truly entails.

While Ryan's emphasis on debt and deficits may resonate with some, it may not be the most effective way to connect with Americans who are struggling to find employment. The Republican Party has historically fared better when it focuses on growth, limited government, lower spending, lower tax rates, and deregulation.

Ultimately, it will be up to Mitt Romney to clarify his own economic growth policies on Thursday night. Until then, the American people are left with a mixed bag of economic analysis and debt-focused rhetoric from Ryan's speech.

Title: Narendra Modi: A Complex Figure on the Verge of Becoming India's Prime Minister

Article:

Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat, is on the cusp of becoming India's next prime minister, with his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) poised for a landslide victory in the country's recent parliamentary elections. Modi's rise to prominence has been meteoric, with many praising his economic growth in Gujarat, where he has been chief minister since 2001. However, his legacy is also marred by religious riots in 2002, which left hundreds of Muslims dead.

Modi's background is marked by his humble beginnings as the son of a tea vendor, who joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, a Hindu nationalist organization, and rose through its ranks. He is married, but only acknowledged his wife's existence recently, sparking questions about his personal life.

As chief minister, Modi has been credited with transforming Gujarat into one of India's best-performing states economically, with the state's economy nearly tripling in size under his leadership. He is known for his decisiveness, getting things done, and rooting out corruption. Many Indian business executives rank Gujarat as one of the easiest states to do business in, with uninterrupted electricity and water supply, and well-maintained roads.

However, not everyone has benefited from Gujarat's economic progress. Half of all children under the age of five suffer from malnutrition, and two-thirds of rural households lack toilets. Additionally, the state's entrepreneurial tradition predates Modi, but he has made the government machinery accountable, a feat many Indians hope he can replicate across the rest of the nation.

The biggest reservation many Indians have about Modi is the massive anti-Muslim violence that broke out under his watch in 2002, which left hundreds of Muslims dead. Critics accuse him of not taking action to stop the violence, and while he has denied any responsibility, subsequent investigations have been criticized. Modi has only recently publicly addressed the violence, saying it shook him deeply, but many victims and critics argue that the comments fell short of an apology.

Modi's critics also point to his vindictive and abrasive nature, and his intolerance of dissent. Some have compared him to Russian President Vladimir Putin, citing his authoritarian tendencies. However, it is likely that Modi would be granted a visa to travel to the US if he becomes prime minister, and he has already met with European officials.

As India's next prime minister, Modi will face numerous challenges, including addressing the country's deep-seated social and economic issues, as well as his own controversial past. While his economic growth in Gujarat has been impressive, many questions remain about his leadership style and ability to govern a diverse and complex country like India.

**Title:** Hurricane Sandy Brings Campaign Scheduling Changes, Warnings for East Coast

**Article:**

As Hurricane Sandy approaches the East Coast, both President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have adjusted their campaign schedules to prioritize safety and preparation. The storm, currently off the coast of Florida, is expected to bring tropical storm-force winds and heavy rainfall to the region, with inland areas potentially seeing up to 2 feet of snow.

The Obama campaign has canceled events in Northern Virginia and Colorado Springs, Colorado, while Mitt Romney has canceled all events scheduled for Virginia on Sunday. Instead, he will campaign in Ohio on Monday morning. The President himself will try to beat out the storm by leaving Washington on Sunday afternoon, holding an event in Youngstown, Ohio, before returning to Washington to monitor the storm.

Federal officials have warned that the East Coast from South Carolina to New Jersey should be prepared for heavy rains and winds, with inland areas potentially seeing significant flooding. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Administrator Craig Fugate emphasized that the storm's reach will extend far inland, affecting areas such as the Ohio Valley and Appalachian regions.

While some have raised concerns about the storm's potential impact on voter turnout in swing states, both the White House and campaign officials downplayed the issue, prioritizing the safety of staff, supporters, and volunteers. "We're closely monitoring the storm. The safety of not only our staff but also our supporters and volunteers is the top priority," said Obama campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki.

As the storm approaches, FEMA and other federal partners are sending teams and resources to potentially impacted areas to support state and local preparedness efforts. The public is urged to closely monitor the storm's progress and follow the guidance and direction of their state and local officials.

Title: Trump Cancels Veterans Day Parade in Washington DC Due to High Costs

Article:

In a surprise move, US President Donald Trump has cancelled a Veterans Day military parade in Washington DC, citing high costs. The event was planned to take place on November 11, the centenary of the end of World War One, and was expected to feature a parade from the White House to the Capitol, with a "heavy air component" at the end.

The estimated cost of the parade was initially reported to be between $10 million and $30 million, but a US official later revealed that the actual cost could be as high as $92 million. Trump took to Twitter to express his disappointment, stating that local politicians had asked for a "ridiculously high" figure, which he deemed too expensive.

The cancellation comes after Trump had previously expressed his admiration for France's Bastille Day parade, which he witnessed during a visit to Paris in 2017. He had initially wanted the US to "top" France's parade, but it appears that the costs associated with staging such an event have proven too high.

The Pentagon has announced that it will explore alternative options for a military parade in 2019, but it is unclear whether the event will take place at a later date.

The cancellation has been met with mixed reactions, with some politicians and military officials expressing disappointment, while others have criticized the idea of a military parade as an "absurd waste of money." The District of Columbia Council, Washington's legislative body, had previously expressed concerns about the plan, citing concerns about the impact on the city's infrastructure and the potential disruption to daily life.

The cancellation also raises questions about the priorities of the Trump administration, particularly in light of the president's decision to cancel military exercises with South Korea in June, citing the potential cost savings. The US had previously held a military parade in 1991 to celebrate the end of the Gulf War, but it appears that the costs associated with staging such an event have become too high for the current administration.

Title: House Passes GOP-Authored Bill to Repeal Unpopular Parts of Obamacare, Faces Uncertain Path in Senate

Article:

The House of Representatives has passed a bill aimed at repealing certain provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The bill, dubbed the Restoring Americans' Healthcare Freedom Reconciliation Act, would repeal insurance mandates on individuals and employers, as well as taxes on medical device sales and generous health plans, also known as the "Cadillac tax." The bill passed with a vote of 240-189, with seven Republicans and one Democrat voting against it.

The bill's passage comes as Republican leaders are leveraging a budget reconciliation tool to bypass a Senate filibuster and pass the bill with a simple majority. However, the bill's path through the Senate is uncertain, as some conservative senators have expressed concerns that it does not go far enough in repealing the ACA.

The bill's sponsors, including Majority Whip Steve Scalise, argue that it is a step towards dismantling Obamacare and providing relief to American workers. However, Democrats have criticized the bill as a repeat of previous attempts to repeal the ACA, which they say would harm millions of Americans who rely on the healthcare law.

The bill's passage also highlights the divisions within the Republican Party, with some members of the House Freedom Caucus supporting the bill while others have expressed reservations. The bill's fate in the Senate is uncertain, as it will need to navigate the chamber's arcane rules and potentially face opposition from some Republican senators.

The bill's passage is also seen as a test of the leadership of House Speaker John Boehner, who is facing pressure from hard-line conservatives to take a stronger stance against the ACA. His potential replacement, Rep. Paul Ryan, has put himself at odds with the Heritage Foundation, which has criticized the bill as not going far enough in repealing the ACA.

Overall, the bill's passage is a significant development in the ongoing debate over healthcare reform, and its fate in the Senate will be closely watched in the coming weeks.

Title: Department of Homeland Security's Ammunition Purchases Under Scrutiny

Article:

The Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) recent ammunition purchases have raised questions and concerns among lawmakers, with some calling for greater transparency and accountability. Republican Representative Jason Chaffetz, chair of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, expressed surprise at the sheer volume of ammunition being purchased by the department, stating that it is "entirely inexplicable" why DHS needs so much.

Chaffetz pointed out that the department has purchased over 260 million rounds of ammunition, with more than 103 million rounds bought in 2012 alone. He compared this to the U.S. Army's small-arms purchases, noting that DHS is using roughly 1,000 rounds more per person. This has led some to question the department's motives and whether the purchases are necessary.

However, DHS officials defended the purchases, stating that the department buys in bulk to save money and that the ammunition is used for training and on-duty purposes. Nick Nayak, chief procurement officer for DHS, clarified that the department is not stockpiling ammunition and that claims of creating broader ammunition shortages in the U.S. are "simply not true."

Despite the department's explanations, some lawmakers remain skeptical. Representative Darrell Issa, chair of the full Oversight and Government Reform Committee, expressed concerns that the rounds may be being stockpiled, then either disposed of, passed to non-federal agencies, or shot indiscriminately. He urged greater transparency and accountability in the department's purchasing practices.

The controversy surrounding the DHS's ammunition purchases has sparked a heated debate, with some lawmakers likening concerns to "conspiracy theories" and others calling for greater scrutiny. As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the department's ammunition purchases will be reevaluated and whether greater transparency will be achieved.

**Romney to Accuse Obama of Misunderstanding Radical Islam in Upcoming Speech**

Mitt Romney is set to deliver a major foreign-policy speech at the Virginia Military Institute, where he will accuse the Obama administration of fundamentally misunderstanding the threat of radical Islam. The Republican presidential nominee will argue that President Obama's approach to foreign policy has been passive and ineffective, and that the country needs a more robust and muscular approach to counter the growing threat of terrorism.

According to excerpts, Romney will say that Obama's initial response to the attacks on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya was to blame an Internet video mocking Islam, rather than acknowledging the deliberate work of terrorists who use violence to impose their dark ideology on others. He will also criticize the administration's decision to cut defense spending and lack of a trade agenda in the Middle East.

Romney will also outline his own vision for foreign policy, which includes using foreign aid to pressure Egypt to protect democracy, building the Syrian opposition, and restarting negotiations towards a two-state solution for Israelis and Palestinians. He will argue that the United States must take a more active role in leading the world and defending its interests, rather than simply reacting to events.

The Obama campaign has responded by saying that Romney has no experience or expertise in foreign policy and has been an "unmitigated disaster" in his previous attempts to engage with foreign leaders. They have also questioned what specific policies Romney would implement to address the threat of terrorism.

The speech comes as the presidential race has become increasingly focused on foreign policy, with the recent attacks on American diplomatic posts in the Middle East and the ongoing crisis in Syria dominating the headlines. The debate has also highlighted the differences between the two candidates' approaches to foreign policy, with Romney advocating for a more muscular and interventionist approach, while Obama has emphasized the need for a more nuanced and diplomatic approach.

Title: Trump's Health Care Betrayal: A Promise Broken

The American Health Care Act, endorsed by President Donald Trump, has sparked widespread criticism and disappointment among those who believed his campaign promises to provide universal healthcare and protect Medicaid. Trump's campaign rhetoric touted a plan to cover everyone, avoid Medicaid cuts, and boost funding for opioid abuse treatment. However, the actual bill does the opposite, with millions expected to lose insurance and Medicaid spending being sacrificed for tax cuts for the wealthy.

Trump's promises were not just election-year rhetoric. He made specific commitments to protect Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid during the 2015 primary and general election. In an interview with the Washington Post, he stated that his plan would offer "insurance for everybody" with "much lower deductibles" and emphasized that ability to pay would not be an issue.

The American Health Care Act, on the other hand, prioritizes a $600 billion tax cut, with the wealthy benefiting the most. The plan is expected to leave millions without insurance, with estimates ranging from 6 million to 15 million people losing coverage. The administration's strategy to downplay the consequences of the bill is not convincing, as the plan's long-term spending cuts require offsetting reductions, which will likely lead to Medicaid cuts and people being thrown off the program.

The bill also disadvantages certain groups, including rural residents who will receive less help due to reduced competition and older Americans who will face higher premiums due to laxer regulation of insurance companies. This means that Trump will not only be breaking his promises but also harming those who voted for him the most.

While some may argue that Trump voters are not concerned about healthcare, it is important to remember that his campaign promises were made to appeal to a broad audience. Trump's supporters likely agreed with his promises on healthcare because they were popular and resonated with their concerns. Now, it appears that Trump is prioritizing his own interests over those of his supporters, leaving many feeling betrayed and disappointed.

Title: Trump's Hydroxychloroquine Admission Raises Questions, but Not Among His Supporters

Article:

President Donald Trump's recent admission to taking hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug not recommended for COVID-19 treatment, has sparked a flurry of questions and concerns among medical experts and the public. However, his supporters seem unfazed by the news, with some even using it as an opportunity to launch personal attacks on others.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi, on the other hand, expressed her concerns about Trump's decision, stating that he should not be taking the drug, especially given his age and weight. Her comments were met with a mix of reactions, with some criticizing her for "fat-shaming" the president.

However, it's worth noting that Trump has a history of making derogatory comments about people's weight, appearance, and other personal characteristics. He has referred to women as "dogs," "pigs," and "fat," and has made jokes about women's bodies. He has also attacked women journalists, mocked people with disabilities, and made offensive comments about immigrants and other groups.

It's clear that Trump's supporters are not offended by his behavior, but rather are using Pelosi's comments as an opportunity to engage in their own brand of "fat-shaming." They are pointing out that Pelosi has criticized Trump's weight, and using it as a way to deflect attention from the president's own behavior.

The irony is not lost on many observers, who point out that Trump's supporters are quick to defend him when he makes offensive comments, but are suddenly outraged when someone else does the same. It's a classic case of "do as I say, not as I do."

In the end, the debate surrounding Trump's hydroxychloroquine use and Pelosi's comments serves as a reminder that politics is often about perception and spin. While some may see Trump's actions as a legitimate concern, others will use it as an opportunity to attack his opponents and engage in their own brand of political gamesmanship.

Title: Senate Republicans Face Challenges in Reducing Insurance Premiums

Article:

Senate Republicans are struggling to find a way to reduce insurance premiums, a key promise they made to repeal Obamacare. While they have a few options to achieve this goal, they are faced with the reality that it may not be as straightforward as they initially thought.
