He references Obamacare architect Jonathan Gruber's statements on how the Obama administration depended on the "stupidity of the American voter" to enable the healthcare reform plan.

In his opinion piece, Gingrich writes, "Listening to a speech in which the President lied about what he was proposing and lied about his authority to implement it, it was hard not to think of the Gruber model – which is really the Obama model, after all. He said what he needed to say to do what he wants to do. The problem is, in the past few years Obama has described on video 22 times how he does not have the legal and Constitutional authority to enact the reforms he announced Thursday night."

Gingrich also notes that Obama has previously stated that there are laws on the books by Congress that are very clear in terms of how to enforce the immigration system, and that he does not have the authority to ignore those congressional mandates. However, this has changed, and it is a shame that Obama apparently thinks Americans are so stupid that they won't figure out he's not telling the truth.

Title: Jerusalem's Complex History: A City of Controversy and Hope

Article:

Jerusalem, a city steeped in history and controversy, has been at the center of international attention in recent years. The city's status as Israel's capital has been a topic of debate, with some calling for the United States to recognize Jerusalem as the capital and relocate its embassy from Tel Aviv. However, the White House has announced that it will not move the embassy to Jerusalem at this time, citing concerns about complicating the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

The idea of moving the embassy to Jerusalem has been a long-standing promise made by some politicians, including President Donald Trump during his 2016 presidential campaign. However, the issue is complex and has been met with criticism from some quarters. The current location of the U.S. embassy in Tel Aviv has been in place since 1949, and the U.S. has maintained a consulate in Jerusalem since 1844.

David Parsons, media director of the International Christian Embassy Jerusalem (ICEJ), has been a vocal advocate for moving the embassy to Jerusalem. He believes that the move would strengthen the peace process and give Israel confidence that its ally, the U.S., is behind it. Parsons also points out that Jerusalem has been a city of great significance to Jews and Christians alike, with a history dating back over 2,000 years.

However, others argue that moving the embassy to Jerusalem would undermine the peace process and make it more difficult to negotiate a deal between Israelis and Palestinians. The current location of the embassy in Tel Aviv has been seen as a symbol of the U.S.'s commitment to being an honest broker in the region.

Despite the controversy surrounding the issue, Parsons remains optimistic about the future of Jerusalem. He believes that the city has a special role to play in the world and that the U.S. moving its embassy there would be a significant step towards fulfilling that role. "This is that promised Son of David, the Messiah, who will rule and reign over the world in peace and righteousness," Parsons said. "We believe that's Jesus, but I think a house of prayer for all people, that exalted throne of the Messiah during the Messianic age. This is Israel's ultimate destiny and Jerusalem's."

For now, the U.S. embassy remains in Tel Aviv, but the debate over Jerusalem's status as Israel's capital is likely to continue.

Title: Judge Weighs Constitutionality of Obama's Immigration Order in Court Challenge

Article:

A federal judge heard arguments Monday in a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of President Barack Obama's immigration order, which aims to spare nearly 5 million people from deportation. The lawsuit was brought by Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his attorney, Larry Klayman, who argue that the president's action is unconstitutional.

During the hearing, Judge Beryl Howell, an Obama nominee, questioned whether Arpaio has legal standing to challenge the president's authority, suggesting that Congress is better equipped to question the president's actions. A lawyer for the Obama administration called the lawsuit a "political dispute" that should be dismissed.

Arpaio and Klayman claim that the president's action is an end-run around Congress and that drastic changes in immigration programs should be stopped. They argue that the administration's policy change is a way for more people to enter the country illegally and commit crimes, adding to the burden of law enforcement.

The Justice Department countered that Obama's program places greater emphasis on removing criminal aliens and recent border crossers, and that the evidence presented by Arpaio is speculative and unsubstantiated. The government also pointed out that ICE can and does release immigrants who have been arrested on criminal charges, including those who have yet to be convicted, for a variety of reasons.

The case is separate from one filed by two-dozen states against Obama's immigration actions and another in which a federal judge declared Obama's immigration plans "unconstitutional" in an unrelated immigration case. The judge is expected to issue a ruling soon.

Klayman, a conservative lawyer who has previously targeted the president, voiced confidence in their case and suggested they might take their suit to a higher court if necessary.

Title: Migrant Caravan Reaches Mexican Border City, Undeterred by US Stance

A group of approximately 400 migrants, including LGBTQ individuals, has arrived in the Mexican border city of Tijuana, seeking asylum in the United States. The group, which broke away from a larger caravan of 5,000 people in Mexico City, traveled to the border on buses, joining a smaller group of about 80 migrants who arrived on Sunday.

The migrants, who hail from Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, claim they are fleeing persecution, poverty, and violence in their home countries. Despite the US government's tougher stance on immigration, the migrants remain determined to continue their journey and claim asylum.

The group's journey began on October 13 in the city of San Pedro Sula, Honduras, and has covered over 4,350 kilometers (2,700 miles) to reach Tijuana. Many migrants have expressed concerns about the dangers of traveling alone, citing attacks by criminal gangs and other risks. Traveling in numbers has provided them with a sense of safety and security.

The current caravan is significantly larger than previous ones, with over 1,000 Hondurans initially departing and thousands more joining from Guatemala and Mexico. The news of the caravan spread quickly after a former politician shared it on Facebook, drawing attention to the plight of the migrants.

US authorities have responded to the caravan by closing down several lanes of traffic at two border crossings from Tijuana to California, installing barbed wire fencing and barricades to reinforce security. The US government has also deployed up to 9,000 troops to the border, with US Defense Secretary James Mattis set to visit the border on Wednesday.

The migrants' arrival comes as the US mid-term elections have highlighted the issue of immigration, with President Donald Trump warning without evidence that the caravan is full of "gang members," "hardened criminals," and even Middle Eastern "terrorists." However, there is a legal obligation for the US to hear asylum claims from migrants who have arrived in the country, regardless of their mode of entry.

The migrants' determination to continue their journey and claim asylum is a testament to their resilience and desperation to escape the violence and instability in their home countries. As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen how the US government will respond to the influx of migrants and whether it will uphold its legal obligations to hear their asylum claims.

Title: Trump Calls for Comedian Samantha Bee to be Fired Over Vulgar Comment About Ivanka Trump

Article:

In a recent controversy, US President Donald Trump has called for comedian Samantha Bee to be fired after she made a vulgar comment about his daughter and White House adviser Ivanka Trump on her cable television program "Full Frontal". The comment was made during a discussion about the president's controversial immigration policies.

The debate over language used by two television stars has become a proxy for the country's political divide, with Bee's liberal-leaning audience on one side and fans of the sitcom "Roseanne" and its Trump-supporting star on the other. The controversy began when Roseanne Barr, the star of the sitcom, made a racist remark in a post on Twitter, comparing a former top Obama administration official to an ape. The remark led to the cancellation of the show's revival by Walt Disney Co.'s ABC network.

Trump criticized ABC and Bob Iger, the chief executive officer of Disney, on Twitter, but did not address the content of Barr's comments. However, he took exception to Bee's use of a crude term for the female anatomy to describe Ivanka Trump on her show. "Why aren't they firing no talent Samantha Bee for the horrible language used on her low ratings show?" Trump said on Twitter. "A total double standard but that's OK, we are winning, and will be doing so for a long time to come!"

Both Bee and the TBS cable network, which airs the show, apologized on Thursday. "I would like to sincerely apologize to Ivanka Trump and to my viewers for using an expletive on my show to describe her last night," Bee said on Twitter. "It was inappropriate and inexcusable. I crossed a line, and I deeply regret it."

Following Trump's remarks, Sal Petruzzi, a TBS spokesman, said there would be no further comment beyond the earlier apologies. State Farm Insurance and Autotrader also suspended their commercials, citing the offensive nature of Bee's comments.

The controversy has sparked a wider debate about the use of language and the role of comedians in society. While some have defended Bee's right to free speech, others have criticized her for using a crude and offensive term. The incident has also highlighted the ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and the media, with some accusing the president of using his Twitter account to attack and intimidate journalists and comedians.

In conclusion, the controversy surrounding Samantha Bee's comment about Ivanka Trump has sparked a wider debate about the use of language and the role of comedians in society. While some have defended Bee's right to free speech, others have criticized her for using a crude and offensive term. The incident has also highlighted the ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and the media, with some accusing the president of using his Twitter account to attack and intimidate journalists and comedians.

Title: Trump Shifts Focus to Democratic Lawmakers' Comments on Israel

Article:

In a move to deflect criticism over his supporters' chants of "Send her back!" at a rally in North Carolina, President Trump has turned the spotlight on comments made by four liberal lawmakers regarding U.S. policy and Israel. Trump departed the White House for his New Jersey golf club, stating that the Democrats' comments on Israel are "so bad" he won't repeat them, and that they "can't get away with that act."

The President's comments come after a Greenville crowd chanted "Send her back!" on Wednesday, referring to Rep. Ilhan Omar, a Somali refugee who became a U.S. citizen before being elected to Congress from Minnesota. Trump has been critical of Omar and the other three freshmen Democrats, known as "The Squad," whom he has labeled as the new "extreme" face of the Democratic Party.

In a tweet on Sunday, Trump told the four lawmakers to "go back" to their countries if they're unhappy, sparking widespread criticism. However, Trump has since focused on the liberal lawmakers' comments on Israel, rather than the chants from his supporters.

When pressed on whether the liberal lawmakers are using their First Amendment rights when they complain about U.S. policy, Trump stated, "We have First Amendment rights, also, we can certainly feel and say what we want." He also denied taking any advice from First Lady Melania Trump or his daughter Ivanka on how to respond to the chants, calling reports to the contrary "fake news."

The controversy surrounding the chants and Trump's response has sparked a heated debate, with some Republicans distancing themselves from the President's comments. The situation highlights the ongoing tensions between Trump and the Democratic Party, particularly over issues related to immigration and national security.

Title: The Unsettling Reality of Obamacare: A Complex and Ongoing Issue

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has been a topic of much debate and controversy since its inception. A recent Washington Post/ABC News poll found that a majority of Americans deem President Obama's presidency a failure, with many criticizing his leadership and the implementation of the healthcare law. The survey also revealed a dismal presidential approval rating on the implementation of Obamacare, with a significant majority opposed to the law.

A new Kaiser Family Foundation poll echoes these findings, showing that support for the president's signature domestic accomplishment is underwater. The opposition to Obamacare is not limited to its implementation, but also extends to its core principles. Many have argued that the law has failed to deliver on its promises, with individual market premiums exploding in 2014 and expected to grow by roughly eight percent in 2015.

The upcoming open-enrollment period for Obamacare is expected to be problematic, with many consumers facing cancellations and renewal letters in October. The HealthCare.gov website is still not fully functional, making it difficult for people to enroll in the program. Additionally, many are concerned about the rising deductibles, narrower networks, and larger rate increases for the plans that got the most enrollment.

Large businesses are also feeling the impact of Obamacare, with many expecting to pay between 4-5% more for health-care benefits for their employees in 2015. Few employers plan to stop providing benefits, but a third are considering cutting or reducing subsidies for employee family members. The data suggests that employees are paying more each year in out-of-pocket health care expenses.

Numerous polls have consistently found that roughly twice as many Americans say they've been personally hurt by Obamacare than helped. While some have benefited from the law, many more have been negatively impacted. The coming months and years will bring more upheaval for millions of Americans who are receiving health coverage through their employers.

The White House knew that employer-based plans would be affected by the Affordable Care Act, and Senate Democrats voted down a Republican effort to reinforce the president's "keep your plan" promise. The reality is that many employer-based plans will continue to change, with some predicting that 80-90% will "disappear" within the next ten years.

In conclusion, the Obamacare debate is far from over. The complex and ongoing issue will continue to affect millions of Americans, with many facing higher costs, reduced benefits, and uncertainty about their healthcare coverage.

Title: Romney Criticizes Trump's Conduct, Trump Fires Back in Twitter Exchange

Article:

In a recent op-ed published in The Washington Post, Senator-elect Mitt Romney (R-Utah) publicly criticized President Donald Trump's conduct, stating that the president has not risen to the occasion and lacks the character and principles required for the office. Romney, who is set to be sworn in to the Senate on Thursday, expressed his disappointment in Trump's actions over the past two years, particularly his recent behavior.

Trump responded to Romney's criticism on Twitter, calling him "so fast" and questioning whether he is a "Flake" like Jeff Flake, a Republican who frequently criticized the president. Trump also encouraged Romney to focus on border security and other issues where he can be helpful.

Some have speculated that Romney's decision to speak out against Trump's style, while still praising some of his policies and appointments, may be a move to position himself as a replacement for Flake, who has been a vocal critic of the president. In 2016, Romney publicly criticized Trump, calling him a "phony" and "fraud," while Trump responded by calling Romney a "failed presidential candidate" who "choked like a dog." After Trump's election, Romney changed his tone, praising some of the president's policy decisions and expressing interest in joining his administration. Trump also publicly supported Romney in his bid for the Senate.

The exchange highlights the ongoing tensions between Trump and his critics, with some seeing it as a sign of a deeper divide within the Republican Party.

**Trump Meets with Moderate Lawmakers, Suggests Wealthy May Face Higher Taxes**

Washington D.C. - In a bid to promote bipartisanship, President Donald Trump met with a group of moderate lawmakers from both parties on Wednesday, sparking speculation about potential tax reform and the possibility of higher taxes for the wealthy.

During the meeting, Trump expressed his willingness to work with Democrats to pass a tax reform package, which could include increasing taxes for the wealthy. "If they have to go higher, they'll go higher, frankly," Trump said, adding that the goal is to benefit the middle class and create jobs.

The meeting comes just a week after Trump made a deal with Democratic leaders Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi to raise the debt ceiling, which some Republicans criticized as a betrayal. Trump's willingness to work with Democrats has raised concerns among some Republicans, who oppose tax hikes.

However, some moderate Republicans, such as Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), are open to considering the idea of higher taxes for the wealthy. "That's not a non-starter for me," Meadows said.

The meeting also included a private dinner at the White House with Democratic leaders Schumer and Pelosi, which some saw as a sign of Trump's willingness to partner with Democrats on key issues. Trump has argued that cutting taxes and simplifying the tax code will spur economic growth and help communities affected by recent hurricanes.

While some Republicans are skeptical about the connection between tax reform and hurricane relief, others see it as a way to address the needs of affected communities. "They want to see a deal on the table," said Rep. Mark Sanford (R-S.C.), referring to conservative voters.

Despite the uncertainty surrounding the specifics of Trump's tax plan, the meeting has sparked a renewed focus on the issue of tax reform and the potential for bipartisan cooperation.

**Title:** Census Citizenship Question Debate Continues to Stir Controversy

**Article:**

The debate surrounding the inclusion of a citizenship question on the 2020 census has sparked intense controversy, with legal and political experts weighing in on the potential consequences. The Trump administration's efforts to add the question have been met with resistance from advocacy groups, demographers, and even the Census Bureau's own staff, who argue that it could lead to an undercount of residents in Democratic-leaning areas.

The question, which asks respondents if they are U.S. citizens, has been a contentious issue since its introduction. Critics argue that it could scare off undocumented immigrants from participating in the census, leading to an inaccurate count and potentially benefiting the Republican party. The Supreme Court blocked the question in June, citing the administration's "contrived" rationale for its inclusion.

Despite the setback, the Trump administration is exploring alternative explanations for adding the question, and the president has hinted at using an executive order to force its inclusion. However, legal experts have dismissed these ideas, saying it would be difficult to convince the courts that a new explanation is not also contrived.

The controversy has already had an impact on the census process, with some experts warning that the constant media coverage linking citizenship and census forms could depress participation rates, particularly in communities with high immigrant and Latino populations. This could lead to an undercount of residents and potentially benefit the Republican party.

The debate highlights the importance of the census, which is required by the U.S. Constitution to count all residents, regardless of their legal status. The information collected becomes the basis for voting maps and the distribution of federal funds. The stakes are high, with an accurate count crucial for ensuring fair representation and resource allocation.

As the debate continues, experts agree that the controversy surrounding the citizenship question has already had an impact on the census process, and the consequences of its inclusion or exclusion will be far-reaching.

Title: UN Event on Cuban Political Prisoners Descends into Chaos as Diplomats Clash

Article:

A recent event at the United Nations (UN) focused on the plight of political prisoners in Cuba turned into a chaotic scene as diplomats from Bolivia and Cuba disrupted the proceedings. The event, titled "Jailed for What? The Plight of Cuba's Political Prisoners," was held in the UN's Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) chamber.

The event aimed to raise awareness about the situation of political prisoners in Cuba, with speakers including former prisoners and relatives of those currently imprisoned under the communist regime. However, the discussion was derailed when diplomats from Bolivia and Cuba, including Bolivian Ambassador Sacha Llorenti, began banging on tables and shouting slogans.

The US Ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, has condemned the behavior of the Cuban and Bolivian delegations, calling it "outrageous" and demanding action from UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. In a letter to Guterres, Haley stated that the event became a "mob scene" and resulted in significant damage to UN property. She also called for the Cuban and Bolivian delegations to pay for the damage they caused.

The UN initially said that the US would be contacted to pay for the damage, but later decided that the UN would bear the cost. Haley has expressed her disappointment and frustration with this decision, stating that the US, as the largest contributor to the UN budget, should not be responsible for the damage.

The Cuban Mission has responded by calling for an investigation into how the event was allowed to take place, describing it as a "political comedy staged on false arguments" and accusing the US of trying to undermine the UN's legitimacy. The Bolivian and Cuban delegations did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The UN's spokesman, Stephane Dujarric, stated that missions must certify that public meetings are consistent with the purposes and principles of the UN and that they are non-commercial in nature. He also noted that it is not the role of UN security to remove disruptive delegates unless they pose a physical threat.

The event's organizer, US ECOSOC Ambassador Kelley Currie, described the behavior of the Cuban delegation as "shocking and disturbing" and expressed concern about the implications for the UN's reputation.

The incident highlights the ongoing tensions between the US and Cuba, as well as the challenges faced by the UN in maintaining a neutral and impartial stance in the face of diplomatic disagreements.

Title: The Unfortunate Exit of Rick Perry from the 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

The recent withdrawal of Rick Perry from the 2016 presidential race is a disappointment, not just for the Republican Party, but for the country as a whole. Perry's experience as the governor of Texas, where he oversaw a thriving economy and upward mobility for middle-class families, is a story that should be told and shared with the rest of the nation.

Perry's record in Texas is a testament to the success of Republican governance, with the state's diverse population, including ethnic, religious, and cultural groups, experiencing economic growth and prosperity. This is a story that Republicans should be eager to share with the rest of the country, showcasing a possible future where America is thriving.

The debates, while necessary, are not the only measure of a presidential candidate's qualifications. Perry's deficiencies in debating may have contributed to his low polling numbers, but this does not necessarily mean he was not qualified to be president. In fact, his experience as governor of Texas, where he oversaw a diverse and thriving economy, makes him a more credible candidate than some of his opponents.

The media's focus on opinion polls and the Republican National Committee's surrender to these polls have created an environment where candidates like Ben Carson, Mike Huckabee, and Donald Trump have gained traction, while more qualified candidates like Perry have been overlooked. This is a travesty, as it prioritizes entertainment and novelty over substance and experience.

Perry's withdrawal from the race is a loss for the party and the country, as his story of success in Texas could have been a powerful narrative to share with the nation. It is not a reflection of his abilities as a candidate, but rather a result of the flawed system that prioritizes polls and media attention over substance and experience.

Title: Neighborhood Disparities Leave Minority Children at a Disadvantage

A recent study by researchers at Brandeis University and Ohio State University has shed light on the stark disparities in neighborhood opportunities across the United States. The Child Opportunity Index, which analyzed data from diversitydatakids.org, reveals that minority children are more likely to live in disadvantaged neighborhoods with limited access to essential resources, such as early childhood education centers, parks, and healthcare facilities.

The study found that approximately 40% of black children and 32% of Hispanic children live in the lowest-opportunity neighborhoods in their areas, compared to just 9% of white children. These disparities are not limited to any particular city or region, but are a nationwide issue.

The consequences of these disparities can be far-reaching and long-lasting. Research has shown that living in a disadvantaged neighborhood can have a negative impact on a child's education and overall well-being, equivalent to missing a year or more of school. This can have a lasting impact, even after the child moves out of the area.

The study highlights the need for policymakers and community leaders to address these disparities and work towards creating more equitable opportunities for all children. By providing access to quality education, healthcare, and other essential resources, we can help level the playing field and give minority children a better chance at success.

In conclusion, the Child Opportunity Index's findings serve as a stark reminder of the need for action to address the systemic issues that perpetuate these disparities. By working together, we can create a more just and equitable society for all children, regardless of their race or background.

Title: Trump's Navy Secretary Nominee Withdraws, Citing Concerns Over Privacy and Business Interests

Article:

In a surprise move, Philip Bilden, the nominee for Secretary of the Navy, has withdrawn from consideration for the post, citing concerns over privacy and the difficulty of separating himself from his business interests. This marks the second Trump nominee to withdraw from a military-related position, following Vincent Viola's decision to step down as nominee for Secretary of the Army earlier this month.

Bilden, a former Army Reserve intelligence officer, had been tapped by President Trump to lead the Navy. However, he ultimately decided that he would not be able to satisfy the Office of Government Ethics' requirements without "undue disruption and materially adverse divestment of my family's private financial interests," according to his statement.

The news comes as the Trump administration faces scrutiny over its ties to Russia, with Bilden's withdrawal adding to the growing list of controversies surrounding the White House. Bilden's decision to withdraw was met with a statement from Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, who expressed understanding for Bilden's decision and promised to recommend a new nominee in the coming days.

Bilden's withdrawal is the latest in a string of setbacks for the Trump administration, which has seen several high-profile nominees withdraw or face criticism over their qualifications and potential conflicts of interest. The Navy Secretary position remains unfilled, with no clear indication of when a new nominee will be announced.

In his statement, Bilden expressed his regret over the decision to withdraw, but emphasized the importance of prioritizing his family's financial interests. "I informed Secretary of Defense Mattis with regret that I respectfully withdraw from consideration as nominee for the 76th Secretary of the Navy," he said.

The withdrawal of Bilden and Viola's earlier decision to step down as Army Secretary nominee have raised questions about the Trump administration's ability to attract qualified candidates for key positions. The White House has faced criticism over its handling of the nomination process, with some arguing that the administration is prioritizing loyalty over expertise.

As the search for a new Navy Secretary nominee continues, the Trump administration will be under increased scrutiny to ensure that its next pick is qualified and free from potential conflicts of interest.

**House Republicans Scramble for Leadership as McCarthy Withdraws from Speaker's Race**

The House Republican Conference is in disarray after Representative Kevin McCarthy announced he would not pursue the speakership, leaving the party without a clear leader and no apparent line of succession. The sudden decision has sent shockwaves through the Capitol, with many lawmakers scrambling to find a new candidate to fill the void.

McCarthy's decision was reportedly due to concerns about the challenges he would face as speaker, including the same issues that plagued his predecessor, John Boehner. He also faced criticism for his role in creating the Select Committee on Benghazi, which some saw as a political ploy to harm Hillary Clinton's presidential prospects.

With McCarthy out of the running, Wisconsin Representative Paul Ryan is now seen as the top contender for the speakership. Ryan has been approached by top Republicans, including Boehner and McCarthy, to reconsider his bid. He has cancelled his fundraising appearances for the next 48 hours and is considering a run.

Other lawmakers are also being floated as potential candidates, including Representatives Lynn Westmoreland of Georgia, Mike Conaway and Bill Flores of Texas, John Kline of Minnesota, and Tom Cole of Oklahoma. Some of these lawmakers are seen as caretakers who could hold the office until after the 2016 elections.

The House Freedom Caucus, a bloc of roughly 40 Republicans, has endorsed Representative Daniel Webster of Florida and vowed to vote together in the closed party election. This development has made it clear that McCarthy's path to the speakership was unlikely.

The sudden leadership vacuum has left the House Republican Conference in disarray, with many lawmakers scrambling to find a new candidate to fill the void. The party's special conference meeting on Friday will aim to get lawmakers on the same page and find a new leader.

In a statement, McCarthy said the party needs a "new face" and that he did not want to win the job with the bare minimum level of support. The search for a new leader is expected to be a long and challenging process, but one that is necessary for the party to move forward.

Title: President Honors Heroes of Recent Mass Shootings, Commemorates Bravery and Sacrifice

Article:

In a solemn ceremony at the White House, President Trump honored six law enforcement officers and five civilians who risked their lives to save others during the recent mass shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas. The President recognized the bravery and selflessness of these individuals, who confronted the shooters and prevented further harm to innocent civilians.

The law enforcement officers, who received the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor, were Sgt. William Knight and Officers Brian Rolfes, Jeremy Campbell, Vincent Carter, Ryan Nabel, and David Denlinger. They responded swiftly to the shooting in Dayton, Ohio, and their actions are credited with preventing more deaths. Although it is unclear which officer fired the fatal shots that killed the gunman, Connor Betts, their bravery and quick response undoubtedly saved lives.

The five civilians honored by the President, Robert Evans, Gilbert Serna, Marisela Luna, Angelica Silva, and Chris Grant, risked their own lives to help others during the El Paso shooting. Chris Grant, who was still recovering from gunshot wounds, threw bottles and merchandise at the gunman to distract him and prevent further harm. Grant's actions, along with those of the other civilians, demonstrate the power of human compassion and bravery in the face of danger.

The President praised the 11 individuals for their courage and selflessness, stating, "In the darkness moments of danger and despair, God calls the bravest to action. These 11 individuals answered the call. They stared down evil. They put love of neighbor above life itself, and we are blessed by their courage. We are honored by their presence."

The recent mass shootings have sparked a national conversation about gun control, with Democrats and mayors from affected cities urging the Senate and White House to take action on House bills calling for stricter background checks. While the President has expressed support for tougher background checks in the past, he has also questioned their value and praised the National Rifle Association (NRA). The President's comments on gun control have been met with criticism from some, who argue that more needs to be done to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.

Title: Kerry's Claims on Iran's Nuclear Program Under Scrutiny

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry's recent announcement of a nuclear deal with Iran has sparked debate and criticism, with some questioning the agreement's effectiveness in curbing the country's nuclear ambitions. In a news conference, Kerry sought to address one of the main concerns: that the deal allows Iran to continue enriching uranium, despite international sanctions and resolutions declaring the activity illegal.

Kerry pointed to Iran's rapid expansion of its nuclear program, citing the country's initial offer to the Bush administration in 2003, which had 164 centrifuges. He noted that since then, the number of centrifuges has grown to 19,000, making it difficult to negotiate restrictions on the program.

However, a closer examination of reports from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and analyses from leading research institutions reveals that the majority of Iran's enrichment capability came online during the Obama administration. According to estimates, Iran had around 3,000 centrifuges by late 2007, and it's likely that the number increased during the Bush-Cheney era, but not to the current level.

This means that roughly 74% of Iran's current centrifuges were installed since the Obama-Biden team took office. Analysts note that around 10,000 of these centrifuges are actively enriching uranium to low levels, consistent with nuclear energy production but not necessarily nuclear weapons production.

Kerry's claims about the history of the Iranian nuclear program have been met with skepticism, with some critics pointing out that his concise timeline omitted significant events and milestones. The secretary's spokesman, Jen Psaki, acknowledged that Iran has made progress on enrichment and developing a nuclear weapon, but emphasized the focus on halting and rolling back the program.

The debate surrounding the nuclear deal and Iran's nuclear program is far from over, with Secretary Kerry set to testify before Congress on December 10. As the discussion continues, it's essential to consider the complexities and nuances of the issue, rather than relying on simplistic narratives or cherry-picked facts.

Title: Senate Vote on Iran Nuclear Deal: A Critical Juncture for International Diplomacy

Article:

The Iran nuclear deal, a complex agreement between six world powers and Iran, is facing a crucial test in the United States Senate. Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon has announced his support for the deal, bringing the total number of senators backing the pact to 31. This development puts President Barack Obama just three votes short of securing the necessary support to protect the deal in Congress.

Merkley's statement highlights the deal's potential benefits, stating that it is the "best available strategy to block Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon." The senator acknowledges that the deal has its shortcomings, including the lifting of sanctions on Iran's conventional arms and ballistic missile technology after a certain period. However, he believes that rejecting the deal would undermine international efforts to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear program.

The Republican-controlled Congress has until September 17 to pass a resolution disapproving the deal, which would require a two-thirds majority in the Senate. If the resolution passes, President Obama has pledged to veto it. The Senate's decision will have significant implications for international diplomacy and the global community's efforts to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

While some Democratic senators remain undecided, Merkley's support brings the total number of Democratic supporters to 31. The remaining 13 Democratic senators have yet to declare their position, and their decisions will be crucial in determining the fate of the deal. Republican Senator Susan Collins of Maine is the only undecided Republican, and her decision is expected to be announced after September 7.

The debate surrounding the Iran nuclear deal highlights the complexities of international diplomacy and the challenges of balancing national interests with global security concerns. As the Senate deliberates, the world waits with bated breath to see whether the deal will be approved, and what implications this will have for global relations and nuclear non-proliferation efforts.

Title: The Impeachment Inquiry: A Test of Loyalty and Principles

Article:

The recent announcement of impeachment proceedings against President Trump has sparked a flurry of reactions, with some Republicans rallying behind the president and others expressing concerns about the potential consequences. As a lifelong Republican who voted for Trump, I have been fascinated by the prospect of a president running for reelection while facing impeachment. However, my fascination has turned to concern as I've witnessed the Trump campaign and allied GOP organizations using the impeachment inquiry as a fundraising tool.

The messages I've received, which parrot and operationalize the strategic concepts I wrote about in September 2018, assume that as a Republican, I will overlook and excuse Trump's behavior no matter how egregious and potentially impeachable. I resent this assumption and am proud to be an American who values the Constitution, separation of powers, and the well-being of our nation before my party.

The questions that linger are: Will Republican elected leaders and voters stand with President Trump no matter what, even if the evidence proves he violated his oath of office? Is our nation careening towards a monumental constitutional crisis that will plunge our nation into an "uncivil war"? These questions hammer home why this is a difficult time for me to be a Republican who cares about how Trump's behavior sets a precedent for future presidents.

As a Republican, I am concerned that my party will be perceived as prioritizing loyalty over principle. I urge my fellow Republicans to consider the long-term implications of our actions and to prioritize the well-being of our nation over party loyalty.

Title: Michelle Obama's Campaign Trail: A Force to Be Reckoned With

Article:

Michelle Obama, the First Lady of the United States, has been making waves on the campaign trail, stumping for key 2013 races and raising money for Democratic candidates. Her appearances have been met with enthusiasm, with her approval ratings remaining high at 65% according to Gallup. Her husband, President Barack Obama, has yet to campaign for any of these candidates, leaving Michelle to take center stage.

Michelle's appearances have been strategic, with her focusing on key races and issues that align with her husband's administration's priorities. Her pitch is that by supporting these candidates, voters are helping her husband's cause, and Republicans are struggling to find a charismatic foil to match her appeal.

Larry Sabato, director of the Center for Politics at the University of Virginia, notes that Michelle's appearances are a great draw for big crowds, and she has little of the downside presented by her husband's controversies. "People assume that the first lady is not involved in Oval Office skullduggery, and usually this is the correct evaluation," he said.

Michelle's appearances have been successful, with her raising an estimated $600,000 for Rep. Edward J. Markey's Senate bid in Massachusetts and attending the Democratic National Committee's Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Leadership gala in New York City.

While some speculate that Michelle's appearances could be an early sign of her potential candidacy for office, Professor Sabato believes she will likely move on to other pursuits once her husband's term ends. "I'd be willing to bet Michelle Obama won't run for office," he said. "While she's clearly enjoying the platform her current unofficial office brings, she wouldn't have chosen politics as the family profession."

Regardless of her future plans, Michelle Obama's appearances on the campaign trail have been a boon for Democratic candidates, and her popularity shows no signs of waning.

**Title:** Trump's Transparency: A Path to Rebuilding Trust in Government

**Article:**

As President-elect Donald Trump prepares to take office, he will face widespread skepticism about his legitimacy. His opponents will likely portray him as governing in unprecedented and reckless ways. However, the best response to such charges is to open the books and expose how the Obama administration commandeered more power than most Americans realized.

Trump should follow the excellent precedent set by President Obama, who released many secret Bush administration legal memos in 2009, explaining why the president was entitled to order torture, deploy troops in American towns and cities, and ignore the Fourth Amendment's prohibition on warrantless, unreasonable searches. This move signaled a new era in Washington and helped Obama earn a reputation as a champion of civil liberties.

In turn, Trump should quickly reveal the secret memos underlying Obama's "targeted killing" drone assassination program. Administration lawyers defeated lawsuits by the ACLU, The New York Times, and others seeking disclosure of key legal papers on how the president became judge, jury, and executioner. A Trump administration could disclose the memos and white papers without endangering anything other than the reputation of the soon-to-be former president and his policymakers.

Trump should also reveal the paper trail preceding and following the U.S. bombing of Libya in 2011. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton labeled the U.S. attack on Libya as "smart power at its best," but the nation has been in chaos ever since the U.S. joined an assault commenced by France and Britain. What did the U.S. government know and when did it know it regarding the likely effects of toppling Libyan dictator Moammar Gadhafi?

Laying out the record could help prevent similar follies in the future. It is naive to assume that "truth will out" from federal bureaucracies. The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) has become largely a mirage. While Obama boasted of "the most transparent administration in history," federal agencies slammed the door on routine requests – especially from the media. The Associated Press reported in 2015 that the Obama administration "set a record again for censoring government files or outright denying access to them" under FOIA.

Trump's promise to end and replace the Affordable Care Act would be greatly assisted by releasing the memos behind Obama's endless "fixes" to that law. For instance, a van-load of senior IRS financial managers were summoned in 2014 to the Old Executive Office Building and only permitted a peek at a secret Office of Management and Budget memo explaining why the Obama administration was entitled to spend $3.9 billion on subsidies for consumer health insurance. As The New York Times reported last year, the IRS officials "were told they could read it but could not take notes or make copies."

Many sweeping regulations have lately been rushed into law with shaky rationales or scant evidence. Obama relied on "bureaucratic bulldozing rather than legislative transparency," according to The New York Times, issuing 50% more "major regulations" than the George W. Bush administration. The Environmental Protection Agency and other agencies have been scandalized by switcheroos to suppress information federal law required them to disclose. Opening the books would be especially helpful for the torrent of midnight edicts the Obama team has issued in recent months.

Recent polls show that fewer than 20% of Americans now trust the federal government. Excessive secrecy spurs many Americans to presume that their rulers are up to no good. Regardless of the policies that Trump chooses, it would be a booster shot for democracy to reveal the back story of the Obama era.

Title: The Gender Pay Gap: A Persistent Issue in the Modern Workplace

Article:

Tuesday marked Equal Pay Day, a day designated by the National Committee on Pay Equity to highlight the ongoing struggle for equal pay between men and women. The day serves as a reminder that, despite progress made since the Equal Pay Act was signed in 1963, the gender pay gap remains a stubborn issue in the modern workplace.

According to the latest census data, women working full-time year-round typically earn 78 cents for every dollar earned by their male counterparts. While this may seem like progress, closer examination reveals that the gap has stalled over the past decade. The Institute for Women's Policy Research reports that, in 2014, the ratio of female-to-male weekly earnings was 82.5 percent.

Research by the Economic Policy Institute shows that men outearn women at every rung of the income ladder, with the gap widening as one moves up the ladder. Women in the 95th percentile of earners made 79 percent of what men in the same percentile earned, while those in the lowest 10th percentile made 91 cents for every dollar earned by their male counterparts.

The gender pay gap is also pronounced among college-educated workers. Men and women who have attended but did not graduate from college have the narrowest gap, with women making about 80 percent of what men made. Among those who have graduated from college, women's pay is about 78 percent of men's pay, and among those with advanced degrees, women make about 74 percent of what men make.

The data suggests that corporate norms and the minimum wage are significant factors influencing pay scales. While policies differ from company to company, the result is that women are still paid less than men. Even at the low end of the income ladder, women in low-wage jobs are paid less than men in low-wage jobs.

The persistence of the gender pay gap highlights the need for continued efforts to address the issue. As the National Committee on Pay Equity notes, the longer the gap persists, the less it can be explained away by factors other than discrimination. It is essential to recognize that the gender pay gap is not just a women's issue, but a societal issue that affects families, communities, and the economy as a whole.

Title: The EPA's Regulatory Overreach: A Critical Examination of the Tier 3 Sulfur Rules

Article:

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has issued over 1,920 regulations since President Obama's inauguration, many of which have been criticized for their lack of environmental and health benefits, but significant economic and unemployment costs. The latest example is the Tier 3 sulfur rule, which aims to further reduce sulfur in gasoline, but experts argue that it will have minimal, if any, health benefits.

According to the Heritage Foundation, the EPA's 20 major rule-making decisions, costing $100 million or more annually, could cost the United States more than $36 billion per year. The Tier 3 rules, in particular, are expected to cost $10 billion in upfront capital expenditures and an additional $2.4 billion in annual compliance expenses, which will raise the price of gasoline by 6 to 9 cents a gallon.

The article highlights the significant progress made in reducing air pollution since 1970, with cars eliminating 99% of pollutants that once came out of tailpipes. The current fleet of vehicles is essentially zero-emission, and the ongoing reduction in on-road emissions has led to improved air quality.

However, the EPA's Tier 3 rules aim to reduce sulfur levels to 10 parts per million, despite the agency's own computer models showing that this would yield essentially no air quality or health benefits. The article notes that the reduction would be equivalent to saving 5 to 12 cents out of $100 million, a tiny improvement that would not even be measurable by equipment existing two decades ago.

The article also criticizes the EPA's approach, which assumes that there is no safe threshold level for pollutants and that they must constantly be ratcheted downward, eventually to zero. This flies in the face of what any competent epidemiologist knows: the dose makes the poison. The article notes that there are chemicals that are essential to proper bodily function at low or trace quantities but become poisonous at higher doses.

The article concludes that the EPA's actions are forcing the country to expend vast financial, human, and technological resources to achieve minimal, or even zero, quantifiable health benefits. It calls for science-based standards and common-sense regulations, and argues that scrapping the unnecessary Tier 3 rules is a good place to start.

Title: The Invisible Women of ISIS: Unveiling the Radicalization of Muslim Women

Article:

The recent reports of an estimated 30 Muslim women from the West, mostly from Britain, joining the Islamic State (ISIS) have sent shockwaves through the global community. However, this phenomenon is not new, as Muslim women have long been a potent force in Islamic jihad. In fact, experts at the Kings College International Center for Radicalization in Britain have been monitoring the online activities of 21 women among the 500 Britons thought to be in Syria with ISIS, revealing that they often attract other women to the extremist group.

These women are drawn to ISIS for various reasons, including a desire to help build the new Islamic State, as called for by ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, or to take on traditional roles such as marriage and childbearing. Others are attracted to the group's call for skilled workers, such as doctors, nurses, and engineers. However, some women are also seeking combat and are joining to wage war.

The British female jihadists are often young, including 16-year-old twins Zara and Salma Halane, 20-year-old Aqsa Mahmoud, and 22-year-old Khadija Dare, who reportedly aspires to be the first ISIS female to behead an "infidel." In the United States, the recent case of 19-year-old Sharon Conley of Colorado is a chilling example of an American female newly converted to Islam and seeking jihad.

Female Islamists, including violent jihadists, have long been prominent. In 2010, Afia Siddiqui, a neuroscientist from Pakistan, was found guilty of attempted murder of U.S. personnel investigating her material support to Al Qaeda. She is now serving an 86-year sentence in federal prison.

Experts note that women have always been swept up by the romance of jihad, just like men. At their most extreme, female jihadists become suicide bombers, as seen in the case of the female Tamil Tigers, who developed the tactic of suicide bombing, which was later adopted by Hezbollah and used during the Second Intifada against Israel.

Radical clerics have issued fatwas legitimizing women as suicide bombers, and some women are motivated by a desire to absolve themselves of sin or to prove their militant credentials. The point is that each woman sees herself as an active jihadist.

The rise of ISIS has brought attention to the brutalities committed against women, including executions, stonings, rape, child marriage, forced marriage, and slavery. However, less attention has been given to women who choose to participate in ISIS as perpetrators, rather than as victims.

Islamist ideology is inherently supremacist, racist, and expansionist, and it is also anti-Semitic and misogynistic. Regardless of what attracts them, women jihadists serve a fleeting purpose for ISIS, and they are unaware that they will progressively lose their freedoms as they empower Islamism through their actions.

Western women are joining ISIS nonetheless, and Americans must recognize the deadly ideology that attracts them for what it is: lethally totalitarian, misogynistic, anti-Semitic, supremacist, and profoundly anti-democratic. By unveiling these invisible women for the radical Jihadists they truly are, we can begin to confront Islamist ideology for what it is: a singularly lethal assault upon our sacred ideals.

Title: Congressional Hispanic Caucus Members Removed from Meeting with ICE, Citing Unprecedented Exclusion

Article:

In a rare and unprecedented move, two members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus (CHC) were removed from a meeting with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) on Thursday. Representatives Luis Gutiérrez of Illinois and Norma Torres of California claimed that Republicans asked them to leave the meeting, which was initially scheduled to discuss the recent rash of raids on immigrant communities.

Gutiérrez expressed shock and disappointment, stating that he had never experienced such an incident in his 20-plus years in Congress. "In 20-plus years, I have never heard of the Republicans controlling what meetings Democrats can have with officials of the executive branch and never had a staffer ask me to leave a meeting to which I am entitled to attend," he said in a statement.

The meeting was arranged by the House minority leader, Nancy Pelosi, who revealed that ICE determined the guest list. Initially, the list excluded all members of the CHC, but Democrats were able to convince ICE to invite the caucus chairwoman, Michelle Lujan Grisham.

Immigrant rights groups are bracing for more deportation raids, with some calling it "the beginning" of a new era of mass deportations. The raids, which have already resulted in the arrest of over 680 undocumented immigrants, have sparked widespread concern and outrage.

The CHC members had initiated the meeting with ICE to discuss the raids, which have been criticized as a "crackdown on illegal criminals" by President Donald Trump. However, the meeting was canceled at the last minute, with ICE citing concerns over the size of the meeting and the need for it to be bipartisan.

The incident has sparked a heated debate, with some lawmakers calling the explanation "bullshit" and others expressing frustration over the lack of transparency and inclusivity. The House speaker, Paul Ryan, defended the decision, stating that his office had organized the briefing and limited it to members with jurisdictional interests in immigration enforcement.

The incident has also sparked a national conversation about the impact of immigration policies on communities and the importance of protecting the rights of undocumented immigrants. As the debate continues, many are left wondering what the future holds for the millions of undocumented immigrants living in the United States.

Title: Trump's Controversial Tweets Spark Diplomatic Tensions on UK Visit

Article:

US President Donald Trump's arrival in the UK has sparked controversy, with his tweets targeting London Mayor Sadiq Khan and Meghan Markle, the Duchess of Sussex. Trump's comments have been met with widespread criticism, with many calling them "un-British" and "divisive."

In his tweets, Trump criticized Khan, calling him a "stone-cold loser" who should focus on crime in London instead of him. He also compared Khan to New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, saying they both have done a "terrible job." Khan had previously written an op-ed in the Observer, calling Trump one of the most egregious examples of a growing global threat and blaming him for stoking the rise of the far-right movement.

Trump's comments about Markle, who is on maternity leave, were also met with criticism. He denied calling her "nasty," despite an audio recording of his comments to The Sun newspaper, in which he used the word "nasty" to describe her. Markle had previously expressed her dislike for Trump during the 2016 presidential campaign, saying she would move to Canada if he were elected.

The controversy surrounding Trump's comments has sparked a heated debate about the role of the British government in hosting the US president. Some argue that the UK should not be rolling out the red carpet for Trump, given his divisive behavior and far-right views. Others believe that the UK should maintain its special relationship with the US, despite Trump's controversial comments.

The diplomatic kerfuffle has also raised questions about the role of social media in shaping public discourse. Trump's tweets have been widely shared and criticized, with many calling for him to be held accountable for his words. The incident highlights the importance of responsible communication and the need for leaders to be mindful of the impact their words can have on others.

As Trump's visit to the UK continues, it remains to be seen how the controversy will unfold and what implications it will have for the special relationship between the two countries.

Title: Hawaii Legislature to Consider Same-Sex Marriage Bill in Special Session

The Hawaii state legislature is set to convene in a special session on Monday to consider the Marriage Equality Act, which would allow same-sex couples to wed. The bill has sparked a heated debate in the state, with proponents arguing that it aligns with Hawaii's values of equality and tolerance, while opponents believe that the decision should be left to voters.

The debate is not new to Hawaii, as the state was at the forefront of the national discussion on same-sex marriage in the 1990s. In 1993, the state's supreme court ruled in favor of same-sex unions, but a constitutional amendment passed in 1998 took jurisdiction away from the courts and gave it to the legislature, which subsequently banned same-sex marriages.

Proponents of the bill, including Governor Neil Abercrombie, argue that it would be a step forward for the state's values of aloha and equality, and would also boost tourism. Opponents, on the other hand, believe that the decision should be left to voters and that the bill would undermine the democratic process.

The Episcopal Diocese of Hawaii has become the largest denomination to announce its support for the bill, with rallies and protests taking place in Honolulu over the weekend. A public hearing on the bill will be held as part of the special session on Monday.

If approved, the bill would take effect on November 18. Hawaii would become the 15th state to legalize same-sex marriage, joining the 14 states where it is already legal and the District of Columbia. Thirty-five states have enacted laws restricting marriage to opposite-sex couples.

The debate is expected to be intense, with both sides presenting their arguments and counterarguments. The outcome remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the issue of same-sex marriage is a complex and controversial one that will continue to be debated and discussed in the coming weeks and months.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Weigh In on Potential Prosecution of Trump

Article:

In a recent interview, Senator Kamala Harris, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, sparked controversy by stating that she believes former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's decision not to charge President Trump with obstruction of justice was due to the Justice Department's policy against indicting a sitting president. Harris emphasized that once Trump leaves office, he would be subject to charges and that the Department of Justice should pursue them.

Harris is not the only high-profile Democrat to suggest that Trump should face criminal charges once out of office. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has also made similar comments, stating that she wants to see Trump "in prison" rather than impeached. Other Democratic presidential candidates, including Senators Elizabeth Warren and Cory Booker, have also hinted that prosecuting Trump might be appropriate.

While some have criticized Pelosi's comments as "vindictive" and "nasty," others see her remarks as a necessary reminder that no one is above the law. Senator David Cicilline, a Democrat from Rhode Island, defended Pelosi's comments, comparing them to the "lock her up" chants that Trump inspired during his 2016 campaign against Hillary Clinton.

Senator Booker, on the other hand, emphasized the importance of upholding the rule of law and the independence of the Department of Justice. He stated that if his attorney general finds probable cause that a law has been broken, he would expect them to hold the alleged offender accountable, regardless of their title or past actions.

The debate surrounding Trump's potential prosecution highlights the ongoing tensions between the Democratic Party and the Trump administration. While some see it as a necessary step towards accountability, others view it as a political witch hunt. As the 2020 presidential election approaches, it remains to be seen how this issue will play out and what implications it will have for the country.

Title: NRCC's Fake News Sites: A New Low in Political Propaganda

Article:

The National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) has taken a bold step in its efforts to sway public opinion by creating a network of fake news websites that masquerade as local news outlets. Dubbed "Election Update 2014," these sites aim to deceive readers into believing they are reading unbiased news when, in reality, they are being fed Republican talking points.

The NRCC has created over two dozen of these fake news sites, each targeting a specific Democratic candidate or incumbent. The sites are designed to mimic the look and feel of local news websites, complete with sections for "Most Popular" articles and "Most Viewed" videos. However, upon closer inspection, it becomes clear that these articles are actually just rehashed Republican opposition research.

One example of these fake news sites is the "Tuscon Update," which targets Arizona Democrat Ron Barber. The article claims that Barber's office is facing questions about pay equality, citing the Arizona Daily Star as its source. However, a closer look reveals that the NRCC is actually the one doing the questioning, using its own research to make claims about Barber's office.

This tactic is a new low in political propaganda, as it eliminates the need for the NRCC to rely on lax ethics standards of certain cable news outlets to get its message out. Instead, they are taking matters into their own hands, creating fake news sites that blur the line between fact and fiction.

The NRCC's actions are a clear attempt to deceive the public and undermine the democratic process. It is essential that voters remain vigilant and not fall prey to these tactics.

Title: Tech Giants Face Criticism for Fostering Polarization and Confirmation Bias

Article:

Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos recently shared his thoughts on the current state of technology, specifically social media, at the Wired 25 conference. Bezos expressed concerns that social media companies are inadvertently fostering polarization and confirmation bias among their users. He believes that social media platforms are creating echo chambers, where users are only exposed to information that confirms their existing beliefs.

A 2017 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found that social media algorithms rely on confirmation biases to surface relevant content for users. This can lead to the creation of "well-shaped, highly segregated, and mostly non-interacting communities" around specific topics, including scientific and conspiracy-like subjects. Users tend to seek out information that confirms their pre-existing beliefs, rather than engaging with opposing viewpoints.

Facebook has recently removed over 800 pages and accounts that were spreading misinformation and fake news ahead of the midterm elections. Google's search algorithm has also been accused of political bias, with some critics arguing that it prioritizes certain search results over others. Twitter has faced similar criticism for allowing tribalistic abuse to run rampant on its platform.

Despite these concerns, Bezos remains optimistic about the potential of technology to drive progress and innovation. He believes that the benefits of technology, such as advancements in biotech, outweigh the risks. However, he also acknowledges that social media companies must take responsibility for the impact their platforms have on users.

Bezos' comments come as social media giants face increasing scrutiny over their role in shaping public discourse and promoting polarization. While some critics argue that social media companies are intentionally manipulating users, Bezos believes that the problem is more nuanced, and that the algorithms used by these platforms are simply a reflection of human nature.

Ultimately, Bezos believes that the key to addressing these issues is to encourage innovation and experimentation, rather than stifling progress. He argues that the benefits of technology, such as advancements in biotech, outweigh the risks, and that social media companies must take responsibility for the impact their platforms have on users.

**Title:** Don't Let Misleading Photos Fool You: Understanding Camera Tricks in Crowds

**Article:**

As the world slowly reopens, we're seeing a surge in photos and videos of crowded beaches, parks, and public spaces. But have you ever stopped to think about the camera tricks that might be at play? A common technique used by photographers is to use a zoom or telephoto lens, which compresses the foreground and background of a picture, making it appear as though people are closer together than they actually are.

This technique can be used to deliberately mislead, but it's also a way to capture the essence of a crowded scene without showing the vast distances between individuals. A photographer might use a long lens to get as much of the scene as possible, rather than trying to deceive the viewer.

To illustrate this point, consider an aerial photo of a beach, taken by the same photographer on the same day as a more zoomed-in shot. Look for the red and white umbrella in the lower left of the aerial shot, and the dark green umbrella at the top center. Now, compare these umbrellas in the two photos. From the original shot, you might think the green umbrella people are right up against the dark blue towel. But from the aerial view, it's clear they're quite far away. Using sunbathers as a scale, it's clear that people are actually maintaining a safe distance.

This camera trick isn't unique to still photos – it can also be used in videos. A recent tweet showed a boardwalk in Ocean City, Maryland, which appeared packed, but a closer look revealed that the camera lens was exaggerating the density. The video showed a man in a baby carrier appearing to be right behind a woman, but by the time the clip cut off, he was still behind her, 20 steps and 13 seconds later.

These misleading crowd shots are a problem as we reopen, as they can create unnecessary anxiety and tension. They make it seem like people are ignoring rules about physical distancing, when in reality, the situation might not be as dire as the photos suggest. Even restaurants that have reopened with strict distancing measures have been shown to be following the rules, but photos from a single angle might make it seem like they're not.

As we navigate this new normal, it's essential to be aware of these camera tricks and not jump to conclusions based on a single photo or video. Let's strive for accuracy and understanding, rather than fueling unnecessary fears and tensions.

**Title:** Republican Presidential Candidates Prepare for High-Stakes Debate as Campaign Enters New Phase

**Article:**

The Republican presidential campaign is gearing up for its next prime-time debate, with candidates vying for attention and momentum in the crowded field. The stakes are high, as the debate stage is expected to see a more combative tone, with candidates taking aim at each other and the issues.

Donald Trump, the long-time front-runner, is no longer invincible, thanks to the surge of Ben Carson, who has overtaken him in Iowa. Trump is expected to throw multiple punches at Carson, who has remained calm and reserved throughout the campaign. The real estate mogul has even suggested that Carson's religious affiliation, Seventh-day Adventism, is extreme.

Jeb Bush, meanwhile, is struggling to regain momentum after a series of consecutive polls showed him falling behind. His campaign is preparing to show a more muscular side, with Bush's advisers suggesting he may try to do just that on the debate stage.

Carly Fiorina, the star of the Republican debate team, is facing the challenge of translating her strong debate performances into lasting poll numbers. Her campaign has pushed back on suggestions that she is going from one breakout moment to the next, emphasizing that she is focused on winning over voters at a slow and steady pace.

The debate is also expected to focus on the economy and jobs, with the debt limit being a contentious issue among Republicans. Some candidates are expected to take a hardline stance against raising the debt ceiling, while others may argue that spending cuts make it worth it.

Four candidates, Mike Huckabee, Chris Christie, John Kasich, and Rand Paul, are struggling to gain traction and are under pressure to boost their rankings and persuade donors to keep funding their campaigns.

The debate will be a test of endurance for all candidates, with the challenge of persuading viewers not to change the channel. With the Iowa caucuses just three months away, every moment counts for the White House hopefuls.

Title: Former Governor Mark Sanford Seeks Redemption in Congressional Race

Article:

Former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford is seeking redemption in the Republican primary for the state's 1st Congressional District. Sanford, who was previously forced to resign as governor after admitting to an extramarital affair, is one of 16 candidates vying for the open seat.

The opportunity to run for Congress arose after Republican Representative Tim Scott was appointed to the Senate, leaving the congressional seat vacant. Sanford, who previously held the seat, is hoping to make a comeback and win the public's trust once again.

In an interview with CNN, Sanford acknowledged that his past mistakes have made him a target for his opponents. However, he believes that his honesty about his personal struggles has made him more relatable to voters.

"I think you learn from the valleys of life rather than the peaks," Sanford said.

Sanford's opponents, including Teddy Turner, the son of CNN founder Ted Turner, are using his past mistakes against him. Turner has been gaining popularity in internal polls and has the backing of his family's deep pockets. However, opponents are filling mailboxes with attack ads, tying him to one of his father's ex-wives, Jane Fonda.

The winner of the Republican primary will likely face off against Democratic candidate Elizabeth Colbert Busch, the sister of comedian Stephen Colbert. Colbert Busch has been gaining momentum in the race and has been emphasizing the importance of the election.

The race is expected to be a tight contest, with many of the candidates vying for the public's attention. State Senator Larry Grooms is another contender, with a strong local endorsement and a staff that includes former Rick Santorum spokesman Hogan Gidley.

John Avlon, a CNN political contributor, believes that Sanford's honesty about his personal struggles has made him more relatable to voters. "There is an affection for a guy who admits he's a sinner and asks for forgiveness, especially down here," Avlon said.

Despite his past mistakes, Sanford is asking the public for a second chance. "At some level or another, we all hope for redemption," he said.

The election is set to take place on Tuesday, with the winner likely to face off against Colbert Busch in the general election.

Title: Trump's Top Strategist Steve Bannon's Future in Jeopardy

Article:

Speculation is growing that Steve Bannon, the chief executive of the conservative news site Breitbart News and a key strategist for President Donald Trump's campaign, may be on his way out of the White House. The rumors come after a string of policy blunders have left Trump's administration reeling.

In a recent interview, Trump was asked about his confidence in Bannon, to which he responded that Bannon was not involved in his campaign until late in the game. This response has sparked concerns that Trump may be distancing himself from Bannon, potentially signaling the end of his tenure as a key advisor.

Historically, Trump has used this tactic to distance himself from associates who have become embroiled in controversy. This includes Paul Manafort and Michael Flynn, who were both implicated in the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

While it is unclear whether Trump's comments are a sign that he is planning to fire Bannon, they do suggest that the relationship between the two is strained. As a key strategist, Bannon has been a vocal advocate for Trump's agenda, but his association with the president has also raised concerns about the administration's ties to white nationalist groups.

Regardless of the outcome, Bannon's departure would mark a significant shift in the Trump administration's inner circle. As a key advisor, Bannon has played a significant role in shaping Trump's policy decisions, and his departure could signal a change in the administration's direction.

For now, it remains to be seen whether Bannon will remain a key player in the Trump administration or if he will be replaced by another advisor. One thing is certain, however: the drama surrounding Bannon's future is sure to continue to captivate the nation.

Title: Fact-Checking a Viral Claim: Bernie Sanders' Tax Proposal

Article:

A recent social media storm has been circulating a claim that 2020 presidential candidate Bernie Sanders proposed a 52% tax rate on incomes above $29,000. The claim has been shared widely on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and Reddit, with some posts even linking it to Sanders' signature proposal, Medicare for All. However, a closer examination of the facts reveals that this claim is false.

The claim likely originated from a memo released by Sanders' Senate office ahead of the introduction of the Medicare for All Act of 2019. The memo discusses different tax proposals to finance the healthcare program, including a progressive income tax schedule with a 52% tax rate, but only applied to incomes over $10 million. Another option proposed is a 7.5% payroll tax, exempting the first $2 million in payroll to protect small businesses. A final option is a 4% income-based premium applicable to all households making more than $29,000.

However, a review of the transcript of the ninth Democratic debate, hosted on February 19, 2020, in Las Vegas, Nevada, shows that no one mentioned a 52% tax rate on incomes above $29,000. Former South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg mentioned the figure $29,000 twice, but not in the context of a tax proposal.

In the debate, Buttigieg did question Sanders' plan to finance Medicare for All, citing a "multi-trillion-dollar hole" and asking where the remaining funds would come from. Sanders responded by mentioning a payroll tax and a wealth tax, which would be used to fund the program.

The claim that Bernie Sanders plans to tax anyone making above $29,000 a year 52% is therefore false. It is essential to verify information before sharing it on social media to avoid spreading misinformation.

**The GOP Establishment's Record of Failure: A Pattern of Disappointment**

The Republican Party's establishment has a long history of choosing candidates who fail to deliver. From Mitt Romney to John McCain, Bob Dole, and the Bushes, the list of failed candidates is long and storied. Even when establishment candidates do win office, their presidencies are often marked by disappointment and a lack of significant achievements.

In the Senate, the Republican establishment has a similar track record of failure. Senators like Ted Cruz, Mike Lee, Rand Paul, and Marco Rubio, who were once considered outsiders, have been co-opted by the establishment and have failed to deliver on their promises.

The GOP establishment's record of choosing candidates is a lesson in abject failure. They have lost elections and even when they win, the results are often disappointing. In contrast, Sarah Palin's record of choosing candidates has been marked by success, with candidates like Cruz, Lee, Paul, and Rubio going on to achieve significant victories.

As the 2014 elections approach, 13 Republican senators face re-election, with an average tenure in Washington of over 18 years. During their time in office, federal spending has nearly doubled, and the national debt has tripled. It is time for these senators to take a hard look at their record and consider the impact of their actions on the country.

The Republican National Committee should listen to its grass-roots voters and allow them to choose their own candidates. The Real Conservatives National Committee, a new independent organization, is working to break the grip of the GOP establishment and elect real conservative leaders.

In conclusion, the GOP establishment's record of failure is a stark reminder that it is time for change. It is time to take a page out of Sarah Palin's playbook and take on the establishment. The future of the Republican Party and the country depends on it.

Title: Florida's New Gun Control Measures Face Legal Challenge from the National Rifle Association

Article:
