Despite the controversy, the RAISE Act is unlikely to pass Congress in its current form, with many lawmakers on both sides of the aisle expressing reservations. The debate is likely to continue, with both sides presenting their arguments and counterarguments in the coming weeks and months.

Title: Obama's Approval Rating Remains Steady Amidst Controversies

Article:

A recent national poll conducted by CNN/ORC International has found that President Barack Obama's approval rating has remained steady, despite a tumultuous week in Washington. The survey, which was conducted on May 17-18, showed that 53% of Americans approve of the job the president is doing, while 45% disapprove.

The poll also found that congressional Republicans are not overplaying their hand when it comes to their reaction to the three controversies that have consumed the nation's capital over the past week and a half. The controversies in question include the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) targeting of tea party and other conservative groups, the Benghazi attack in Libya, and the Justice Department's secret collection of phone records from the Associated Press.

According to the survey, more than seven in 10 Americans say that the IRS's actions were unacceptable, while 55% say that the president's statements about the scandal are completely or mostly true. Additionally, 59% of respondents believe that the U.S. government could have prevented the Benghazi attack, and 54% say that congressional Republicans are not overreacting in their handling of the matter.

The poll also found that Americans are taking all three controversies very seriously, with 55% saying the IRS and Benghazi matters are very important to the nation, and 53% saying the same thing about the AP case. However, only 43% of respondents say they have a great deal or some confidence in the people who run the federal government.

The CNN poll was conducted by ORC International and surveyed 923 adults nationwide by telephone. The survey's sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.

Title: Republican Debate: A Spirited and Contentious Affair

The final debate before Super Tuesday saw a dramatic shift in the tone and tenor of the Republican primary campaign, as Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz finally turned their attention away from each other and focused on Donald Trump. The debate, marked by heated exchanges and personal attacks, set a new low for the Republican Party, which had been craving a moment like this to shake up the race.

Rubio, in particular, had several standout moments, using a series of quick comebacks to respond to Trump's insults and criticisms. He even managed to turn the tables on Trump, referencing his own gaffe from the New Hampshire debates, where he repeated himself five times. Rubio's performance was a far cry from the "Marco Roboto" of weeks past, as he rolled his eyes, waved his hands for effect, and seemed more human than ever before.

Glenn Beck, a Cruz supporter, praised Rubio's performance as his best yet, giving new life to his campaign and potentially reviving hopes that Trump might not run away with the nomination.

However, Trump continued to use the same talking points against Rubio and Cruz, amplifying the vitriol and personal attacks. Rubio was now a "sweaty-faced choke artist" instead of just an inexperienced young man, while Cruz was a "basket case" and a "crazy zealot." Cruz responded in kind, asking Trump to "get back on his meds."

Despite the intense and contentious debate, it remains unclear whether this performance will be enough to propel either Rubio or Cruz into the front-runner position. With nearly half of the delegates needed to win the nomination on the line, Trump still leads in almost every state, and it's unclear whether this debate will be enough to change the trajectory of the race.

**House Republicans Face Uphill Battle to Pass Healthcare Bill**

The Republican-backed healthcare bill is facing an uncertain future as House Republicans struggle to gather enough votes to pass the legislation. Despite White House optimism, GOP lawmakers and congressional aides say the bill is short of the votes needed to pass.

House Speaker Paul Ryan and President Trump are meeting to discuss the way forward on the bill, which would repeal and replace ObamaCare. The bill has been met with opposition from both moderates and conservatives, who are concerned about the impact on healthcare coverage and costs.

In an effort to win over conservatives, House leaders proposed a fresh amendment repealing Obama's requirement that insurers cover 10 specified services, including maternity and mental health care. However, this move has been met with skepticism from moderates, who fear it will lead to higher premiums and reduced coverage.

The bill has been a contentious issue, with Democrats blasting what they see as Republicans' "amateurish" maneuvering. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi called it a "rookie's error" to bring the legislation to a vote so early, and urged fellow Democrats to oppose the legislation.

The bill's passage is crucial for President Trump, who has made repealing and replacing ObamaCare a key campaign promise. If the bill fails, Trump has threatened to move on to tax reform. The House Rules Committee is expected to prepare the bill for a vote starting at 7am ET on Friday.

While the outcome is uncertain, the debate highlights the challenges facing Republicans in passing healthcare legislation. The bill's fate will be a test of the party's ability to deliver on its campaign promises and navigate the complex healthcare landscape.

**Breaking News: US Welcomes Home Detainees from North Korea in Dramatic Early Morning Scene**

In a historic moment, President Donald Trump welcomed home three American detainees from North Korea on Thursday, marking a significant step towards improving relations between the two nations. The former prisoners, Kim Dong Chul, Kim Sang-duk (also known as Tony Kim), and Kim Hak-song, were greeted by the President, Vice President Mike Pence, and their wives at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland.

The dramatic scene unfolded in the early morning hours, with the President and First Lady boarding a medical plane to greet the men, who were released from North Korean custody. Trump thanked Kim Jong Un for allowing the men to go before a planned meeting between the two leaders, calling it a "big thing" and "very important" to him.

The three men, who were accused of anti-state activities by North Korea, were taken to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland, for further evaluation and medical treatment. Their release is seen as a sign of thawing relations between the US and North Korea, following Kim's pledge to suspend missile tests and close a nuclear test site.

The event was also marked by Trump's lighthearted remarks, joking that the scene "probably broke the all-time record for television ratings at 3 o'clock in the morning." The President also expressed his hope for a "big success" in his planned meeting with Kim and emphasized the importance of denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula.

The former detainees, who were released after being held for an undisclosed period, thanked Trump and the US government for securing their freedom in a statement released by the State Department. They expressed their gratitude to the US government, President Trump, Secretary Pompeo, and the American people for bringing them home, calling it "like a dream we are very, very happy."

The release of the three men comes amid renewed uncertainty around the summit between Trump and Kim, following the President's decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal. However, the event marks a significant step towards improving relations between the two nations and a potential breakthrough in the denuclearization process.

Title: US and Russia Struggle to Rebuild Trust Amid Election Interference Concerns

Article:

The United States and Russia are facing a significant challenge in rebuilding trust between the two nations, following Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warned Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov of the "serious mistrust" between the two countries, citing the Kremlin's actions as a major obstacle to improving relations.

Tillerson emphasized that while the US is not looking to "cut everything off" over a single issue, the damage to the relationship is significant. He also indicated that the US will respond to Russia's expulsion of 755 staff from the US embassy in Moscow by September 1. The move was a retaliatory measure taken by Russia in response to US sanctions imposed last month.

The US intelligence community believes that Russia attempted to influence the outcome of the 2016 election, which saw Donald Trump take office. Moscow has vehemently denied any involvement, and the issue has sparked a tit-for-tat response from both sides. The US Congress passed legislation imposing sanctions on Russia for election meddling and military actions in Crimea and Ukraine, which President Trump signed into law last week.

Despite the tensions, Tillerson expressed a willingness to work with Russia on issues such as violence in Eastern Ukraine. The US Secretary of State met with Lavrov on the sidelines of the ASEAN meeting in the Philippines, where he emphasized the need to address the "serious differences" between the two countries.

The comments come as President Trump has faced criticism for his administration's handling of the Russia investigation. Trump has refused to point fingers at Moscow for the hacking of Democratic Party emails during the election campaign, and has condemned the investigations as a "witch hunt." The new sanctions law also prevents Trump from lifting sanctions or returning Russian diplomatic compounds in the US, which were seized by the Obama administration in retaliation for alleged Russian meddling.

The situation highlights the complex and challenging nature of US-Russia relations, as both sides struggle to rebuild trust and find common ground.

Title: The Complexities of Immigration: A Look at the Numbers and the Politics

Article:

The recent surge of families crossing the US-Mexico border has sparked a heated debate about immigration policies and the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. Edilberto Lanza Mejia, a 26-year-old from Honduras, shared his story with The Houston Chronicle, detailing his experience of being released by US immigration officials after being held in a cell for five days. He was part of a group of 80-90 people who were overwhelmed the system, leading to their release with a promise to report to immigration officials weeks later.

The Obama administration attributes the influx of families to recent violence in Central American countries. However, the flow of minors crossing the border has been steady for over a decade, with an average of 7,000 to 8,000 cases per year from 2002 to 2011. In 2012, the number jumped to 13,625, and this year, the federal government is estimating 80,000 cases.

The increase in unaccompanied minors crossing the border is often linked to the DACA program, which allowed some undocumented immigrants who came to the US as minors to defer deportation for two years. The program was initially intended to be temporary, but it has been extended multiple times. Critics argue that the program's arbitrary lines, such as the age 30 cutoff, make no logical or moral sense.

The DREAM Act, which passed the House of Representatives in 2010, had a similar age 30 cutoff, but it was not passed by the Senate. The S. 744 bill, which was introduced in 2013, had a cutoff date of December 31, 2011, but it was not passed. The arbitrary lines in these programs have led to confusion and frustration among those affected.

Central Americans have figured out that if they wait long enough, they can take advantage of the DACA program or other amnesty programs. A detained undocumented immigrant from Guatemala told The Christian Science Monitor, "They're saying that women and children are allowed to stay. If you make it, they take you to a shelter and take care of you and let you have permission to stay."

Texas Governor Rick Perry has asked the Obama administration to change its immigration policies, particularly the practice of releasing illegal immigrants into the US with only a promise to appear in court. A Homeland Security official told The Houston Chronicle, "We need a policy change so we can send these families and children back home instead of turning them loose."

The complexities of immigration policies and the politics surrounding them continue to be a topic of debate. As the numbers of unaccompanied minors crossing the border continue to rise, it is essential to examine the root causes of the issue and the impact of policies on those affected.

Title: New Disclosures Reveal Paul Manafort's Involvement in Ukraine Lobbying Efforts

Article:

Recent disclosures have shed new light on the involvement of Paul Manafort, former campaign chairman for President Donald Trump, in lobbying efforts on behalf of a Brussels-based think tank that supported Ukraine's Party of Regions. The think tank, the European Centre for a Modern Ukraine, paid Mercury, a lobbying firm, over $1.2 million for work between May 2012 and May 2014.

According to the disclosures, Manafort met with several U.S. government officials, including Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), former Arizona Republican Congressman Jim Kolbe of the International Republican Institute, Paula Dobriansky of the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, and Nadia Diuk of the National Endowment for Democracy. These meetings, which had not been previously disclosed, conflict with Mercury's previous claims that it did not coordinate with Manafort.

Manafort's presence at the Washington meetings raises questions about his involvement in the lobbying efforts and whether he was working on behalf of the Party of Regions, which was led by former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, a Manafort client. Manafort's spokesman, Jason Maloni, downplayed the significance of the meetings, stating that they were "incidental contact" and that Manafort might report his foreign lobbying activities in response to advice from authorities.

Mercury partner Michael McKeon said that Manafort referred his Brussels think tank client to the firm, and that Manafort's involvement was limited to a few meetings. However, the disclosures suggest that Manafort's role may have been more extensive than initially claimed.

The disclosures also raise questions about Mercury's compliance with the Foreign Agents Registration Act, which requires firms to report their lobbying activities to the Justice Department. Mercury had previously reported its lobbying efforts to Congress under the Lobbying Disclosure Act, but did not itemize each interaction and expense. The firm relied on assurances from the think tank that it was not funded or controlled by a foreign political party.

While violating the disclosure law is criminal, the office that enforces it usually settles for bringing lobbyists into compliance instead of bringing charges. The other lobbying firm working for the think tank, the Podesta Group, also retroactively filed with the Justice Department earlier this month.

The new disclosures highlight the importance of transparency in lobbying efforts and the need for greater accountability in the political process. As the investigation into Manafort's activities continues, it remains to be seen what further revelations will come to light.

**Title:** Illinois Abortion Bills Spark Controversy: Thousands Protest and Debate Ensues

**Article:**

A contentious debate has erupted in Illinois over two proposed abortion bills, with thousands of protesters taking to the state capitol in Springfield to express their concerns. The bills, introduced by Illinois Democrats, aim to increase access to abortion services and eliminate certain restrictions.

One bill would allow abortions up until the moment of birth for any reason, while the other would eliminate the requirement for minors to notify their parents before obtaining an abortion. Pro-life advocates argue that these measures would lead to a significant increase in abortions and disregard the health and safety of women.

Illinois Right to Life Action's Mary Kate Knorr stated, "There is widespread outcry from the people of Illinois against these extreme anti-women and anti-children bills since they were introduced a month ago. Residents from all corners of Illinois are expressing outrage at this proposed legislation, which disregards the health and safety of women."

The proposed legislation has sparked concerns among pro-life advocates, who argue that it would lead to an increase in abortions and disregard the health and safety of women. Dr. Michael New of Catholic University stated, "Essentially, when the price of abortion goes down, the incidence increases, and if low-income women can get abortion subsidized through Medicaid programs, they're more likely to get abortions."

The repeal of the Parent Notification of Abortion Act of 1995 could also lead to an increase in abortions, as it would eliminate the requirement for minors to notify their parents before obtaining an abortion. The bill's sponsor, State Sen. Elgie Sims, Jr. (D-Chicago), argued that the goal of the new bill was to increase "authentic family conversations."

However, opponents of the bill argue that it would lead to a significant increase in abortions and disregard the health and safety of women. State Sen. Jason Plummer (R-Edwardsville) stated, "We're talking about the termination of a life, right? And so, for there to be maybe a hurdle or two there, I don't think as a society is necessarily the worst thing because... we're talking about the termination of a heartbeat, and that's a significant concern of mine."

The debate has also sparked concerns among pro-life advocates, who argue that the bills would lead to an increase in abortions and disregard the health and safety of women. Illinois Right to Life Action reports that the bills would allow unregulated abortion up until the moment of birth for any reason and would strip away all parental rights, along with any requirement of medical certification by staff or facility.

The progressive measures have been introduced by Democrats in both chambers, but only the Senate is seeing success as the measure is stalled in the House. The debate is expected to continue as both sides of the issue weigh in on the proposed legislation.

Title: A Fresh Perspective on American Foreign Policy: A Call for Realism and Prudence

Article:

As President Donald Trump embarks on his first international trip, it is an opportune moment to reassess the state of American foreign policy and the challenges the country faces. The 45th president's approach to international relations has been met with skepticism by some, who view his style as abrasive and uncoordinated. However, it is essential to separate substance from style and examine the underlying principles guiding his decisions.

One of the most significant criticisms of Trump's approach is that he has defined the enemy too broadly, lumping together various groups and nations without nuance. This lack of distinction has led to accusations of xenophobia and Islamophobia. While it is true that Trump's rhetoric has been criticized for being overly simplistic, it is also important to acknowledge that his predecessors, including Barack Obama, have also faced criticism for their handling of international relations.

Obama's approach to the Middle East, in particular, has been criticized for being overly idealistic and naive. His administration's emphasis on spreading democracy and promoting human rights has been seen as ineffective and even counterproductive. Trump's approach, on the other hand, is more pragmatic and focused on national interests. He has recognized that the Middle East is a complex and treacherous region, where alliances are often based on convenience rather than shared values.

Trump's critics argue that his approach is too cynical and lacks a moral compass. However, it is essential to recognize that the Middle East is a region where moral clarity is often a luxury that can be afforded only by those who are not directly affected by the consequences of their actions. Trump's approach may be seen as brutal or pragmatic, but it is a recognition of the harsh realities of international politics.

As Trump continues his tour, it is crucial to separate fact from fiction and to examine the substance of his policies rather than his style. His critics may view him as a disruptor, but it is essential to recognize that his approach is a response to the failures of previous administrations. Trump's emphasis on national interests and his willingness to challenge the status quo may be uncomfortable, but it is a necessary step towards a more realistic and effective foreign policy.

Ultimately, Trump's success will depend on his ability to balance his nationalistic instincts with a recognition of the importance of international cooperation. His critics may view him as a threat to the international order, but it is essential to recognize that his approach is a response to the failures of previous administrations. As he continues his tour, it is crucial to examine the substance of his policies and to separate fact from fiction.

**Title:** The Dark Side of Health Information: How YouTube's Algorithmic Biases Widen Health Literacy Disparities

**Article:**

The internet has become the go-to source for health information, with 75% of Americans turning to online platforms like YouTube for answers. However, a closer look at the content and algorithms used by these platforms reveals a concerning trend: the widening of health literacy disparities.

YouTube, in particular, has emerged as a significant source of health information, with billions of views daily. While it's a valuable resource, the platform's algorithmic biases can steer users toward questionable content, exacerbating existing disparities in health literacy.

A significant fraction of the U.S. population lacks proficient health literacy skills, making it difficult for them to understand basic health information, such as reading prescription labels or comprehension of medical instructions. Studies have consistently shown that only 12% of adults have proficient health literacy skills.

Research has also found that social media platforms like YouTube can widen these disparities by steering users toward content that may not be medically valid. A study examining YouTube videos on diabetes found that the most popular and engaging videos are less likely to have medically valid information.

The issue lies in the algorithms used by these platforms, which prioritize engagement and popularity over medical validity. This means that users with limited health literacy are more likely to encounter misinformation, including fake cures and misleading medical advice.

The consequences of this can be severe, particularly for minority groups, who are already disproportionately affected by limited health literacy. Studies have shown that the impact of limited health literacy disproportionately affects minorities, making it even more challenging for them to access accurate health information.

Correcting these algorithmic biases and providing better information to users is crucial to promoting equity in health communication. For instance, incorporating feedback from clinicians, patients, and end-users into algorithm design can help reduce the spread of misinformation.

While some progress has been made, more research is needed to understand the state of health literacy among minority populations, particularly in urban areas. Cultural barriers and insufficient education also contribute to the challenges faced by minority groups in managing their chronic health conditions.

In conclusion, the proliferation of health information on YouTube and other social media platforms highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of health literacy and its impact on health disparities. By acknowledging the biases in these algorithms and working to correct them, we can promote more equitable access to accurate health information and improve overall health outcomes.

**Senate Republicans Block Tax Cut Bill, Citing Need for Amendments**

In a move that has sparked controversy, Senate Republicans blocked a $84 billion tax cut bill on Thursday, citing their desire to introduce amendments to the legislation. The bill, which aimed to revive a raft of expired tax breaks, failed to clear a procedural hurdle, with a vote of 53-40 falling short of the 60 votes needed to advance the measure.

The dispute centers around the lack of amendments allowed by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, with Republicans expressing frustration that they have not been given the opportunity to propose changes to the bill. Specifically, they are seeking to repeal the Obamacare medical device tax, which they argue is a key issue.

Senator Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) emphasized the importance of standing up for the right to introduce amendments, stating, "Don't we care a little more about freedom and the right to bring up your amendments and the right to be a participant in the process?" He added, "It's not about trying to stop this bill – it's saying, 'Look, we've had enough of this crap.'"

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) criticized Republicans for their decision, saying, "Republicans can't take 'yes' for an answer – they just voted against the second bipartisan bill in less than a week. That's what just happened: the Republicans voted against tax cuts. So maybe the Republicans will hear from their friends down on K Street and around the country and maybe they will learn this is pretty important to everybody."

The impasse has left lawmakers uncertain about the future of the tax cut bill, with some predicting a brief delay before a resolution is reached. Senator Dan Coats (R-Ind.) suggested that the chamber could still complete work on the bill by Memorial Day, while others believe it may not be resolved until a post-election lame-duck session.

The dispute highlights the ongoing gridlock and partisan bickering in the Senate, with lawmakers struggling to find common ground and compromise.

Title: Congress Avoids Government Shutdown, But Funding Fight Looms in December

Article:

The United States Congress has temporarily avoided a government shutdown, but the threat of a funding showdown is far from over. The immediate crisis was averted when Speaker John Boehner announced his resignation, removing any doubt about a clean spending bill being passed this week. However, the real challenge lies ahead, as lawmakers must agree on a new funding bill for the new fiscal year.

Democrats are demanding an increase in domestic spending caps, while hawkish Republicans are pushing for more funding for defense programs. Fiscal conservatives are opposed to any additional spending. The outcome of this funding fight is far from certain, with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stating that there is no agreement beyond a short-term funding bill this week.

The Senate will make the first move to steer Congress away from a shutdown, with a key procedural vote on Monday evening on a bill that would fund the government through December 11 and not strip money from Planned Parenthood. Senate Democratic and GOP leadership aides said there would be no issue clinching the 60 votes needed to advance the short-term spending bill.

The House will follow suit and send the bill to President Barack Obama for his signature, just in time to avert the second federal government shutdown since 2013. However, the real battle is expected to begin in December, when lawmakers must agree on a new funding bill for the new fiscal year.

In the meantime, House Republicans are diverting their energy into investigating whether Planned Parenthood profited from the sale of fetal tissue, allegations stemming from a series of undercover sting videos. The House GOP has announced the establishment of a select committee to probe the accusations, which has drawn condemnation from Democrats.

The House will also vote on measures restricting abortion and drafting a reconciliation measure to defund Planned Parenthood. However, reconciliation rules in the Senate are more complicated, and GOP leaders have not yet indicated whether they will follow suit and use the procedural tool to strip funding from Planned Parenthood.

Some House conservatives were not appeased by the leadership's strategy, lobbying instead to push the funding fight to the brink of a shutdown. However, they were resigned to the fact that a spending bill without Planned Parenthood restrictions was inevitable.

The funding fight is expected to be a contentious one, with Democrats likely to provide the lion's share of votes to keep the government open beyond Wednesday. Republicans oppose the stopgap measure for reasons beyond money for Planned Parenthood, with some senators rejecting the current level of spending overall.

The real challenge lies ahead, as lawmakers must agree on a new funding bill for the new fiscal year. The outcome of this funding fight is far from certain, and the threat of a government shutdown looms large.

**Title:** UN Reports 1 Million Children Fleeing Violence in Syria, Urges Global Action

**Article:**

The United Nations has released a grim statistic, revealing that over 1 million children have fled violence in Syria since the conflict began in 2011. The majority of these children, three-quarters of whom are under the age of 11, have been forced to leave their homes and families behind. The UN's children's agency, UNICEF, has called on the international community to take immediate action to address the crisis.

The UN's announcement comes as the organization pushes for an immediate investigation into an alleged chemical weapons attack near Damascus. The Syrian government has denied the allegations, calling them "illogical and fabricated." However, unverified footage shows civilians, including children, suffering from horrific symptoms and rows of shrouded bodies, which chemical weapons experts have confirmed are consistent with nerve agents.

UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has renewed calls for UN inspectors to be allowed to investigate the claims immediately, stating that there is "no good reason" for any party to decline this opportunity to get to the truth. The UN is acting quickly to address the allegations, with its top disarmament representative, Angela Kane, set to fly to Syria to investigate the claims.

The Syrian conflict has become the worst refugee crisis since the genocide in Rwanda in 1994, with over 100,000 people killed and 2 million displaced within the country. Children are among the most vulnerable, with 1 million forced to flee and 2 million displaced. The UN's High Commissioner for Refugees, Antonio Guterres, has warned that the "youth of Syria are losing their homes, their family members, and their futures."

Education is a top concern for Syrian refugee families, with 48% of the refugee population being children who are unable to attend official schooling in their host countries. The longer children stay out of school, the less likely they are to eventually return, according to a March report from Save the Children. In Jordan, CARE found that over 60% of school-age children are not attending any classes, despite the availability of free schooling.

UNICEF officials have urged the international community to respond to the problem, stating that it belongs to everyone and that the global community has failed in its responsibility to the children of Syria. "We must all share the shame," said UNICEF's Anthony Lake. "Because while we work to alleviate the suffering of those affected by this crisis, the global community has failed in its responsibility to this child. We should stop and ask ourselves how, in all conscience, we can continue to fail the children of Syria."

The crisis in Syria highlights the need for global cooperation and action to address the humanitarian crisis and ensure the well-being of the children affected.

Title: Kurdish Forces Make Gains Against ISIS, With American Support

Article:

Kurdish forces, backed by American military support, have made significant gains against the Islamic State (ISIS) in the region around Mount Sinjar. The Kurdish Peshmerga fighters have acquired a small number of armored Humvees, abandoned by the Iraqi Army, and have been using them to push back against the extremist group.

Despite the challenges they face, the Peshmerga have been able to make progress, with the help of American military advisers on the ground. Roughly two dozen United States Special Forces members are serving as advisers to the Peshmerga forces, providing guidance on tactics and strategy.

The Kurdish forces, led by General Waisi's Zeravani Force, have spread out to secure a broader swath of Highway 47, cutting off one of the main supply routes for ISIS between Syria and the vital city of Mosul in Iraq. By midday, Kurdish officials reported controlling about 22 miles of the highway, stretching both east and west of Sinjar.

The Peshmerga fighters have also been using American-provided equipment, including A-10 attack planes and B-1 heavy bombers, to target ISIS positions. The sound of military jets and explosions has become a familiar soundtrack for the Kurdish forces as they push forward.

Despite the progress, the fight against ISIS is far from over. The Peshmerga will continue to face challenges as they work to secure the region and push back against the extremist group. However, with American support and determination, the Kurdish forces are making significant strides in the fight against ISIS.

Title: Former Republican Lawmakers Urge Congress to Block Trump's National Emergency Declaration

Article:

A group of 24 former Republican lawmakers has written an open letter to their current colleagues, urging them to block President Trump's national emergency declaration. The letter, published by Politico, argues that the move would expand executive authority and set a dangerous precedent.

The former lawmakers, who served between 1967 and 2013, point out that the national emergency declaration was made after Republicans failed to secure the $5.7 billion requested for the construction of a border wall as part of a broader spending package. They argue that the expansion of executive authority would eventually be wielded against Republicans by a Democratic administration.

"What will you do when a president of another party uses the precedent you are establishing to impose policies to which you are unalterably opposed?" they ask. "There is no way around this difficulty: what powers are ceded to a president whose policies you support may also be used by presidents whose policies you abhor."

The House is set to vote this week on a resolution to end the national emergency, which has received the support of only one Republican, Representative Justin Amash of Michigan. The former lawmakers' letter highlights the potential long-term consequences of the national emergency declaration and the importance of maintaining the balance of power between the branches of government.

In their letter, the former lawmakers emphasize their commitment to the principles of limited government and the importance of upholding the authority of the legislative branch. They urge their current colleagues to resist the temptation to surrender powers to the executive branch and to prioritize the preservation of the Constitution.

The debate surrounding the national emergency declaration highlights the ongoing tensions between the executive and legislative branches of government. While some argue that the declaration is necessary to address the crisis at the southern border, others see it as an overreach of executive authority. The outcome of the vote in the House will be closely watched, as it could have significant implications for the balance of power in Washington.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach to Governance: A New Era in Presidential Power?

Article:

In a departure from traditional presidential norms, Donald Trump has become the most dominant figure in American politics, despite being the most unpopular first-year president in modern history. Trump's unconventional approach to governance has raised questions about the limits of presidential power and the potential consequences of his actions.

Historians and experts have noted that Trump is pushing the boundaries of what is considered acceptable presidential behavior. "You've got someone who is defining the presidency very differently," said Michael Beschloss, a presidential historian. "Trump is essentially saying, 'I'm not going to operate just within the boundaries that the founders might have expected or people might have expected for 200 years. I'm going to operate within the boundaries of what is strictly legal, and I'm going to push those boundaries if I can.'"

Trump's willingness to challenge traditional norms has led to concerns about the erosion of institutional checks and balances. "Everyone else seemed to play within a certain box," said William M. Daley, who served as a cabinet secretary under Bill Clinton and White House chief of staff under Barack Obama. "But this one is totally outside the box."

Trump's use of executive power has been a key aspect of his presidency. Like his predecessor, Barack Obama, Trump has made ambitious use of his executive pen to enact sweeping policies. However, Trump has been more aggressive in his approach, lashing out at judges, lawmakers, investigators, and journalists who anger him.

Trump's sense of government is not based on coalition building or a balancing act between equal branches. Instead, he believes he has an "absolute right" to order the Justice Department to open or close investigations into himself or his foes. Some lawyers argue that the Constitution gives him wide latitude over the executive branch, but critics warn that thwarting the special counsel's Russia investigation could lead to impeachment proceedings.

The talk of "absolute" power and Trump's affinity for foreign strongmen have fueled fears of authoritarianism. While Trump has not yet followed through on his threats, his bark has become a power unto itself, and the question remains whether he will continue to push the boundaries of presidential power in the next stage of his tenure.

Title: Honoring the Fallen: A Reflection on Memorial Day

Article:

As Memorial Day approaches, many of us take a moment to reflect on the sacrifices made by those who have given their lives in service to our country. For some, like myself, the holiday holds a deeper significance, as it serves as a reminder of the ultimate sacrifices made by those who have served and those who continue to serve.

I remember the day I received my draft notice in 1971, and how it changed the course of my life. I was sent to Korea, not Vietnam, and served in the 2nd Infantry Division's Army Medical Corps. My experience was vastly different from what I had learned in medical school, where I was trained with proper medical tools and equipment. In Korea, we had to make do with limited resources, often relying on makeshift solutions to treat wounded soldiers.

As I look back on my time serving during the Vietnam era, I am reminded of the many lives lost and the sacrifices made by those who served alongside me. I think of the three doctors I worked with, Dr. Tom Cherry, Dr. Mike Fichette, and Dr. John Strauss, who worked tirelessly to care for the nearly 10,000 infantrymen. I think of the two soldiers we saved from extreme heat exhaustion after storming a hill days before Memorial Day in 1973. And I think of the fallen, who gave their lives for our country and will never return.

Memorial Day is a time to reflect on the sacrifices made by those who have given their lives in service to our country. It is a time to honor their memories and the impact of their sacrifices. We can never fully repay those who lost their lives fighting for our freedom or their families who made endless sacrifices on our behalf. But we can honor them through prayer and reflection, through ceremonies and tradition, and even through legislation.

As a veteran, I am passionate about finding ways to ease the burdens of Gold Star families, who carry on the legacy of our fallen heroes. The Forever GI Bill, which I authored, allows eligible veterans to use their GI Bill benefits at any point in their lifetime, and the Fry Scholarship Improvement Act of 2019 extends eligibility for the Fry Scholarship to surviving spouses and children of deceased National Guard and Reserve members.

This Memorial Day, I challenge everyone to find a way to honor those who lost their life in service. This can be done in many ways, such as saying a prayer, visiting a local VA cemetery, calling your member of Congress, or volunteering with a Veterans Service Organization (VSO). There are many incredible VSOs to choose from, and many that focus specifically on honoring our nation's fallen, such as America's Gold Star Families, Tragedy Assistance Program for Survivors, and the Travis Manion Foundation.

It is an honor to be a veteran, but it is far greater an honor to spend my days working to advance causes that serve and support them and their families. On Memorial Day, I give thanks for those who made the ultimate sacrifice, and I pray for every life lost fighting for our freedom.

Title: US Lawmakers Reach Deal in Principle on Farm Bill, Capping Months of Debate

Article:

Washington D.C. - After months of intense negotiations, US lawmakers have reached a deal in principle on the 2018 Farm Bill, a crucial piece of legislation that provides $867 billion in funding for food and agriculture programs. The agreement was announced by the chairmen and ranking members of the Senate and House Agriculture Committees.

The bill covers a range of programs, including crop subsidies and support for accessing export markets, which are essential for American farmers. The funding is particularly important as farmers face challenges due to the ongoing trade wars with key commercial partners like China, which has been absent from the market since the imposition of tariffs.

The latest bill, passed in 2014, expired on September 30 after talks over its replacement broke down. The main sticking points in the negotiations were the imposition of stricter work requirements for recipients of food stamps and forestry provisions following the deadly wildfires in California.

While the agreement is a significant step forward, lawmakers still need to finalize the language and CBO scores before the bill can be voted on. The agreement may be voted on as a standalone bill or as part of a larger package. Lawmakers have until the end of the year to finalize the process, and once passed, the bill will go to the president for signature.

The deal is a relief for American farmers, who have been struggling to cope with the impact of the trade wars and other challenges. The bill's passage will provide much-needed support for the agricultural industry and help ensure a stable food supply for American consumers.

Title: US Defense Secretary Visits Baghdad Amid Efforts to Recapture Mosul from ISIS

Article:

US Defense Secretary Ash Carter arrived in Baghdad on an unannounced visit to discuss the ongoing efforts to recapture the city of Mosul from the Islamic State (ISIS). The visit comes as Iraqi forces, backed by Kurdish and other local forces, launched a large-scale offensive to retake the city, which was overrun by ISIS in 2014.

During his visit, Carter met with Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, who emphasized that Iraqi forces can handle the battle themselves and do not need Turkish involvement. Al-Abadi stated that the Iraqi government is committed to liberating Mosul and other territories from ISIS, and that the country's sovereignty is key to the success of the operation.

The US goal is to resolve disputes between partners in the coalition and to fight the common enemy, ISIS. Carter expressed confidence that a constructive role for Turkey can be planned, but it appears that Iraq is not interested in accepting Turkish involvement at this time.

Meanwhile, a US service member was killed in an explosion outside Mosul, the fourth death since the US began military operations in the region in August 2014. The incident highlights the risks faced by those involved in the fight against ISIS.

In a separate development, an apparent counter-attack by ISIS fighters resulted in the deaths of 80 people, mostly Kurdish security forces, in the city of Kirkuk. The attack occurred as Iraqi forces advanced on Mosul, about 100 miles to the northwest.

The Iraqi government has imposed a sundown curfew on the city and has reported that most of the terrorists involved in the attack have been eliminated. The attack was the result of a terrorist attack and not a military breach, according to al-Abadi.

In another development, hundreds of people were treated for breathing problems caused by a burning sulfur plant in Mishraq, south of Mosul. The plant was set ablaze on Thursday, causing gray smoke to spread to nearby villages, resulting in respiratory issues and nosebleeds.

The United Nations Human Rights Office has received reports that hundreds of families were forced out of villages and herded towards Mosul, potentially to be used as human shields by ISIS. The UN has expressed concerns about the safety of these civilians and has called on the Iraqi government to do its utmost to protect them.

The recapture of Mosul is a complex and challenging operation, and the international community is closely watching the situation. The US and its allies are working to support the Iraqi government in its efforts to defeat ISIS and restore stability to the region.

**Title:** White House Pushes to Ease Restrictions on Guantanamo Detainees Amid Congressional Resistance

**Article:**

The debate over Guantanamo Bay is heating up on Capitol Hill as the White House seeks to ease restrictions on transferring detainees out of the Cuba-based prison camp. The administration is pushing for a Senate defense policy bill that would allow the transfer of cleared detainees to other countries, as well as lift a ban on bringing suspected terrorist prisoners to the United States for detention, trial, or medical treatment.

However, lawmakers are resistant to moving too quickly, citing concerns about recidivism among former detainees. An official estimate last year found that nearly 28% of former detainees were suspected of returning to the battlefield. Some lawmakers, such as Senator Kelly Ayotte (R-NH), argue that reducing the standard for transfers would be a mistake.

The White House is hoping to use the Senate bill to advance its long-stalled goal of shutting down the prison camp. Administration officials say the bill would ease restrictions and allow for the transfer of prisoners who have been cleared for transfer but are still held due to a complicated Pentagon certification process.

Despite the push from the White House, the House earlier this year approved a measure that further restricts transfers, including a ban on sending detainees to Yemen. Yemen is a particular challenge since more than half of the 164 detainees are from there, and it is home to the world's most active Al Qaeda branch.

The debate is not new, with the Obama administration having imposed a ban on Yemeni transfers after a Nigerian man attempted to blow up a U.S.-bound flight on Christmas 2009. However, Obama lifted the moratorium in his speech at National Defense University in May, saying Guantanamo has become a symbol of an America that flouts the rule of law.

Administration officials say Guantanamo is too costly, with annual spending on the prison camp totaling $454 million, or about $2.7 million per detainee. The White House is pushing for a three-step plan to close the facility: transferring out those who have been approved, prosecuting others, and making a plan for the remaining detainees accused of participating in dangerous plots.

While some lawmakers, such as Senator John McCain (R-Ariz.), agree that the administration does not need more flexibility, others, like Chris Anders, senior legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, argue that there is a growing recognition that Guantanamo cannot stay open forever and harms national security.

The debate is likely to continue as the White House and lawmakers weigh the pros and cons of transferring detainees out of Guantanamo.

Title: Obama's Remarks on Ferguson: A Delicate Balance Between Sympathy and Restraint

Article:

In his recent remarks on the Ferguson protests, President Obama struck a careful balance between expressing sympathy for the community's outrage over Michael Brown's killing and emphasizing the need for restraint and respect for the law. The President's approach was met with criticism from some quarters, who felt he was too subdued and didn't delve deeply enough into the pain of the racial divide.

However, others praised Obama's measured tone, noting that he avoided inflaming a difficult situation and instead focused on the need for peaceful protest and respect for the rights of all individuals. The President acknowledged the passions and anger of the community, but also emphasized the importance of not giving into that anger and instead working towards justice.

Obama's comments were also seen as a nod to the concerns of African-Americans, who have long felt marginalized and disrespected by law enforcement. The President acknowledged the "gulf of mistrust" between communities of color and law enforcement, and emphasized the need for investigations to be conducted fairly and without bias.

However, some critics felt that Obama didn't go far enough in addressing the root causes of the problem, such as poverty and lack of opportunity. The President did acknowledge that "young black men commit crime," but emphasized the need for them to be held accountable and for communities to work together to address the underlying issues.

Overall, Obama's remarks on Ferguson were a delicate balancing act, aimed at expressing sympathy and understanding while also emphasizing the need for respect for the law and peaceful protest. While some may have felt he didn't go far enough, others praised his measured approach and commitment to finding a way forward.

Title: The War for Christmas: A Divisive Pledge or a Celebration of Inclusion?

Article:

The holiday season is upon us, and with it, the age-old debate about the meaning and significance of Christmas. For some, it's a time for joy, family, and festive cheer. For others, it's a symbol of religious and cultural identity. In recent years, the debate has taken a divisive turn, with some advocating for a more inclusive approach and others pushing for a more exclusive, Christian-centric celebration.

Donald Trump's recent pledge to "Make America Say Merry Christmas Again" has sparked a heated discussion about the role of religion in American society. While some see it as a harmless expression of patriotism and holiday cheer, others view it as a thinly veiled attempt to impose Christian values on a diverse population.

The debate is not new, but it has taken on a new level of urgency in the wake of Trump's election. His supporters see it as a way to reclaim a perceived loss of Christian values in American culture, while his detractors view it as a form of cultural imperialism.

The reality is that Christmas is a holiday that has evolved over time, influenced by various cultures and traditions. It's a time for families to come together, for friends to share in the joy of the season, and for individuals to reflect on the true meaning of the holiday.

Rather than trying to impose a specific interpretation of Christmas on the entire country, perhaps it's time to focus on what unites us, rather than what divides us. By embracing the diversity of American culture and acknowledging the many ways in which people celebrate the holiday, we can create a more inclusive and welcoming environment for all.

In the end, the true meaning of Christmas is not about what we say or how we say it, but about the values of love, kindness, and generosity that it embodies. Let's focus on spreading those values, rather than getting bogged down in petty squabbles over semantics.

Title: The Media's Struggle: Trump's War on Journalism and the Future of Democracy

Article:

The recent election of Donald Trump as the 45th President of the United States has sparked a heated debate about the role of the media in the political process. Trump's campaign was marked by his criticism of the media, singling out individual journalists and challenging the very foundations of freedom of the press. As president-elect, Trump's war on the media continues, with him berating networks for their "outrageous" and "dishonest" coverage and calling for loosening of libel laws.

This development has significant implications for the media's ability to provide the public with a clear view of presidential decision-making. While presidential animosity towards the press is not new, Trump's approach is unique in its intensity and potential impact. The media's role as a watchdog and critic of the government is crucial to a functioning democracy, and Trump's attacks on the media threaten to undermine this essential function.

The media's credibility has been declining in recent years, with a Pew survey showing that only 22% of Americans gave the press an A or B for its campaign coverage. A Gallup poll found that just 32% of the public trusts the press to report news "fully, accurately, and fairly." The media's decline in credibility has been driven primarily by Republicans, who are increasingly turning to alternative sources of news and opinion.

The trend is particularly concerning among younger Americans, who tend to be more liberal and are more likely to get their news from social media. Just 26% of those under the age of 50 trust the news media, compared to 38% of those 50 or older. The rise of social media has also contributed to the decline in trust, with only 34% of American adults trusting the information they get from social media sources.

The media's response to Trump's attacks is uncertain, and the past 30 years do not provide much cause for optimism. The news industry has been struggling with fragmentation and the emergence of the internet, leading to a decline in hard news budgets and investigative journalism. Instead, much of what passes for American journalism today is simply information recycled from government sources.

However, there are signs that Trump's election may lead to a reinvigorated sense of duty on the part of journalists, news organizations, and NGOs. Whether these initial responses add up to an effective counterpoint to Trump's bully pulpit remains to be seen. Ultimately, the future of democracy depends on the media's ability to hold those in power accountable and provide the public with a clear view of the issues.

Title: Public Opinion on Political Correctness: A Majority View

Article:

A recent survey conducted by More in Common, an international research initiative, has shed light on the public's perception of political correctness. The study found that a significant majority of Americans view political correctness as a problem, with 80% of respondents considering it a concern. This sentiment is not limited to any particular age group, with 74% of those aged 24-29 and 79% of those under 24 expressing discomfort with political correctness.

The survey also revealed that education level and income are better indicators of one's stance on political correctness than age or race. The most highly educated Americans are more likely to view hate speech as a significant problem, but political correctness is not a concern. This suggests that political correctness is not a universally accepted concept, and its perceived importance varies greatly depending on individual perspectives.

The findings of the survey have implications for political campaigns and the media. A publication that fails to accurately represent the views of the majority of Americans on this issue may see its influence wane and readership decline. Similarly, a political candidate who misrepresents the public's views on political correctness may struggle to build public support and remedy social injustices.

The survey's results also highlight the importance of understanding the complexities of public opinion. While progressive activists may be passionate about political correctness, they represent a small minority of the population. The "exhausted majority" – those who are neither strongly liberal nor conservative – hold a more nuanced view of the issue. By acknowledging and engaging with this majority, politicians and media outlets can build bridges and foster more effective communication.

Ultimately, the survey's findings underscore the need for a more nuanced understanding of public opinion on political correctness. By recognizing the complexities of the issue and the diverse perspectives of the American public, we can work towards a more informed and inclusive society.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Criticizes President Obama's Handling of Islamic State

Article:

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal has written a scathing critique of President Obama's handling of the Islamic State (ISIS) terrorist group, saying that the President is "incapable of being commander-in-chief of the United States of America." In an opinion piece published on Fox News, Jindal argues that Obama's refusal to acknowledge the threat of "radical Islamic terrorism" and his reluctance to use the term "radical Islam" are a major obstacle to defeating the group.

Jindal also took aim at recent comments made by State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf, who said that "we can't kill our way out of this war" and suggested that a lack of job opportunities could be driving people to join ISIS. Jindal called this statement "madness" and said it demonstrates that Obama is not up to the job of being commander-in-chief.

Furthermore, Jindal criticized Obama's request for an authorization for the use of military force, which he said is too restrictive and would prevent the military from being able to effectively defeat ISIS. He called the prohibition on ground troops a "political strategy designed to appease the left" and said it would hinder the ability of the military to complete its mission.

Jindal's critique comes as he lays the groundwork for a possible presidential run in 2016. While his comments are likely to be seen as provocative by some, they reflect a growing frustration among some politicians and military leaders with Obama's handling of the ISIS threat.

Title: IRS and White House Refuse to Disclose Private Taxpayer Information Sharing

Article:

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the White House have refused to disclose whether they share private taxpayer information with President Obama's top aides, sparking concerns about the potential misuse of sensitive data. The IRS has already stated it lacks the capability to retrieve the relevant emails, but the White House's chief counsel, W. Neil Eggleston, assured Congress that the agency will address the issue "eventually."

In a letter to House Committee on Ways and Means Chairman Paul Ryan, Eggleston wrote that the IRS would tackle the request after completing its document productions already in progress. However, this stance contradicts IRS Commissioner John Koskinen's 2014 letter, which stated that the agency was logistically incapable of performing the search due to the sheer volume of emails involved.

The controversy surrounds the IRS's handling of private taxpayer information, which has been at the center of several scandals, including the targeting of tea party groups and the illegal release of private taxpayer information concerning the National Organization for Marriage. Some outside pressure groups argue that the IRS's improper behavior goes further, including disclosing private taxpayer information to the White House.

The IRS has been under fire for years over its handling of taxpayer information, and the White House's refusal to disclose the information has raised concerns about the potential misuse of sensitive data. The IRS's inspector general investigated the issue of private taxpayer information sharing, but refused to release documents and is currently facing a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit over the matter.

The House and Senate are now investigating IRS and White House communications, and the IRS has turned over hundreds of thousands of pages of documents in the tea party investigation. The controversy highlights the importance of transparency and accountability in the handling of taxpayer information, and the need for both the IRS and the White House to be transparent about their actions.

Mark W. Everson, a former IRS commissioner, said that both sides try to observe a strict division between the White House and the IRS, and that he can't recall any instances of the White House requesting private taxpayer information. However, the current IRS commissioner, John Koskinen, has told Congress that he is working in good faith to restore trust in the agency and to cooperate with lawmakers' investigations.

The controversy surrounding the IRS's handling of private taxpayer information highlights the need for transparency and accountability in government agencies. The public has a right to know whether their personal information is being shared with the White House or other government agencies, and the IRS and the White House must be transparent about their actions.

Title: Guantanamo Bay Inmates Clash with Guards Over Individual Cell Housing

Article:

A recent decision by military authorities at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to transition inmates from communal housing to individual cells sparked a clash between prisoners and guards on Saturday. The move was intended to improve surveillance and monitoring, but it led to a confrontation that resulted in at least one detainee being injured by a rubber bullet.

According to the U.S. Southern Command, the decision was made after detainees began covering windows and surveillance cameras, limiting the guards' ability to monitor them at all times. The forced transfer was also used as an opportunity to evaluate the health of the prisoners, with dozens of them on a hunger strike.

The prisoners resisted the move with improvised weapons, including batons, broomsticks, and plastic water bottles, according to official reports. In response, four less-than-lethal rounds were fired, but there were no serious injuries to guards or detainees.

The incident occurred in an area of Guantanamo Bay that had evolved into a "medium-security" section since the first inmates were brought there over 10 years ago. The move to individual cells was seen as a way to improve control and security, but it has been met with resistance from the prisoners.

The hunger strike, which has been ongoing for several months, was sparked by inmates' anger over guards' searching their Qurans and other practices that began after a change in command at the base last summer. The Pentagon has named 11 inmates who are being force-fed to prevent them from starving themselves to death.

The number of prisoners on hunger strike fluctuates, with some reports citing 43 prisoners out of a total of 166, while others put the number at over 60, citing sources in the military and the inmates' defense attorneys. The incident highlights the ongoing challenges and tensions at Guantanamo Bay, where prisoners have been held for over a decade without trial or conviction.

Title: Republican Candidates Opt Out of National Convention, Citing Focus on Senate Races and Party Reforms

Article:

A growing number of Republican politicians have announced they will not attend the upcoming national convention in Tampa, Florida, citing various reasons, including a focus on their own Senate races and dissatisfaction with the party's direction. Former presidential candidate Jon Huntsman and former Virginia Senator George Allen are among those who have opted out of the August 27-30 event.

Huntsman, who finished third in the New Hampshire primary, stated that he will not attend any future Republican conventions until the party focuses on a "bigger, bolder, more confident future for the United States." He emphasized the need for the party to prioritize problem-solving, inclusiveness, and addressing the trust deficit.

Allen, who is currently running for the Senate seat of retiring Democratic Senator Jim Webb, cited his busy campaign schedule as the reason for his absence. Critics have accused him of being a "quintessential Washington insider," which may have contributed to his decision to distance himself from the national party.

Three other Republican Senate candidates, Heather Wilson in New Mexico, Rep. Denny Rehberg in Montana, and Linda McMahon in Connecticut, have also declined to attend the convention, citing the need to focus on their respective races.

Huntsman, who won two delegates for his third-place finish in New Hampshire, will release those delegates to Mitt Romney, whom he has endorsed. In his announcement, Huntsman emphasized the importance of putting the country before politics, echoing his campaign theme "Country First."

**Ocean Warming and Acidification Threaten Shark Survival**

A recent study published in Scientific Reports has raised concerns about the impact of ocean warming and acidification on shark populations. Researchers from Stellenbosch University in South Africa and the Department of Environmental Affairs found that increased carbon dioxide levels in the oceans could lead to the corrosion of shark teeth and scales, compromising their ability to swim, hunt, and feed.

The study, led by fisheries biologist Lutz Auerswald, focused on puff adder shy sharks, a small, bottom-dwelling species of cat shark that is easily handled and not endangered. The researchers found that even a moderate decrease in ocean pH, similar to what is predicted to occur by 2300, can cause significant damage to the sharks' scales.

The study's findings suggest that sharks could be displaced as apex predators, disrupting entire ocean food webs. This is particularly concerning for endangered species like great white sharks, which are already struggling to survive. The researchers note that the impacts of acidification would likely vary between species, with some sharks more resilient than others.

The study's authors emphasize the importance of testing species by species to understand the effects of ocean acidification. While some species, like lobsters, may be more resilient, others, like abalones, may be more vulnerable. The researchers highlight the need for further research to better understand the impacts of ocean warming and acidification on shark populations and to develop effective conservation strategies to protect these important predators.

Title: Stand Your Ground Laws: Separating Fact from Fiction

Article:

The debate surrounding stand your ground laws has been a contentious one, with some arguing that they promote a culture of violence and others claiming they are a necessary tool for self-defense. However, a closer examination of the data reveals a more nuanced picture.

Twenty-four states have adopted some variation of a stand-your-ground law, with the first being Florida in 2005. These laws aim to remove the legal "duty to retreat" in the face of danger while in a public place, allowing individuals to defend themselves with lethal force if necessary. But do these laws lead to an increase in gun violence?

Research suggests that the answer is not a simple yes or no. A study by Georgia State University economists found that stand-your-ground laws are associated with a significant increase in homicides among whites, particularly white males. The study estimated that between 28 and 33 additional white males are killed each month as a result of these laws. Additionally, the researchers found an increase in emergency room visits and hospital discharges related to firearm-inflicted injuries.

However, not all states have seen an increase in gun violence. In fact, some states that have adopted stand-your-ground laws have seen a decline in homicides and non-negligent manslaughters. Florida, for example, saw an uptick in these crimes after passing its law in 2005, but the trend has since returned to the pre-law levels. Similarly, Texas has seen a decline in these crimes since implementing its law.

A chart from McClatchy's interactive tool shows the rates of homicide in states with stand-your-ground laws, with some states experiencing a slight increase, while others have seen no change or a decline. Washington D.C., which has some of the strictest gun control regulations in the country, has seen a higher rate of murders and manslaughters.

While some may argue that stand-your-ground laws are a recipe for disaster, the data suggests that the relationship between these laws and gun violence is more complex. Policymakers would do well to consider the evidence and not jump to conclusions.

Title: Trump Visits Puerto Rico to Assess Hurricane Recovery Efforts, Praises Progress Made

Article:

President Donald Trump arrived in Puerto Rico on Tuesday to assess the progress of hurricane recovery efforts, saying that his toughest critic on the island, San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz, has "come a long way" since criticizing the federal response. The president's visit comes nearly two weeks after Hurricane Maria made landfall in Puerto Rico, causing widespread destruction and leaving many without access to basic necessities like food, water, and electricity.

During his visit, Trump praised the progress made in clearing roads and restoring communications, saying that truck drivers need to start transporting goods to affected areas. He also acknowledged that the situation in Puerto Rico is "much tougher" than in Texas and Florida, where he has received praise for his administration's response.

However, Trump's visit was met with criticism from Oxfam, an international organization that fights poverty, which accused the US government of mounting a "slow and inadequate response" to the crisis. The organization's president, Abby Maxman, said that essential services like clean water, food, fuel, electricity, and healthcare are in short supply, and that the administration is instead offering excuses and criticism.

The president's visit also comes after a Twitter exchange with Cruz, who had criticized the federal response as "killing us with inefficiency." Trump responded by saying that the island's residents want everything done for them and that it should be a community effort. The exchange highlights the ongoing debate over the federal government's response to the disaster and the challenges faced by Puerto Rico in recovering from the devastating storm.

**Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon Found Dead in Woods, Cause of Death Unclear**

Seoul, South Korea - Park Won-soon, the longtime mayor of South Korea's capital, Seoul, was found dead in wooded hills in northern Seoul on Friday, sparking a massive search operation by police. The 64-year-old mayor had been reported missing by his daughter earlier in the day.

According to police, Park's body was discovered at around midnight, with no signs of foul play. The cause of death remains unclear, pending further investigation.

The news comes amid a criminal probe and media reports of alleged sexual harassment against Park. A former secretary had filed a complaint against the mayor, alleging he had sexually harassed her. Police confirmed the complaint but did not elaborate on the nature of the allegations.

In a note left on his desk, Park apologized to everyone and thanked those who had supported him throughout his life. He also requested that his body be cremated and his ashes scattered over his parents' grave.

Park's family released a statement urging people to avoid spreading "groundless statements" and warning that they would take legal action against anyone spreading false information.

Park was a longtime civic activist and human rights lawyer who was elected Seoul mayor in 2011. He was known for his advocacy on social and economic inequalities and his criticism of corrupt ties between large businesses and politicians.

As a lawyer, Park was credited with winning the country's first sexual harassment conviction. He was also an outspoken critic of Japan's colonial-era policies towards Korea, including the mobilization of Korean and other women as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers.

Park's death has sparked a mix of reactions on social media, with some expressing condolences and others criticizing him for allegedly exploiting his power to harass a subordinate and then taking his own life to "avoid the fallout."

Title: Trump Administration Considers Returning to Traditional Definition of Sex

Article:

The Trump administration is considering a proposal to redefine the term "sex" in federal law, sparking controversy and debate among transgender rights activists and advocates. The proposed change would define sex as "a person's status as male or female based on immutable biological traits identifiable by or before birth," a definition that has been in place for millennia.

The proposal is seen as a rollback of the Obama administration's expansion of Title IX, which added gender identity and expression as protected characteristics under federal anti-discrimination law. The Obama administration's move was seen as a major victory for the transgender community, but critics argue that it was an overreach of executive power and ignored the original intent of the law.

The Trump administration's proposal would return the definition of sex to its original meaning, which is based on biological characteristics such as chromosomes, hormones, and genitalia. This definition would not affect the legal protections afforded to transgender individuals, as they would still be protected under other federal laws and regulations.

However, transgender rights activists and advocates argue that the proposed change would erase the identities of transgender individuals and deny their existence. They claim that the definition of sex is a social construct and that it is not fixed or binary.

The debate highlights the ongoing controversy surrounding gender identity and the role of government in defining and protecting the rights of marginalized communities. While some see the proposed change as a necessary correction of an overreach of executive power, others view it as a threat to the rights and dignity of transgender individuals.

Regardless of one's stance on the issue, it is clear that the debate is complex and multifaceted, and will likely continue to be a topic of discussion and controversy in the coming months and years.

Title: Supreme Court Expansion and Reform: A Contentious Issue in the 2020 Election

Article:

The debate over the Supreme Court's composition and size has been reignited, with some Democrats advocating for expansion and others pushing back against the idea. The controversy stems from the Republican-led Senate's decision to block President Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, and subsequent appointments by President Trump, which have shifted the Court's ideological balance.

Some Democratic presidential hopefuls, such as Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Pete Buttigieg, have expressed support for expanding the Court, citing the need to counterbalance the current conservative majority. However, Republicans are strongly opposed to any changes, viewing it as a threat to the Court's independence and impartiality.

Representative Mark Green (R-TN) has introduced a constitutional amendment to limit the number of Supreme Court justices to nine, arguing that the Court must remain a fair and impartial branch of government. Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) has also spoken out against court packing, calling it a "litmus test" for Democratic candidates and a threat to the Court's legitimacy.

The debate has been fueled by recent Supreme Court decisions, including the overturning of a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruling, which granted the Department of Homeland Security authority to detain illegal immigrants after a court hearing. Progressives have expressed concerns about the Court's growing conservative lean, while Republicans see the Court as a vital check on the other branches of government.

The issue is likely to remain a contentious topic in the 2020 election, with both sides presenting their arguments and counterarguments. While some see expanding the Court as a means to achieve a more balanced judiciary, others view it as a threat to the Court's independence and the Constitution's original intent.

**Title:** Clinton Launches Voter Registration Drive to Mobilize Sympathetic Voters Amid Immigration Concerns

**Article:**

In a bid to galvanize Latino and other households ahead of the 2016 presidential election, Hillary Clinton's campaign has launched a national voter registration program, "Mi Sueño, Tu Voto" (My Dream, Your Vote). The initiative aims to harness the political power of the 730,000 young immigrants known as Dreamers, who are prohibited from voting themselves.

The program, announced on the four-year anniversary of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, will focus on battleground states like Colorado, Nevada, North Carolina, and Florida, where Latinos and other immigrants make up a significant portion of the voting base. The campaign hopes to capitalize on the fear and outrage sparked by Donald Trump's immigration rhetoric, which has been met with widespread criticism from the Latino community.

Clinton's campaign believes that by mobilizing Dreamers and their supporters, they can persuade sympathetic voters to head to the polls in November. The program will also serve as a reminder of Trump's pledge to eliminate DACA and deport millions of immigrant families, a move that has sparked widespread concern and anxiety.

The "Mi Sueño, Tu Voto" program is part of an aggressive effort by the Clinton campaign to woo the record 27.3 million eligible Latino voters in 2016. Polling shows Trump doing worse with Latino voters than any GOP presidential candidate since 1996. The campaign will hold events across the country, including in Florida, Nevada, and North Carolina, to unveil the program and mobilize supporters.

While Obama's campaign had no formal organization program for Dreamers, door-knocking by those young immigrants helped mobilize many Latino voters who could vote. Clinton believes she can harness their power in a more formal way, particularly given her opponent's stance on immigration.

The program's national director, Lorella Praeli, stated, "DREAMers have played a pivotal role in our campaign, advocating for families who constantly live in fear of deportation – so we've created a program that aims to turn these stories into action." Astrid Silva, a Nevada DREAMer and immigrant rights activist, added, "We may not have the right to vote, but 'Mi Sueño, Tu Voto' will help ensure that our stories are heard and it will send a clear signal to Donald Trump that we can't be silenced."
