Judd claims that the troops are not being utilized effectively, as they are stationed far from the border and must be accompanied by agents, creating more work and not freeing up agents for patrols.

Judd compared the current deployment to those under the Obama and Bush administrations, stating that troops were allowed to take on more responsibilities, such as setting up lookout and observation posts, grading roads, and mending fences. In contrast, the current deployment has limited the National Guard's capabilities, according to Judd.

A Pentagon official disputed Judd's characterization, stating that the National Guard's usage has not changed significantly under the three administrations. However, Acting Border Patrol Chief Carla Provost countered that the National Guard presence does free up some agents, as troops can replace one person on teams monitoring the border remotely, allowing agents to be deployed on the front line.

Homeland Security spokeswoman Katie Waldman noted that the operation is not yet at full capacity and that more troops are on the way after a third request for assistance was recently approved. President Donald Trump's plan called for 2,000 to 4,000 National Guard troops from nearby states to support Border Patrol operations.

The debate highlights the differing opinions on the effectiveness of the National Guard's role in supporting Border Patrol operations. While some see the deployment as a necessary measure to enhance security, others believe it has not lived up to expectations.

**Thai Cave Rescue Efforts Continue as Four Boys Emerge, Eight Remain**

The rescue of 12 Thai boys and their soccer coach trapped in a flooded cave has sparked a global outpouring of emotion and admiration. The perilous rescue operation, which began on Sunday, has seen four of the boys emerge, with the remaining eight still trapped in the cave.

The rescue effort, led by Thai officials and international teams, has been ongoing for over two weeks, with the boys and their coach becoming trapped on June 23 after a soccer practice. Heavy rainfall has made the rescue challenging, with the cave's water levels dropping by about a foot on Saturday, allowing rescuers to walk deeper into the cave.

The four boys who have emerged so far are being taken to a hospital for medical assessments, with the remaining eight still trapped in the cave. The rescue operation is expected to continue through Monday, with the weather forecast predicting more heavy rainfall.

The rescue effort has been met with widespread praise and admiration, with SpaceX CEO Elon Musk offering to build a small submarine to aid the rescue. The British media have closely followed the story, with it being the most-read story on France's Le Monde and making the front of China's state-run Xinhua news website.

The Thai government has thanked the team of 90 rescue workers, more than half of whom are from international teams, for their efforts. The rescue operation has been deemed a success, with the boys being found alive and in good condition.

The boys' handwritten notes to their families, which were transported by divers and made public on Saturday, have brought comfort to those waiting anxiously for their safe return. One of the boys, Tun, wrote, "Mom and Dad, please don't worry, I am fine. I've told Yod to get ready to take me out for fried chicken. With love."

The rescue operation is a testament to the bravery and resilience of the boys, their coach, and the rescue teams involved. As the remaining eight boys are brought to safety, the world can breathe a collective sigh of relief, knowing that this incredible story has a happy ending.

Title: Debating Media Bias: A Complex and Nuanced Issue

Article:

The debate about media bias is a contentious one, with both sides of the political spectrum claiming to be the victim of unfair reporting. In our latest podcast, "How Biased Is Your Media?", we delve into the complexities of media bias and examine the various methods used to measure its impact.

The concept of media bias is not a new one, and it's a topic that has been explored in various forms of media. However, the question remains: who is more biased, the left or the right? To answer this, we spoke with a range of media practitioners and academic scholars who have tackled this issue head-on.

One of the most notable studies on media bias is the work of Tim Groseclose and Jeff Milyo, who analyzed the language used by media outlets to determine their political leanings. According to their research, most media outlets have a liberal bias, with the Wall Street Journal being the most liberal of all, even surpassing the New York Times. Fox News, on the other hand, is one of the few outlets that leans to the right.

The study's findings are based on the frequency of citations of think-tank research in media outlets, which is then compared to the think-tank research cited by elected officials on the House and Senate floor. The results show that most media outlets are more liberal than the average Congress member.

Another study by University of Chicago economists Matthew Gentzkow and Jesse Shapiro used text analysis to examine common Democratic and Republican phrases in Congress to determine which way newspapers lean. Their research found that newspapers tend to lean left, but the reasons behind this bias are more complex than simply being liberal or conservative.

The debate about media bias is not a simple one, and it's clear that both sides have valid points. While some argue that the media is biased towards the left, others claim that the right is more biased. The truth lies somewhere in between, and it's up to each individual to form their own opinion.

In our podcast, we explore the complexities of media bias and examine the various methods used to measure its impact. We also hear from a range of media practitioners and academic scholars who have tackled this issue head-on. Whether you're a media enthusiast or a skeptic, this podcast is sure to provide a nuanced and informative look at the complex issue of media bias.

**Senate Confirms Tom Price as Secretary of Health and Human Services**

The Senate confirmed Representative Tom Price (R-Ga.) as the new Secretary of Health and Human Services in a 52-47 vote on Friday. The confirmation came after a contentious debate, with Democrats expressing concerns over Price's stance on healthcare and entitlement programs.

Price, a physician and former chairman of the House Budget Committee, has been a vocal supporter of repealing the Affordable Care Act and overhauling Medicare. Democrats argued that his views are at odds with President Trump's campaign promises, which included protecting and improving the healthcare system.

Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) called Price the "exact opposite" of what Trump campaigned on, citing his support for privatizing Medicare. Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) criticized Price's investments in health-related companies, saying he should be disqualified for "basic ethics."

Despite the opposition, Republicans believe Price's confirmation is crucial to syncing up with the White House on the plan to repeal and replace ObamaCare. Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) hopes the confirmation will speed up the process, while Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) praised Price as the "right man" to lead the department.

Price's confirmation marks a significant step forward for the Trump administration's healthcare agenda, but the debate is far from over. Democrats are likely to continue using Price's stance on Medicare as a target in their efforts to block future healthcare reforms.

Title: Washington's Budget Impasse: A Tale of Two Sides

Article:

As the deadline for the sequester looms, Washington is abuzz with activity, but the urgency to find a solution seems to be lacking. The White House and Congress are engaged in a high-stakes game of political posturing, with neither side willing to budge. President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner have not spoken since Thursday, and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Boehner have not met since January 21.

The sequester, a series of across-the-board spending cuts, is set to take effect on Friday, but neither side seems to be in a hurry to find a solution. Obama has called for slashing tax loopholes to offset the cuts, while Boehner has proposed closing loopholes as part of a broader tax reform effort. The Senate is set to vote on a bill to increase taxes on high-income earners, but it is unlikely to pass the House.

The real problem is that neither bill would pass the other chamber. The House will leave town on Friday, just as the cuts take effect, leaving many wondering what the future holds. Republicans are caught in a bind, torn between messaging about Obama's role in crafting the sequester and the need to cut spending.

Boehner and his team believe they are in a strong position, with Obama calling for tax increases to blunt the impact of the cuts and Boehner standing firm on cutting spending. However, the same week that bipartisanship seems out of reach, Boehner is voicing support for a major bipartisan undertaking: tax reform. He has designated the leadership's most prized bill title, H.R. 1, to rewriting the Tax Code.

The question remains: what's the urgency in solving this crisis? With the sequester set to take effect and neither side willing to budge, it seems that the answer may be "none."

Title: Former Police Officer Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison for Fatal Shooting of Unarmed Man

Article:

A federal judge has sentenced former police officer Michael Slager to 20 years in prison for the fatal shooting of Walter Scott, an unarmed black man, in a 2015 traffic stop in South Carolina. The decision comes after Slager pleaded guilty to violating Scott's civil rights by using excessive force.

The incident was captured on video by a bystander's cellphone, drawing national attention to the case and renewing concerns about police treatment of minorities. The footage showed Slager shooting Scott eight times, hitting him five times, as Scott was running away.

In court, Slager acknowledged that he had committed a "terrible mistake" and expressed remorse for his actions. However, the judge rejected the defense argument that Slager was provoked or acted in the heat of passion, instead finding that he had committed second-degree murder and obstructed justice by lying to investigators.

The sentence is a rare instance of a police officer being held accountable for an on-duty shooting. Scott's family and their lawyers hailed the punishment as a historic moment for justice, calling on law enforcement to rethink the use of deadly force.

While some family members forgave Slager, others expressed ongoing pain and trauma from the incident. "We will never be the same again," said Anthony Scott, the motorist's older brother. "How could someone shoot someone in the back like that as they were running away?"

The case has sparked a wider conversation about police accountability and the need for greater transparency and accountability in law enforcement.

Title: Political Frenzy Surrounds Romney's Response to Embassy Attacks

Article:

The recent attacks on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya have sparked a heated debate in the political arena, with both sides trading barbs over the handling of the crisis. Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's response to the attacks drew criticism from both the left and right, with some Republicans seeing it as an opportunity to paint President Obama as the heir to Jimmy Carter.

Romney's statement, which condemned the attacks and criticized the administration's response, was met with skepticism by some who felt it was too early and too political. Democrats, on the other hand, accused Romney of being reckless and lacking a comprehensive plan to address the crisis.

The attacks have added a foreign policy crisis to the mix, which some analysts see as reminiscent of the Iranian hostage situation that plagued Carter's presidency in the 1980s. This has led some Republicans to draw parallels between Obama's handling of the crisis and Carter's, with some even going so far as to compare the two presidents.

However, others have defended Romney's response, saying it was timely and correct. "Romney's condemnation of the apology wasn't embarrassing or too early; it was correct, it was timely, and the only beef commentators have with it is that the White House didn't issue it first," said Danielle Pletka, vice president for foreign- and defense-policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute.

The debate highlights the complexities of foreign policy and the challenges of responding to crises in a rapidly changing world. While some see Romney's response as a political ploy, others believe it is a necessary step in addressing the crisis and protecting American interests.

Ultimately, the attacks on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya serve as a stark reminder of the importance of diplomacy and the need for a comprehensive approach to foreign policy. As the political rhetoric continues to swirl, it is clear that the stakes are high and the challenges are great.

Title: John Kerry's Unlikely Success: A Year of Diplomatic Progress

Article:

John Kerry, the United States Secretary of State, has defied expectations and achieved significant diplomatic progress in his first year in office. Despite inheriting a complex and challenging international landscape, Kerry has demonstrated creativity, tenacity, and a willingness to take risks, earning him widespread praise from diplomats and experts.

Kerry's success can be attributed to his tireless travel schedule, mastery of the facts, and force of personality. He has built on the work of his predecessor, Hillary Clinton, to restore diplomacy to the center of U.S. foreign policy. Kerry has also shown a willingness to challenge leaders overseas and within the administration, earning him the respect of many.

The secretary's efforts have yielded significant progress on several fronts. He has helped broker a chemical weapons deal with Syria, made progress on the Iran nuclear negotiations, and launched a renewed push for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. While challenges remain, Kerry's achievements have raised expectations for his tenure and the potential for future breakthroughs.

However, Kerry's success is not without its challenges. The success of his efforts will depend on the ability to capitalize on the progress made in the coming year. The fate of the Iran deal, the effectiveness of the Syria chemical weapons agreement, and the prospects for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks will all be crucial in determining Kerry's legacy.

Moreover, the secretary's work is not limited to the Middle East. The United States must also address the decay in Iraq, the potential for similar instability in Afghanistan, and the broader global challenges posed by the spread of extremism and terrorism.

In conclusion, John Kerry's first year as Secretary of State has been marked by significant diplomatic progress. While challenges remain, his achievements have raised expectations for his tenure and the potential for future breakthroughs. The coming year will be crucial in determining Kerry's legacy and the success of his efforts to shape U.S. international priorities.

Title: Trump's Response to Coronavirus Raises Concerns Amid Growing Pandemic Risk

Article:

The Trump administration's handling of the coronavirus outbreak has raised concerns about its preparedness and response to the growing pandemic risk. While the virus is still under control within the US, experts warn that a poor response could have devastating political consequences for President Trump.

The administration's recent press conference on the virus was marked by inconsistencies and downplaying of the risk. President Trump emphasized the importance of treating the coronavirus like the flu, but also downplayed the likelihood of a widespread US outbreak, despite warnings from public health officials. The confirmation of a new US case, which may have been transmitted locally, has raised concerns about the potential for a pandemic.

Sources close to the White House revealed that the decision to put Vice President Mike Pence in charge of the administration's response was made just yesterday, with some officials expressing shock and surprise at the announcement. Pence's involvement in Trump's re-election campaign has raised concerns about the politicization of the response.

Trump's statements have been influenced by his concerns about the stock market, which has been affected by the virus. He has also warned Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar to avoid criticizing China's response to the virus, saying they have "enough problems" without additional criticism.

The administration's response has been criticized for being slow and disjointed, with some experts warning that a poor response could have serious consequences for public health and the economy. As the pandemic risk continues to grow, the administration's ability to respond effectively will be crucial in preventing a global health crisis.

**Government Surveillance Programs Spark Controversy: What You Need to Know**

The recent revelations about two secret National Security Agency (NSA) intelligence-gathering programs have sparked widespread debate and concern about government surveillance. The programs, revealed by the Guardian and Washington Post, involve collecting phone records and data from major Internet companies, including Google and Facebook.

The NSA's Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, has issued a statement defending the programs, calling the leak "reprehensible" and emphasizing the importance of the programs in preventing terrorist attacks. Clapper also moved to declassify information about the programs, stating that they are subject to strict court-imposed restrictions and are used to target non-U.S. persons outside the United States.

The programs, which began in 2007, involve the FBI and NSA tapping into major Internet companies to collect audio, video, and other data. The data is then used to identify suspicious individuals and conduct secondary searches. The Utah Data Center is believed to be a repository for this material.

The companies involved, including Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and others, have issued statements saying they only comply with legal requests for data and do not provide direct access to government agencies. However, critics argue that the programs violate privacy and civil liberties, and that the government's claims of strict oversight and safeguards are not sufficient.

The controversy has sparked a heated debate about the balance between national security and individual privacy. While some argue that the programs are necessary to prevent terrorist attacks, others believe that the government's actions are an overreach and a threat to democracy.

In the midst of the controversy, the government has taken the rare step of moving to declassify information about the programs, in an effort to defend them against criticism. The debate is likely to continue, as the public weighs the importance of national security against the need to protect individual privacy and civil liberties.

Title: UN Report Highlights Discrepancies in Voting Practices, Raising Concerns for the US

Article:

A recent report by the US State Department has shed light on the voting practices of the United Nations General Assembly and Security Council in 2018. The report highlights the significant discrepancies between the US and other member states, with the US voting against 70% of resolutions requiring a vote. This is a stark contrast to the Obama administration, where the US was in alignment with the UN 41% of the time.

The report also analyzed the voting records of the 15 members of the UN Security Council and 193 members of the General Assembly, comparing them to the US. The results show that the US is out of sync with the UN in more than two-thirds of votes, raising concerns within the Trump administration about the organization's alignment with US interests.

The report also examined the voting patterns on Israel-related resolutions, with the US voting against 21 anti-Israel resolutions in 2018, a significant increase from the previous year. The US supported these resolutions just 14% of the time, highlighting the ongoing anti-Israel bias within the UN.

The report also listed the top 10 countries that are most out of sync with the US, including Burundi, Syria, North Korea, Turkmenistan, Venezuela, Nicaragua, Niger, Cuba, and Iran. Afghanistan and Pakistan, which receive significant US aid, voted with the US only 19% and 15% of the time, respectively.

On the other hand, the report highlighted the friendliest countries to the US, including Israel, Micronesia, Canada, Australia, Marshall Islands, Great Britain, Hungary, France, Poland, and the Czech Republic.

The report's findings have sparked concerns about the value for money of the US contribution to the UN, with the US paying more than 20% of the UN budget. The report also noted that the US has pulled out of several UN institutions, including the Human Rights Council and UNESCO, and has reduced its funding to the UN Palestinian refugee agency.

In response to the report, new UN Ambassador Kelly Craft has slammed anti-Israel bias at the UN, stating that it is "inexcusable" and that the US will "vigorously oppose all such efforts." Israel's Ambassador Danny Danon has also spoken out against anti-Israel bias, citing instances of progress and successes in recent years.

The report's findings are likely to be addressed by President Trump during his address to the UN General Assembly on Tuesday, as he weighs the value for money of the US contribution to the UN and the organization's alignment with US interests.

Title: Leaks and Intelligence Sharing: A Delicate Balance in the Fight Against Terrorism

Article:

The recent leaks of sensitive information related to the Manchester bombing investigation have sparked a heated debate about the importance of maintaining confidentiality in counterterrorism efforts. The National Police Chiefs' Council in Britain has condemned the leaks, stating that they undermine investigations and erode the trust between law enforcement agencies. Manchester's top police official, Chief Constable Ian Hopkins, echoed this sentiment, emphasizing the distress caused to families of victims and witnesses.

The controversy surrounding the leaks has led to a temporary suspension of intelligence sharing between British and American authorities. However, after receiving fresh assurances from the Trump administration, the police have resumed sharing information. Mark Rowley, an assistant commissioner at Scotland Yard, emphasized that the police are working closely with international partners, including those in the "Five Eyes" intelligence alliance.

The leaks have also raised questions about the role of intelligence sharing in the fight against terrorism. While some argue that transparency is essential in this context, others believe that the disclosure of sensitive information can put lives at risk and hinder investigations.

The New York Times has faced criticism for its coverage of the Manchester bombing, with some accusing the publication of sensationalism and disrespect for the victims. However, the newspaper maintains that its reporting is guided by strict guidelines and is essential to informing the public about the impact of terrorism.

In a broader context, the leaks have highlighted the complex and often delicate balance between maintaining confidentiality and sharing information in the fight against terrorism. The Trump administration has taken a mixed stance on leaks, praising them during the presidential campaign but criticizing them in recent months.

As the world grapples with the challenges of terrorism, it is essential to strike a balance between transparency and confidentiality. While leaks can be damaging, they can also be a necessary tool in the fight against terrorism. Ultimately, the key is to find a balance that prioritizes the safety of individuals and the integrity of investigations while also keeping the public informed about the threats they face.

**Missouri Governor Poised to Sign Restrictive Abortion Law, Joining Wave of State-Level Restrictions**

Missouri Governor Mike Parson is expected to sign a bill banning most abortions in the state after the eighth week of pregnancy, a move that would make Missouri one of the most restrictive states in the country. The bill, approved by the Republican-controlled state legislature last week, would join a growing list of states imposing new restrictions on abortion.

The Missouri bill, like others passed in several other states this year, aims to challenge the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision, which established a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy. The bill would not include exceptions for cases of rape or incest, unlike some other states' laws.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has vowed to sue to block the Alabama law, which bans abortion at all times and in almost all cases, including those resulting from rape or incest. The ACLU has also joined Planned Parenthood in suing Ohio over its six-week abortion ban.

Mississippi will defend its new law banning abortion once a fetal heartbeat has been detected in a federal appeals court, after the Center for Reproductive Rights sued to block it from taking effect.

The debate over abortion is one of the most contentious social issues in the United States, with opponents citing religious beliefs that fetuses deserve rights similar to those of infants, while abortion rights advocates argue that the bans deprive women of equal rights and put those seeking illegal methods at risk.

Several other states, including Kentucky, Georgia, Utah, Mississippi, and Arkansas, have passed new restrictions on abortion this year. The conservative majority on the Supreme Court, bolstered by two judicial appointments by President Donald Trump, has emboldened lawmakers to push for stricter laws.

The Supreme Court took no action on appeals seeking to revive two abortion restrictions enacted in Indiana in 2016, leaving the fate of these laws uncertain.

Title: NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg Discusses Burden-Sharing and Defense Spending with Fox Business Network

Article:

NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg recently appeared on Fox Business Network's "Mornings with Maria" with host Maria Bartiromo, where he discussed the alliance's efforts to increase defense spending and burden-sharing among its member countries.

Stoltenberg emphasized that NATO's primary concerns are the rise of terrorism and the importance of fair burden-sharing within the alliance. He noted that President Trump has been clear about the need for European allies and Canada to spend more, and that this message is having an impact. According to Stoltenberg, all allies have begun to increase their defense spending, and many have plans in place to meet the 2% of GDP target by 2024.

The NATO Secretary General also highlighted the progress made by some countries in meeting the 2% target. He mentioned that more allies now meet the target, and that all allies have begun to increase their defense spending. Stoltenberg also noted that the majority of allies have plans in place to be at the 2% target by 2024.

The discussion also touched on President Trump's frustration with what he sees as a lack of fairness in NATO's financial contributions. In a speech in July 2018, Trump stated that some countries were not meeting their commitments, and that the alliance's defense spending was going down. He also tweeted that all NATO nations must meet their 2% commitment and that it should ultimately go to 4%.

According to a NATO press release, the alliance came to an agreement in 2014 that each member state would increase its defense spending to 2% of its respective GDP by 2024. The release also noted that several countries have significantly increased their contributions since 2014, including Estonia, Romania, Lithuania, Latvia, Poland, and Bulgaria.

The United States still provides the most defense spending, with 3.42% of its GDP, according to the NATO report. Stoltenberg emphasized that the increased spending will allow NATO to invest in new capabilities, including advanced fighter aircraft, attack helicopters, missile defense, and surveillance drones.

Overall, the discussion highlighted the importance of burden-sharing and defense spending within NATO, and the progress made by some countries in meeting the alliance's targets.

Title: Virginia Lawmakers Consider New Gun Ownership Requirements

Article:

A proposed bill in the Virginia state legislature aims to regulate the ownership of certain firearms, specifically AR-15s and other semi-automatic rifles deemed "assault firearms" by lawmakers. Delegate Mark Levine (D) introduced the legislation, which would require owners of these weapons to obtain a license from the state.

Under the proposed bill, HB 961, owners of AR-15s and other "assault firearms" would need to apply for a permit from the Department of State Police. Those who fail to comply would be labeled felons. The legislation defines an "assault firearm" as a semi-automatic center-fire rifle that expels single or multiple projectiles by action of an explosion of a combustible material, with a fixed magazine capacity exceeding 10 rounds.

The bill also outlines specific cosmetic characteristics that would categorize a gun as an "assault firearm," including folding or telescoping stocks, pistol grips, thumbhole stocks, and other features. If the bill passes and is signed into law, current owners of AR-15s and other "assault firearms" would have a grace period to obtain a license from the state.

Delegate Levine's bill aims to address concerns about the proliferation of certain firearms and the potential risks they pose to public safety. The proposed legislation would provide a framework for responsible gun ownership and help ensure that individuals who own these weapons are aware of their responsibilities and obligations.

The debate surrounding gun ownership and regulation is complex and contentious, with proponents of stricter regulations citing concerns about public safety and opponents arguing that such measures infringe on Second Amendment rights. As the bill moves through the legislative process, it remains to be seen whether it will become law and what implications it may have for gun owners in Virginia.

Title: Gun Control Efforts Face Uncertain Future Amid Shift in Public Opinion

Article:

In the aftermath of the Newtown, Connecticut, massacre, President Barack Obama pledged to use his office to pass new gun control laws. The president has since held rallies, used children as props, and urged Congress to "finish the job" for the nation's children. However, recent polls suggest that public support for stricter gun laws is waning.

According to CBS News, support for stricter gun laws dropped from 57% to 47%, while CNN reported a decline from 52% to 43%. An ABC News/Washington Post poll showed a slight decrease from 54% to 52%, still lower than the support for gay marriage. The latest trend in polling suggests that Congress may have waited too long to address gun control.

The proposed assault weapons ban and limit on magazine size have been rejected by Democrats in the Senate, and the debate has shifted to increasing the reach of background checks. Any bill that passes the Senate and House will be less extensive than the president or his supporters would like.

The gun control debate has highlighted the president's limitations as a legislative mechanic and his inability to shape public opinion. Before writing rhetorical checks that his own party's majority leader in the Senate, Harry Reid, couldn't cash, the president might have consulted with Reid about what was plausible and adjusted accordingly. It's true that 90% of Americans support universal background checks, but even the NRA wants states to keep more complete records of who is forbidden from purchasing guns.

The article does not take a stance on the issue of gun control, but rather presents the facts and statistics to provide a neutral perspective on the current state of the debate.

Title: GOP Debate: A Night of Heated Discussions and Memorable Moments

The second Republican presidential debate has come and gone, with 11 candidates taking the stage to discuss a range of topics, from immigration to vaccinations. The debate, hosted by CNN, saw a mix of strong performances and memorable moments, with some candidates standing out more than others.

Carly Fiorina, who was bumped up from the "kids table" debate following a change in CNN's eligibility criteria, wasted no time in justifying her presence on the main stage. She dominated the first third of the debate, showcasing her knowledge on foreign policy and her ability to seamlessly connect Iran and pro-life issues.

Fiorina's performance was marked by her tactful response to a question about Donald Trump's "look at that face" comment, choosing not to engage in a personal attack and instead focusing on the issue at hand.

Other notable moments came from Senator Rand Paul, who called out Governor Jeb Bush for his past marijuana use and reluctance to support medical or recreational marijuana legalization. Bush admitted to smoking weed, and the two engaged in a heated debate on the topic.

Senator Marco Rubio had a solid performance, highlighting the need for sensible immigration reform and a merit-based system. He emphasized the importance of fixing the legal immigration system, which he believes "no longer works."

Governor Chris Christie was more lively and focused than in the first debate, defending President Bush's invasion of Afghanistan and citing his family's personal experience on September 11, 2001, and his work as a prosecutor.

One of the most surprising moments came when Dr. Ben Carson and Donald Trump were asked to address Trump's claim that vaccines cause autism. Carson, a neurosurgeon, failed to condemn Trump's comments and instead opted for a lame joke, leaving many viewers scratching their heads.

Governors Jeb Bush and Scott Walker didn't have any particularly memorable lines, but their exchange defending George W. Bush's policies was a highlight.

Overall, the debate saw a range of strong performances and memorable moments, with some candidates standing out more than others. As the campaign season continues, it will be interesting to see how these candidates' performances shape their chances in the election.

Title: Emmy Awards Ratings Plummet as Trump Bashing Dominates the Show

Article:

The 69th annual Emmy Awards, hosted by Stephen Colbert, have seen a significant decline in viewership, with a 2.4% drop from the 2016 edition. The event, which focused heavily on attacking President Trump, has been met with lukewarm reception from American audiences. The 8.2 overnight rating among metered market households is the lowest in Emmy history, with six markets in Florida still recovering from Hurricane Irma.

Media Research Center vice president Dan Gainor believes the Emmys are a "Hollywood bubble show" that fails to represent the interests of the majority of Americans. "Actors and directors get to pretend they are important because they are doing such insightful takes on life in America, when they have zero idea what life in America is for the other 330 million people," Gainor told Fox News.

Despite the low ratings, Gainor doesn't think the Emmys will shy away from politics anytime soon. "Hollywood won't walk away from politics. The left wants to force politics into every single aspect of our lives -- from sports to movies to the food we eat. They won't be satisfied until we are all appropriately woke to their struggles du jour," Gainor said.

The event saw several attacks on President Trump, including Alec Baldwin's acceptance speech for his portrayal of Trump on "Saturday Night Live." Baldwin mocked Trump for not winning an Emmy during his time hosting "The Apprentice." Former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer even made an appearance to poke fun at his tenure, sparking controversy among viewers.

Academy Awards prognosticator Steve Pond called the event "the most political Emmys show ever," with voters opting for programs with a political agenda, such as "The Handmaid's Tale" and "Atlanta," over less-polarizing shows like "Stranger Things." "Voters made it clear: They were sending a message," Pond wrote.

Gainor believes the Emmys celebrate shows that few people care about, such as "The Handmaid's Tale" and "Veep," rather than shows that resonate with the general public. "The only show the Emmys were honoring that most people even recognize was 'Saturday Night Live,'" Gainor said.

The Emmys went head-to-head against NBC's "Sunday Night Football," which likely didn't help viewership. The awards have now hit new ratings lows for three straight years. Perhaps some viewers want to enjoy the awards show as an escape from politics, or perhaps some viewers simply don't agree with everything the Hollywood elite has to say.

Title: The Disconnect Between Public Opinion and Political Action: A Complex Web of Factors

Article:

The recent failure of a bill to expand background checks on gun sales in the US Senate has sparked widespread disappointment and frustration among those advocating for stricter gun control measures. The bill, which had the support of 54 senators, was unable to overcome the 60-vote threshold required to overcome a filibuster. This outcome has left many wondering why, despite overwhelming public support, the legislation did not become law.

Several factors contribute to the disconnect between public opinion and political action. Firstly, the Senate's rules allow for minority groups to block legislation, even if it has majority support. In this case, the bill required 60 votes to pass, but only received 54. This highlights the importance of the Senate's unique structure and the need for a supermajority to pass legislation.

Secondly, politicians often prioritize the opinions of their constituents over those of the general public. While polls may show widespread support for a particular issue, elected officials may not feel the same level of urgency or passion among their constituents. This can lead to a disconnect between what the public wants and what their representatives do.

Thirdly, the intensity of opinions can play a significant role in shaping political outcomes. A passionate minority can be more effective in influencing politicians than a relatively indifferent majority. In the case of gun control, those opposed to stricter regulations are often more vocal and active in their opposition, while supporters may be less engaged.

Fourthly, the timing of events can also impact the outcome. The Newtown shootings, which sparked renewed calls for gun control, occurred during a period of relative calm in Congress, and the issue may have faded from the public's attention as the legislative session progressed.

Finally, the ability of presidents to drive public opinion and political action is limited. While President Obama has used his bully pulpit to advocate for gun control, his efforts may not be enough to overcome the complex web of factors that influence political outcomes.

The failure of the background check bill is a reminder that the relationship between public opinion and political action is complex and multifaceted. While it is natural to feel frustrated and disappointed by the outcome, it is essential to understand the various factors that contribute to the disconnect. By acknowledging these factors, we can work towards finding solutions that better align public opinion with political action.

Title: Bloomberg Drops Out of Presidential Race, Endorses Biden

Article:

Billionaire media mogul Michael Bloomberg has officially dropped out of the Democratic presidential race, citing a lack of momentum and a desire to support a candidate with a better chance of defeating President Trump. Bloomberg, who entered the race late and spent over $500 million on advertising, won only one contest, American Samoa, and secured four delegates, which cost him around $5 million per delegate.

In a statement, Bloomberg acknowledged that his presence on the ballot had likely blunted the momentum of his fellow candidate, former Vice President Joe Biden, and that staying in the race would make it more difficult to achieve his goal of defeating Trump. He threw his support and fortune behind Biden, citing the former vice president's commitment to issues such as gun safety, healthcare, climate change, and good jobs.

Bloomberg's exit leaves just two major candidates remaining in the race: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii. Former Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Amy Klobuchar, who dropped out of the race earlier, have also endorsed Biden.

President Trump took to Twitter to respond to Bloomberg's decision, saying that the billionaire had "saved himself a billion dollars" by dropping out and that he would now "pour money into Sleepy Joe's campaign, hoping to save face." Trump also predicted that Bloomberg would "fire Tim O'Brien and all of the fools and truly dumb people who got him into this mess."

Bloomberg's departure from the race marks the end of his presidential bid, which was marked by a significant investment of his personal fortune and a late entry into the contest. Despite his efforts, he was unable to gain significant traction and ultimately decided to throw his support behind Biden.

Title: Education Department Issues New Guidance on Enrolling Undocumented Students

The United States Department of Education has issued new guidance to public school districts, emphasizing their obligation to enroll students regardless of their immigration status. The guidance, announced by Attorney General Eric Holder and Education Secretary Arne Duncan, aims to ensure that schools do not discriminate against children of undocumented parents.

The updated guidance encourages schools to be more flexible in accepting documents from parents, such as utility bills or leases, to prove a child's age and residence. This move is intended to address concerns that some schools have been requiring parents to provide Social Security numbers or driver's licenses, which can be difficult for undocumented immigrants to obtain.

The guidance is based on a 1982 Supreme Court decision, Plyler v. Doe, which established that children of undocumented immigrants have a right to a public education. The court struck down a Texas statute that denied funding for education to the children of illegal immigrants and a school district's attempt to charge undocumented persons an annual $1,000 tuition fee for each illegal immigrant student.

Some states and school boards have challenged the ruling, with California being a notable example. In 1994, California voters approved a referendum to deny all state-funded benefits, including education, to illegal immigrants. The courts later struck down the referendum.

The Education Department's Office for Civil Rights has received 17 complaints related to enrollment policies since it first issued guidance in 2011. Complaints were filed in Ohio, Colorado, Louisiana, New Mexico, North Carolina, and Washington, D.C., among others.

The updated guidance is intended to ensure that schools do not create barriers for undocumented children and families seeking to access public education. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has praised the guidance, stating that it reaffirms the principle that all children living in the country have a right to equal access to public education.

In conclusion, the new guidance aims to promote equal access to education for all students, regardless of their immigration status. It is essential for schools to adhere to this guidance and ensure that no child is locked out of the schoolhouse door.

**Syria's Chemical Weapons Allegations Spark International Concern and Debate**

The Syrian government's alleged use of poison gas in an attack near Damascus has sparked widespread concern and debate, with the international community calling for a thorough investigation. The incident has reignited the debate over President Obama's "red line" and the potential consequences for the embattled Syrian regime.

Rebel forces claim that the attack killed hundreds, with videos and photos showing victims convulsing and choking, and children wrapped in white shrouds with their faces visible. The Syrian regime has denied the allegations, but the White House is urging the regime to allow a 20-member team of United Nations chemical weapons inspectors to examine the new sites.

The incident has sparked an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council, with Argentina's ambassador calling for a "thorough, impartial, and prompt investigation." Russia and China approved the move, but blocked a proposal by the United States and its allies to issue a stronger statement on the incident.

The reports emerged almost a year to the day after President Obama issued his "red line" warning, saying he would ensure that Damascus would suffer "enormous consequences" if chemical weapons were used or even prepared for deployment. The White House has not yet confirmed the reports, but the incident poses a test for the embattled Syrian regime.

The international community is divided on the best course of action. Some lawmakers on Capitol Hill are calling for intervention to stop the civil war, which has killed over 100,000 people, according to UN estimates. Others are urging caution, citing the potential risks and uncertainties of military intervention.

The Pentagon has expressed concerns about the effectiveness of any military action, with General Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, writing that the side the US chooses to support must be ready to promote American interests when the balance shifts in their favor. The general also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a no-fly zone, which could draw the US deeper into the conflict.

The incident has also sparked debate about the effectiveness of President Obama's "red line" policy. Some lawmakers argue that the US has not taken sufficient action to enforce the policy, while others argue that the US should be cautious and avoid getting drawn into another costly and complicated conflict.

The investigation is now in the hands of the UN team, which will have to renegotiate with the Syrian government to gain access to the sites. The incident highlights the ongoing challenges and complexities of the Syrian crisis, and the need for a comprehensive and impartial investigation to determine the facts.

**Title:** Hospital Housekeepers and Maintenance Workers on the Front Lines of the COVID-19 Battle

**Article:**

As the novel coronavirus continues to spread across the United States, hospital housekeepers and maintenance workers are quietly toiling on the front lines, often without the necessary personal protective equipment (PPE) to keep themselves safe. These essential workers, who are responsible for keeping hospitals running, are often overlooked and underappreciated.

Katina McDavis, a 43-year-old housekeeper at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, spends 40 hours a week cleaning hospital rooms. She and her colleagues are often left without guidance on when and how to protect themselves, and sometimes are told they don't need PPE at all.

According to a non-scientific poll by the Service Employees International Union, 75% of respondents, mostly housekeepers and nurse's assistants in Chicago and Indiana, have been told either they don't need PPE or must ask a nurse for it. However, many maintenance workers and housekeepers report receiving conflicting messages when they ask what precautions are needed.

Hospitals have protocols in place to keep housekeepers safe, but often drop the ball on communicating them, said Anne Igoe, vice president of a Chicago-based branch of the Service Employees International Union. For example, rooms with COVID-19 patients have been mistakenly labeled otherwise, leading housekeepers to enter with insufficient PPE.

Some hospitals are seeking to hire more housekeepers to cope with the increased patient loads and demands, but retaining those they hire is another matter. Angel Medrano, a recruiter of hospital housekeeping staff in the San Francisco Bay Area, said a hospital he works with tripled the number of housekeeping staff it required in March. However, around 20 people quit within the first couple of days on the job, mostly over concerns over PPE.

The lack of N95 masks is a major concern for many of these workers, who are often at higher risk of contracting the virus due to their jobs. Kimberly Hughes, a housekeeper at a Montana hospital, has the chronic inflammatory lung disease COPD, leaving her at higher risk of complications from COVID-19. She has been told to hold a 60-pound bag of laundry from a COVID-19 patient's room away from her body, but said she couldn't.

The pandemic has also taken a toll on the mental health of these workers. A mechanic at NYU Langone in New York, who declined to be named for fear of losing his job, said he is so worried about getting infected that he is living apart from his wife and three-year-old son until the pandemic ends. His son recently woke up to a nightmare that his mother was taken away in an ambulance, and he worries about how he will explain to his son that his daddy probably won't be able to come for his birthday.

These workers are the unsung heroes of the COVID-19 pandemic, working tirelessly behind the scenes to keep hospitals running. It is essential that their concerns about PPE and safety are heard and addressed to ensure their well-being and the well-being of those they care for.

Title: The Paradox of Trump's Popularity: Unpacking the Logic Behind His Support

Article:

In a recent commencement speech at Rutgers University, former President Barack Obama criticized the current political climate, specifically targeting anti-intellectualism and the rejection of facts and evidence. He emphasized the importance of critical thinking, science, and expertise in policy-making. However, the question remains: why do Donald Trump's supporters continue to back him despite his often illogical and factually inaccurate statements?

One possible explanation is that Trump's supporters are seeking a sense of action and emotional connection, rather than intellectual rigor. According to a study by the Monitor, Trump's supporters feel that he has tapped into something deep within them, a sense of American exceptionalism and a desire to make the country "big and bad" again.

This perspective is supported by political scientists Eric Oliver and Wendy Rahn, who found that Trump voters are more likely to distrust traditional sources of authority, including experts and mainstream media. This is a key characteristic of political populism, which emphasizes the power of the people over the elite.

In this context, Trump's supporters may not see his statements as "debunked" or "illogical," but rather as a refreshing departure from the usual political norms. They may view themselves as the rational ones in the national political discussion, as opposed to Obama's Democrats.

The article highlights the complexity of the Trump phenomenon, which cannot be reduced to a simple explanation. While Obama's critique of anti-intellectualism is well-taken, it is essential to understand the emotional and psychological factors that drive Trump's supporters. Ultimately, the debate over Trump's presidency is not just about facts and evidence but also about the values and beliefs that shape our political discourse.

**Ross Perot, Businessman and Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89**

Ross Perot, a billionaire businessman, philanthropist, and independent presidential candidate, has passed away at the age of 89 after a five-month battle with leukemia. Perot, who ran for president in 1992 and 1996, was known for his unconventional approach to politics and his commitment to supporting U.S. veterans.

Born in Texas, Perot started his career in sales at IBM, where he excelled, and later founded his first company, Electronic Data Systems, with just $1,000 in savings. He went on to launch Perot Systems, which was acquired by Dell in 2009 for $3.9 billion.

As a presidential candidate, Perot ran on a platform of fiscal responsibility and protectionism, winning nearly 19% of the vote in the 1992 election, the biggest slice of the electorate for a third-party candidate since Theodore Roosevelt's Bull Moose Party in the 1912 election. He was known for his quirky personality and his ability to connect with voters through his non-traditional campaign route, which included lengthy time slots on network television to lay out his political views.

Perot was also a veteran himself, serving in the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War, and went on to become a lifelong advocate for U.S. veterans. He was honored in 2009 by then-Veterans Affairs Secretary James Peake for his advocacy efforts.

Perot's legacy extends beyond his business and political endeavors. He was a man of integrity and compassion, who touched the lives of countless people through his charitable endeavors and unwavering support of the military and veterans. His family, including his wife, Margot, five children, and 16 grandchildren, survive him.

Perot's impact on American politics was significant, and he was described by Allan Lichtman, a distinguished professor of history at American University, as "certainly the most influential political force in the late 20th century from outside the regular party system."

Title: Midterm Election Polls Show Democrats' Advantage Narrows as Voters Compartmentalize Family Separation Issue

Article:

A recent CBS poll has revealed that the Democrats' advantage over Republicans heading into the November midterm elections has narrowed to just four points. The poll, conducted between June 21-22, 2018, surveyed 2,063 adults and had a margin of error of 2.6%. The results show that 36% of respondents want to see Republicans maintain control of Congress, while 40% prefer a Democratic-controlled Congress.

The poll also highlights the complexity of the family separation issue, with nearly 73% of Americans opposing the practice of separating children from their parents as a form of deterrence. However, the results suggest that voters are compartmentalizing the issue, with many placing blame on the parents for bringing their children into the U.S. illegally. According to the poll, half of voters believe parents are mostly to blame, rising to roughly eight in 10 among Republicans.

The poll also found that voters in key states such as Texas, Florida, and Arizona believe Hispanic illegal and legal immigrants have had a negative impact on their lives. Nearly four in 10 voters in these states say immigrants from Mexico and South America have made life worse, compared to a lower 33% among voters across the country. Republicans are particularly likely to say immigrants have negatively impacted their state.

The poll also notes that the gun control debate has had an impact on the Democrats' advantage since January. The Washington Post poll in April found that the gap between support for the two parties in House races has narrowed considerably since the gun control debate became a raging issue after the Florida school shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in February. The poll suggested that neither Democrats nor Republicans hold an advantage in support among the 42% of likely voters who want congressional candidates to share their views on the issue.

Overall, the poll highlights the complexity of the issues driving voter sentiment and the challenges facing both parties as they head into the midterm elections.

**Obama's Path to Victory: A Different Year, Different Challenges**

As the Democratic National Convention gets underway in Charlotte, North Carolina, President Barack Obama faces a unique set of challenges in his bid for re-election. With unemployment rates still high, Obama must make the case that his economic policies are the better path to sustained recovery, while also re-energizing his 2008 base and addressing concerns among independents and conservative Democrats in battleground states.

Historically, no incumbent has been re-elected with unemployment rates as high as they are today. However, Obama's campaign believes he has several key advantages, including his incumbency and the ability to cobble together multiple paths to 270 Electoral College votes.

The economy remains the driving force behind the 2012 election, with the unemployment rate stuck at 8.3% in February 2009 and 8.3% in August 2012. While the Obama administration argues that its policies are slowly helping to pull the economy out of recession, the Romney campaign sees this as proof that the president's economic policies have failed.

To make his case, Obama will focus on the fairness of his approach and the need for a sustained recovery. He will also aim to re-energize his 2008 base, which was critical to his victory. However, the president's campaign recognizes that it cannot rely solely on the dynamics that motivated Obama voters four years ago and must make gains among independents and conservative Democrats.

The convention will also be a test case for the Obama campaign's ground game, with North Carolina being a key battleground state. Additionally, the 2016 factor will be present, with Vice President Joe Biden having a coveted speaking slot and Hillary Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, attending the convention.

As the Democratic Party gathers in Charlotte, it is clear that the Obama presidency has been a time of deep decline for the party, with losses in the Senate, House of Representatives, and governorships. However, Obama remains the undisputed leader of the party, and his re-election campaign will be a critical test of his ability to adapt and evolve to the changing political landscape.

**Palin Files Lawsuit Against The New York Times for Defamation**

Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican vice presidential candidate, has filed a lawsuit against The New York Times for defamation, alleging that the newspaper falsely linked her to the 2011 shooting of Democratic Rep. Gabrielle Giffords.

According to documents filed in federal court, Palin claims that an editorial published by The New York Times on June 14, 2017, falsely accused her of inciting the shooting, which killed six people and wounded 13 others. The editorial claimed that a map created by Palin, which placed crosshairs over Democratic districts, was a "clear" link to incitement, but this claim has been widely disputed.

The lawsuit states that The New York Times knew the assertion was false, but published it anyway, causing harm to Palin's reputation. The suit seeks at least $75,000 in damages.

The controversy surrounding the editorial has sparked debate about the role of political rhetoric in inciting violence. While some have argued that Palin's map was a contributing factor, others have pointed out that the shooter, Jared Loughner, had a history of mental health issues and had been planning the attack for years before the map was even created.

The New York Times has since updated its editorial to include a correction, stating that no link was established between political incitement and the shooting. However, Palin's lawsuit claims that the damage had already been done, and that the newspaper's actions were "excessive" and "cruel."

The case is the latest in a long-standing debate about the role of the media in shaping public opinion and the potential consequences of political rhetoric.

Title: Trump Announces "Second Step Act" to Focus on Successful Reentry and Reduce Unemployment for Americans with Past Criminal Records

Article:

In a celebratory event at the White House, President Trump hailed the bipartisan criminal justice reform bill, the First Step Act, which was approved by Congress in December. The president announced plans for a "Second Step Act," although he provided few details about its contents and timeline. The First Step Act aims to give prisoners who exhibit good behavior shorter sentences, particularly for nonviolent drug offenses, and reduce recidivism rates.

The president highlighted the bipartisan nature of the bill, which has garnered praise from both the left and the right. The event coincided with a broader Prison Reform Summit. Since signing the First Step Act, over 16,000 inmates have enrolled in drug treatment programs, according to the president.

One beneficiary of the law, who was released earlier due to the First Step Act, emphasized the need for the law to be fully funded to be effective. However, the president's proposed budget requests only a fraction of the allocated funding, $14 million compared to the $75 million over five years called for in the legislation.

The First Step Act was propelled by Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner, along with nonprofit and other outside groups, overcoming opposition from a handful of hard-right conservatives like Senator Tom Cotton. The law aims to reduce recidivism rates by providing incentives for good behavior and addressing the root causes of criminal behavior. While the First Step Act is a step in the right direction, it remains to be seen what the Second Step Act will entail and how it will address the complex issues surrounding criminal justice reform.

Title: The Benghazi Whitewash: A Critical Examination of the New York Times' Account

Article:

The recent article by David Kirkpatrick in The New York Times has sparked controversy and criticism, with many questioning the thoroughness and accuracy of the report. The article aimed to provide a detailed account of the events surrounding the 2012 Benghazi attack, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens. However, critics argue that the article's findings are incomplete and lack new information, relying heavily on previously known facts.

The article's focus on trivial details, such as the vase in the living room of one of the suspects' mothers, has been criticized for being irrelevant to the main issue at hand. The article's failure to provide any new insights or revelations has led many to question its purpose and relevance.

The article's timing and placement have also been questioned, with some arguing that it was published to help Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. The article's appearance on the front page of The New York Times on a slow news week has been seen as a deliberate attempt to distract from more pressing issues.

The article's findings have been met with skepticism by many, including Rep. Adam Schiff of California, who praised the article for providing "valuable insights" but noted that it was "heavily reliant on people who had reason to provide the story that they did." The article's failure to provide any new information or revelations has left many wondering what the purpose of the article was.

The Benghazi attack remains a contentious issue, with many questioning the Obama administration's handling of the crisis. Hillary Clinton's role in the events surrounding the attack has been criticized, and her legacy is likely to be forever tied to the Benghazi incident. The article's publication has sparked a renewed debate about the administration's handling of the crisis and the role of the media in reporting on it.

In conclusion, the article by David Kirkpatrick in The New York Times has been met with criticism and skepticism, with many questioning its accuracy and relevance. The article's failure to provide new information or insights has left many wondering what the purpose of the article was, and its timing and placement have been seen as suspicious. The Benghazi attack remains a contentious issue, and the article's publication has sparked a renewed debate about the administration's handling of the crisis.

Title: Community Rallies Around Heroes Who Intervened in Hate Crime Attack

Article:

A fundraising campaign has raised over $600,000 (£468,000) for the families of three men who lost their lives or were severely injured while defending a Muslim teenager and her friend on a train in Portland, Oregon. Taliesin Myrddin Namkai-Meche and Ricky John Best were killed, and Micah David-Cole Fletcher was severely injured after intervening in a verbal tirade against the teens, one of whom was wearing a hijab.

The 35-year-old suspect, who allegedly made anti-Muslim statements during the attack, is due to appear in court on Tuesday, charged with two counts of aggravated murder, attempted murder, intimidation, and being a felon in possession of a restricted weapon. The FBI is still investigating whether the suspect will face charges for hate crime.

Micah David-Cole Fletcher, who sustained a knife wound to his neck, is recovering in the hospital. His mother described the injury as "a millimetre" from his jugular vein. Fletcher posted a picture from his hospital bed, accompanied by a poem, which included the line "I spat in the eye of hate and lived."

The three men have been hailed as heroes in their local community, with many paying tribute to their bravery. Destinee Mangum, the 16-year-old Muslim teenager who was traveling with her friend, expressed her gratitude to the men who risked their lives to defend her and her friend. "I just want to say thank you to the people who put their life on the line for me, because they didn't even know me and they lost their lives because of me and my friend and the way we look," she said.

A vigil was held in memory of Namkai-Meche, 23, a recent college graduate, and Best, 53, an army veteran and father of four, on Saturday evening. The event drew close to 1,000 people, and numerous tributes have been paid to the men online. The city's mayor, Oregon governor Kate Brown, and former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton have also expressed their condolences.

The incident has sparked widespread outrage and concern about the rise of hate crimes in the United States. While US President Donald Trump has yet to comment on the attack, a tweet by a reporter asking for his comment has been liked over 4,000 times. Veteran journalist Dan Rather wrote an open letter to Trump, imploring him to speak out about the deaths, saying, "Two Americans have died leaving family and friends behind. They are mourned by millions more who are also deeply worried about what might come next. I hope you can find it worthy of your time to take notice."

Title: Vice Presidential Debate: Pence and Kaine Face Off in Farmville, Virginia

Article:

The highly anticipated vice presidential debate between Indiana Governor Mike Pence and Virginia Senator Tim Kaine is set to take place on Tuesday night in Farmville, Virginia. While both candidates have impressive resumes, Pence is expected to dominate the debate, with Kaine struggling to keep up.

Pence, a seasoned politician with a strong background in public service, has been a net positive for the Trump campaign, reassuring voters that Trump will appoint competent people to high-ranking positions and be replaced by a capable leader if needed. Kaine, on the other hand, has been a net negative for the Clinton campaign, with his repeated attacks on Trump and defense of Clinton's handling of classified information failing to make a significant impact.

The debate is expected to be a crucial moment for both campaigns, with Pence looking to build on his strong performance in recent weeks and Kaine trying to turn the tide in his favor. While some may argue that vice presidential debates don't matter, they can have a significant impact on a campaign's momentum.

In the past, vice presidential debates have had a significant impact on the outcome of elections. In 2008, Alaska Governor Sarah Palin's strong performance against Joe Biden helped to revitalize the McCain-Palin ticket, while in 2012, Joe Biden's strong showing against Paul Ryan helped to boost Barack Obama's re-election efforts.

This debate will be no exception, with Pence looking to build on his strong performance and Kaine trying to turn the tide in his favor. The media will be watching closely, and the outcome could have a significant impact on the outcome of the election.

In conclusion, the vice presidential debate between Pence and Kaine is set to be a crucial moment in the election season. While Pence is expected to dominate the debate, Kaine will be looking to make a strong impression and turn the tide in his favor. The outcome will be closely watched, and could have a significant impact on the outcome of the election.

Title: Google News Algorithm Favors Left-Leaning Sources, Study Finds

Article:

A recent study by media technology group AllSides has shed light on the alleged bias of Google News, suggesting that the search engine's algorithm favors left-leaning news sources over conservative ones. The study analyzed the Google News homepage for two weeks, examining 123 individual measurements and concluding that 65% of the news links provided were liberal, while only 16% were conservative. The remaining 20% were considered to be from a middle perspective.

The study found that left-wing news outlets were consistently ranked higher in the search results, with right-wing news sources often relegated to the bottom of the page, 12 positions down. The study noted that popular news sources like ABC, CNN, and The New York Times were heavily favored, while conservative outlets like Breitbart, The Blaze, and Fox News were less prominent.

The study's methodology included analyzing the news sources listed on the Google News homepage, with 91% of the measurements indicating a preference for left-leaning news sources over those with a right-leaning bias. Furthermore, 80% of the measurements preferred left-wing news over news from a center source.

AllSides CEO John Gable expressed concerns about the implications of this bias, stating that technology "overly puts a spotlight on the most popular perspective, or the perspective that most fits you, and that cuts out other perspectives." This, he believes, reduces an individual's ability to decide for themselves or know the whole story.

Google responded to the study, denying any bias towards a political ideology and stating that the search engine's purpose is not to set a political agenda. However, the study's findings have sparked concerns about the potential impact of algorithmic bias on the dissemination of information and the diversity of perspectives available to users.

Title: Sanders to Emphasize Clinton's Superiority on Key Issues in Convention Address

Article:

As the Democratic National Convention gets underway in Philadelphia, Senator Bernie Sanders is set to deliver a crucial opening night address to delegates, alongside First Lady Michelle Obama. The Vermont senator will stress the importance of unity and highlight Hillary Clinton's superiority on key issues, such as economics, healthcare, education, and the environment.

According to Sanders' spokesman, Michael Briggs, the senator will emphasize that Clinton is "far superior" to her Republican opponent, Donald Trump, on these critical issues. Briggs also noted that Sanders will highlight the agreements he reached with Clinton on expanding healthcare access and making public colleges tuition-free for students from families with annual incomes up to $125,000.

In his speech, Sanders is also expected to criticize Trump for siding with the Koch brothers and echoing fossil fuel industry claims that climate change is a hoax, despite the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activity is causing devastating harm.

Despite some Sanders supporters expressing anger over the Democratic National Committee's (DNC) email scandal and the continued use of superdelegates in the nominating process, the Sanders campaign appears satisfied with the outcome of a rules committee meeting on Saturday, which proposed a commission to reduce the number of unelected delegates in primary contests.

Sanders will use his speech to urge supporters to continue pushing their agenda outside the mainstream and to flag ways in which they can continue to transform America. He will emphasize the importance of creating a government that represents all Americans, not just the 1%, and will stress the need for economic, social, racial, and environmental justice.

The convention got off to a rocky start on Sunday, with Democratic National Committee Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz announcing her resignation following revelations of bias against Sanders during the primary contest with Clinton. However, Sanders has since swung behind Clinton, claiming that his campaign has moved the party's nominee to the left in a series of negotiations over policy.

Overall, Sanders' speech is expected to be a call to action for his supporters, urging them to continue pushing for progressive policies and to work towards a more just and equitable society.

Title: FDA and CDC's Regulatory Hurdles Hampered Early Detection of COVID-19 in the US

Article:

The United States is renowned for its innovative biotech companies and university research laboratories, which should have given the country a significant advantage in detecting and monitoring emerging cases of COVID-19. However, a recent report by The New York Times reveals that officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) hindered private and academic development of diagnostic tests, potentially delaying the country's response to the pandemic.

In January, Dr. Helen Chu, a Seattle infectious disease expert, had collected a large number of nasal swabs from local residents experiencing symptoms as part of a research project on flu. She proposed testing those samples for coronavirus infections, but the CDC told her that her lab was not certified as a clinical laboratory under regulations established by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, a process that could take months. The FDA refused to approve Chu's test, citing the lack of certification.

Meanwhile, the CDC required that public health officials use only the diagnostic test designed by the agency, which was released on February 5. Unfortunately, this test was found to be flawed. The CDC's insistence on a top-down centralized testing regime slowed down the process of disease detection as the infection rate accelerated.

Frustrated, Chu and her colleagues began testing on February 25 without government approval. They quickly detected a coronavirus infection in a local teenager with no recent travel history, which suggested that the disease had been circulating in the western part of Washington for weeks. The CDC's delay in approving Chu's test and the subsequent flawed test released by the agency hindered the country's response to the pandemic.

The Seattle Flu Study highlights the challenges posed by existing regulations and red tape, which can impede the rapid rollout of testing. In contrast, other countries were able to ramp up their testing efforts much earlier and faster. The US response to the pandemic has been slow, and the consequences of this delay will likely be severe.

Title: Trump Administration Expands Arguments Against DACA, Citing Border Surge and Enforcement Concerns

Article:

The Trump administration has filed new court documents outlining its case against the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which was introduced by the Obama administration in 2012. In the documents, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen argues that the program has contributed to the surge of children and families crossing the border, and that it is the responsibility of Congress, not the executive branch, to make decisions on immigration policy.

Nielsen's memo cites the fact that tens of thousands of minors have illegally crossed the border in recent years, and that the government must take a strong stance on immigration enforcement to deter future attempts. She argues that the DACA program, which allows certain young undocumented immigrants to stay and work in the US, has created a "loophole" that has allowed these minors to be released into the country.

The Trump administration's stance is in contrast to that of California Attorney General Xavier Becerra, who has successfully argued in court that the phaseout of DACA was unlawful. Becerra's legal team has argued that DACA recipients have built up a legal interest in the program, and that it cannot be revoked without the government going through the full process of notice and comment.

The Trump administration's memo also argues that DACA was always intended to be a temporary program, and that it has been rubber-stamped for applicants who meet the age and education requirements. Nielsen said that while Dreamers are "sympathetic" figures, it is not enough reason to grant them special relief, and that such decisions should be made on a case-by-case basis by Congress, not the executive branch.

The debate over DACA has been ongoing for years, with some arguing that it is a necessary program to protect young immigrants who were brought to the US as children, and others arguing that it is an overreach of executive authority. The Trump administration's latest filing is the latest development in this ongoing debate, and it is likely to continue to be a contentious issue in the coming months.

Title: Cuomo's Presidential Ambitions: A Rollercoaster Ride of Promises and Disappointments

Article:

Mario Cuomo, the former Governor of New York, was a polarizing figure during his time in office. His popularity ratings had fluctuated over the years, with some periods of high acclaim and others of significant decline. Despite his efforts to revitalize his image, Cuomo's presidential aspirations remained a topic of much speculation and disappointment.

In the early 1990s, Cuomo's popularity was waning, and state legislators were emboldened to challenge him. He attributed his declining support to the media's coverage of his response to presidential rumors, stating that the press had unfairly portrayed him as a liar. However, the recession and declining state revenues also played a significant role in his struggles.

Despite the challenges, Cuomo managed to win a third term in 1990, defeating his Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, a financial consultant and economics adviser to presidents. However, his victory was not as convincing as his previous win against Mario O'Rourke four years prior.

In his State of the State address, Cuomo acknowledged the difficulties his state was facing, stating, "This is a wonderful year for raw truth. We don't have any money." However, he still had one more presidential flirtation left, announcing in October 1991 that he was "looking at" a run. Many of his supporters grew weary of his repeated declarations, viewing them as a ploy to revitalize his image.

Ultimately, Cuomo announced in December 1991 that he would not be a presidential candidate, citing the lack of support from Republicans to pass a budget as the reason. In a later interview, Cuomo expressed his frustration that no one had taken him at his word, stating that he would have run had Republicans agreed to his request.
